title: 2024 BMT Geometry #1
text: Andrew has three identical semicircular mooncake halves, each with radius $3,$ and uses them to construct the following shape, which contains an equilateral triangle in the center. Compute the perimeter around this shape, in bold below.
solution: Note that each of the semicircular pieces has a length of $$\frac{2\cdot3\cdot\pi}{2}=3\pi $$ so the answer is $3\cdot3\pi=\boxed{9\pi} $ $\square$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #2
text: On a chalkboard, Benji draws a square with side length $6.$ He then splits each side into $3$ equal segments using $2$ points for a total of $12$ segments and $8$ points. After trying some shapes, Benji finds that by using a circle, he can connect all $8$ points together. What is the area of this circle?
solution:
By the Pythagorean Theorem the radius of the circle is 
 \begin{align*}
\sqrt{1^2+3^2} &= \sqrt{1+9} \\
&= \sqrt{10} \end{align*} so the answer is $$(\sqrt{10})^2\cdot\pi=\boxed{10\pi} $$ $\square$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #3
text: A square with side length $6$ has a circle with radius $2$ inside of it, with the centers of the square and circle vertically aligned. Aarush is standing $4$ units directly above the center of the circle, at point $P.$ What is the area of the region inside the square that he can see? (Assume that Aarush can only see parts of the square along straight lines of sight from $P$ that are unblocked by any other objects.)

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #4
text: Two circles, $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$, are internally tangent at $A.$ Let $B$ be the point on $\omega_2$ opposite of $A.$ The radius of $\omega_1$ is $4$ times the radius of $\omega_2.$ Point $P$ is chosen on the circumference of $\omega_1$ such that the ratio $\tfrac{AP}{BP}=\tfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{7}}.$ Let $O$ denote the center of $\omega_2.$ Determine $\tfrac{OP}{AO}.$
solution: Click to reveal hidden text Let $X$ denote the center of $\omega_1$ Let $r$ denote the radius of $\omega_2$ so the radius of $\omega_1$ is $4r$ Using the median length formula on $\triangle PXA$ we have $\sqrt{7}=\frac12 \sqrt{2(2\sqrt{3})^2+2(4r)^2 (4r)^2}$ and after expanding and simplifying we get $r=\frac12$ Using the median length formula on $\triangle PBA$ we have $PO=\frac12 \sqrt{2(2\sqrt{3})^2+2(\sqrt{7})^2 1}$ and after expanding and simplifyingwe get that $PO=\frac{\sqrt{37}}2$ thus $\frac{OP}{AO}=\boxed{\sqrt{37}}$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #5
text: Let $U$ and $C$ be two circles, and kite $BERK$ have vertices that lie on $U$ and sides that are tangent to $C.$ Given that the diagonals of the kite measure $5$ and $6,$ find the ratio of the area of $U$ to the area of $C.$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #6
text: Let triangle $\triangle{ABC}$ be acute. Point $D$ is the foot of the altitude of $\triangle{ABC}$ from $A$ to $\overline{BC},$ and $E$ is the foot of the altitude of $\triangle{ABC}$ from $B$ to $\overline{AC}.$ Let $F$ denote the point of intersection between $\overline{BE}$ and $\overline{AD},$ and let $G$ denote the point of intersection between $\overline{CF}$ and $\overline{DE}.$ The areas of triangles $\triangle{EFG}, \triangle{CDG},$ and $\triangle{CEG}$ are $1,4,$ and $3,$ respectively. Find the area of $\triangle{ABC}.$
solution:
By similarity we have $[FDG]=\frac{4}{3} \frac{FD}{CE}=\frac{2}{3} \frac{FE}{CD}=\frac{1}{2}$ 
 
 Since $[DFEC]=\frac{28}{3}$ and we could compute $[BFD]=\frac{112}{15} [AFE]=\frac{28}{9}$ Since $\frac{BD}{CD}=\frac{[BFD]}{[CFD]}$ we have $\frac{BD}{CD}=\frac{7}{5}$ so $[ABC]=[ADC]\cdot \frac{12}{5}$ where $[ADC]=\frac{28}{9}+\frac{28}{3}=\frac{112}{9} [ABC]=\boxed{\frac{448}{15}}$ as desured

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #7
text: In parallelogram $ABCD,$ $E$ is a point on $\overline{AD}$ such that $\overline{CE} \perp \overline{AD},$ $F$ is a point on $\overline{CD}$ such that $\overline{AF} \perp \overline{CD},$ and $G$ is a point on $\overline{BC}$ such that $\overline{AG} \perp \overline{BC}.$ Let $H$ be a point on $\overline{GF}$ such that $\overline{AH} \perp \overline{GF},$ and let $J$ be the intersection of lines $EF$ and $BC.$ Given that $AH=8, AE=6,$ and $EF=4,$ compute $CJ.$
solution: Firstly since $\angle{GAF}=\angle{D}=\angle{DCG}$ which implies $AGCFE$ are concyclic Extend $FE$ to $T$ such that $FT=8$ Thus we have $AT=2\sqrt{5}$ Since $\angle{TAE}=\angle{HAG} \frac{AH}{AG}=\frac{AT}{AE} AG=\frac{24}{\sqrt{5}}$ Note $\angle{TEA}=\angle{J} \tan{J}=\tan \angle{JEA}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}=\frac{EC}{CJ}=\frac{AG}{CJ} CJ=\frac{48}{5}$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #9
text: Let $\triangle{ABC}$ be a triangle with incenter $I,$ and let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}.$ Line $AM$ intersects the circumcircle of triangle $\triangle{IBC}$ at points $P$ and $Q.$ Suppose that $AP=13, AQ=83,$ and $BC=56.$ Find the perimeter of $\triangle{ABC}.$
solution:
Note $\angle{ABI}=\angle{CBI}=\angle{ATI}$ where $T=AC\cap (BIC)$ we have $AB=AT$ 
 
 POP implies $PM\cdot QM=28^2 PM=14 QM=56$ and $AP\cdot AQ=AT\cdot AC=AB\cdot AC=13\cdot 83$ 
 
 By stewart $AB^2+AC^2=2(AM^2+CM^2)=2(28^2+27^2)$ We have $(AB+AC)^2=2(28^2+27^2+13\cdot 83)=72^2 72+56=\boxed{128}$

title: 2024 BMT Geometry #10
text: The incircle of scalene triangle $\triangle{ABC}$ is tangent to $\overline{BC}, \overline{AC},$ and $\overline{AB}$ at points $D, E,$ and $F,$ respectively. The line $EF$ intersects line $BC$ at $P$ and line $AD$ at $Q.$ The circumcircle of $\triangle{AEF}$ intersects line $AP$ again at point $R \neq A.$ If $QE=3, QF=4, $ and $QR=8,$ find the area of triangle $\triangle{AEF}.$
solution:
Let $I$ be the incenter of $\triangle{ABC}$ The key observation is the following Claim $R$ $Q$ $I$ are collinear 
 
 Proof Note that $AEIF$ is cyclic since $\angle{AEI} = \angle{AFI} = 90^{\circ}$ In particular this implies that $AI$ is the diameter of $(AEIF)$ Also $R$ lies on this circle so $$\angle{PRE} = \angle{PFA} = \angle{EFA}$$ and $$\angle{ERQ} = \angle{ERI} = \angle{EFI}$$ Adding them we obtain $$\angle{PRE} + \angle{ERQ} = \angle{PRQ} = \angle{EFA} + \angle{EFI} = 90^{\circ}$$ This implies that $\angle{ARQ} = 90^{\circ}$ but because $\angle{ARI} = 90^{\circ}$ our claim is proven $\square$ 
 
 By power of a point on $Q$ $$FQ \cdot QE = RQ \cdot QI \implies QI = \frac{3}{2}$$ By Pythagorean Theorem \begin{align*} AQ^2 &= AR^2 + 64 \\ AI^2 &= AR^2 + \frac{361}{4} \end{align*} Note that $AE=AF$ so by Stewart's Theorem \begin{align*} 4\cdot 3\cdot 7 + 7AQ^2 &= 4AE^2 + 3AE^2 \\ 12 + AQ^2 &= AE^2 \\ AR^2 + 76 &= AE^2 \end{align*} Let $r$ be the radius of the incircle Then $$r^2 = AI^2 AE^2 = \frac{361}{4} 76 = \frac{57}{4}$$ By Law of Cosines on $\triangle{IEF}$ \begin{align*} 49 &= r^2 + r^2 2r^2\cos{(180^{\circ} \angle{A})} \\ 49 &= 2r^2 + 2r^2\cos{\angle{A}} \\ \cos{\angle{A}} &= \frac{49 2r^2}{2r^2}=\frac{41}{57} \end{align*} Thus $$\sin{\angle{A}} = \sqrt{1 \left(\frac{41}{57}\right)^2} = \frac{28\sqrt{2}}{57}$$ Now by Law of Cosines on $\triangle{AEF}$ \begin{align*} 49 &= AE^2 + AE^2 2AE^2\cdot \frac{41}{57} \\ AE^2 &= \frac{49\cdot 57}{32}\end{align*} Therefore $$[AEF] = \frac{1}{2} \cdot AE^2 \cdot \sin{\angle{A}} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{49\cdot 57}{32} \cdot \frac{28\sqrt{2}}{57} = \boxed{\frac{343\sqrt{2}}{16}}$$

text: Let $\omega$ be a circle with center $O$ and radius $8$, and let $A$ be a point such that $AO = 17$. solution: Click to reveal hidden text Note that $AP = AQ = 15$ Now Let $X = PB$ We have $X = BT$ where $T$ is the point of tangency of $BC$ with $\omega$ Furthermore $AB = 15 X$ Doing the same for $CQ$ we have $15+15 = \boxed{30}$

title: 2023 BMT Geometry #5
text: Triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ has side lengths $AB = 8$, $BC = 15$, and $CA = 17$. Circles $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ are externally tangent to each other and within $\vartriangle ABC$. solution: Click to reveal hidden text Let the radius of $\omega_1 = r$ Looking at side $BC$ we have the total length will have segments of $4r$ $r$ and the final part we can find by trig bashing to be $16r$ Therefore our answer is $\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$

title: 2023 BMT Geometry #6
text: In triangle $\vartriangle ABC$, let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{AC}$. solution: Click to reveal hidden text By PoP we have $AM = MC = 2k$ where $MX = k$ Furthermore $AOC = 90$ so the radius is $2k\sqrt{2}$ Therefore we have a triangle with side lengths $2k\sqrt{2} 2k\sqrt{2}$ and $5k$ Solving we get $\boxed{\frac{5\sqrt{7}}{16}}$

title: 2023 BMT Geometry #9
text: Let triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ be acute, and let point $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$. Let $E$ be on line segment $\overline{AB}$ such that $\overline{AE} \perp \overline{EC}$. Then, suppose $T$ is a point on the other side of $\overleftrightarrow{BC}$ as $A$ is such that $\angle BTM = \angle ABC$ and $\angle TCA = \angle BMT$. If $AT = 14$, $AM = 9,$ and $\frac{AE}{AC} =\frac27$, compute $BC$.
solution:
Note that because \begin{align*} \angle{ABT} &= \angle{ABC} + \angle{CBT} \\ &= \angle{BTM} + \angle{MBT} \\ &= \angle{BTM} + 180^{\circ} \angle{BTM} \angle{BMT} \\ &= 180^{\circ} \angle{TCA} \end{align*} $ABTC$ is cyclic Claim $\triangle{ABM} \sim \triangle{ATC}$ 
 
 Proof Extend $TM$ past $M$ to intersect $(ABTC)$ at $D$ Since $$\angle{DMC} = \angle{BMT} \quad\text{and}\quad \angle{ADT} = \angle{TCA} = \angle{BMT}$$ $ABCD$ is a trapezoid In particular since it is cyclic it is an isosceles trapezoid Combining this fact with $M$ being the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$ we have $$\angle{MAC}=\angle{BDM}=\angle{BDT}=\angle{BAT}$$ Thus we can conclude that $\angle{BAM} = \angle{TAC}$ Also $$\angle{ABM} = \angle{ABC} = \angle{ATC}$$ so we have $\triangle{ABM} \sim \triangle{ATC}$ as claimed $\square$ 
 
 We obtain $$AB \cdot AC = AM \cdot AT = 126$$ Note that $$\cos{\angle{BAC}} = \frac{AE}{AC} = \frac{2}{7}$$ By Law of Cosines \begin{align*} BC^2 &= AB^2 + AC^2 2 \cdot AB \cdot AC \cos{\angle{BAC}} \\ BC^2 &= AB^2 + AC^2 72\end{align*} By Stewart's Theorem \begin{align*} \frac{BC}{2} \cdot \frac{BC}{2} \cdot BC + AM^2 \cdot BC &= AC^2 \cdot \frac{BC}{2} + AB^2 \cdot \frac{BC}{2} \\ AB^2 + AC^2 &= \frac{BC^2}{2} + 162 \end{align*} Therefore $$BC^2 = 180 \quad\text{so}\quad BC = \boxed{6\sqrt{5}}$$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #1
text: Lakshay chooses two numbers, $m$ and $n$, and draws two lines, $y = mx + 3$ and $y = nx + 23$. Given that the two lines intersect at $(20, 23)$, compute $m + n$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text Each line passes through the point so we can easily plug in the point and solve for $m$ and $n$ \[23 = 20m + 3 \rightarrow m = 1\] \[23 = 20n + 23 \rightarrow n = 0\] So our answer is $1+0 = \fbox{1}$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #2
text: For real numbers $x$ and $y$, suppose that $|x| - |y| = 20$ and $|x| + |y| = 23$. Compute the sum of all possible distinct values of $|x - y|$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text \[|x| = \frac{43}{2}\] \[ |y| = \frac{3}{2}\] There are only two cases for $|x y|$ which are \[|\frac{43}{2} \frac{3}{2}| = 20\] and \[|\frac{43}{2} + \frac{3}{2}| = 23\] Giving $23 + 20 = \fbox{43}$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #3
text: Consider two geometric sequences $16$, $a_1$, $a_2$, $...$ and $56$, $b_1$, $b_2$, $... $ with the same common nonzero ratio. Given that $a_{2023} = b_{2020}$, compute $b_6 - a_6$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text Let $r$ be the common ratio \[a_{2023} = 16\cdot r^{2023} = b_{2020} = 56 \cdot r^{2020}\] Therefore \[r^3 = \frac{7}{2}\] \[b_6 = 56\cdot r^6\] \[a_6 = 16\cdot r^6\] \[b_6 a_6 = r^6(56 16) = r^6(40) = \frac{49\cdot40}{4} = \fbox{490}\]

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #4
text: Let f$(x)$ be a continuous function over the real numbers such that for every integer $n$, $f(n) = n^2$ and $f(x) $ is linear over the interval $[n, n + 1]$. There exists a unique two-variable polynomial $g$ such that $g(x, \lfloor x \rfloor) = f(x)$ for all $x$. Compute $g(20, 23)$. (Here, $\lfloor x \rfloor$ is defined as the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. For example, $\lfloor 2\rfloor = 2$ and $\lfloor -3.5 \rfloor = -4$.)
solution: Click to reveal hidden text Let $x$ be a real number contained within the interval \[ [\lfloor x \rfloor \lfloor x \rfloor + 1)\] We wish to find the equation of the line going through the two points on the parabola by using the extreme points of this bound as they are both integral Therefore the line passes through \[ (\lfloor x \rfloor \lfloor x \rfloor ^2)\] and \[(\lfloor x \rfloor + 1 (\lfloor x \rfloor+1)^2)\] The equation of the line will therefore be \[y = (2\lfloor x \rfloor +1) x (\lfloor x \rfloor^2 + \lfloor x \rfloor)\] This contains our point $x$ and matches our function $f$ therefore this is our unique function $g$ \[g(x y) = (2y+1)x (y^2+y)\] Plugging in $g(20 23) = 47*20 (529+23) = \fbox{388}$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #5
text: Let $p$, $q$, and $r$ be the three roots of the polynomial $x^3 -2x^2 + 3x - 2023$. Suppose that the polynomial $x^3 + Bx^2 +Mx + T$ has roots $p + q$, $p + r$, and $q + r$ for real numbers $B$, $M$, and $T$. Compute $B -M + T$.
solution: Assume the roots of the polynomial $x^3 2x^2+3x 2023$ are $\alpha \beta \gamma $ and the roots of the polynomial $x^3+Bx^2+Mx+T$ are $\alpha+\beta $ $\beta+\gamma $ and $\gamma+\alpha$ By Vieta's Relation we get $\sum_{cyc}{}\alpha=2 $ $\sum_{cyc}{}\alpha\beta=3 $ and $\prod_{cyc}{}\alpha=2023 $ Applying TOR we get $$\boxed{\alpha+\beta=2 \gamma }$$ Now plug in the value of $\alpha+\beta$ in the given problem we get $$x^3 2x^2+3x 2023=0$$ $$(2 \alpha)^3 2(2 \alpha)^2+3(2 \alpha) 2023\implies\boxed{t^3 4t^2+7t+2017=0 }$$ Therefore we get $$B M+T\implies\boxed{2006 }$$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra #6
text: Define a sequence $a_0$, $a_1$, $a_2$, $,...$ recursively by $a_0 = 0$, $a_1 = 1$, and $a_{n+2} = a_{n+1} + xa_n$ for each $n \ge 0$ and some real number $x$. The infinite series $$ \sum^{\infty}_{n=0}\frac{a_n}{10^n} = 1.$$Compute $x$.
solution:
First the recursive sequence $a_{n}$ has the characteristic equation $r^2 r x = 0 \Rightarrow r = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+4x}}{2}$ (call the '+' root $K$ and the ' ' root $k$ for simplicity) and the general form $a_{n} = AK^n + Bk^n$ (for real constants $A$ & $B$ ) Knowing that $a_{0}=0 a_{1}=1$ we find that $B = A$ and $A = 1/\sqrt{1+4x}$ Hence $a_{n} = (1/\sqrt{1+4x}) \cdot (K^n k^n)$ 
 
 Next the infinite geometric series computes to $1 = (1/\sqrt{1+4x}) \cdot [1/(1 (K/10)) 1/(1 (k/10))]$ 
 
 or $1 = (1/\sqrt(1+4x)) \cdot [20/(19 \sqrt{1+4x}) 20/(19+\sqrt{1+4x})]$ 
 
 or $1 = (1/\sqrt{1+4x}) \cdot [40\sqrt{1+4x} / (361 (1+4x))]$ 
 
 or $1 = 40/(360 4x)$ 
 
 or $360 4x = 40$ 
 
 or $4x = 320$ 
 
 or $\fbox{x = 80}$

title: 2023 BMT Algebra Tiebreaker #3
text: Compute the real solution for$ x$ to the equation $$(4^x + 8)^4 - (8^x - 4)^4 = (4 + 8^x + 4^x)^4.$$
solution: Click to reveal hidden text \[a = 4^x+8\] \[b = 8^x 4\] \[a^4 b^4 = (a+b)^4\] When we cancel the terms notice that there should be a factorable $b$ as no term will be without a $b$ Therefore a solution is $b=0$ Plugging in it works so \[x = \frac{2}{3}\]

title: 2023 BMT Discrete #1
text: Compute the three-digit number that satisfies the following properties: $\bullet$ The hundreds digit and ones digit are the same, but the tens digit is different. $\bullet$ The number is divisible by $9$. $\bullet$ When the number is divided by $5$, the remainder is $1$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text We can represent our number as $aba$ from the first constraint From the third we see that $a \equiv 1 \bmod 5$ Therefore $a = 1 6$ If $a = 1$ then our number is $171$ If it were $6$ then it would have to be $666$ which is not allowed since all the digits are the same therefore the answer is $\fbox{171}$

title: 2023 BMT Discrete #9
text: Shiori places seven books, numbered from $1$ to $7$, on a bookshelf in some order. Later, she discovers that she can place two dividers between the books, separating the books into left, middle, and right sections, such that: $\bullet$ The left section is numbered in increasing order from left to right, or has at most one book. $\bullet$ The middle section is numbered in decreasing order from left to right, or has at most one book. $\bullet$ The right section is numbered in increasing order from left to right, or has at most one book. In how many possible orderings could Shiori have placed the books? For example, $(2, 3, 5, 4, 1, 6, 7)$ and $(2, 3, 4, 1, 5, 6, 7)$ are possible orderings with the partitions $2, 3, 5|4, 1|6, 7$ and $2, 3, 4|1|5, 6, 7$, but $(5, 6, 2, 4, 1, 3, 7)$ is not.

title: 2023 BMT Discrete #10
text: Let $a$ denote the positive real root of the polynomial $x^2 -3x-2$. Compute the remainder when $\lfloor a^{1000}\rfloor $ is divided by the prime number $997$. Here, $\lfloor r\rfloor$ denotes the greatest integer less than $r$.

title: 2023 BMT Discrete Tiebreaker #1
text: Mataio has a weighted die numbered $1$ to $6$, where the probability of rolling a side $n$ for $1 \le n \le 6$ is inversely proportional to the value of $n$. If Mataio rolls the die twice, what is the probability that the sum of the two rolls is $7$?

title: 2023 BMT Discrete Tiebreaker #2
text: Andrew, Benji, and Carlson want to split a pile of $5$ indistinguishable left shoes and $7$ indistinguishable right shoes. Andrew is practical and wants the same number of left and right shoes. Benji is greedy and wants the most shoes out of the three of them. Carlson is a trickster and wants Benji to have a different number of left and right shoes. How many ways are there to split up the shoes in a way that suits everyone’s desires?

title: 2023 BMT Discrete Tiebreaker #3
text: Bessie the cow is hungry and wants to eat some oranges, which she has an infinite supply of. Bessie starts with a fullness level of $0$, and each orange that she eats increases her fullness level by $85$. She can also eat lemons, and each time she eats a lemon, her fullness level is halved, rounding down. What is the smallest number of lemons that Bessie should have in order to be able to attain every possible nonnegative integer fullness level?

title: 2023 BMT General #1
text: Arjun eats twice as many chocolates as Theo, and Wen eats twice as many chocolates as Arjun. If Arjun eats $6$ chocolates, compute the total number of chocolates that Arjun, Theo, and Wen eat.

title: 2023 BMT General #2
text: Compute $1 \times 4 - 2 \times 3 + 2 \times 5 - 3 \times 4 + 3 \times 6 - 4 \times 5 + 4 \times 7 - 5 \times 6 + 5 \times 8 - 6 \times 7.$

title: 2023 BMT General #4
text: Suppose $a$, $b$, and $c$ are numbers satisfying the three equations: $$a + 2b = 20,$$$$b + 2c = 2,$$$$c + 2a = 3.$$Find $9a + 9b + 9c$.

text: Recall that an arithmetic sequence is a sequence of numbers such that the difference between any two consecutive terms is the same. Suppose $x_1$, $x_2$, $x_3$ forms an arithmetic sequence. If $x_2 = 2023$, compute $x_1 + x_2 + x_3$.

title: 2023 BMT General #8
text: One of Landau’s four unsolved problems asks whether there are infinitely many primes $p$ such that $p- 1$ is a perfect square. How many such primes are there less than $100$?

title: BMT 2023 Guts #16

She finally sums up the value of her die roll and the value on each card she drew to get a score of $S$. Let $A$ be the set of all obtainable scores. Compute the probability that $S$ is greater than or equal to the median of $A$.

title: BMT 2023 Guts #23

title: BMT 2022 Fall Algebra P3
text: Suppose we have four real numbers $a,b,c,d$ such that $a$ is nonzero, $a,b,c$ form a geometric sequence, in that order, and $b,c,d$ form an arithmetic sequence, in that order. Compute the smallest possible value of $\frac{d}{a}.$ (A geometric sequence is one where every succeeding term can be written as the previous term multiplied by a constant, and an arithmetic sequence is one where every succeeeding term can be written as the previous term added to a constant.)
solution:
sol Let us rewrite all the numbers in terms of $a$ Let the common ratio of the geometric series be $r$ That means that $b=ar$ and $c=ar^2$ The common difference between $b$ and $c$ is $a(r^2 r)$ which means that $d=ar^2+a(r^2 r)=a(2r^2 r)$ This means that $\frac{d}{a}=2r^2 r$ and the minimum of $2r^2 r$ over real $r$ is the minimum value of $\frac{d}{a}$ 
 
 The minimum value of $2r^2 r$ is $\boxed{ \frac{1}{8}}$ which is our answer

title: BMT 2022 Fall Algebra P4
text: Find all real $x$ such that $$\lfloor x \lceil x \rceil \rfloor = 2022.$$Express your answer in interval notation.
solution: Note that the problem simplifies to $2022 \leq x \lceil x \rceil < 2023$ $x\lceil x \rceil$ is also strictly increasing Therefore we only need to consider when $x\lceil x \rceil=2022$ and $x\lceil x \rceil=2023$ which only have one solution $2022$ is very close to $2025=45^2$ so let $\lceil x \rceil =45$ We get that $x\lceil x \rceil=2022$ when $x=\frac{2022}{45}$ which is between $44$ and $45$ We also get that $x\lceil x \rceil=2023$ when $x=\frac{2023}{45}$ which is also between $44$ and $45$ Since these values of $x$ satisfy the initial assumption we can conclude that these are the solutions of the equations Since the desired expression is between these numbers inclusive on the lower end and exclusive on the higher end we can conclude the desired interval of $x$ is $\left[ \frac{2022}{45} \frac{2023}{45} \right)$

title: BMT 2022 Fall Algebra P8
solution: Nice Let $P(x)=(x+x_1)(x+x_2)(x+x_3)\cdots(x+x_{2022})$ We are given $P(n)=2^n$ for $0\le n\le 2021$ and want $P(2022)$ Consider the polynomial $Q(x)=\binom{x}{2021}+\cdots+\binom{x}{0}$ For $0\le n\le 2021$ $Q(n)=2^n$ Thus $P(x) Q(x)$ has roots $0 1 2 \cdots 2021$ Since it’s monic and has degree $2022$ $P(x) Q(x)=x(x 1)\cdots(x 2021)$ Thus with $x=2022$ $P(2022)=2022!+2^{2022} 1$

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P1, General P3 (Food!)
text: For lunch, Lamy, Botan, Nene, and Polka each choose one of three options: a hot dog, a slice of pizza, or a hamburger. Lamy and Botan choose different items, and Nene and Polka choose the same item. In how many ways could they choose their items?
solution: Nene and Polka can both chose one of the $3$ options available Lamy can chose from $3$ options and Botan can chose from $2$ options (excluding the one that Lamy already chose) Hence the answer is $3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 = \boxed{18} $

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P2
text: Compute the number of positive integer divisors of $100000$ which do not contain the digit $0.$
solution: sol $100000 = 2^5 \cdot 5^5 $ The number can not be divisible by both $5$ and $2 $ Hence there are $5$ possible non zero powers of $2$ and $5$ possible non zero powers of $5$ that satisfy the given condition it is easy to confirm that those $10$ numbers do not contain the digit $0 $ We must include $1$ also Thus the answer is $5 + 5 + 1 = \boxed{11} $

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P3
text: Katie and Allie are playing a game. Katie rolls two fair six-sided dice and Allie flips two fair two-sided coins. Katie’s score is equal to the sum of the numbers on the top of the dice. Allie’s score is the product of the values of two coins, where heads is worth $4$ and tails is worth $2.$ What is the probability Katie’s score is strictly greater than Allie’s?
solution: sol We proceed by casework When Allie gets two heads there is no way for Katie to get a strictly greater score than Allie When Allie gets first head then second tails there are $10$ possible ways for Katie to get a strictly greater score than Allie There are also $10$ possible ways when Allie gets tails first and heads second When Allie gets both tails there are $30$ possible ways for Katie to get a strictly greater score than Allie There are $(6 \cdot 6) \cdot (2 \cdot 2) = 144$ total possible outcomes Hence the answer is $\frac{10+10+30}{36 \cdot 4} = \boxed{\frac{25}{72}} $

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P5
text: Given a positive integer $n,$ let $s(n)$ denote the sum of the digits of $n.$ Compute the largest positive integer $n$ such that $n = s(n)^2 + 2s(n) - 2.$
solution:
We have given a natural number $N $ satisfying the equation 
 
 $(1) \ \ N = S^2 + 2S 2$ 
 
 where $S$ is the sum of the digits of $N$ 
 
 Let $k$ be the number of digits of $N$ Hence $N \geq 10^{k 1}$ and $S \leq 9k$ which according to equation (1) implies 
 
 $10^{k 1} < (9k + 1)^2$ 
 
 yielding $k \leq 3$ 
 
 Assume $k=3$ The fact that $9 \mid N S$ combined with equation (1) give us 
 
 $9 \mid (S 1)(S + 2)$ 
 
 i e $(2) \ \ S \equiv 1 7 \pmod{9}$ 
 
 According to equation (1) 
 
 $10^2 + 3 \leq N + 3 = (S + 1)^2$ 
 
 which means $S\geq 10$ The fact that $S \leq 9k \leq 9 \cdot 3 = 27$ result in 
 
 $(3) \ \ 10 \leq S \leq 27$ 
 
 Combining conditions (2) and (3) we obtain 
 
 $S \in \{10 16 19 25\}$ 
 
 which according to equation (1) result in 
 
 $(4) \ \ N + 3 = (S + 1)^2 \in \{11^2 17^2 20^2 26^2\}$ 
 
 i e $N \in \{118 286 397 673\}$ 
 
 with 
 
 $(5) \ \ S + 1 \in \{11 17 20 17\}$ 
 
 respectively Therefore according to conditions (4) and (5) equation (1) is satisfied when 
 
 $N \in \{118 286 397\}$ 
 
 Conclusion The largest natural number $N$ which satisfies equation (1) is $N=397$

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P6

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P7
text: Luke the frog has a standard deck of $52$ cards shuffled uniformly at random placed face down on a table. The deck contains four aces and four kings (no card is both an ace and a king). He now begins to flip over the cards one by one, leaving a card face up once he has flipped it over. He continues until the set of cards he has flipped over contains at least one ace and at least one king, at which point he stops. What is the expected value of the number of cards he flips over?

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P8
text: Define the two sequences $a_0, a_1, a_2, \cdots$ and $b_0, b_1, b_2, \cdots$ by $a_0 = 3$ and $b_0 = 1$ with the recurrence relations $a_{n+1} = 3a_n + b_n$ and $b_{n+1} = 3b_n - a_n$ for all nonnegative integers $n.$ Let $r$ and $s$ be the remainders when $a_{32}$ and $b_{32}$ are divided by $31,$ respectively. Compute $100r + s.$
solution: For $n=0$ $a_{0}+1=4$ which is not equal to $3a_{0}+b_{0}$ There is probably a typo in your question statement

title: BMT 2022 Fall Discrete P9
text: Lysithea and Felix each have a take-out box, and they want to select among $42$ different types of sweets to put in their boxes. They each select an even number of sweets (possibly $0$) to put in their box. In each box, there is at most one sweet of any type, although the boxes may have sweets of the same type in common. The total number of sweets they take out is $42.$ Let $N$ be the number of ways can they select sweets to take out. Compute the remainder when $N$ is divided by $42^2 - 1.$

title: BMT 2022 Discrete Tiebreaker p2

title: BMT 2022 Discrete Tiebreaker p3
text: Let $A$ be the product of all positive integers less than $1000$ whose ones or hundreds digit is $7$. Compute the remainder when $A/101$ is divided by $101$.

title: BMT 2022 Geometry # 1 / General 6
text: To fold a paper airplane, Austin starts with a square paper $F OLD$ with side length $2$. First, he folds corners $L$ and $D$ to the square’s center. Then, he folds corner $F$ to corner $O$. What is the longest distance between two corners of the resulting figure?
solution: It is not difficult to see that the resulting figure is a trapezoid with bases of length $1$ and $2$ and one leg with length $1$ perpendicular to both bases Therefore by the Pythagorean Theorem it follows that the longest distance between two corners of the resulting figure is $$\sqrt{1^2+2^2}=\sqrt{1+4}=\boxed{\sqrt{5}} $$ $\square$

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #2 / General #15

Darlnim adds points $T$, $O$, $W$, and $N$, which are the midpoints of $\overline{BE}$, $\overline{ER}$, $\overline{RK}$, and $\overline{KB}$, respectively. Lastly, Sylvia constructs square $CALI$ whose edges contain the vertices of $BERK$, such that $\overline{CA}$ is parallel to $\overline{BO}$. Compute the area of $CALI$.

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #3 / General #18
text: Let equilateral triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ be inscribed in a circle $\omega_1$ with radius $4$. Consider another circle $\omega_2$ with radius $2$ internally tangent to $\omega_1$ at $A$. Let $\omega_2$ intersect sides $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ at $D$ and $E$, respectively, as shown in the diagram. Compute the area of the shaded region.
solution:
Note that the shaded region can be split into circular segment $BC$ and the shape formed by subtracting circular segment $DE$ from trapezoid $BDEC $ 
 
 The former has area 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{1}{3}\cdot4^2\pi \frac{1}{2}\cdot4^2\cdot\sin 120^\circ \\
&= \frac{16\pi}{3} 8\cdot\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\
&= \frac{16\pi}{3} 4\sqrt{3} \end{align*} and the latter has area 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4^2\sqrt{3}}{4} \left(\frac{1}{3}\cdot2^2\pi \frac{1}{2}\cdot2^2\cdot\sin 120^\circ\right) &= 3\sqrt{3} \left(\frac{4\pi}{3} 2\cdot\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) \\
&= 3\sqrt{3} \frac{4\pi}{3}+\sqrt{3} \\
&= 4\sqrt{3} \frac{4\pi}{3} \end{align*} 
 Hence the area of the shaded region is $$\left(\frac{16\pi}{3} 4\sqrt{3}\right)+\left(4\sqrt{3} \frac{4\pi}{3}\right) = \boxed{4\pi} $$ $\square$

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #4 / General #21
text: On regular hexagon $GOBEAR$ with side length $2$, bears are initially placed at $G, B, A$, forming an equilateral triangle. At time $t = 0$, all of them move clockwise along the sides of the hexagon at the same pace, stopping once they have each traveled $1$ unit. What is the total area swept out by the triangle formed by the three bears during their journey?

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #5
text: Steve has a tricycle which has a front wheel with a radius of $30$ cm and back wheels with radii of $10$ cm and $9$ cm. The axle passing through the centers of the back wheels has a length of $40$ cm and is perpendicular to both planes containing the wheels. Since the tricycle is tilted, it goes in a circle as Steve pedals. Steve rides the tricycle until it reaches its original position, so that all of the wheels do not slip or leave the ground. The tires trace out concentric circles on the ground, and the radius of the circle the front wheel traces is the average of the radii of the other two traced circles. Compute the total number of degrees the front wheel rotates. (Express your answer in simplest radical form.)

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #6 / General #24
text: Triangle $\vartriangle BMT$ has $BM = 4$, $BT = 6$, and $MT = 8$. Point $A$ lies on line $\overleftrightarrow{BM}$ and point $Y$ lies on line $\overleftrightarrow{BT}$ such that $\overline{AY}$ is parallel to $\overline{MT}$ and the center of the circle inscribed in triangle $\vartriangle BAY$ lies on $\overline{MT}$. Compute $AY$.

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #7
text: In triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ with orthocenter $H$, the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$ intersects $\overline{BC}$ at $Y$. Given that $AH = 4$, $AY = 6$, and the distance from $Y$ to $\overline{AC}$ is $\sqrt{15}$, compute $BC$.
solution: Let the center of the circumcircle of $\triangle{ABC}$ be $O$ Drop $OM\bot BC$ By a well known lemma $AH=2OM OM=2$ As $\angle{BAC}=\angle{BOM}$ the goal is to find $\tan \angle{BOM}$ Note $\sin \angle{YAC}=\frac{\sqrt{15}}{6} \cos 2\angle{YAC}=1 2\sin^2{\angle{YAC}}=\frac{1}{6}$ Thus $\tan \angle{BOC}=\sqrt{35}\implies BC=2BM=4\sqrt{35}$

title: BMT 2022 Geometry #8
text: Anton is playing a game with shapes. He starts with a circle $\omega_1$ of radius $1$, and to get a new circle $\omega_2$, he circumscribes a square about $\omega_1$ and then circumscribes circle $\omega_2$ about that square. To get another new circle $\omega_3$, he circumscribes a regular octagon about circle $\omega_2$ and then circumscribes circle $\omega_3$ about that octagon. He continues like this, circumscribing a $2n$-gon about $\omega_{n-1}$ and then circumscribing a new circle $\omega_n$ about the $2n$-gon. As $n$ increases, the area of $\omega_n$ approaches a constant $A$. Compute $A$.

title: BMT 2022 Guts Round Set 7 p19-21
text: Guts Round / Set 7 p19. Let $N \ge 3$ be the answer to Problem 21. A regular $N$-gon is inscribed in a circle of radius $1$. text: For triangle $\vartriangle ABC$, define its $A$-excircle to be the circle that is externally tangent to line segment $BC$ and extensions of $\overleftrightarrow{AB}$ and $\overleftrightarrow{AC}$, and define the $B$-excircle and $C$-excircle likewise. title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 1
text: What is the largest $n$ such that there exists a non-degenerate convex $n$-gon such that each of its angles are an integer number of degrees, and are all distinct?
solution: This implies that each exterior angle is distinct and they must sum to $360^\circ$ A good starting point is to see when the sum of the first $n$ integers equals $360$ (or is close) We have $\frac{n(n+1)}{2}=360 \rightarrow n(n+1)=720$ Note when $n=26$ $n(n+1)=702$ but when $n=27$ we have $n(n+1)=756$ which is too high The answer is $n=\boxed{26}$

title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 2

title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 3

title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 4

title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 5
text: Suppose the side lengths of triangle $ABC$ are the roots of polynomial $x^3 - 27x^2 + 222x - 540$. What is the product of its inradius and circumradius?
solution: Let $a$ $b$ and $c$ be the roots of the polynomial resembling the side opposite from its vertex with the same (uppercase) letter We know the inradius is equal to $\frac{\text{area}}{\frac{a+b+c}{2}}$ and the circumradius is equal to $\frac{abc}{4 \cdot \text{area}}$ Therefore their product is equal to $\frac{2abc}{4(a+b+c)} \rightarrow \frac{540}{2(27)}=\boxed{10}$

title: BMT 2017 Spring - Geometry 10
text: Colorado and Wyoming are both defined to be $4$ degrees tall in latitude and $7$ degree wide in longitude. In particular, Colorado is defined to be at $37^o N$ to $41^o N$, and $102^o03' W$ to $109^o03' W$, whereas Wyoming is defined to be $41^o N$ to $45^o N$, and $104^o 03' W$ to $111^o 03' W$. Assuming Earth is a perfect sphere with radius $R$, what is the ratio of the areas of Wyoming to Colorado, in terms of $R$?

title: 2017 BMT Team 1
text: You are racing an Artificially Intelligent Robot, called Al, that you built. You can run at a constant speed of $10$ m/s throughout the race. Meanwhile, Al starts running at a constant speed of $ 1$ m/s. Thereafter, when exactly $ 1$ second has passed from when Al last changed its speed, Al’s speed instantaneously becomes $1$ m/s faster, so that Al runs at a constant speed of $k$ m/s in the kth second of the race. (Start counting seconds at $ 1$). Suppose Al beats you by exactly $1$ second. How many meters was the race?
solution: After $k$ seconds the robot has travelled $\frac{k(k 1)}{2}$ meters (the sum of the first $k$ integers) and you have travelled $10k$ meters We have $k(k 1)=20k \rightarrow k 1=20 \rightarrow k=21$ seconds This means the race was $\boxed{210}$ meters

title: 2017 BMT Team 2
text: Colin has $900$ Choco Pies. He realizes that for some integer values of $n \le 900$, if he eats n pies a day, he will be able to eat the same number of pies every day until he runs out. How many possible values of $n$ are there?
solution: This is just the number of factors of $900$ $900=2^2 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^2$ so $(2+1)^3=\boxed{27}$

title: acute <AOB by 2 darts on a  circular board 2017 BMT Team 4
text: $2$ darts are thrown randomly at a circular board with center $O$, such that each dart has an equal probability of hitting any point on the board. The points at which they land are marked $A$ and $B$. What is the probability that $\angle AOB$ is acute?
solution: Let $A$ be any point on the circumference (it does not matter where since we can always "rotate" the circle to place the point anywhere on the circumference) $\angle{AOB}$ is acute iff minor arc $\overarc{AB}$ $< 90^\circ$ If we "rotate" the circle such that $A$ is the topmost point on the circle then $B$ must be a point above the horizontal diameter The answer is $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}$

title: right triangle, incircle and circumcircle related 2017 BMT Team 9
text: Let $AB = 10$ be a diameter of circle $P$. Pick point $C$ on the circle such that $AC = 8$. Let the circle with center $O$ be the incircle of $\vartriangle ABC$. Extend line $AO$ to intersect circle $P$ again at $D$. Find the length of $BD$.
solution:
Let $A=(0 0)$ $B=(10 0)$ and $C$ be a point below the diameter $\overline{AB}$ If $C=(x y)$ we can solve for $C$ through a system $$\sqrt{x^2+y^2}=8 \rightarrow x^2+y^2=64$$ $$\sqrt{(x 10)^2+y^2}=6 \rightarrow x^2+y^2 20x= 64$$ Therefore $64 20x= 64 \rightarrow 20x=128 \rightarrow x=\frac{32}{5}$ So $y= \frac{24}{5}$ since $y$ is negative To find the coordinates of the incenter remember the following (idk if there's a name for this) let $(x_A y_A)$ $(x_B y_B)$ and $(x_C y_C)$ be the three vertices of the triangle with side lengths $a$ $b$ and $c$ being opposite from the vertices with the same capital letter Then the coordinates of the incenter are equal to $\left(\frac{ax_A+bx_B+cx_C}{a+b+c} \frac{ay_A+by_B+cy_C}{a+b+c} \right)$ Using what we know the coordinates of the incenter are $\left(\frac{6(0)+8(10)+10\left(\frac{32}{5}\right)}{6+8+10} \frac{6(0)+8(0)+10\left( \frac{24}{5}\right)}{6+8+10}\right) \rightarrow \left(\frac{144}{24} \frac{ 48}{24} \right) = (6 2)$ The equation of the line that passes through $A$ and $O$ is $y= \frac{1}{3}x$ and this intersects the bottom half of the circle or $y= \sqrt{25 (x 5)^2} \rightarrow y= \sqrt{10x x^2}$ We have $ \frac{1}{3}x= \sqrt{10x x^2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{9}x^2=10x x^2 \rightarrow \frac{10}{9}x^2=10x$ Since $x \neq 0$ we have $\frac{10}{9}x=10 \rightarrow x=9$ so $y= 3$ The distance from $(9 3)$ to $(10 0)$ is $\sqrt{(10 9)^2+(0+3)^2}=\boxed{\sqrt{10}}$

title: common area of 4 equilaterals in a square 2017 BMT Team 13
text: $4$ equilateral triangles of side length $1$ are drawn on the interior of a unit square, each one of which shares a side with one of the $4$ sides of the unit square. What is the common area enclosed by all $4$ equilateral triangles?
solution:
Given the square $ABCD\ \ A(0 0) B(1 0) C(1 1) D(0 1)$ 
 Points of the equilateral triangles $E(\frac{1}{2} 1 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2})$ and $F(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \frac{1}{2})$ 
 
 The line $AF\ \ y=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}x$ intersects the line $DE\ \ y 1= \sqrt{3}x$ in the point $G(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \frac{1}{4})$ 
 Points $E'(\frac{1}{2} 0) G'(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} 0)$ 
 
 Area $\triangle AGG'\ =\ \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{4}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{32}$ 
 Area trapezoid $GG'E'E\ =\ \frac{1}{2} \cdot (\frac{1}{4}+1 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}) \cdot (\frac{1}{2} \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4})=\frac{16 9\sqrt{3}}{32}$ 
 The common area enclosed by all $4$ equilateral triangles $1 8 \cdot (\frac{\sqrt{3}}{32}+\frac{16 9\sqrt{3}}{32})=2\sqrt{3} 3$

title: 2017 BMT Individual 6
text: For how many numbers $n$ does $2017$ divided by $n$ have a remainder of either $1$ or $2$?
solution: If the divisor $n$ gives remainder $1$ then $n|2016$ Since $2016 = 2^5 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 7$ there are $36$ possibilities here If the divisor $n$ gives remainder $2$ then $n|2015$ Since $2015 = 5 \cdot 13 \cdot 31$ there are $8$ possibilities here The sum is $36+8=44$ BUT we overcounted since the number $1$ appears in both products The answer is $44 2=\boxed{42}$

Storage Break it into $2$ alternating series The 1st series is $\frac{\frac{20}{3}}{1 \frac{1}{9}}=\frac{15}{2}$ 
 The 2nd series is $\frac{\frac{17}{9}}{1 \frac{1}{9}}=\frac{17}{8}$ 
 The sum is $\frac{60+17}{8}=\boxed{\frac{77}{8}}$

title: 2017 BMT Individual 14
text: Let $x$ be the first term in the sequence $31, 331, 3331,...$ which is divisible by $17$. How many digits long is$ x$?
solution: I'll admit I had to look up the "divisibility by 17" trick because this question is ridiculous There has to be a better solution than this To test divisibility for $17$ subtract five times the last digit from the rest of your number and see if the resulting number is divisible by $17$ If the entire number is $n$ digits then we have $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 1 \text{ digits}} 5=\underbrace{33 3}_{n 2 \text{ digits}}27$ But this must also be divisible by $17$ and there are no obvious multiples from small values of $n 2$ so we continue $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 2 \text{ digits}}2 7(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 3 \text{ digits}}297$ Even when $n=3$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 3 \text{ digits}}29 7(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 4 \text{ digits}}294$ When $n=4$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 4 \text{ digits}}29 4(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 5 \text{ digits}}309$ When $n=5$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 5 \text{ digits}}30 9(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 6 \text{ digits}}285$ When $n=6$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 6 \text{ digits}}28 5(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 7 \text{ digits}}303$ When $n=7$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 7 \text{ digits}}30 3(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 8 \text{ digits}}315$ When $n=8$ no luck $\underbrace{33 3}_{n 8 \text{ digits}}31 5(5) = \underbrace{33 3}_{n 9 \text{ digits}}306$ When $n=9$ we have $306$ which is divisible by $17$ Therefore $n=\boxed{9}$

title: 2017 BMT Discrete #9
text: $n$ balls are placed independently uniformly at random into $n$ boxes. One box is selected at random, and is found to contain $b$ balls. Let $e_n$ be the expected value of $b^4$. Find $$\lim_{n \to \infty}e_n.$$
solution:
Without loss of generality always choose the first box The probability that it contains exactly $k$ balls is $\binom nk n^{ n}(n 1)^{n k}\leq\frac{n^k}{k!}\cdot\frac{1}{n^k}\cdot\frac{(n 1)^{n k}}{n^{n k}}\leq\frac{1}{k!}$ Hence if we ignore all but the first $m$ terms we will underestimate by at most $\sum\limits_{k=m+1}^{\infty}\frac{k^4}{k!}<\infty$ Hence we can take the limit of each term individually Using $\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\binom nk\frac{1}{n^k}=\frac{1}{k!}$ and $\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left(1 \frac 1n\right)^{n k}=\frac 1{\mathrm e}$ this gives the sum 
 \[
\sum\limits_{k=0}^\infty \frac{k^4}{k!} \] By repeatedly differentiating the power series of $\mathrm e^x$ and multiplying by $x$ we find that this converges to $\boxed{15}$

title: 2017 BMT Analysis #4
text: Find the value of $\frac12+\frac{4}{2^2} +\frac{9}{2^3} +\frac{16}{2^4} +...$
solution:
We need to find the value of 
 $$
x=\dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{4}{2^2}+\dfrac{9}{2^3}+\dfrac{16}{2^4}+ \cdots \quad (1)
$$ 
 We can start by multiplying $(1)$ by $\dfrac{1}{2}$ giving us 
 $$\dfrac{1}{2}x=\dfrac{1}{2^2}+\dfrac{4}{2^3}+\dfrac{9}{2^4}+\dfrac{16}{2^5} \cdots \quad (2)$$ 
 $(1) (2)$ gets us 
 $$\dfrac{1}{2}x=\dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{3}{2^2}+\dfrac{5}{2^3}+\dfrac{7}{2^4}+ \cdots \quad (3)$$ 
 Multiply $(3)$ by $\dfrac{1}{2}$ 
 $$\dfrac{1}{4}x=\dfrac{1}{2^2}+\dfrac{3}{2^3}+\dfrac{5}{2^4}+\dfrac{7}{2^5}+ \cdots \quad (4)$$ 
 Now doing $(3) (4)$ and simplifying the fractions gets us 
 $$\dfrac{1}{4}x=\dfrac{1}{2}+(\dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{1}{2^2}+\dfrac{1}{2^3}+ )$$ 
 Notice that the terms inside the parentheses form an infinite geometric series with a first term and common ratio of $\dfrac{1}{2}$ Therefore the sum of the geometric series is $1$ and $\dfrac{1}{4}x$ is evaluated as $\dfrac{3}{2}$ Solving for $x$ gives us our final answer of $\boxed{6}$

title: BMT 2016 Spring - Geometry 4
text: $ABC$ is an equilateral triangle, and $ADEF$ is a square. If $D$ lies on side $AB$ and $E$ lies on side $BC$, what is the ratio of the area of the equilateral triangle to the area of the square?
solution:
Let the intersection of the square and $AC$ be $G$ and let the sidelength of the square be $x $ We can easily see that the area of the square is $x^2$ while $FG=\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}$ and $EG=x \frac{x}{\sqrt{3}} $ From a simple angle chase we see that $\triangle GEC$ is equilateral meaning that the sidelength of the equilateral triangle is $x+\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}$ 
 Now for the computation $$\frac{(x+\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}})^2 * \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}}{x^2}$$ $$\boxed{\frac{2\sqrt{3}+3}{6}}$$

title: regular octagon from a square  2016 BMT Team 2
text: Jennifer wants to do origami, and she has a square of side length $ 1$. However, she would prefer to use a regular octagon for her origami, so she decides to cut the four corners of the square to get a regular octagon. Once she does so, what will be the side length of the octagon Jennifer obtains?
solution:
We would like to cut a right triangle off each corner Let the side length of that triangle be $s $ Now the side length of this octagon is equal to $1 2s $ However it is also equal to $s\sqrt{2} $ because it is the hypotenuse of a right isosceles triangle with side length $s $ Thus we have $1 2s=s\sqrt{2}\implies 1=s(2+\sqrt{2}) $ Therefore we find that $\boxed{s=\frac{1}{2+\sqrt{2}}=\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{2}} $ 
 $\blacksquare$

 $$((x \star y) \star z) (y \star (z \star x))$$ $$((2xy+x+y) \star z) (y \star (2xz+x+z))$$ $$(2(2xy+x+y)(z)+2xy+x+y+z) (2(y)(2xz+x+z)+2xz+x+y+z)$$ $$4xyz+2xz+2yz+2xy+x+y+z 4xyz 2xy 2yz 2xz x y z$$ $$=\boxed{0}$$ (for all $x y z$ )

title: BMT 2016 Spring - Individual 6
text: Let $g_0 = 1$, $g_1 = 2$, $g_2 = 3$, and $g_n = g_{n-1} + 2g_{n-2} + 3g_{n-3}$. For how many $0 \le i \le 100$ is it that $g_i$ is divisible by $5$?
solution:
Claim $g_n \equiv g_{n+8}\text{ } \forall \text{ } n \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq0} $ 
 
 Proof We proceed by induction $\underline{\text{Base Case }}$ We have 
 \begin{align*}
(g_0 g_1 g_2) \equiv (1 2 3) \pmod{5}
&\implies g_3 \equiv 3\cdot1+2\cdot2+3\cdot1 \equiv 3+4+3 \equiv 10 \equiv 0 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_4 \equiv 1\cdot0+2\cdot3+3\cdot2 \equiv 0+6+6\equiv 12 \equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_5 \equiv 1\cdot2+2\cdot0+3\cdot3 \equiv 2+0+9 \equiv 11 \equiv 1 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_6 \equiv 1\cdot1+2\cdot2+3\cdot0 \equiv 1+4+0 \equiv 5 \equiv 0 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_7\equiv 1\cdot0+2\cdot1+3\cdot2 \equiv 0+2+6\equiv8\equiv 3\pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_8 \equiv 1\cdot3+2\cdot0+3\cdot1\equiv 3+0+3\equiv 6 \equiv 1 \equiv g_0 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_9 \equiv 1\cdot1+2\cdot3+3\cdot0 \equiv 1+6+0\equiv 7 \equiv 2 \equiv g_1 \pmod{5} \\
&\implies g_{10} \equiv 1 \cdot 2 + 2\cdot1+3\cdot3\equiv 2+2+9\equiv 13 \equiv 3 \equiv g_2 \pmod{5} \end{align*} so the desired result holds for $n=0 1 2 $ 
 
 $\underline{\text{Inductive Assumption }}$ Assume that the desired result holds for some $n=k k+1 k+2 $ where $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq0} $ 
 
 $\underline{\text{Inductive Step }}$ We have 
 \begin{align*}
g_{(k+3)+8} &\equiv g_{k+11} \\
&\equiv g_{k+10}+g_{k+9}+g_{k+8} \\
&\equiv g_{k+2}+g_{k+1}+g_{k} \\
&\equiv g_{k+3} \end{align*} completing the inductive step Hence by the Principle of Mathematical Induction we have proven the desired result $\blacksquare$ 
 
 Therefore in the range $[8i 8i+7] $ where $i$ is a nonnegative integer there are exactly $2$ values of $j$ such that $g_j$ is divisible $5 $ 
 
 It follows that in the range $[0 95] $ there are exactly $11\cdot2=22$ values of $j$ such that $g_j$ is divisible Also note that $$(g_{96} g_{97} g_{98} g_{99} g_{100}) \equiv (g_0 g_2 g_3 g_4) \equiv (1 2 3 0 2) \pmod{5} $$ so in total there are $$22+1=\boxed{23}$$ integer values of $i$ such that $0 \leq i \leq 100$ and $g_i \equiv 0 \pmod{5} $ $\square$

text: Define $ P(\tau ) = (\tau + 1)^3$. If $x + y = 0$, what is the minimum possible value of $P(x) + P(y)$?
solution: Note $P(x)+P(y)=(x+1)^3+(y+1)^3$ but since $y= x$ we can simplify to $(x+1)^3+( x+1)^3 \rightarrow (x^3+3x^2+3x+1)+( x^3+3x^2 3x+1) \rightarrow 6x^2+2$ This is a quadratic its minimum comes from its vertex $(0 2)$ So the answer is $\boxed{2}$

title: BMT 2016 Spring - Individual 9
text: On $5 \times 5$ grid of lattice points, every point is uniformly randomly colored blue, red, or green. Find the expected number of monochromatic triangles T with vertices chosen from the lattice grid, such that some two sides of $T$ are parallel to the axis.
solution:
First let us count the number of triangles $T$ with vertices chosen from the lattice grid such that two sides of $T$ are parallel to the axes There are $25$ choices for the vertex opposite the hypotenuse and then $4^2=16$ choices for the other two vertices for a total of $$25\cdot16=400 $$ 
 Note that for any triangle $T$ with vertices chosen from the lattice grid there is a $$3\cdot\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^3 = 3\cdot\frac{1}{27}=\frac{1}{9}$$ probability that the vertices of the triangle are all the same color Hence by Linearity of Expectation the answer is $$400\cdot\frac{1}{9} = \boxed{\frac{400}{9}} $$ $\square$

title: BMT 2016 Spring - Individual 10
text: Define $T_n =\sum^{n}){i=1} i(n + 1 - i)$. Find $\lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{T_n}{n^3}$.
solution:
We have 
 \begin{align*}
T_n &= \sum_{i=1}^n i(n+1 i) \\
&= n\sum_{i=1}^n i + \sum_{i=1}^n i \sum_{i=1}^n i^2 \\\
&= n \cdot \frac{n(n+1)}{2} + \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \frac{n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} \\
&= \frac{3n^2(n+1)+3n(n+1) n(n+1)(2n+1)}{6} \\
&= \frac{p(n)}{6} \end{align*} where $p(n)$ is a polynomial of degree $3 $ 
 
 Hence we have 
 \begin{align*}
\lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{T_n}{n^3} &= \lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{p(n)}{6n^3} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{1}{6}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2016 BMT Discrete #7
text: Consider the graph on $1000$ vertices $v_1, v_2,...v_{1000}$ such that for all $1 \le i < j \le 1000$, $v_i$ is connected to $v_j$ if and only if $i$ divides $j$. Determine the minimum number of colors that must be used to color the vertices of this graph such that no two vertices sharing an edge are the same color.
solution: We claim that $10$ colors is the desired minimum To see why ten colors are needed observe that $v_1 v_2 v_4 \dots v_{512}$ form a clique of size $10$ To see why ten colors suffice color the numbers according to the number of primes occuring in their prime factorization (counted with multiplicity) Since $1000<2^{10}$ it follows that each number contains at most $9$ prime factors so $10$ colors are needed for this coloring On the other hand if $i$ properly divides $j$ it clearly must have less prime factors

title: 2016 BMT Analysis #8
text: Evaluate the following limit $$\lim_{x\to 0} (1 + 2x + 3x^2 + 4x^3 +...)^{1/x}$$
solution:
$L = \lim_{x\to 0}(1 + 2x + 3x^2 + 4x^3 + )^{1/x} = \lim_{x\to 0} \left(\sum_{r=1}^{\infty}r x^{r 1}\right)^{1/x}$ 
 
 Now $\sum_{r=0}^{\infty} x^r = \frac{1}{1 x} |x| < 1$ 
 
 On differentiating both sides wrt $x$ we get 
 
 $\sum_{r=1}^{\infty} r x^{r 1} = \frac{1}{(1 x)^2}$ 
 
 Therefore $L = \lim_{x\to 0} \left(\frac{1}{(1 x)^2}\right)^{1/x} = \boxed{e^{2}}$

title: 2016 BMT Analysis #10
text: Evaluate $$\sum^{\infty}_{k=0} \left( \frac{-1}{8}\right)^k {2k \choose k}$$
solution:
Using the Generating function for Central Binomial Coefficient we've 
 
 $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \binom{2k}{k} x^k = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 4x}} |x| < \frac{1}{4}$ 
 
 On plugging $x = \frac{ 1}{8}$ in the above equation we get 
 
 $\sum^{\infty}_{k=0} \left( \frac{ 1}{8}\right)^k {2k \choose k} = \boxed{\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}}$

title: 2015 BMT Team 1
text: A fair $6$-sided die is repeatedly rolled until a $1, 4, 5$, or $6$ is rolled. What is the expected value of the product of all the rolls?
solution: Consider there being $k$ rolls before the $1 4 5 6$ is rolled The expected value of the product of the $k$ rolls is $\frac{1}{6^k} \cdot (2+3)^k$ and the expected value of the product of that and the last roll is $\frac{1}{6^{k+1}} \cdot (2+3)^k \cdot (1+4+5+6)$ We sum this over all $k=0 1 \ldots$ and get $16$

title: lines // to sides of 3-4-5 triangle bisecting areas 2015 BMT Team 4
text: Triangle $ABC$ has side lengths $AB = 3$, $BC = 4$, and $CD = 5$. Draw line $\ell_A$ such that $\ell_A$ is parallel to $BC$ and splits the triangle into two polygons of equal area. Define lines $\ell_B$ and $\ell_C$ analogously. The intersection points of $\ell_A$, $\ell_B$, and $\ell_C$ form a triangle. Determine its area.
solution:
@parmenides51 One way to affirm the following calculations is a calculation showing that the ratio of the smaller leg to the bigger leg of the constructed right triangle is $3 4$ This is to be expected considering that the constructed right triangle must be similar to the given $3$ $4$ $5$ right triangle $\triangle\mathit{ABC}$ is put on the Cartesian plane so that $A = (0 0)$ $B = (3 0)$ and $C = (3 4)$ So the equation of the line through the hypotenuse in standard form is $4s 3t = 0$ 
 
 
 Vertical line 
 A vertical line $\ell$ through $\triangle\mathit{ABC}$ partitions the region bound by it into another right triangle and a right trapezoid enclosing regions of the same area If $\ell$ intersects $\overline{\mathit{AB}}$ at $(x 0)$ the area of the smaller right triangle is $(2/3)x^{2}$ and since the height of the right trapezoid is $3 x$ the area of it is 
 $$ \frac{2}{3}\Bigl(x^{2} 9\Bigr) $$ The only positive solution to 
 $$\frac{2}{3} \ x^{2} = \frac{2}{3}\Bigl(x^{2} 9\Bigr)$$ is $3\big\slash\sqrt{2}$ 
 
 Horizontal line 
 A horizontal line $k$ through $\triangle\mathit{ABC}$ partitions the region bound by it into another right triangle and a right trapezoid enclosing regions of the same area If $k$ intersects $\overline{\mathit{BC}}$ at $(3 y)$ the area of the smaller right triangle is 
 $$\frac{1}{2} \Bigl(4 y\Bigr)\left(3 \frac{3}{4} \ y\right)
= \frac{3}{8}\Bigl(y 4\Bigr)^{2} $$ and since the height of the right trapezoid is $y$ the area of it is 
 $$3y \frac{3}{8} \ y^{2} $$ The only two solutions to the quadratic equation 
 $$\frac{3}{8}\Bigl(y 4\Bigr)^{2} = 3y \frac{3}{8} \ y^{2}$$ are $4 2\sqrt{2}$ and $4 + 2\sqrt{2}$ Since $y < 4$ $4 + 2\sqrt{2}$ is an extraneous solution Line parallel to hypotenuse 
 A line $j$ through $\triangle\mathit{ABC}$ that is parallel to hypotenuse $\overline{\mathit{AC}}$ partitions the region bound by it into another right triangle and a trapezoid enclosing regions of the same area If $j$ intersects $\overline{\mathit{AB}}$ at $(x 0)$ it intersects $\overline{\mathit{BC}}$ at 
 $$P = \left(3 \ 4 \frac{4}{3} \ x\right) $$ and so the area of the smaller right triangle is 
 $$\frac{1}{2}\Bigl(3 x\Bigr)\left(4 \frac{4}{3} \ x\right)
= \frac{2}{3}\Bigl(x 3\Bigr)^{2} $$ Since the equation of the line through the hypotenuse is $4s 3t = 0$ the distance between $(x 0)$ and the line is 
 $$\frac{\lvert 4x \rvert}{\sqrt{4^{2} + ( 3)^{2}}} = \frac{4}{5} \ x $$ The length of the line segment between $(x 0)$ and $P$ is 
 $$\frac{5}{3}\Bigl(3 x\Bigr) $$ The area of the trapezoid is 
 $$\left(\frac{\ \ \dfrac{5}{3}\Bigl(3 x\Bigr) + 5 \ \ }{2}\right)\frac{4}{5} \ x
= 4x \frac{2}{3} \ x^{2} $$ The only two solutions to the quadratic equation 
 $$\frac{2}{3}\Bigl(x 3\Bigr)^{2} = 4x \frac{2}{3} \ x^{2}$$ are $3 3\big\slash\sqrt{2}$ and $3 + 3\big\slash\sqrt{2}$ Since $x < 3$ $3 + 3\big\slash\sqrt{2}$ is an extraneous solution The equation of line $j$ is 
 $$y = \frac{4}{3} \ x + 2\sqrt{2} 4 $$ 
 Vertices of the new right triangle 
 The intersection of lines $j$ and $\ell$ is at 
 $$\left(\frac{3}{\ \sqrt{2}\ } \ 4\sqrt{2} 4\right) $$ and the intersection of lines $j$ and $k$ is at 
 $$\left(6 3\sqrt{2} \ 4 2\sqrt{2}\right) $$ So the area of the new right triangle is 
 $$\frac{1}{2}\left\lvert \Bigl(6 3\sqrt{2}\Bigr) \frac{3}{\ \sqrt{2}\ }\right\rvert
\left\lvert \Bigl(4 2\sqrt{2}\Bigr) \Bigl(4\sqrt{2} 4\Bigr)\right\rvert
= \frac{3}{2}\Bigl(3\sqrt{2} 4\Bigr)^{2} $$

title: 2015 BMT Team 11
text: Write down $1, 2, 3,..., 2015$ in a row on a whiteboard. Every minute, select a pair of adjacent numbers at random, erase them, and insert their sum where you selected the numbers. (For instance, selecting $3$ and $4$ from $1, 2, 3, 4, 5$ would result in $1, 2, 7, 5$.) Repeat this process until you have two numbers remaining. What is the probability that the smaller number is less than or equal to $2015$?
solution: The key idea is that we can draw a single line splitting the numbers into two sets \[ \{1 2 \ldots N\} \quad \text{and} \quad \{N+1 N+2 \ldots 2015\} \] We want the smaller sum to be less than or equal to $2015$ This occurs when $N \leq 62$ or $N = 2014$ for a total of $63$ possible values of $N$ Note that $N$ ranges from $1$ to $2014$ So the probability the smaller number is less than or equal to $2015$ is $\tfrac{63}{2014}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 1
text: Let $x,y,z,w$ be integers such that $2^x+2^y+2^z+2^w=24.375$. Find the value of $xyzw$.
solution: Let $x>y>z>w$ If $x=4$ then $y=3$ and realize $\frac{3}{8}=2^{ 2}+2^{ 3}$ so the answer is $4(3)( 2)( 3)=\boxed{72}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 2
text: Let $g(x)=1+2x+3x^2+4x^3+\ldots$. Find the coefficient of $x^{2015}$ of $f(x)=\frac{g(x)}{1-x}$.
solution:
It is easy to see that $$g(x) = 1 + 2x+3x^2+4x^3 = \frac{1}{(1 x)^2} $$ so the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
[x^{2015}] f(x) &= [x^{2015}] \frac{g(x)}{1 x} \\
&= [x^{2015}] \frac{1}{(1 x)^3} \\
&= \binom{2017}{2} \\
&= \boxed{2033136} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 3
text: Find all integer solutions to \begin{align*} x^2+2y^2+3z^2&=36,\\ 3x^2+2y^2+z^2&=84,\\ xy+xz+yz&=-7. \end{align*}
solution:
For now let's only focus on positive integers for $x$ we will come back to negative integers later From the first equation $x \leq 6$ but it is impossible for $x=6$ so we look at $x=5$ This gives $2y^2+3z^2=11$ which has solutions $(y z)=(\pm 2 \pm 1)$ So for this case $(x y z)=(\pm 5 \pm 2 \pm 1)$ For $x<5$ there are no solutions (assuming $x \in \mathbb{N}$ ) 
 
 From the first two equations $4x^2+4y^2+4z^2=120 \rightarrow x^2+y^2+z^2=30$ which implies $x \leq 5$ Also note that $(x+y+z)^2=x^2+y^2+z^2+2(xy+xz+yz) \rightarrow (x+y+z)^2=30 14 \rightarrow x+y+z= \pm 4$ When $x+y+z=4$ we have $(x y z)=(5 2 1)$ only and when $x+y+z= 4$ we have $(x y z)=( 5 2 1)$ only These are the only two solutions The answers are $(x y z)=\boxed{(5 2 1) \text{ and } ( 5 2 1)}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 4
text: Let $\{a_n\}$ be a sequence of real numbers with $a_1=-1$, $a_2=2$ and for all $n\ge3$, $$a_{n+1}-a_n-a_{n+2}=0.$$Find $a_1+a_2+a_3+\ldots+a_{2015}$.
solution:
It becomes easier to rewrite as $a_{n+2}=a_{n+1} a_n$ 
 Therefore $a_3=3$ $a_4=1$ $a_5= 2$ $a_6= 3$ $a_7= 1$ $a_8=2$ so the sequence is cyclic every six terms But $a_1+a_2+a_3+ \dots + a_{2015} = a_1+a_2+(a_2 a_1)+(a_3 a_2)+(a_4 a_3) + \dots + (a_{2013} a_{2012})+(a_{2014} a_{2013})=a_2+a_{2014}$ so it suffices to find $a_{2014}$ Since $2014 \equiv 4 \pmod{6}$ $a_{2014}=a_4=1$ so the answer is $2+1=\boxed{3}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 5
text: Let $x$ and $y$ be real numbers satisfying the equation $x^2-4x+y^2+3=0$. If the maximum and minimum values of $x^2+y^2$ are $M$ and $m$ respectively, compute the numerical value of $M-m$.
solution: Note that this is equal to $(x 2)^2+y^2=1$ which is a circle with center $(2 0)$ and radius $1$ Note that $x^2+y^2$ is equal to the square of the distance from a point on the circle to the origin The closest point ends up being $(1 0)$ and the farthest point ends up being $(3 0)$ (since the circle's center lies on the $x$ axis) so the answer is $3^2 1^2=\boxed{8}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 6
text: The roots of the equation $x^5-180x^4+Ax^3+Bx^2+Cx+D=0$ are in geometric progression. The sum of their reciprocals is $20$. Compute $|D|$.
solution: Great problem Let the roots be $a$ $ar$ $ar^2$ $ar^3$ and $ar^4$ By Vieta's formulas $a+ar+ar^2+ar^3+ar^4=180 \rightarrow a(r^4+r^3+r^2+r+1)=180$ and from the given condition $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{ar}+\frac{1}{ar^2}+\frac{1}{ar^3}+\frac{1}{ar^4}=20$ Multiply the equation by $ar^4$ on both sides to get $r^4+r^3+r^2+r+1=20ar^4$ But from the first equation $r^4+r^3+r^2+r+1=\frac{180}{a}$ so we have $\frac{180}{a}=20ar^4 \rightarrow 20a^2r^4=180 \rightarrow \left(ar^2\right)^2=9 \rightarrow ar^2= \pm 3$ We want $|D|=| a(ar)(ar^2)(ar^3)(ar^4)| = |a^5r^{10}| = |(ar^2)^5| = \boxed{243}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 7
text: Evaluate $\sum_{k=0}^{37}(-1)^k\binom{75}{2k}$.
solution: This is awfully close to $2^{75}=\sum_{n=0}^{75} \binom{75}{n}$ except $n=2k$ Also realize $\text{sum of the coefficients}\left[{(1+k)^{75}}\right]=\sum_{n=0}^{75} \binom{75}{n}$ Since this is an alternating series it motivates us to use complex numbers using the real part of the expansion of when $k=i$ $(1+i)^{75}$ The summation is equal to finding $\text{Re}\left[(1+i)^{75}\right]$ converting gives $1+i= \sqrt{1^2+1^2} e^{\arctan{(1)} i} = \sqrt{2}e^{i \tfrac{\pi}{4}}$ so $\text{Re}\left[(1+i)^{75}\right]=\text{Re} \left(\sqrt{2}e^{i \tfrac{\pi}{4}}\right)^{75} \rightarrow 2^{\frac{75}{2}} \cos{\frac{75 \pi}{4}} \rightarrow 2^{\frac{75}{2}} \cdot 2^{\frac{ 1}{2}} = \boxed{ 2^{37}}$

title: 2015 BMT Spring Analysis 10
text: Evaluate $$\int^{\pi/2}_0\ln(4\sin x)dx.$$
solution: Click to reveal hidden text The $4$ being multiplied by $\sin x$ seems random so we can pull it out using the fact that $\log(ab) = \log a + \log b$ $$\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(4\sin x)\ dx = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln4 + \ln(\sin x)\ dx = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln4+\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x)\ dx$$ To find $\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x)\ dx$ we can set the integral to a value $I$ and manipulate the $I$ to find the value $$I = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x)\ dx$$ Before continuing notice that $\ln(\sin x)$ is symmetric about $x=\frac{\pi}{2}$ over the interval $[0 \pi]$ Why Click to reveal hidden text Because $\ln x \to \infty$ as $x\to0^+$ $\sin(\ln x)$ has vertical asymptotes at $x=0$ and $x=\pi$ (when $\sin x=0$ ) Using some trig identities we know that for $x\in [0 \pi]$ $\sin x = \sin(\pi x)$ Therefore $\ln(\sin x) = \ln(\sin(\pi x))$ and $\ln(\sin(\pi x))$ is symmetric over the interval $[0 \pi]$ with the axis of symmetry being $x=\pi/2$ This means that $$I=\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x)\ dx = \int_{\pi/2}^\pi\ln(\sin x)\ dx = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln\left(\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} x\right)}_{\cos x}\right)\ dx = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\cos x)\ dx$$ Therefore $$2I = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x) + \ln(\cos x)\ dx = \int_0^{\pi/2}\underbrace{\ln(\overbrace{\sin x\cos x}^{\sin2x=2\sin x\cos x})}_{\ln a+\ln b = \ln ab}\ dx = \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln\left( \frac{1}{2}\sin2x \right)dx$$ Just as with the $4$ from the original problem we can pull out the $\frac{1}{2}$ to get $$2I = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + \int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin2x)\ dx$$ Using $u$ substitution on $\sin 2x\Rightarrow u=2x du=2dx$ giving $$2I = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + \frac{1}{2}\int_0^\pi \ln(\sin u)\ du$$ Because $\ln(\sin x)$ is symmetric about $x=\frac{\pi}{2}$ over the interval $[0 \pi]$ (from earlier ) $\int_0^\pi \ln(\sin u)\ du = 2\underbrace{\int_0^{\pi/2} \ln(\sin u)\ du}_{I} = 2I$ Substituting back into the original $$2I = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + \frac{1}{2}\cdot2I \Longrightarrow I = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)$$ Now we can find our original (the one from the beginning of the problem ) $$\frac{\pi}{2}\ln4+\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(\sin x)\ dx = \frac{\pi}{2}\ln4+\frac{\pi}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) = \boxed{\frac{\pi}{2}\ln2}$$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 2
text: Suppose we list the decimal representations of the positive even numbers from left to right. Determine the $2015^{th}$ digit in the list.
solution:
The concatenation of even numbers is equal to $$24681012141618 \dots$$ 
 From one digit numbers we get $4$ digits From two digit numbers we get $2 \cdot 45 = 90$ digits From three digit numbers we get $3 \cdot 450 = 1350$ digits From four digit numbers we get a lot more digits In fact we need exactly $2015 1350 90 4=571$ more digits Notice that $\frac{571}{4}=142 \text{ r}3$ so we take the fourth digit of the $142$ n d number Notice the sequence of four digit numbers is equal to $a_n=998+2n$ so we require $a_{142}=1282$ The answer is $\boxed{2}$

title: BD^2=? <ABC=90^o,AB=12, BC=9,CD=20, DA=25, 2015 BMT Individual 3
text: A quadrilateral $ABCD$ has a right angle at $\angle ABC$ and satisfies $AB = 12$, $BC = 9$, $CD = 20$, and $DA = 25$. Determine $BD^2$..
solution:
Let $\angle{BCA}=\theta$ Then $\sin{\theta}=\frac{4}{5}$ By the Law of Cosines on $\triangle{BCD}$ we get $BD^2=9^2+20^2 2(9)(20)\cos(90+\theta)$ Use $\cos(90+\theta)= \sin{\theta}$ to get $BD^2=481 360\left( \frac{4}{5}\right)=\boxed{769}$ 
 
 (there are probably a million other ways to do this)

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 4
text: A train traveling at $ 80$ mph begins to cross a $ 1$ mile long bridge. At this moment, a man begins to walk from the front of the train to the back of the train at a speed of $5$ mph. The man reaches the back of the train as soon as the train is completely off the bridge. What is the length of the train (as a fraction of a mile)?
solution: Since the train is travelling at $80$ mph it will take the train $\frac{1}{80}$ hour to cross the bridge Thus it takes the man exactly $\frac{1}{80}$ hour to reach the back of the train but the man is also walking at $5$ mph Therefore $d=5\left(\frac{1}{80}\right) = \boxed{\frac{1}{16} \text{ mile}}$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 5

solution: Since $P$ and $Q$ are subsets and there are $2^{10}$ possible subsets there are exactly $2^{10} 2$ pairs of sets that work since we cannot use $S$ or $\emptyset$ However we must also divide by $2$ since with sets we can just "flip" the ordering of the subsets so the answer is $2^9 1=\boxed{511}$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 6
text: An integer-valued function $f$ satisfies $f(2) = 4$ and $f(mn) = f(m)f(n)$ for all integers $m$ and $n$. If $f$ is an increasing function, determine $f(2015)$.
solution: By the method of undetermined coefficients let $f(x)=ax^2$ Then $f(mn)=am^2n^2$ and $f(m)f(n)=am^2 \cdot an^2$ so $am^2n^2=a^2m^2n^2$ This implies $a^2=a$ or $a=1$ (since $a=0$ gives a horizontal line) Thus $f(x)=x^2$ and obviously the given condition is met Therefore $f(2015)=\boxed{2015^2}$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 8
text: An integer is between $0$ and $999999$ (inclusive) is chosen, and the digits of its decimal representation are summed. What is the probability that the sum will be $19$?
solution:
First note that there are $1000000$ integers between $0$ and $999999$ inclusive It is easy to see that the generating function for the sum of the digits of the decimal representation of integers in the range $[0 999999]$ is 
 \begin{align*}
(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^9)^6 &= \left(\frac{1 x^{10}}{1 x}\right)^6 \\
&= \frac{(1 x^{10})^6}{(1 x)^6} \\
&= (1 x^{10})^6(1 x)^{ 6}
\end{align*} Hence the number of integers in the given range whose sum of digits in decimal representation is $19$ is 
 \begin{align*}
[x^{19}] \left((1 x^{10})^6(1 x)^{ 6}\right) &= [x^{19}]\left((1 x)^{ 6}\right) 10[x^{9}]\left((1 x)^{ 6}\right) \\
&= \binom{24}{19} 10\binom{14}{9} \\
&= 42504 10\cdot2002\\
&= 42504 20020 \\
&= 22484 \end{align*} so the answer is $$\frac{22484}{1000000} = \boxed{\frac{5621}{250000}} $$ $\square$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual 9
text: The number $2^{29}$ has a $9$-digit decimal representation that contains all but one of the $10$ (decimal) digits. Determine which digit is missing
solution:
Very typical question involving mod 9 
 $2^{29}\equiv(2^6)^4\cdot2^5\equiv32\equiv5\bmod9 $ 
 The sum of digits is $0+1+ +8+9 m=45 m$ where $m$ is the missing digit This sum must be divisible by 9 so $45 m\equiv5\bmod 9\Rightarrow m\equiv 4\bmod 9 $ so $m$ must be $\fbox{4} $

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual Tiebreaker #1
text: Compute the surface area of a rectangular prism with side lengths $2, 3, 4$.
solution:
Taking the sum of the areas of the six faces of the rectangular prism the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
2\cdot(2\cdot3+3\cdot4+4\cdot2) &= 2\cdot(6+12+8) \\
&= 2\cdot26 \\
&= \boxed{52} \end{align*} $\square$

title: BMT 2015 Spring - Individual Tiebreaker #2
text: Let $S_n = 1 + 2 +,,, + n$. Define $$T_n =\frac{S_2}{S_2- 1}\cdot \frac{S_3}{S_3 - 1}\cdot... \cdot \frac{S_n}{S_n - 1}.$$Find $T_{2015}.$
solution:
We have 
 \begin{align*}
T_{2015} &= \prod_{k=2}^{2015} \frac{S_k}{S_k 1} \\
&= \prod_{k=2}^{2015} \frac{\frac{k(k+1)}{2}}{\frac{k(k+1)}{2} 1} \\
&= \prod_{k=2}^{2015} \frac{k(k+1)}{(k 1)(k+2)} \\
&= \frac{(2\cdot3)\cdot(3\cdot4)\cdot(4\cdot5)\cdot\ldots\cdot(2014\cdot2015)\cdot(2015\cdot2016)}{(1\cdot4)\cdot(2\cdot5)\cdot(3\cdot6)\cdot(4\cdot7)\cdot\ldots\cdot(2011\cdot2014)\cdot(2012\cdot2015)\cdot(2013\cdot2016)\cdot(2014\cdot2017)} \\
&= \frac{2\cdot3^2\cdot (4^2\cdot5^2\cdot\ldots\cdot2014^2)\cdot2015^2\cdot2016}{1\cdot2\cdot3\cdot(4^2\cdot5^2\ldots\cdot2014^2)\cdot2015\cdot2016\cdot2017} \\
&= \frac{2\cdot3^2\cdot2015^2\cdot2016}{1\cdot2\cdot3\cdot2015\cdot2016\cdot2017} \\
&= \frac{3\cdot2015}{2017} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{6045}{2017}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Geometry 6
text: Square $ABCD$ has side length $5$ and arc $BD$ with center $A$. $E$ is the midpoint of $AB$ and $CE$ intersects arc $BD$ at $F$. $G$ is placed onto $BC$ such that $FG$ is perpendicular to $BC$. What is the length of $FG$?
solution: Since $E$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AB}$ $AE=BE=\tfrac{5}{2}$ And by Pythagorean Theorem $BC^2+BE^2=CE^2 \rightarrow 5^2+\left(\tfrac{5}{2}\right)^2=CE^2 \rightarrow CE^2=\tfrac{125}{4} \rightarrow CE=\tfrac{5\sqrt{5}}{2}$ Instead of drawing the arc draw the entire circumference of the circle since it is obvious that $ABCD$ is cyclic So by Power of the Point $\left(\tfrac{5}{2}\right)^2=\tfrac{5\sqrt{5}}{2} \cdot EF \rightarrow EF = \tfrac{5 \xcancel{25}}{2 \xcancel{4}} \cdot \tfrac{\xcancel{2}}{\xcancel{5}\sqrt{5}} = \tfrac{\sqrt{5}}{2}$ Thus $CF=3\sqrt{5}$ Also notice $\triangle{CBE} \sim \triangle{CGF}$ by AA so $\tfrac{BE}{CE}=\tfrac{GF}{CF} \rightarrow \tfrac{\tfrac{5}{2}}{\tfrac{5\sqrt{5}}{2}}=\tfrac{FG}{3\sqrt{5}} \rightarrow FG = 3\xcancel{\sqrt{5}} \cdot \tfrac{\xcancel{5}}{\xcancel{2}} \cdot \tfrac{\xcancel{2}}{\xcancel{5}\xcancel{\sqrt{5}}} = \boxed{3}$

title: right triangle inscribed in circle 2014 BMT Team 4
text: In a right triangle, the altitude from a vertex to the hypotenuse splits the hypotenuse into two segments of lengths $a$ and $b$. If the right triangle has area $T$ and is inscribed in a circle of area $C$, find $ab$ in terms of $T$ and $C$.
solution:
The altitude is equal to $\sqrt{ab}$ by the Geometric Mean Theorem and by the Inscribed Angle Theorem the radius of the circle is $\frac{a+b}{2}$ hence $C=\pi \left(\frac{a+b}{2} \right)^2 = \frac{\pi}{4}(a+b)^2$ 
 The area of the triangle is $T=\frac{1}{2}(a+b)(\sqrt{ab})$ 
 
 Notice that $\frac{T^2}{C}=\frac{\frac{1}{4}(a+b)^2(ab)}{\frac{\pi}{4}(a+b)^2} = \frac{ab}{\pi}$ so we just have to plop on another $\pi$ The answer is $\boxed{\frac{\pi T^2}{C}}$

title: 2014 BMT Team 11
text: Suppose that $x^{10} + x + 1 = 0$ and $x^100 = a_0 + a_1x +... + a_9x^9$. Find $a_5$.
solution:
Notice $x^{10} = x 1$ so \[ x^{100} = ( 1)^{10} \times (x+1)^{10} = (x+1)^{10} = \sum_{i=0}^{10} \binom{10}{i} x^i \] and hence for $i=10$ it only affects the values $a_1$ and $a_0$ So the answer is 
 \[ \binom{10}{5} = \boxed{252} \]

solution: It can be verified that there are 4 total intersections and since both graphs are symmetric about $x = \frac{7}{2}$ the answer is $4 * \frac{7}{2} = \boxed{14}$

title: 2014 BMT Team 15
text: Suppose a box contains $28$ balls: $1$ red, $2$ blue, $3$ yellow, $4$ orange, $5$ purple, $6$ green, and $7$ pink. One by one, each ball is removed uniformly at random and without replacement until all $28$ balls have been removed. Determine the probability that the most likely “scenario of exhaustion” occurs; that is, determine the probability that the first color to have all such balls removed from the box is red, that the second is blue, the third is yellow, the fourth is orange, the fifth is purple, the sixth is green, and the seventh is pink.
solution: Consider a random arrangement of these 28 balls clearly there is a $7/28$ chance that a pink ball is drawn last Now given that a pink ball is drawn last we can remove all such pink balls without disturbing the probability that a 'scenario of exhaustion' occurs Similarly there is thus a $6/21$ chance that a green ball is drawn 'last' we continue multiplying to get $1/315$ at the end

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Analysis 2
text: Find the smallest positive value of $x$ such that $x^3-9x^2+22x-16=0$.
solution: Storage Using the factor theorem we see that $(x 2)$ is a factor $$x^3 9x^2+22x 16=(x 2)(x^2 7x+8)=(x 2)(x 8)(x+1)$$ Thus the smallest positive value is $\boxed{2}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Analysis 4
text: The function $f(x)=x^5-20x^4+ax^3+bx^2+cx+24$ has the interesting property that its roots can be arranged to form an arithmetic sequence. Determine $f(8)$.
solution:
Let the roots be $m 2n$ $m n$ $m$ $m+n$ $m+2n$ From Vieta's their sum is equal to $20$ so $5m=20 \rightarrow m=4$ 
 The product of the roots is $ 24$ so $(16 4n^2)(16 n^2)(4)= 24 \rightarrow (16 4n^2)(16 n^2)= 6$ 
 
 Note $f(8)=\left(8 \left(4 2n\right)\right)\left(8 \left(4 n\right)\right)\left(8 4\right)\left(8 \left(4+n\right)\right)\left(8 \left(4+2n\right)\right)$ 
 $\rightarrow 4\left(4+2n\right)\left(4+n\right)\left(4 n\right)\left(4 2n\right)$ 
 $\rightarrow 4(4+2n)(4 2n)(4+n)(4 n)$ 
 $\rightarrow 4\underbrace{(16 4n^2)(16 n^2)}_{\text{equal to } 6} = \boxed{ 24}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Analysis 6
text: Find $f(2)$ given that $f$ is a real-valued function that satisfies the equation $$4f(x)+\left(\frac23\right)(x^2+2)f\left(x-\frac2x\right)=x^3+1.$$
solution:
Sub in $x=1$ to get $4f(1)+2f( 1)=2$ 
 Sub in $x= 1$ to get $4f( 1)+2f(1)=0$ 
 Solving the system gives $f(1)=\frac{2}{3}$ and $f( 1)= \frac{1}{3}$ 
 Sub in $x=2$ to get $4f(2)+4f(1)=9 \rightarrow 4f(2)+\frac{8}{3}=9 \rightarrow 4f(2)=\frac{19}{3} \rightarrow f(2)=\boxed{\frac{19}{12}}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Analysis P1
text: Suppose that $a,b,c,d$ are non-negative real numbers such that $a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2=2$ and $ab+bc+cd+da=1$. Find the maximum value of $a+b+c+d$ and determine all equality cases.
solution: Notice that $(a+b+c+d)^2=a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2+2(ab+bc+cd+da)+2(ac+bd) \rightarrow (a+b+c+d)^2=4+2(ac+bd)$ and by AM GM $a^2+c^2 \geq 2ac$ and $b^2+d^2 \geq 2bd$ meaning that $(a+b+c+d)^2 \geq 4+(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2) \rightarrow (a+b+c+d)^2 \geq 6$ meaning the maximum value is $\boxed{\sqrt{6}}$ Equality occurs when $a=c=\frac{\sqrt{6} \pm \sqrt{2}}{4}$ and $b=d=\frac{\sqrt{6} \mp \sqrt{2}}{4}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Individual 1
text: A festive number is a four-digit integer containing one of each of the digits $0, 1, 2$, and $4$ in its decimal representation. How many festive numbers are there?
solution:
The first digit has three choices so the answer is $3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 = \boxed{18}$ 
 
 Alternatively note there are $4!=24$ possibilities and exactly a fourth of them start with a zero so $\frac{3}{4}(24)=18$

title: area of ABC wanted AB=EF, BC=FD, CA=DE=2. 2014 BMT Individual 3
text: Suppose $ \vartriangle ABC$ is similar to $\vartriangle DEF$, with $ A$, $ B$, and $C$ corresponding to $D, E$, and $F$ respectively. If $\overline{AB} = \overline{EF}$, $\overline{BC} = \overline{FD}$, and $\overline{CA} = \overline{DE} = 2$, determine the area of $ \vartriangle ABC$.
solution:
Let $AB=EF=a$ $BC=FD=b$ with $\triangle{DEF}$ being $r$ times larger than $\triangle{ABC}$ We get the following system $$ar=2$$ $$br=a$$ $$b=2r$$ 
 Subbing the third equation into the second gives $2r^2=a$ and subbing this into the first gives $2r^3=2 \rightarrow r^3=1$ Since $r$ is real $r=1$ so the triangles are congruent Therefore $a=b=2$ Both triangles are equilateral with area $\frac{2^2 \sqrt{3}}{4}=\boxed{\sqrt{3}}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Individual 7
text: If $f(x, y) = 3x^2 + 3xy + 1$ and $f(a, b) + 1 = f(b, a) = 42$, then determine $|a + b|$.
solution:
We have $3a^2+3ab+2=3b^2+3ab+1=42$ Setting the first and second equations equal to the third gives $$3a^2+3ab=40 \rightarrow 3a(a+b)=40$$ $$3b^2+3ab=41 \rightarrow 3b(a+b)=41$$ Dividing the first equation by the second gives $\frac{a}{b}=\frac{40}{41}$ 
 Divide the second equation by $b^2$ to get $3+3\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)=\frac{41}{b^2} \rightarrow 3+\frac{120}{41}=\frac{41}{b^2} \rightarrow \frac{243}{41}=\frac{41}{b^2} \rightarrow b^2=\frac{41^2}{3^5} \rightarrow b=\pm \frac{41}{9\sqrt{3}} \rightarrow b=\pm \frac{41\sqrt{3}}{27}$ So $a=\pm \frac{40\sqrt{3}}{27}$ and regardless of which ordered pair you choose $|a+b|=\boxed{3\sqrt{3}}$

title: BMT 2014 Spring - Individual 18
text: Suppose the polynomial $f(x) = x^{2014}$ is equal to $f(x) =\sum^{2014}_{k=0} a_k {x \choose k}$ for some real numbers $a_0,..., a_{2014}$. Find the largest integer $m$ such that $2^m$ divides $a_{2013}$.
solution: Basically we see that $x^{2014}$ only occurs when $k=2014$ thus in order to make the coeffient $1$ $a_{2014}=2014!$ to get rid of the denominator created by $\binom{x}{2014} $ This means that the $x^{2013}$ term has a coefficient of $ 1 2 3 \dots 2013$ which has a sum of $1007*2013 $ Since the only term with another $x^{2013}$ is when $k=2013$ we see that $a_{2013}=2013!*1007*2013 $ Since $1007$ and $2013$ have no factors of $2$ we proceed with Legendre's on $2013!$ which gives us $1006+503+251+125+62+31+15+7+3+1=\boxed{2004}$
