text: Let $MATH$ be a square with $MA = 1$. Point $B$ lies on $AT$ such that $\angle MBT = 3.5 \angle BMT$. What is the area of $\vartriangle BMT$?
solution:
Let $m\angle BMT = a$ Then $m\angle MBA = (180 3 5a)$ since $\triangle MAB$ is right $m\angle AMB =(3 5a 90)$ 
 Thus $3 5a 90+a = 45$ as $m \angle AMT = 45^o$ 
 ( $\overline{MT}$ is a diagonal of the rectangle) It follows that $a = 30$ so $m\angle AMB = 15^o$ 
 thus $\triangle MAB$ is a $15 75 90$ triangle By Trigo we obtain $\tan 15^o = 2 \sqrt{3}$ which then gives $AB=2 \sqrt{3}$ 
 and hence we get area of $\triangle BMT$ as $\boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3} 1}{2}}$

The chord then hinges around $V_3$, then $V_4$, and so on, continuing until $ P$ is back at its original position. Find the total length traced by $ P$.
solution:
If I understand the problem correctly 1st round from rotating around $V_2 V_4 V_{16}$ $P$ travels each time $2\cdot \frac{15}{17}\pi$ 
 from rotating around $V_3 V_5 V_{17}$ $P$ travels each time $ \frac{15}{17}\pi$ 
 To get back in its initial position P needs to travel one more time around this heptathingie 
 
 2nd round from rotating around $V_1 V_3 V_{17}$ $P$ travels each time $2\cdot \frac{15}{17}\pi$ 
 from rotating around $V_2 V_4 V_{16}$ $P$ travels each time $\frac{15}{17}\pi$ 
 
 Almost there! 
 One more rotation around $V_1$ of length $\frac{15}{17}\pi$ and $P$ is back where it started The total length travelled by the point is $30 \pi$ units

title: min area of an hexagon, lines through O // sides ABC 2019 BMT Individual 16
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB = 26$, $BC = 51$, and $CA = 73$, and let $O$ be an arbitrary point in the interior of $\vartriangle ABC$. Lines $\ell_1$, $\ell_2$, and $\ell_3$ pass through $O$ and are parallel to $\overline{AB}$, $\overline{BC}$, and $\overline{CA}$, respectively. The intersections of $\ell_1$, $\ell_2$, and $\ell_3$ and the sides of $\vartriangle ABC$ form a hexagon whose area is $A$. Compute the minimum value of $A$.
solution:
First realize that the minimum area of the hexagon is $\frac{2}{3}$ that of the triangle regardless of the angle measures of the triangle This can be proven using arguments regarding parallel lines and similar triangles PROOF Symbols $l_1$ intersects $AC$ at $D$ $BC$ at $G$ $l_2$ intersects $AB$ at $F$ $AC$ at $I$ $l_3$ intersects $AB$ at $E$ $BC$ at $H$ So $DEFGHI$ is the hexagon whose minimum area needs to be found Now By tracing parallel lines and similar triangles we have 
 $$\frac{A_{EFO}}{A_{ABC}}+\frac{A_{OGH}}{A_{ABC}}+\frac{A_{DOI}}{A_{ABC}}=\left(\frac{FO}{BC}\right)^2+\left(\frac{GH}{BC}\right)^2+\left(\frac{OI}{BC}\right)^2$$ $$= \left(\frac{BG}{GC}\right)^2+\left(\frac{GH}{BC}\right)^2+\left(\frac{HC}{BC}\right)^2$$ $$\geq \frac{1}{3} \left(\frac{BG}{GC}+\frac{GH}{BC}+\frac{HC}{BC}\right)^2=\frac{1}{3}$$ (last line follows Cauchy Schwarz) 
 Now We have $A_{EFO}+A_{OGH}+A_{DOI} \geq \frac{A_{ABC}}{3}$ and from there $A_{AED}+A_{FBG}+A_{IHC} \leq \frac{A_{ABC}}{3}$ 
 Therefore Area of hexagon $DEFGHI$ = $A_{ABC} \left( A_{AED}+A_{FBG}+A_{IHC} \right) \geq \frac{2}{3}$ 
 Equality is reached when $O$ is the centroid of $\triangle ABC$ 
 
 Using Heron's Formula we get area of triangle as $\sqrt{75\cdot 49\cdot 24\cdot 2}=420$ 
 Thus the minimum area of hexagon is $\frac{2\cdot 420}{3} = \boxed{280}$

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 3
text: $2018$ people (call them $A, B, C, \ldots$) stand in a line with each permutation equally likely. Given that $A$ stands before $B$, what is the probability that $C$ stands after $B$?
solution:
Denote $P<Q$ as meaning " $P$ stands before $Q$ " 
 
 Let $X$ be the event that $A<B$ and $Y$ be the event that $B<C$ Then what we're trying to find is $P(Y|X)$ 
 
 $P(Y\cap X)$ is the probability that $A<B<C$ Since each of $A<B<C$ $A<C<B$ $B<A<C$ $B<C<A$ $C<A<B$ and $C<B<A$ are all equally likely to happen then this means the probability is $P(Y\cap X)=\frac16$ 
 
 $P(X)$ is the probability that $A<B$ Since each of $A<B$ and $B<A$ are equally likely to happen the probability is $P(X)=\frac12$ 
 
 The answer is 
 $$P(Y|X)=\frac{P(Y\cap X)}{P(X)}=\frac{\frac16}{\frac12}=\boxed{\frac13}$$

solution: You can place 14 bishops as shown in the diagram below On the left they are placed in a row so none are threatened To assure the most you must place bishops on the right You can't place them in the top right corner or in the bottom right corner because the bishops in the bottom left and top left would threaten them respectively So $8+6=\boxed{14}$

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 6
text: A rectangular prism with dimensions $20$ cm by $1$ cm by $7$ cm is made with blue $1$ cm unit cubes. The outside of the rectangular prism is coated in gold paint. If a cube is chosen at random and rolled, what is the probability that the side facing up is painted gold?
solution:
Each cube has $6$ faces The number of all the faces is $20\cdot1\cdot7\cdot6=840$ 
 
 The number of faces with gold paint is equal to the surface area of the prism which is $2(20\cdot1+1\cdot7+7\cdot20)=334$ 
 
 Now since each face is equally likely to come up the answer is $\frac{334}{840}=\boxed{\frac{167}{420}}$

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 9
text: Circles $A$, $B$, and $C$ are externally tangent circles. Line $PQ$ is drawn such that $PQ$ is tangent to $A$ at $P$, tangent to $B$ at $Q$, and does not intersect with $C$. Circle $D$ is drawn such that it passes through the centers of $A$, $B$, and $C$. Let $R$ be the point on $D$ furthest from $PQ$. If $A$, $B$, and $C$ have radii $3$, $2$, and $1$, respectively, the area of triangle $PQR$ can be expressed in the form of $a+b\sqrt{c}$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are integers with $c$ not divisible by any prime square. What is $a + b + c$?
solution:
Geometry $AB^2=AC^2+BC^2$ 
 $\triangle ABC$ is right angled at $C D$ is the mid point of $AB$ 
 The foot $E$ of $D$ on $PQ$ is the mid point of $PQ$ 
 $DE=2 5 RE=5 PQ=\sqrt{5^2 1^2}=2\sqrt6 [PQR]=5\sqrt6$

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 10
text: A rectangular prism has three distinct faces of area $24$, $30$, and $32$. The diagonals of each distinct face of the prism form sides of a triangle. What is the triangle’s area?
solution:
$AB=24$ 
 $AC=30$ 
 $BC=32$ 
 $B=24/A$ 
 $C=30/A$ 
 Substituting into the third equation we get that $720/A^2=32$ so $A^2=22 5$ We do similar things to solve for the other terms We get that $B^2=25 6$ and $C^2=40$ We know that the diagonals of the each side using Pythagorean's Theorem will be $\sqrt{a^2+b^2}$ $\sqrt{a^2+c^2}$ and $\sqrt{b^2+b^2}$ So the sides of the triangle will be $\sqrt{62 5}$ $\sqrt{65 6}$ and $\sqrt{48 1}$ We then use Heron's The semi perimeter is $s=\frac{\sqrt{62 5}+\sqrt{65 6}+\sqrt{48 1}}{2}$ We plug into Heron's and get $625$

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 12
text: Let $f: [0, 1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a monotonically increasing function such that $$f\left(\frac{x}{3}\right) = \frac{f(x)}{2}$$$$f(1 0 x) = 2018 - f(x).$$If $f(1) = 2018$, find $f\left(\dfrac{12}{13}\right)$.
solution:
IsabeltheCat wrote Let $f [0 1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a monotonically increasing function such that 
 $$f\left(\frac{x}{3}\right) = \frac{f(x)}{2}$$ $$f(1 0 x) = 2018 f(x) $$ If $f(1) = 2018$ find $f\left(\dfrac{12}{13}\right)$ 
 Are you sure this is correct? Becuse there is no function which satisfies this If one takes $x<y$ we have 
 $$f(10x)=2018 f(x)\implies f(10x)+f(x)=2018$$ $$f(10y)=2018 f(y)\implies f(10y)+f(y)=2018$$ This gives 
 $$f(10x)+f(x)=f(10y)+f(y)$$ which is impossible since $f(10x)+f(x)<f(10y)+f(y)$ as $f$ is monotonically increasing

title: BMT 2018 Team Round Problem 15
text: Let triangle $ABC$ have side lengths $AB = 13$, $BC = 14$, $AC = 15$. Let $I$ be the incenter of $ABC$. The circle centered at $A$ of radius $AI$ intersects the circumcircle of $ABC$ at $H$ and $J$. Let $L$ be a point that lies on both the incircle of $ABC$ and line $HJ$. If the minimal possible value of $AL$ is $\sqrt{n}$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}$, find $n$.
solution:
The first thing to observe here is that $HJ$ is in fact tangent to the incircle of $ABC$ at $L$ To prove this we see that $A$ is the circumcenter of triangle $HIJ$ so by the incenter excenter lemma $I$ is the incenter of triangle $HJM$ In addition observe that by Euler's theorem that $d^2 = R^2 2rR$ so the inradius of $HJM$ equal to the inradius of $ABC$ 
 
 Let $HJ$ intersect $AB$ at $N$ and $AC$ at $O$ The main observation is that triangle $AON$ is similar to triangle $ABC$ To prove this observe that by power of a point theorem $AN \times NB = HN \times NJ = AI^2 AN^2 \implies AN(NB + AN) = AN \times AB = AI^2$ Similarly $AO \times AC = AI^2$ Hence $AN \times AB = AO \times AC \implies \frac{AN}{AC} = \frac{AO}{AB}$ Thus by SAS similarity triangle $AON$ is similar to triangle $ABC$ Let the $A$ excenter of triangle $ABC$ be tangent to $BC$ at $U$ and the incircle of $ABC$ to be tangent at $BC$ at $R$ It is well known that $BR = UC = s b = 6$ Since the height from $A$ of the triangle is $12$ we have by the pythagorean theorem that 
 $$12^2 + (14 6 5)^2 = AU^2 \implies AU = \sqrt{153} = 3\sqrt{17}$$ In addition it is well known that the ratio of the in radius to the $A$ exradius is $\frac{s a}{s} = \frac{7}{21} = \frac{1}{3}$ Hence $AL = \frac{AU}{3} = \sqrt{17}$ so the answer is $\boxed{17}$

title: BMT 2018 Algebra Round Problem 1
text: An airplane accelerates at $10$ mph per second and decelerates at $15$ mph/sec. Given that its takeoff speed is $180$ mph, and the pilots want enough runway length to safely decelerate to a stop from any speed below takeoff speed, what’s the shortest length that the runway can be allowed to be? Assume the pilots always use maximum acceleration when accelerating. Please give your answer in miles.
solution: We know that the initial speed for takeoff is 0 mph because the plane isn't moving The final speed is at most 180 mph so the distance is at most $90\cdot t$ where t is the time t = 18 seconds or $\frac{1}{200}$ hours so our answer for this part is $\frac{9}{20}$ for how far it can go when accelerating For decelerating t = 12 seconds or $\frac{1}{300}$ hours so our answer for this part is $\frac{3}{10}$ Adding them up gives $\frac{3}{4}$ miles

title: BMT 2018 Algebra Round Problem 2
text: If there is only $1$ complex solution to the equation $8x^3 + 12x^2 + kx + 1 = 0$, what is $k$?
solution:
In order for there to be exactly one complex solution then the cubic must be of the form $8(x \alpha)^3=0$ for some complex $\alpha$ 
 
 We have 
 $$8x^3+12x^2+kx+1=8x^3 24\alpha x^2+24\alpha^2 x 8\alpha^3=0\implies\alpha= \frac12$$ Therefore $$k=24\alpha^2=\boxed6$$

title: 2018 BMT Algebra Tiebreakers 3
solution:
By series multisection or commonly known as unity filter we have $\sum_{k=0}^{\left\lfloor\frac{n}{p}\right\rfloor} a_{pk+q}x^{pk+q}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} a_{pk+q}x^{pk+q}=\frac{1}{p}\sum_{k=0}^{p 1}\varepsilon^{ kq}f(\varepsilon^kx) ~\varepsilon=e^{2i\pi/p}$ 
 Here $a_r=\binom{2018}{r}x^r ~f(x)=(1+x)^{2018} ~p=3 ~q=2$ 
 \begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^{672}\binom{2018}{3k+2}x^{3k+2}&=\frac{1}{3}\sum_{k=0}^{2}\omega^{ 2k}f(\omega^kx)\\
\sum_{k=0}^{672}\binom{2018}{3k+2}&=\frac{1}{3}\sum_{k=0}^{2}\omega^{ 2k}f(\omega^k)\\
&=\frac{\omega^{ 2\cdot0}f(1)+\omega^{ 2\cdot1}f(\omega)+\omega^{ 2\cdot2}f(\omega^2)}{3}\\
&=\frac{f(1)+\omega^{ 2}f(\omega)+\omega^{ 4}f(\omega^2)}{3}\\
&=\frac{2^{2018}+\omega^{ 2}(1+\omega)^{2018}+\omega^{ 4}(1+\omega^2)^{2018}}{3}\\
&=\frac{2^{2018}+\omega^{ 2}( \omega^2)^{2018}+\omega^{ 4}( \omega)^{2018}}{3}\\
&=\frac{2^{2018}+\omega^2+\omega^1}{3}=\frac{2^{2018} 1}{3}
\end{align*} Now 
 \begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^{672}\binom{2018}{3k+2}&\equiv \frac{2^{2018} 1}{3}\equiv x\pmod3\\
\implies &2^{2018} 1\equiv 3x\pmod{3\cdot\gcd(3 3)}\\
&2^{2018} 1\equiv 3x\pmod9\\
&3\equiv 3x\pmod9\\
&1\equiv x\pmod{\frac{9}{\gcd(3 9)}}\\
&1\equiv x\pmod3\\
\sum_{k=0}^{672}\binom{2018}{3k+2}&\equiv \boxed{1}\pmod3
\end{align*}

title: BMT 2018 Spring - Geometry 9
text: What is the least integer a greater than $14$ so that the triangle with side lengths $a - 1$, $a$, and $a + 1$ has integer area?
solution: Note $s=\frac{3a}{2}$ so the area of the triangle is equal to $\sqrt{\frac{3a}{2}\left(\frac{3a}{2} (a 1)\right)\left(\frac{3a}{2} a\right)\left(\frac{3a}{2} (a+1)\right)} \rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{3a}{2}\left(\frac{a}{2}+1\right)\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)\left(\frac{a}{2} 1\right)} \rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{3a^2}{4}\left(\frac{a^2}{4} 1\right)} \rightarrow \frac{a}{2} \sqrt{\frac{3a^2}{4} 3}$ Let $a=2u$ The expression is equal to $u\sqrt{3u^2 3}$ The outside of the square root is always an integer so we want $3u^2 3$ to be a perfect square Since $a>14$ $u>7$ Note $3u^2 3=3(u 1)(u+1)$ so for this to be a perfect square either $u 1$ or $u+1$ is a multiple of three (since both cannot) If $u$ is odd then both of the unknown factors are even If $u$ is even the other two factors are odd and we know one of these is a multiple of three But we know $u>7$ so we test out possibilities and see if the result is a perfect square A lot of results can be eliminated since $u 1$ or $u+1$ can become a prime that is greater than $3$ which would make that value impossible So the next best value for $u$ cannot be within one of a multiple of $5$ $7$ or any other prime greater than $3$ (unless that factor is a perfect square) $u=8$ fails by checking $u=9 10 11 12 13 14 15 16$ fail because of an unnecessary prime factor $17$ fails by checking $u=18 19 20 21 22 23 24 25$ fail because of an unnecessary prime factor but $u=26$ works since we get $3(25)(27)=5^2 \cdot 3^4$ a perfect square Since $u=26$ $a=\boxed{52}$

title: BMT 2018 Spring - Geometry 10
text: A plane cuts a sphere of radius $ 1$ into two pieces, one of which has three times the surface area of the other. What is the area of the disk that the sphere cuts out of the plane?
solution: The plane is cut halfway between the tip of the sphere and the center of the sphere which splits the sphere's surface area into a $3 1$ ratio Therefore the radius of the disc is $\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+r^2=1^2 \rightarrow r^2=\frac{3}{4}$ so the area of the disc is $\pi r^2 = \boxed{\frac{3 \pi}{4}}$

solution: Note that $A_2=2$ and the final product telescopes to $\frac{2}{A_{k}}$ where $k \rightarrow \infty$ In fact this implies that the regular polygon becomes arbitrarily close to a circle which has area $\pi$ The answer is $\boxed{\frac{2}{\pi}}$

title: 2018 BMT Combinatorics #7
text: Let S be the set of line segments between any two vertices of a regular $21$-gon. If we select two distinct line segments from $S$ at random, what is the probability they intersect? Note that line segments are considered to intersect if they share a common vertex.

title: 2018 BMT Combinatorics #8
text: Moor and nine friends are seated around a circular table. Moor starts out holding a bottle, and whoever holds the bottle passes it to the person on his left or right with equal probability until everyone has held the bottle. Compute the expected distance between Moor and the last person to receive the bottle, where distance is the fewest number of times the bottle needs to be passed in order to go back to Moor.

title: 2018 BMT Combinatorics #9

We first randomly select a random positive integer $N$ where $N$ takes the value $n$ with probability $\frac{1}{2^n}$. We then take a $2 \times N$ grid and randomly color each cell black or white independently with equal probability. Compute the probability the resulting grid has a valid tiling.

title: Sprind Round (2012) #1
text: Let $ \{a_n\}_{n=1}^\infty $ be an arithmetic progression with $ a_1 > 0 $ and $ 5\cdot a_{13} = 6\cdot a_{19} $. What is the smallest integer $ n$ such that $ a_n<0 $?
solution:
mathisawesome wrote Let $ \{a_n\}_{n=1}^\infty $ be an arithmetic progression with $ a_1 > 0 $ and $ 5\cdot a_{13} = 6\cdot a_{19} $ What is the smallest integer $ n$ such that $ a_n<0 $ ? 
 Let $d$ be the common difference Then 
 
 $a_{13} = a_1 + 12d = \frac{6a_{19}}{5}$ 
 
 $a_{19} = a_1 + 18d$ 
 
 Substituting from the second equation into the first equation we get $a_1 + 12d = \frac{6 (a_1 + 18d)}{5} \rightarrow a_1 = 48d$ and therefore $a_1 + 48d = 0$ 
 
 But this is exactly equal to $a_{49}$ so we need to go one term further to $a_{50}$ to achieve a term less than 0 Thus $\boxed{n = 50}$

title: Spring Round (2012) #2
text: Find the smallest number with exactly 28 divisors.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text Let the prime factorization be $p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}p_3^{n_3}\cdots$ We know that $28=\prod_{i}(n_i+1)=2^2\cdot 7$ so distributing higher exponents to lowest primes gives $2^6\cdot 3\cdot 5 = \boxed{960}$

title: Sprind Round (2012) #3
text: Find the largest prime factor of \[ \frac{1}{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{2012}{n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)\dots(n+2012)}} \]
solution: Storage The answer is simply the largest prime factor less than $2012$ which is $\boxed{2011}$

title: Spring Round (2012) #4
text: Tyler rolls two $ 4025 $ sided fair dice with sides numbered $ 1, \dots, 4025 $. Given that the number on the ﬁrst die is greater than or equal to the number on the second die, what is the probability that the number on the ﬁrst die is less than or equal to $ 2012 $?
solution: Solution There are $1+2+\hdots+2012$ ways for the first die to be at most 2012 and $1+2+\hdots+4025$ total ways for the first die to be at least the second die Thus the answer is $\frac{1+2+\hdots+2012}{1+2+\hdots+4025}=\frac{2012(2013)}{4025(4026)}=\frac{1006}{4025}$

title: Spring Round (2012) #5
text: Let ${ a\uparrow\uparrow b = {{{{{a^{a}}^a}^{\dots}}}^{a}}^{a}} $, where there are $ b $ a's in total. That is $ a\uparrow\uparrow b $ is given by the recurrence \[ a\uparrow\uparrow b = \begin{cases} a & b=1\\ a^{a\uparrow\uparrow (b-1)} & b\ge2\end{cases} \] What is the remainder of $ 3\uparrow\uparrow( 3\uparrow\uparrow ( 3\uparrow\uparrow 3)) $ when divided by $ 60 $?
solution:
mathisawesome wrote Let ${ a\uparrow\uparrow b = {{{{{a^{a}}^a}^{\dots}}}^{a}}^{a}} $ where there are $ b $ a's in total That is $ a\uparrow\uparrow b $ is given by the recurrence \[ a\uparrow\uparrow b = \begin{cases} a & b=1\\ a^{a\uparrow\uparrow (b 1)} & b\ge2\end{cases} \] What is the remainder of $ 3\uparrow\uparrow( 3\uparrow\uparrow ( 3\uparrow\uparrow 3)) $ when divided by $ 60 $ ? 
 By checking modulo $20$ we get $ 3\uparrow\uparrow( 3\uparrow\uparrow ( 3\uparrow\uparrow 3)) \equiv 27\mod 60$

title: Spring Round (2012) #6
text: Let $ \text{ABCD} $ be a cyclic quadrilateral, with $ \text{AB} = 7 $, $ \text{BC} = 11 $, $ \text{CD} = 13 $, and $ \text{DA} = 17 $. Let the incircle of $ \text{ABD} $ hit $ \text{BD} $ at $ \text{R} $ and the incircle of $ \text{CBD} $ hit $ \text{BD} $ at $ \text{S} $. What is $ \text{RS} $?
solution:
Solution Let the incircle of ABD meet AB BD and AD at E R and G respectively Let the incircle of BCD meet BC CD and BD at F G and S respectively Then $AE=AF=x \implies FD=RD=17 x BE=BR=7 x$ 
 
 Similarly $CF=CG=y \implies DG=DS=13 y BF=BS=11 y$ 
 
 Note that $BS+DS=24 2y=BD=BR+RD=24 2x$ and so $x=y$ 
 
 Finally $RS=RD SD=(17 x) (13 y)=4 x+y=\boxed{4}$

title: Spring Round (2012) #7
text: Let $ a $, $ b $, $ c $, $ d $, $ (a + b + c + 18 + d) $, $ (a + b + c + 18 - d) $, $ (b + c) $, and $ (c + d) $ be distinct prime numbers such that $ a + b + c = 2010 $, $ a $, $ b $, $ c $, $ d \neq 3 $, and $ d \le 50 $. Find the maximum value of the diﬀerence between two of these prime numbers.
solution:
mathisawesome wrote Let $ a $ $ b $ $ c $ $ d $ $ (a + b + c + 18 + d) $ $ (a + b + c + 18 d) $ $ (b + c) $ and $ (c + d) $ be distinct prime numbers such that $ a + b + c = 2010 $ $ a $ $ b $ $ c $ $ d \neq 3 $ and $ d \le 50 $ Find the maximum value of the diﬀerence between two of these prime numbers From $\begin{cases} a+b+c+18+d=2028+d\in \mathbb{P} \\ a+b+c+18 d=2028 d\in \mathbb{P} \end{cases}$ <*> thus $d$ is odd $c+d$ is prime number greater than $2$ so $c+d$ is odd then $c$ is even prime number $c=2$ 
 $3$ or $7$ is not the last digit of $d$ if not $2028 d$ or $2028+d$ is multiple of $5$ and it is not prime Also $d\leq 50$ $d$ and $d+2$ are both prime thus $d\in {5 11 29 41}$ Check for <*> we get $d\in {11 41}$ or $d\leq 41$ 
 Among these number $ a $ $ b $ $ c $ $ d $ $ (a + b + c + 18 + d) $ $ (a + b + c + 18 d) $ $ (b + c) $ and $ (c + d) $ $(a+b+c+18+d)$ is the greatest $c=2$ is the smallest $(a+b+c+18+d) c=(2028+d) 2=2026+d\leq 2026+41=\boxed{2067}$

title: Spring Round (2012) #8
text: You are tossing an unbiased coin. The last $ 28 $ consecutive ﬂips have all resulted in heads. Let $ x $ be the expected number of additional tosses you must make before you get $ 60 $ consecutive heads. Find the sum of all distinct prime factors in $ x $.
solution:
Answer 65821 
 
 Solution Let $E_n$ be the expected number of flips to get 60 consecutive heads if you have already had $n$ consectuvive heads in the current run Here run means a series of uninterupted heads Then we have the following recurrence \[E_n = 1+\frac{1}{2}*(E_{n+1}+E_0)\] 
 What this is saying is that if you have $n$ consecutive heads then on your next flip you have an even chance of either getting heads and having $n+1$ consecuitve heads or getting tails and resetting back to zero Now we know that $E_{60}=0$ so then we have 
 \[E_{60 t}=\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^{t 1}{\frac{1}{2}^i}+E_0\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}{\frac{1}{2}^i}\] 
 Plugging in $t=60$ and solving for $E_0$ we get \[E_0=2*(2^{60} 1)\] 
 Now $28=60 32$ thus 
 \[E_{28}=E_{60 32}=\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^{31}{\frac{1}{2}^i}+2*(2^{60} 1)\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{32}{\frac{1}{2}^i}\] 
 Simplifying we get 
 \[E_{28}=2^{59}*(2^{32} 1)\] 
 So we have $2$ as a prime divisor so to get the remaining prime divisors we need to find the prime divisors of 
 $2^{32} 1$ 
 \[2^{32} 1=(2^{16}+1)(2^{8}+1)(2^{4} 1)(2^{4}+1)=65537*257*15*17\] 
 so from $15$ and $17$ we get $3 5 17$ as prime divisors Now we just need to find the prime divisors of $65537$ and $257$ 
 $17^2=289>257$ so any prime divisor of $257$ must be less than $17$ this leaves $2 3 5 7 11 13$ which can all be checked easily by hand to deterime that $257$ is prime As for $65537$ I had a hunch that it was prime but could not find a nice shortcut to prove it so I wound up doing the rather tedious task of testing all primes less than $\sqrt{65537}$ to determine that it is indeed prime Thus the solutions is $2+3+5+17+257+65537=65281$

title: (A(s)+A(t))/(A(a)+A(b)), areas of circles 2012 BMT Team 6
text: A circle with diameter $AB$ is drawn, and the point $ P$ is chosen on segment $AB$ so that $\frac{AP}{AB} =\frac{1}{42}$. Two new circles $a$ and $b$ are drawn with diameters $AP$ and $PB$ respectively. The perpendicular line to $AB$ passing through $ P$ intersects the circle twice at points $S$ and $T$. Two more circles $s$ and $t$ are drawn with diameters $SP$ and $ST$ respectively. For any circle $\omega$ let $A(\omega)$ denote the area of the circle. What is $\frac{A(s)+A(t)}{A(a)+A(b)}$?
solution:
$\triangle{ASB}$ is a right triangle because it is inscribed at the diameter Then $\triangle{APS}$ and $\triangle{BPS}$ are similar WLOG $AP = 1$ and $PB = 41$ 
 Using similar triangles we get that \[ \frac{AP}{SP} = \frac{SP}{PB} \implies SP = \sqrt{41} \] 
 $\triangle{ATB}$ is congruent to $\triangle{ASB}$ so $PT = \sqrt{41}$ and $ST = 2\sqrt{41}$ 
 All the areas are proportional to the diameters squared so the final ratio should be 
 \[ \frac{41 + (4)41}{1+41^2} = \boxed{\frac{205}{1681}}\]

title: 2012 BMT Team 8
text: Let $\phi$ be the Euler totient function. Let $\phi^k (n) = (\underbrace{\phi \circ... \circ \phi}_{k})(n)$ be $\phi$ composed with itself $k$ times. Define $\theta (n) = min \{k \in N | \phi^k (n)=1 \}$. For example, $\phi^1 (13) = \phi(13) = 12$ $\phi^2 (13) = \phi (\phi (13)) = 4$ $\phi^3 (13) = \phi(\phi(\phi(13))) = 2$ $\phi^4 (13) = \phi(\phi(\phi(\phi(13)))) = 1$ so $\theta (13) = 4$. Let $f(r) = \theta (13^r)$. Determine $f(2012)$.

title: 2012 BMT Team 9
text: A permutation of a set is a bijection from the set to itself. For example, if $\sigma$ is the permutation $1 7\mapsto 3$, $2 \mapsto 1$, and $3 \mapsto 2$, and we apply it to the ordered triplet $(1, 2, 3)$, we get the reordered triplet $(3, 1, 2)$. Let $\sigma$ be a permutation of the set $\{1,..., n\}$. Let $$\theta_k(m) = \begin{cases} m + 1 & \text{for} \,\, m < k\\ 1 & \text{for} \,\, m = k\\ m & \text{for} \,\, m > k\end{cases}$$Call a finite sequence $\{a_i\}^{j}_{i=1}$ a disentanglement of $\sigma$ if $\theta_{a_j} \circ...\circ \theta_{a_j} \circ \sigma$ is the identity permutation. For example, when $\sigma = (3, 2, 1)$, then $\{2, 3\}$ is a disentaglement of $\sigma$. Let $f(\sigma)$ denote the minimum number $k$ such that there is a disentanglement of $\sigma$ of length $k$. Let $g(n)$ be the expected value for $f(\sigma)$ if $\sigma$ is a random permutation of $\{1,..., n\}$. What is $g(6)$?

title: 2012 BMT Tournament Round 2 - Berkley Math Tournament
text: p1. $4$ balls are distributed uniformly at random among $6$ bins. What is the expected number of empty bins? p2. Compute ${150 \choose 20 }$ (mod $221$). p3. On the right triangle $ABC$, with right angle at$ B$, the altitude $BD$ is drawn. $E$ is drawn on $BC$ such that AE bisects angle $BAC$ and F is drawn on $AC$ such that $BF$ bisects angle $CBD$. Let the intersection of $AE$ and $BF$ be $G$. Given that $AB = 15$,$ BC = 20$, $AC = 25$, find $\frac{BG}{GF}$. p4. What is the largest integer $n$ so that $\frac{n^2-2012}{n+7}$ is also an integer? p5. What is the side length of the largest equilateral triangle that can be inscribed in a regular pentagon with side length $1$? p6. Inside a LilacBall, you can find one of $7$ different notes, each equally likely. Delcatty must collect all $7$ notes in order to restore harmony and save Kanto from eternal darkness. What is the expected number of LilacBalls she must open in order to do so? PS. You had better use hide for answers.
solution: We want the largest integer so that $(n^2 2012)/(n+7)$ is also an integer Using long division we obtain $$(n^2 2012)=(n+7)(n)+( 7n 2012)=(n+7)n+( 7n 49) 1963$$ Thus $\dfrac{n^2 2012}{n+7}$ is an integer iff $1963/(n+7)$ is also an integer The largest $n$ this happens for is $1963 7=1956$

text: p1. Denote $S_n = 1 + \frac12 + \frac13 +...+ \frac{1}{n}$. What is $144169\cdot S_{144169} - (S_1 + S_2 +... + S_{144168})$? p2. Let $A,B,C$ be three collinear points, with $AB = 4$, $BC = 8$, and $AC = 12$. Draw circles with diameters $AB$, $BC$, and $AC$. Find the radius of the two identical circles that will lie tangent to all three circles. p3. Let $s(i)$ denote the number of $1$’s in the binary representation of $i$. What is $$\sum_{x=1}{314}\left( \sum_{i=0}^{2^{576}-2} x^{s(i)} \right) \,\, mod \,\,629?$$ p4. Parallelogram $ABCD$ has an area of $S$. Let $k = 42$. $E$ is drawn on AB such that $AE =\frac{AB}{k}$. $F$ is drawn on $CD$ such that $CF = \frac{CD}{k}$. $G$ is drawn on $BC$ such that $BG = \frac{BC}{k}$. $H$ is drawn on $AD$ such that $DH = \frac{AD}{k}$. Line $CE$ intersects $BH$ at $M$, and $DG$ at $N$. Line $AF$ intersects $DG$ at $P$, and $BH$ at $Q$. If $S_1$ is the area of quadrilateral $MNPQ$, find $\frac{S_1}{S}$. p5. Let $\phi$ be the Euler totient function. What is the sum of all $n$ for which $\frac{n}{\phi(n)}$ is maximal for $1 \le n \le 500$? p6. Link starts at the top left corner of an $12 \times 12$ grid and wants to reach the bottom right corner. He can only move down or right. A turn is defined a down move immediately followed by a right move, or a right move immediately followed by a down move. Given that he makes exactly $6$ turns, in how many ways can he reach his destination? PS. You had better use hide for answers.

title: 2012 BMT Tournament Round 5 - Berkley Math Tournament
text: p1. Let $n$ be the number so that $1 - 2 + 3 - 4 +... - (n - 1) + n = 2012$. What is $4^{2012}$ (mod $n$)? p2. Consider three unit squares placed side by side. Label the top left vertex $P$ and the bottom four vertices $A,B,C,D$ respectively. Find $\angle PBA + \angle PCA + \angle PDA$. p3. Given $f(x) = \frac{3}{x-1}$, then express $\frac{9(x^2-2x+1)}{x^2-8x+16}$ entirely in terms of $f(x)$. In other words, $x$ should not be in your answer, only $f(x)$. p4. Right triangle with right angle $B$ and integer side lengths has $BD$ as the altitude. $E$ and $F$ are the incenters of triangles $ADB$ and $BDC$ respectively. Line $EF$ is extended and intersects $BC$ at $G$, and $AB$ at $H$. If $AB = 15$ and $BC = 8$, find the area of triangle $BGH$. p5. Let $a_1, a_2,..., a_n$ be a sequence of real numbers. Call a $k$-inversion $(0 < k\le n)$ of a sequence to be indices $i_1, i_2,.., i_k$ such that $i_1 < i_2 <.. < i_k$ but $a_{i1} > a_{i2} >...> a_{ik}$. Calculate the expected number of $6$-inversions in a random permutation of the set $\{1, 2,..., 10\}$. p6. Chell is given a strip of squares labeled $1,.., 6$ all placed side to side. For each $k \in {1,..., 6}$, she then chooses one square at random in $\{1,..., k\}$ and places a Weighted Storage Cube there. After she has placed all $6$ cubes, she computes her score as follows: For each square, she takes the number of cubes in the pile and then takes the square (i.e. if there were 3 cubes in a square, her score for that square would be $9$). Her overall score is the sum of the scores of each square. What is the expected value of her score? PS. You had better use hide for answers.

title: 2012 BMT Tournament Round, Championship Round  - Berkley Math Tournament
text: p1. If $n$ is a positive integer such that $2n+1 = 144169^2$, find two consecutive numbers whose squares add up to $n + 1$. p2. Katniss has an $n$-sided fair die which she rolls. If $n > 2$, she can either choose to let the value rolled be her score, or she can choose to roll a $n - 1$ sided fair die, continuing the process. What is the expected value of her score assuming Katniss starts with a $6$ sided die and plays to maximize this expected value? p3. Suppose that $f(x) = x^6 + ax^5 + bx^4 + cx^3 + dx^2 + ex + f$, and that $f(1) = f(2) = f(3) = f(4) = f(5) = f(6) = 7$. What is $a$? p4. $a$ and $b$ are positive integers so that $20a+12b$ and $20b-12a$ are both powers of $2$, but $a+b$ is not. Find the minimum possible value of $a + b$. p5. Square $ABCD$ and rhombus $CDEF$ share a side. If $m\angle DCF = 36^o$, find the measure of $\angle AEC$. p6. Tom challenges Harry to a game. Tom first blindfolds Harry and begins to set up the game. Tom places $4$ quarters on an index card, one on each corner of the card. It is Harry’s job to flip all the coins either face-up or face-down using the following rules: (a) Harry is allowed to flip as many coins as he wants during his turn. (b) A turn consists of Harry flipping as many coins as he wants (while blindfolded). When he is happy with what he has flipped, Harry will ask Tom whether or not he was successful in flipping all the coins face-up or face-down. If yes, then Harry wins. If no, then Tom will take the index card back, rotate the card however he wants, and return it back to Harry, thus starting Harry’s next turn. Note that Tom cannot touch the coins after he initially places them before starting the game. Assuming that Tom’s initial configuration of the coins weren’t all face-up or face-down, and assuming that Harry uses the most efficient algorithm, how many moves maximum will Harry need in order to win? Or will he never win? PS. You had better use hide for answers.
solution: s3 Let $g(x)=x^6 + ax^5 + bx^4 + cx^3 + dx^2 + ex + (f 7)$ so that $g(1) = g(2) = g(3) = g(4) = g(5) = g(6) = 0$ Therefore the roots of $g(x)$ are $1 2 3 4 5 6$ and by Vieta $a= 21$

title: 2012 BMT Tournament Round, Consolation Round - Berkley Math Tournament
text: p1. How many ways can we arrange the elements $\{1, 2,..., n\}$ to a sequence $a_1, a_2,..., a_n$ such that there is only exactly one $a_i$, $a_{i+1}$ such that $a_i > a_{i+1}$? p2. How many distinct (non-congruent) triangles are there with integer side-lengths and perimeter $2012$? p3. Let $\phi$ be the Euler totient function, and let $S = \{x| \frac{x}{\phi (x)} = 3\}$. What is $\sum_{x\in S} \frac{1}{x}$? p4. Denote $f(N)$ as the largest odd divisor of $N$. Compute $f(1) + f(2) + f(3) +... + f(29) + f(30)$. p5. Triangle $ABC$ has base $AC$ equal to $218$ and altitude $100$. Squares $s_1, s_2, s_3,...$ are drawn such that $s_1$ has a side on $AC$ and has one point each touching $AB$ and $BC$, and square $s_k$ has a side on square $s_{k-}1$ and also touches $AB$ and $BC$ exactly once each. What is the sum of the area of these squares? p6. Let $P$ be a parabola $6x^2 - 28x + 10$, and $F$ be the focus. A line $\ell$ passes through $F$ and intersects the parabola twice at points $P_1 = (2,-22)$, $P_2$. Tangents to the parabola with points at $P_1, P_2$ are then drawn, and intersect at a point $Q$. What is $m\angle P_1QP_2$? PS. You had better use hide for answers.
solution:
A4 (with sol) For all the odd numbers it's simply $N$ itself so we can first add up $1 3 5 7\dots 27 29$ which is sums to $225$ Next for the even numbers there are the numbers only divisible by 2 ( $2\cdot 1 2\cdot 3 2\cdot 5\dots 2\cdot 15$ ) and the numbers only divisible by 4 ( $4\cdot 1 4\cdot 3\dots 4\cdot 7$ ) and the numbers only divisible by 8 ( $8\cdot 1 8\cdot 3$ ) and lastly one number only divisible by 16 $16\cdot 1$ We take the odd numbers in these products $1 3 5 \dots 15$ and $1 3 5 7$ and $1 3$ and $1$ and add these together to get $64+16+4+1$ = $85$ Adding that with the original $225$ gets $\boxed{310}$ 
 Edit @below oh sorry my silly (and dumb) mistake you're right about the answer

title: 2024 HMNT General #1
text: Six consecutive positive integers are written on slips of paper. The slips are then handed out to Ethan, Jacob, and Karthik, such that each of them receives two slips. The product of Ethan's numbers is $20,$ and the product of Jacob's numbers is $24.$ Compute the product of Karthik's numbers.
solution: Notice that we must factor $20 = 4 \cdot 5$ because otherwise the difference between the two numbers is greater than 5 We also have that we must factor the $24$ as $3 \cdot 8$ This gives the numbers $3 4 5 6 7 8$ are the 6 consecutive numbers So the remaining numbers are $6 7$ which gives $6 \cdot 7 = 42$

text: Let $RANDOM$ be a regular hexagon with side length $1.$ Points $I$ and $T$ lie on segments $\overline{RA}$ and $\overline{DO},$ respectively, such that $MI=MT$ and $\angle{TMI}=90^\circ.$ Compute the area of triangle $MIT.$
solution: By symmetry we can notice that $IT$ is the height of the hexagon which is just $\sqrt{3}$ So $MI = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{2}}$ So the area is just $\frac{3}{4}$

title: 2024 HMNT General #4
text: Compute the number of ways to pick a three-element subset of $$\{10^1+1, 10^2+1, 10^3+1, 10^4+1, 10^5+1, 10^6+1, 10^7+1\}$$such that the product of the $3$ numbers in the subset has no digits besides $0$ and $1$ when written in base $10.$
solution: When we expand $(10^{a} + 1)(10^{b} + 1)(10^{c} + 1)$ for $1 < a < b < c \leq 7$ we see that the only way to get a digit that is not $0$ or $1$ is if $a + b = c$ So there are $35$ ways to choose $a b c$ and then there are $9$ ways to get values of $a b c$ such that $a + b = c$ by listing out all possibilities This gives the answer $35 9 = 26$

We only need to find when is $f(x)=4$ then sum up possible $3x+1 3x+2$

 Thus the desired value is then $3\cdot 4+6(4+5+7+8)=\boxed{156}$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #1
text: Compute the number of ways to fill each of the $12$ empty cells in the grid below with one of $T, A, L,$ or $C$ such that each of the four rows, columns, and bolded $2 \times 2$ square regions contains each letter exactly once.
solution: Note that there are $2^2=4$ choices of filling in the remaining squares in the top left and bottom right bolded $2 \times 2$ squares and two of them give a unique solution while the other two give no solution so the answer is $\boxed{2} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #2
text: Paul is in the desert and has a pile of gypsum crystals. No matter how he divides the pile into two nonempty piles, at least one of the resulting piles has a number of crystals that, when written in base $10,$ has a sum of digits at least $7.$ Given that Paul’s initial pile has at least two crystals, compute the smallest possible number of crystals in the initial pile.
solution: We are given that either $S(x)$ or $S(n x)$ is at least $7$ for all $1 \le x \le n 1$ for some positive integer $n $ where $S(\bullet)$ represents the sum of digits in base $10$ function It is well known that $S(m)+S(n) \ge S(m+n)$ for positive integers $m$ and $n $ Therefore in order to guarantee that at least one of $S(x)$ or $S(n x)$ is at least $7 $ we want to have $S(n)=13 $ (If $S(n) < 13 $ then it is not difficult to show that we can find an $x$ such that both $S(x)$ and $S(n x)$ are less than $7 $ ) The smallest such positive integer is $\boxed{49} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #3
text: Points $K,A,L,C,I,T,E$ are such that triangles $CAT$ and $ELK$ are equilateral, share a center $I,$ and points $E,L,K$ lie on sides $CA, AT, TC$ respectively. If the area of triangle $CAT$ is double the area of triangle $ELK$ and $CI = 2,$ compute the minimum possible value of $CK.$
solution:
Since $CI=2 $ we know that the height of $CAT$ is $3 $ so it's side length is $2\sqrt{3} $ Therefore the side length of $ELK$ is $$\frac{2\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{2}} = \sqrt{6} $$ Now let $CK=x $ It follows that $CE=2\sqrt{3} x $ Applying the Law of Cosines in $\triangle{CEK}$ gives 
 \begin{align*}
EK^2 = CE^2 + CK^2 2 \cdot CE \cdot CK \cdot \cos(\angle{C}) &\implies (\sqrt{6})^2 = (2\sqrt{3} x)^2+x^2 2 \cdot (2\sqrt{3} x) \cdot x \cdot \cos(60^\circ) \\
&\implies 6 = 12 4\sqrt{3}x + x^2 + x^2 2 \cdot (2\sqrt{3}x x^2) \cdot \frac{1}{2} \\
&\implies 2x^2 4\sqrt{3}x+6 = 2\sqrt{3}x x^2 \\
&\implies 3x^2 6\sqrt{3}x+6 = 0 \\
&\implies x^2 2\sqrt{3}x = 2 = 0 \\
&\implies x = \sqrt{3} \pm 1 \end{align*} Hence the minimum possible value of $CK$ is $\boxed{\sqrt{3} 1} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #4
text: Compute $$\sum_{i=1}^{4} \sum_{t=1}^{4} \sum_{e=1}^{4} \left\lfloor \frac{ite}{5} \right\rfloor.$$
solution: Notice the numbers $it 2 \cdot it 3 \cdot it 4 \cdot it$ modulo 5 form a permutation of 1 2 3 4 So we simplify the sum to $$\sum_{i = 1}^{4} \sum_{t = 1}^{4} \frac{it + 2it + 3it + 4it 10}{5} = \sum_{i = 1}^{4} \sum_{t = 1}^{4} 2it 2 = 2 \cdot (1 + 2 + 3 + 4)^2 2 \cdot 4^2 = 168$$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #5
text: Alf, the alien from the $1980$s TV show, has a big appetite for the mineral apatite. However, he’s currently on a diet, so for each integer $k \ge 1,$ he can eat exactly $k$ pieces of apatite on day $k.$ Additionally, if he eats apatite on day $k,$ he cannot eat on any of days $k + 1, k + 2, \ldots, 2k - 1.$ Compute the maximum total number of pieces of apatite Alf could eat over days $1,2, \ldots,99,100.$
solution: We notice that if he eats on day $k$ then he cannot eat on days $\lfloor \frac{k}{2} \rfloor + 1$ to $k 1$ So we can see it is optimal to eat on days 100 50 25 12 6 3 1 Adding these gives the answer 197

Jasper and Rose take turns making one of the following two moves: remove a positive integer number of ounces (possibly all) from the leftmost nonempty jug, or remove an equal positive integer number of ounces from the two leftmost nonempty jugs, possibly emptying them. Neither player may remove more ounces from a jug than it currently contains. Jasper plays first. A player’s score is the number of ounces they take from Quart $\text{Z}.$ If both players play to maximize their score, compute the maximum score that Jasper can guarantee.

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #8
text: For all positive integers $r$ and $s,$ let $\text{Top}(r,s)$ denote the top number (i.e., numerator) when $r$ $s$ is written in simplified form. For instance, $\text{Top}(20,24) = 5.$ Compute the number of ordered pairs of positive integers $(a,z)$ such that $200 \le a \le 300$ and $\text{Top}(a,z) = \text{Top}(z,a-1).$

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #9
text: Compute the number of ways to color each cell of an $18 \times 18$ square grid either ruby or sapphire such that each contiguous $3 \times 3$ subgrid has exactly $1$ ruby cell.

title: 2024 HMNT Theme #10
text: Isabella the geologist discovers a diamond deep underground via an X-ray machine. The diamond has the shape of a convex cyclic pentagon $PABCD$ with $AD|| BC$. Soon after the discovery, her X-ray breaks, and she only recovers partial information about its dimensions. She knows that $AD = 70, BC = 55, PA: PD = 3: 4$, and $PB: PC = 5: 6$. Compute $PB$.
solution:
Let $BD=AC=d AB=CD=x AP=3k DP=4k BP=5m CP=6m$ 
 
 By Ptolemy in $ABCD 55\cdot 70+x^2=d^2$ 
 
 By Ptolemy in $ABCP 6mx+165k=5md$ 
 
 By Ptolemy in $CDPB 5mx+220k=6md$ 
 
 For second and third equation time four and three respectively and subtract we could attain $9mx=2md 9x=2d$ 
 
 Let $x=2a d=9a d^2 x^2=77a^2=55\cdot 70 a=5\sqrt{2} BD=AC=45\sqrt{2} AB=CD=10\sqrt{2}$ plug such value to equation 2 we have $165k+60\sqrt{2}m=225\sqrt{2}m k=\sqrt{2}m$ 
 
 By Law of Cosines in $\triangle{APB} \triangle{CPD} \frac{9k^2+25m^2 200}{30mk}=\frac{16k^2+36m^2 200}{48mk}$ substitute $k=\sqrt{2}m m^2=150 BP=5m=\boxed{25\sqrt{6}}$

The divided rectangles are then colored black and white such that the bottom left corner of the grid is black, and no two rectangles adjacent by an edge share a color. text: Let $P$ be a point inside isosceles trapezoid $ABCD$ with $AB \parallel CD$ such that $$\angle{PAD}=\angle{PDA}=90^\circ-\angle{BPC}.$$If $PA=14, AB=18,$ and $CD=28,$ compute the area of $ABCD.$
solution: Let $P'$ be the reflection of $P$ over the perpendicular bisector of $AB$ Then we have $\angle AP'D=90 \angle BPC$ which is half of $\angle APD$ combined with $AP=DP$ we have $P'$ is on the circle centered at $P$ passing through $A$ and $D$ implying $PP'=14$ Now some simple pythag gives the desired answer as $345\sqrt{3}$

solution: First note that all of these lines passes through the point $( 1 1) $ Thus if we draw the lines in one by one each added line will add $2$ to the total number of regions that the plane is divided into Hence the answer is $6 \cdot 2 = \boxed{12} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #6
text: The vertices of a cube are labeled with the integers $1$ through $8,$ with each used exactly once. Let $s$ be the maximum sum of the labels of two edge-adjacent vertices. Compute the minimum possible value of $s$ over all such labelings.
solution: Since each vertex is adjacent to three other vertices it follows that at least one of the numbers adjacent to $8$ must be greater than or equal to $3 $ Therefore the minimum possible $s$ is at least $11 $ This is achievable by having the faces have the quadruples of numbers $(1 6 3 8) $ $(1 6 4 7) $ $(7 4 5 2) (2 5 3 8) (1 7 2 8) $ and $(6 4 5 3)$ on the six faces so the answer is indeed $\boxed{11} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #8
text: Derek is bored in math class and is drawing a flower. He first draws $8$ points $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_8$ equally spaced around an enormous circle. title: 2024 HMNT Guts #9
text: Compute the remainder when $$1002003004005006007008009$$is divided by $13.$
solution: Note that $1001 = 7 \times 11 \times 13$ and $1000 \equiv 1 \pmod{1001}$ It follows that the answer is $9 8+7 6+5 4+3 2+1=\boxed{5}$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #11
text: A four-digit integer in base $10$ is friendly if its digits are four consecutive digits in any order. A four-digit integer is shy if there exist two adjacent digits in its representation that differ by $1.$ Compute the number of four-digit integers that are both friendly and shy.
solution:
If we have four consecutive digits $A<B<C<D $ it is not difficult to see that the only permutations of those digits that do not have any consecutive digits next to each other are the permutations $BDAC$ and $CADB $ Therefore if $(A B C D)=(0 1 2 3) $ then there are $18 2=16$ shy permutations and if $(A B C D)$ is any of the quadruples $(1 2 3 4) \ldots (6 7 8 9) $ then there are $24 2=22$ shy permutations for a total of 
 \begin{align*}
16 + 6 \cdot 22 &= 16 + 132 \\
&= \boxed{148} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #12

solution: If we place face $\mathcal{P}$ at the top such that face $1$ is the face directly facing us then the bottom left face that we can see is $11 $ so the bottom face would be $\boxed{5} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #13
text: Let $f$ and $g$ be two quadratic polynomials with real coefficients such that the equation $f(g(x)) = 0$ has four distinct real solutions: $112, 131, 146,$ and $a.$ Compute the sum of all possible values of $a.$
solution:
Let the roots of $f$ be $r$ and $s $ Then it follows that the equation $f(g(x))=0$ can be rephrased as $g(x)=r$ or $g(x)=s $ These can be rearranged to $g(x) r=0$ and $g(x) s=0 $ so it is evident by Vieta that both of these equations will have an equal sum of roots Therefore the numbers $112 131 146 $ and $a$ must be able to be separated into two pairs such that the sum of the numbers in each pair is equal Taking cases on which number $a$ is paired with we get a $131+146 112 112+146 131 $ and $112+131 146 $ for a sum of 
 \begin{align*}
(131+146 112)+(112+146 131)+(112+131 146) &= 2\cdot(112+131+146) (112+131+146) \\
&= 112+131+146 \\
&= \boxed{390} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #14

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #15
text: Compute the sum of the three smallest positive integers $n$ for which $$\frac{1+2+3+\cdots+(2024n-1)+2024n}{1+2+3+\cdots+(4n-1)+4n}$$is an integer.
solution:
Firstly we have 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{1+2+3+\cdots+(2024n 1)+2024n}{1+2+3+\cdots+(4n 1)+4n} &= \frac{\tfrac{2024n(2024n+1)}{2}}{\tfrac{4n(4n+1)}{2}} \\
&= \frac{506(2024n+1)}{4n+1} \\
&= 506^2 \frac{506^2 506}{4n+1} \\
&= 506^2 \frac{505 \cdot 506}{4n+1} \\
&= 506^2 \frac{2 \cdot 5 \cdot 11 \cdot 23 \cdot 101}{4n+1} \end{align*} Now noting that $5 11 23 $ and $101$ are congruent to $1 3 3 $ and $1$ modulo $4 $ respectively it is not difficult to find that the $3$ smallest positive divisors of $505 \cdot 506$ that are congruent to $1$ modulo $4$ are $5 101 $ and $253 $ These correspond to $n=1 25 $ and $63 $ so the answer is $1+25+63=\boxed{89} $ $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #17
text: Compute the number of ways to shade in some subset of the $16$ cells in a $4 \times 4$ grid such that each of the $25$ vertices of the grid is a corner of at least one shaded cell.
solution:
Firstly since the corner vertices must be a corner of at least one shaded cell all four of the corner cells of the $4 \times 4$ grid must be shaded in Then it is not difficult to see that we must simply have at least one cell shaded in all four of the $1 \times 2$ "edges" and at least one cell shaded in the center $2 \times 2$ square yielding an answer of 
 \begin{align*}
(2^2 1)^4 \cdot (2^4 1) &= (4 1)^4 \cdot (16 1) \\
&= 3^4 \cdot 15 \\
&= 81 \cdot 15 \\
&= \boxed{1215} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #21
text: Two points are chosen independently and uniformly at random from the interior of the $X$-pentomino shown below. Compute the probability that the line segment between these two points lies entirely within the $X$-pentomino.
solution:
Note that there is a $\tfrac{8}{25}$ chance that the two points are in adjacent outer squares of the $X$ pentamino and then in that case the probability that the line segment between them lies entirely within the $X$ pentomino is $\tfrac{1}{2}$ by symmetry Hence the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{17}{25} + \frac{8}{25} \cdot \frac{1}{2} &= \frac{17}{25} + \frac{4}{25} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{21}{25}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2024 HMNT Guts #24
text: Let $f(x) = x^2 +6x+6.$ Compute the greatest real number $x$ such that $f(f(f(f(f(f(x)))))) = 0.$
solution:
f(x) = x² + 6x + 6 = (x + 3)² 3 
 
 f(x) + 3 = (x + 3)² 
 
 f²(x) + 3 = [f(x) + 3]² = (x + 3)⁴ 
 
 Then f⁶(x) = (x + 3)⁶⁴ 3 
 
 Now (x + 3)⁶⁴ 3 = 0 
 
 x + 3 = ± 3^1/64 
 
 x = 3^1/64 3 or 3^1/64 3 
 
 Therefore greatest real number x such that f⁶(x) = 0 is 3^1/64 3

solution:
Construct right triangles $ACP$ and $ABQ$ such that $\angle{ABQ}=\angle{ACP}=90^{\circ}$ 
 
 By congruent triangles we could have $QC=AD AE=BP AD^2+AE^2=CQ^2+BP^2 BP^2=3^2+(4\sqrt{2})^2+2\cdot 3\cdot 4\sqrt{2}\cdot \frac{1}{2}=41+12\sqrt{2}$ and $BQ^2=4^2+18+12\sqrt{2}=34+12\sqrt{2}$ sum up to $75+24\sqrt{2}$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November Team #7 |AE - FD|, incircle of equilateral
text: In equilateral triangle $ABC$, a circle $\omega$ is drawn such that it is tangent to all three sides of the triangle. A line is drawn from $A$ to point $D$ on segment $BC$ such that $AD$ intersects $\omega$ at points $E$ and $F$. If $EF = 4$ and $AB = 8$, determine $|AE - FD|$.
solution:
Given the equilateral $\triangle ABC\ \ A(0 4\sqrt{3}) B( 4 0) C(4 0)$ choose $D(\lambda 0)$ 
 
 The incircle $x^{2}+y^{2} \frac{8\sqrt{3}}{3}y=0$ intersects the line $AD\ \ y= \frac{4\sqrt{3}}{\lambda}(x+\lambda)$ 
 (using the condition $EF=4$ ) in the points $E(\frac{\sqrt{5} 1}{2} \frac{3\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{15}}{2})$ and $F(\frac{\sqrt{5}+1}{2} \frac{3\sqrt{3} \sqrt{15}}{2})$ 
 
 Then $AE=2\sqrt{5} 2$ and $FD=\frac{6\sqrt{5}}{5} 2$

solution: Clearly the number must be of one of the forms $pqrt pqr^2 $ or $p^3q $ where $p q r $ and $t$ are distinct primes The smallest numbers of these forms are $210 60 $ and $24 $ respectively so the answer is $\boxed{24} $ $\square$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November General #3
text: A $24$-hour digital clock shows times $h: m: s$, where $h$, $m$, and $s$ are integers with $0 \le h \le 23$, $0 \le m \le 59$, and $0 \le s \le 59$. How many times $h: m: s$ satisfy $h + m = s$?
solution:
Note that if $0 \le s \le 22 $ then there are $s+1$ pairs $(h m)$ such that $0 \le h \le 23 0 \le m \le 59 $ and $h+m=s$ and if $23 \le s \le 59 $ then there are $24$ such pairs $(h m) $ so the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
1 + 2 + \ldots + 23 + 24 \cdot 38 &= 12 \cdot 23 + 24\cdot37 \\
&= 12\cdot23+12\cdot74 \\
&= 12\cdot97 \\
&= \boxed{1164} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November General #4
text: A $50$-card deck consists of $4$ cards labeled " i" for $i = 1, 2,..., 12$ and $2$ cards labeled "$13$". If Bob randomly chooses $2$ cards from the deck without replacement, what is the probability that his $2$ cards have the same label?
solution:
The desired probability is simply 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{12\cdot\binom{4}{2} + 1 \cdot \binom{2}{2}}{\binom{50}{2}} &= \frac{12\cdot6+1\cdot1}{25\cdot49} \\
&= \frac{72+1}{1225} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{73}{1225}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November General #6
text: Find the number of positive integer divisors of $12! $ that leave a remainder of $1$ when divided by $3$.
solution:
First note that the prime factorization of $12!$ is $$12! = 2^{10} \cdot 3^5 \cdot 5^2 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 $$ Clearly we can disregard the powers of $3 $ and we can also temporarily disregard the $7 $ as it is congruent to $1$ modulo $3 $ by just multiplying by $2$ in the end Hence we wish to find the number of positive integer divisors of $2^{10} \cdot 5^2 \cdot 11$ that are congruent to $1$ modulo $3 $ 
 
 If we let an arbitrary divisor be $2^a \cdot 3^b \cdot 11^c $ this divisor being congruent to $1$ modulo $3$ is equivalent to $a+b+c$ being even since $2 5 $ and $11$ are all congruent to $ 1$ modulo $3 $ However note that $c$ can be either $0$ or $1 $ so it follows that no matter what values of $a$ and $b$ we choose we can always choose a $c$ that makes $a+b+c$ even Therefore the number of positive divisors of $2^{10} \cdot 5^2 \cdot 11$ that are congruent to $1$ modulo $3$ is $$3 \cdot 11 = 33 $$ It follows that the final answer is $$33 \cdot 2 = \boxed{66} $$ $\square$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November General #8
text: How many of the first $1000$ positive integers can be written as the sum of finitely many distinct numbers from the sequence $3^0$, $3^1$, $3^2$,$...$?
solution: It is not difficult to see that the positive integers that can be written as the sum of finitely many distinct numbers from the sequence $3^0 3^1 3^2 \ldots$ is precisely the set of positive integer whose base $3$ representation contains only $0$ s and $1$ s Note that $$1000 = 1101001_3 $$ so the answer is $$1101001_2 = \boxed{105} $$ $\square$

title: 2013 HMNT - HMMT November Theme #  1
text: Two cars are driving directly towards each other such that one is twice as fast as the other. The distance between their starting points is $4$ miles. When the two cars meet, how many miles is the faster car from its starting point?
solution: Since the faster car has a speed that it two times that of the slower car it follows that the distance from the starting point of the faster car to the meeting point is two times the distance from the starting point of the slower car to the meeting point Hence the answer is $$\frac{2}{3} \cdot 4 = \boxed{\frac{8}{3}} $$ $\square$
