title: 2017 PUMaC Team 1
text: Call an ordered triple $(a, b, c)$ of integers feral if $b -a, c - a$ and $c - b$ are all prime. Find the number of feral triples where $1 \le a < b < c \le 20$.
solution:
Noticing that $ c a=(c b)+(b a) $ deduce that $ c a $ and $ c a 2 $ are twin primes which implies 
 $$ (b a c b)\in\{ (2 3) (3 2) (2 5) (5 2) (2 11) (11 2) (2 17) (17 2) \} $$ and along with $ c\le 20 $ this implies that there are by symmetry in the above set $ 2\cdot (20 (b a) (c b)) =2\cdot (20 (c a)) $ triplets $ (a b c) $ with fixed $ b a $ and $ c b $ So the total number of feral triples $ (a b c) $ is $$ 2\cdot\sum_{p\in\{5 7 13 19\}} (20 p) =72 $$

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 2
text: Let $a\%b$ denote the remainder when $a$ is divided by $b$. Find $\Sigma_{i=1}^{100}(100\%i)$.
solution: $$ \sum_{i=1}^{100} 100\%i =\sum_{i=1}^{100} \left( 100 i\cdot\left\lfloor \frac{100}{i} \right\rfloor \right) =10000 \sum_{i=1}^{100}\sum_{j=1+\lfloor 100/(1+i) \rfloor}^{\lfloor 100/i \rfloor} ij= $$ $$ =10000 \left( \sum_{\stackrel{1\le i\le 10}{i|100}} \sum_{j=1+\lfloor 100/(1+i) \rfloor}^{\lfloor 100/i \rfloor} ij +\sum_{\stackrel{1\le i\le 10}{i \not |100}} \sum_{j=1+\lfloor 100/(1+i) \rfloor}^{\lfloor 100/i \rfloor} ij +\sum_{10<i\le 100}\sum_{j=1+\lfloor 100/(1+i) \rfloor}^{\lfloor 100/i \rfloor} ij \right) = $$ $$ =10000 (5\cdot 100+3\cdot 33 +6\cdot 16 +7\cdot 14 +8\cdot 12 +9\cdot 11 +11\cdot 9 +12\cdot 8+ $$ $$ +(13+14)\cdot 7 +(15+16)\cdot 6 +(17+18+19+20)\cdot 5 + (21+22+23+24+25)\cdot 4 + $$ $$ +(26+27+\cdots +33)\cdot 3+ (34+35+\cdots +50)\cdot 2+(51+52+\cdots +100)\cdot 1) = $$ $$ =3187 $$

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 3
text: Let $f(x) = (x - 5)(x - 12)$ and $g(x) = (x - 6)(x - 10)$. Find the sum of all integers $n$ such that $\frac{f(g(n))}{f(n)^2}$ is defined and an integer.
solution:
Noticing that any two consecutive numbers are coprime and that $ \frac{f(g(n))}{(g(n))^2} =\frac{(n 4)(n 11)}{(n 5)(n 12)} $ we get that $ \frac{n 11}{n 5} \frac{n 4}{n 12}\in\mathbb{Z} $ 
 Observe that 
 $$ n=5 \frac{6}{ 1+(n 11)/(n 5)} =12+\frac{8}{1+(n 4)/(n 12)} $$ to deduce that 
 $$ \left( \frac{n 4}{n 12} 1 \right)\left( 5\frac{n 11}{n 5} 11 \right) =\left( \frac{n 11}{n 5} 1 \right)\left( 12\frac{n 4}{n 12} 4 \right) $$ and that 
 $$ |1 (n 11)/(n 5)|\le 6 |1+(n 4)/(n 12)|\le 8 $$ Now according to this we have 
 $$ \left( \frac{n 11}{n 5} \frac{n 4}{n 12} \right)\in\{( 1 1) (0 7) (1 1) (7 0)\} $$ which implies that $ n\in\{ 4 8 11 \} $ 
 So the final answer is $ 23 $

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 4
text: Ayase chooses three numbers $a, b, c$ independently and uniformly from the interval $[-1, 1]$. The probability that $0 < a + b < a < a + b + c$ can be expressed in the form $\frac{p}{q}$, where $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime positive integers. What is $p + q$?

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 5
text: Define the sequences $a_n$ and $b_n$ as follows: $a_1 = 2017$ and $b_1 = 1$. For $n > 1$, if there is a greatest integer $k > 1$ such that $a_n$ is a perfect $k$th power, then $a_{n+1} =\sqrt[k]{a_n}$, otherwise $a_{n+1} = a_n + b_n$. If $a_{n+1} \ge a_n$ then $b_{n+1} = b_n$, otherwise $b_{n+1} = b_n + 1$. Find $a_{2017}$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 6
text: In regular pentagon $ABCDE$, let $O \in CE$ be the center of circle $\Gamma$ tangent to $DA$ and $DE$. $\Gamma$ meets $DE$ at $X$ and $DA$ at $Y$. Let the altitude from $B$ meet $CD$ at $P$. If $CP = 1$, the area of $\vartriangle COY$ can be written in the form $\frac{a}{b} \frac{\sin c^o}{\cos^2 c^o}$, where $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime positive integers and $c$ is an integer in the range $(0, 90)$. Find $a + b + c$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 7
text: $2017$ voters vote by submitting a ranking of the integers $\{1, 2,..., 38\}$ from favorite (a vote for that value in $1$st place) to least favorite (a vote for that value in $38$th/last place). Let $a_k$ be the integer that received the most $k$th place votes (the smallest such integer if there is a tie). Find the maximum possible value of $\Sigma_{k=1}^{38} a_k$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 8
text: Tristan is eating his favorite cereal, Tiger Crunch, which has marshmallows of two colors, black and orange. He eats the marshmallows by randomly choosing from those remaining one at a time, and he starts out with $17$ orange and $5$ black marshmallows. If $\frac{p}{q}$ is the expected number of marshmallows remaining the instant that there is only one color left, and $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime positive integers, find $p + q$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 9
text: The set $\{(x, y) \in R^2| \lfloor x + y\rfloor \cdot \lceil x + y\rceil = (\lfloor x\rfloor + \lceil y \rceil ) (\lceil x \rceil + \lfloor y\rfloor), 0 \le x, y \le 100\}$ can be thought of as a collection of line segments in the plane. If the total length of those line segments is $a + b\sqrt{c}$ for $c$ squarefree, find $a + b + c$. ($\lfloor z\rfloor$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to $z$, and $\lceil z \rceil$ is the least integer greater than or equal to $z$, for $z \in R$.)

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 10
text: Given a positive integer $x \le 233$, let $a$ be the remainder when $x^{1943}$ is divided by $233$. Find the sum of all possible values of $a$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 11
text: For a sequence of $10$ coin flips, each pair of consecutive flips and count the number of “Heads-Heads”, “Heads-Tails”, “Tails-Heads”, and “Tails-Tails” sequences is recorded. These four numbers are then multiplied to get the Tiger number of the sequence of flips. How many such sequences have a Tiger number of $24$?

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 12
text: Call a positive integer $n$ tubular if for any two distinct primes $p$ and $q$ dividing $n, (p + q) | n$. Find the number of tubular numbers less than $100,000$. (Integer powers of primes, including $1, 3$, and $16$, are not considered tubular.)

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 13
text: A point-sized cue ball is fired in a straight path from the center of a regular hexagonal billiards table of side length $1$. If it is not launched directly into a pocket but travels an integer distance before falling into one of the pockets (located in the corners), find the minimum distance that it could have traveled.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 14
text: Eric rolls a ten-sided die (with sides labeled $1$ through $10$) repeatedly until it lands on $3, 5$, or $7$. Conditional on all of Eric’s rolls being odd, the expected number of rolls can be expressed as $\frac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Compute $m + n$.
solution: Note that the expected value is $$\displaystyle \frac{\sum_{n=1}^\infty n \cdot \left(\frac{2}{10}\right)^{n 1} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)}{\sum_{n=0}^\infty \left(\frac{2}{10}\right)^{n 1} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)} $$ This holds as the sum of the probabilities of Eric rolling a 3 5 or 7 after a string of only odd numbers is $\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty n \cdot \left(\frac{2}{10}\right)^{n 1} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)$ however the probability that Eric rolls a 3 5 or 7 before rolling an even number is $\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^\infty \left(\frac{2}{10}\right)^{n 1} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)$ so we divide one by the other to account for the cases where Eric rolled an even number before a 3 5 or 7 Note that $$ \displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty n \cdot \left(\frac{2}{10}\right)^{n 1} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{10}\right) = \frac{3}{2} \cdot \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n}{5^n} = \frac{3}{2} \cdot S$$ for a sum $S$ We have $$S/5 + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{5^{n+1}} = S \frac{1}{5} \implies S = \frac{5}{16} $$ Thus the answer is $$\displaystyle \frac{\frac{5}{16} \cdot \frac{3}{2}}{\frac{3}{8}} = \frac{5}{4}$$ giving an answer os $\boxed{9}$

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 15
text: How many ordered pairs of positive integers $(x, y)$ satisfy $yx^y = y^{2017}$?
solution: Very casey problem The fact that $ y $ cannot contain prime factors in its prime decomposition other than $ 2 3 7 $ results from the fact that $ 2016=2^53^27 $ and that a product of primes cannot be less than the successor of a power of one of them (due to a much weaker version of the inequality $ 2^n\ge 1+n $ )

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 16
text: Robert is a robot who can move freely on the unit circle and its interior, but is attached to the origin by a retractable cord such that at any moment the cord lies in a straight line on the ground connecting Robert to the origin. Whenever his movement is counterclockwise (relative to the origin), the cord leaves a coating of black paint on the ground, and whenever his movement is clockwise, the cord leaves a coating of orange paint on the ground. The paint is dispensed regardless of whether there is already paint on the ground. The paints covers $1$ gallon/unit $^2$, and Robert starts at $(1, 0)$. Each second, he moves in a straight line from the point $(\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta))$ to the point $(\cos(\theta+a),\sin(\theta+a))$, where a changes after each movement. a starts out as $253^o$ and decreases by $2^o$ each step. If he takes $89$ steps, then the difference, in gallons, between the amount of black paint used and orange paint used can be written as $\frac{\sqrt{a}- \sqrt{b}}{c} \cot 1^o$, where $a, b$ and $c$ are positive integers and no prime divisor of $c$ divides both $a$ and $b$ twice. Find $a + b + c$.

title: 2017 PUMaC Team 17
text: Zack keeps cutting the interval $[0, 1]$ of the number line, each time cutting at a uniformly random point in the interval, until the interval is cut into pieces, none of which have length greater than $\frac35$. The expected number of cuts that Zack makes can be written as $\frac{p}{q}$ for $p$ and $q$ relatively prime positive integers. Find $p + q$.

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A1/B3
text: For her daughter’s $12\text{th}$ birthday, Ingrid decides to bake a dodecagon pie in celebration. Unfortunately, the store does not sell dodecagon shaped pie pans, so Ingrid bakes a circular pie first and then trims off the sides in a way such that she gets the largest regular dodecagon possible. If the original pie was $8$ inches in diameter, the area of pie that she has to trim off can be represented in square inches as $a\pi - b$ where $a, b$ are integers. What is $a + b$?
solution:
The radius is $4$ 
 The area of the dodecagon is $3\cdot4^2=48$ 
 The area of the circle is $16\pi$ 
 The answer is $16+48=\boxed{64}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A2/B4
text: Terry the Tiger lives on a cube-shaped world with edge length $2$. Thus he walks on the outer surface. He is tied, with a leash of length $2$, to a post located at the center of one of the faces of the cube. The surface area of the region that Terry can roam on the cube can be represented as $\frac{p \pi}{q} + a\sqrt{b}+c$ for integers $a, b, c, p, q$ where no integer square greater than $1$ divides $b, p$ and $q$ are coprime, and $q > 0$. What is $p + q + a + b + c$? (Terry can be at a location if the shortest distance along the surface of the cube between that point and the post is less than or equal to $2$.)
solution:
draw the cube's net 
 
 We want to find the area of the intersection of the net and the circle This is $\frac{8}3 \pi+4\sqrt{3} 4$ 
 Our answer is $14$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A3/B5
text: Cyclic quadrilateral $ABCD$ satisfies $\angle ADC = 2 \cdot \angle BAD = 80^\circ$ and $\overline{BC} = \overline{CD}$. Let the angle bisector of $\angle BCD$ meet $AD$ at $P$. What is the measure, in degrees, of $\angle BP D$?
solution: Since $ABCD$ is cyclic we know that $\angle C = 140^\circ$ and $\angle B = 100^\circ$ Since $CP$ bisects $\angle C$ we have $\angle DCP = 70^\circ$ so $\angle CPD = 180^\circ 70^\circ 80^\circ = 30^\circ$ Since $BC = CD$ by $SAS$ we have $\triangle BCP \cong \triangle DCP$ Therefore $\angle BPD = 2 \cdot \angle CPD = 2 \cdot 30^\circ = \boxed{60^\circ}$

In a packing, each ball lies outside every other ball, and every ball lies inside the boundaries of the tetrahedron. If $r$ can be expressed in the form $\frac{\sqrt{a}+b}{c}$ where $a, b, c$ are integers such that $\gcd(b, c) = 1$, what is $a + b + c$?
solution: is it 46???

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A5/B7
text: Let $P, A, B, C$ be points on circle $O$ such that $C$ does not lie on arc $\widehat{BAP}$, $\overline{P A} = 21, \overline{P B} = 56, \overline{P C} = 35$ and $m \angle BP C = 60^\circ$. Now choose point $D$ on the circle such that $C$ does not lie on arc $\widehat{BDP}$ and $\overline{BD} = 39$. What is $AD$?
solution: By law of cosines on $\triangle BPC$ we have $BC^2 = 56^2+35^2 56 \cdot 35$ so $BC = 49$ Then by ptolemy's theorem on $ABCP$ we have $35 \cdot AB+21 \cdot 49 = 56 \cdot AC$ Rearranging we obtain $8 \cdot AC 5 \cdot AB = 3 \cdot 49$ Now notice that $\angle BAC = \angle BPC = 60^\circ$ Then by law of cosines on $\triangle BAC$ we have $49^2 = AB^2 + AC^2 AB \cdot AC$ Since $8 \cdot AC 5 \cdot AB = 3 \cdot 49$ we quickly see that $AC=AB=49$ satisfies this system Therefore $\triangle ABC$ is in fact equilateral so $\angle ADB = 180^\circ \angle BCA = 120^\circ$ Then by law of cosines on $\triangle ADB$ we have $49^2 = 39^2 + AD^2 +39 \cdot AD$ so $AD = \boxed{16}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A6/B8
text: Triangle $ABC$ is inscribed in a unit circle $\omega$. Let $H$ be its orthocenter and $D$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$. Let $\triangle XY Z$ be the triangle formed by drawing the tangents to $\omega$ at $A, B, C$. If $\overline{AH} = \overline{HD}$ and the side lengths of $\triangle XY Z$ form an arithmetic sequence, the area of $\triangle ABC$ can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$. What is $p + q$?
solution: First note that $\triangle ABC$ is the contact triangle of $\triangle XYZ$ We will attack the orthocenter condition first let the height from $A$ to be $BC$ be denoted as $h$ Reflect $H$ over to $H'$ which is well known to lie on $(ABC)$ Using trig then power of a point $$BD\cdot DC=AD\cdot DH'\implies h\cot{B}\cdot h\cot{C}=h\cdot \frac{h}{2}$$ $$ \implies \tan{B}\cdot\tan{C}=2$$ Let $I$ be the center of $(ABC)$ (or we can also look at it as the incenter of $\triangle XYZ$ ) Noting that $\angle ZIA=\angle BCA$ and $\angle YIA=\angle ABC$ $$\tan{B}\cdot \tan{C}=\frac{AZ}{1}\cdot\frac{AY}{1}=2$$ Now let $XB=XC=x$ $YA=YC=y$ and $ZA=ZB=z$ The orthocenter condition thus gives us that $2yz=2$ It is well known that the inradius of a triangle can be represented as $\sqrt{\frac{xyz}{x+y+z}}$ (proof heron's) but the inradius is just the circumradius of $(ABC)$ which is $1$ so we have $$x+y+z=xyz\implies x+y+z=2x\implies x=y+z$$ (ok this is where this solution is slightly sketchy) Ok now we aren't really given much information about which of $AB BC CA$ is the longest and shortest so we can't really figure out which side of $\triangle XYZ$ will be the average of the three sides This is equivalent to having two of $x y z$ adding up to two times the third one This means we can automatically eliminate $x$ as the sum of $\frac{y+z}{2}$ or else $x$ would be $0$ Since this problem is "symmetric" about $A$ WLOG let $2z=x+y$ Then $$2z=x+y\implies 2z=2y+z\implies z=2y\implies z=2 y=1 x=3$$ but then wait !! you notice that this means $\triangle XYZ$ is just a $3 4 5$ ! ! ! 111! !!1 1one! Now it suffices to calculuate $[ABC]$ which can be done by just subtracting the outer three triangles formed from the total area to get an answer of $\frac{6}{5}\implies \boxed{11}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A7
text: Triangle $ABC$ has $\overline{AB} = \overline{AC} = 20$ and $\overline{BC} = 15$. Let $D$ be the point in $\triangle ABC$ such that $\triangle ADB \sim \triangle BDC$. Let $l$ be a line through $A$ and let $BD$ and $CD$ intersect $l$ at $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Let the circumcircles of $\triangle BDQ$ and $\triangle CDP$ intersect at $X$. The area of the locus of $X$ as $l$ varies can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{p}{q}\pi$ for positive coprime integers $p$ and $q$. What is $p + q$?
solution:
From $\triangle ADB \sim \triangle BDC$ we have that $(BDC)$ is tangent to $AB$ and $AC$ Let $BQ \cap (BDC) = R$ By Pascal on $RBBDCC$ $BD \cap RC \in QA$ But $BD \cap QA = P$ so $R C P$ are collinear ie $R = BQ \cap CP$ lies on $(BDC)$ 
 
 Let $O$ be the center of $(BDC)$ Now note that $X$ is the Miquel point of cyclic quadrilateral $RBDC$ so $X$ lies on $PQ$ and $OX \perp PQ \implies OX \perp XA$ Also it is clear that $AO$ is a diameter of $(ABC)$ so this means that $X \in (ABC)$ 
 
 Thus the locus of $X$ is just $(ABC)$ 
 $$R^2 = \left( \frac{abc}{4K} \right)^2\frac{15^2 \cdot 20^4}{16 \cdot \frac{55 \cdot 25 \cdot 15 \cdot 15}{16}} = \frac{1280}{11} \implies \boxed{1219} $$ 
 Replacing "Let $D$ be the point in $\triangle ABC$ such that $\triangle ADB \sim \triangle BDC$ " with "Let $D$ be a point in $\triangle ABC$ such that $\angle ABD = \angle BCD$ " would not change the problem since $D$ only needs to lie on the circle through $B$ and $C$ tangent to $AB$ and $AC$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry A8
text: The incircle of acute triangle $ABC$ touches $BC, AC$, and $AB$ at points $D, E$, and $F$, respectively. Let $P$ be the second intersection of line $AD$ and the incircle. The line through $P$ tangent to the incircle intersects $AB$ and $AC$ at points $M$ and $N$, respectively. Given that $\overline{AB} = 8, \overline{AC} = 10$, and $\overline{AN} = 4$, let $\overline{AM} = \tfrac{a}{b}$ where $a$ and $b$ are positive coprime integers. What is $a + b$?
solution:
Since $DFPE$ is harmonic we see that the tangent at $P$ intersects $\overleftrightarrow{BC}$ on $\overleftrightarrow{EF} $ say at $T $ Then as $\overline{AD}$ is the polar of $T $ $(A \overline{AD}\cap \overline{EF} P D) = 1 $ We can project this from $T$ onto $AB$ and $AC$ to see that $(A E N C)=(A F M B)= 1 $ The former equality yields 
 \[\frac{NA}{NE}=\frac{CA}{CE}\implies \frac{4}{s a 4}=\frac{10}{s b}\implies 4\left(\frac{a}{2} 1\right)=10\left(5 \frac{a}{2}\right)\implies a=\frac{46}{7} \] while the latter yields 
 \[\frac{MA}{MF}=\frac{BA}{BF}\implies \frac{AM}{s a AM}=\frac{8}{s b}\implies AM\left(\frac{16}{7}\right)=8\left(\frac{40}{7} AM\right)\implies AM=\frac{40}{9} \] whence it follows that the answer is $40+9=\boxed{49} $

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry B1
text: Find the distance $\overline{CF}$ in the diagram below where $ABDE$ is a square and angles and lengths are as given: The length $\overline{CF}$ is of the form $a\sqrt{b}$ for integers $a, b$ such that no integer square greater than $1$ divides $b$. What is $a + b$?
solution: Extend the sides of the outside triangles to form a square as shown Then $FC = (FE+EX) \sqrt{2} = (8+15) \sqrt{2} = 23 \sqrt{2}$ Therefore $a+b = \boxed{25}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Geometry B2
text: Let $ABCD$ be a regular tetrahedron with side length $1$. Let $EF GH$ be another regular tetrahedron such that the volume of $EF GH$ is $\tfrac{1}{8}\text{-th}$ the volume of $ABCD$. The height of $EF GH$ (the minimum distance from any of the vertices to its opposing face) can be written as $\sqrt{\tfrac{a}{b}}$, where $a$ and $b$ are positive coprime integers. What is $a + b$?
solution: The volume of $ABCD$ is given by $\frac{1^3}{6\sqrt{2}} = \frac{1}{6\sqrt{2}}$ and the area of one of its bases is $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}$ Therefore $\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \cdot h = \frac{1}{6\sqrt{2}}$ where $h$ is the height of $ABCD$ Solving for $h$ we obtain $h = \frac{2}{\sqrt{6}}$ Since $EFGH$ has $\frac{1}{8}$ t h the volume of $ABCD$ its height must be half the height of $ABCD$ Therefore the height of $EFGH$ is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{6}}$ so $a+b = \boxed{7}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A1/B2
text: What is the $22\text{nd}$ positive integer $n$ such that $22^n$ ends in a $2$? (when written in base $10$).
solution: Note that $22^n \equiv 2^n \pmod{10}$ If $2^n \equiv 2 \pmod{10}$ then $n \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$ Therefore the $22 \text{nd}$ positive integer that is $1 \pmod{4}$ is $4 \cdot 22 + 1 = \boxed{85}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A2/B3
text: What is the sum of all positive integers $n$ such that $\text{lcm}(2n, n^2) = 14n - 24$?
solution:
If $n$ is even then $\text{lcm}\left(2n n^2\right)=n^2$ and hence $n=2 12$ 
 
 If $n$ is odd then $\text{lcm}\left(2n n^2\right)=2n^2$ and hence $n=3 4$ ( $4$ is invalid) So the sum of $n$ is $2+3+12=\boxed{17}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A3/B6
text: What is the largest positive integer $n$ less than $10, 000$ such that in base $4$, $n$ and $3n$ have the same number of digits; in base $8$, $n$ and $7n$ have the same number of digits; and in base $16$, $n$ and $15n$ have the same number of digits? Express your answer in base $10$.
solution:
If $n$ and $3n$ have the same number of digits in base $4$ then $4^a \le n < \frac{4^{a+1}}{3}$ for some integer $a$ This implies that $1000 \dots 0 \le n_4 \le 1111 \dots 1$ where $n_4$ is the base $4$ representation of $n$ Converting to base $2$ we see that $1000 \dots 0 \le n_2 \le 10101 \dots 01 $ 
 
 Similarly if $n$ and $7n$ have the same number of digits in base $8$ then $1000 \dots 0 \le n_8 \le 1111 \dots 1$ or $1000 \dots 0 \le n_2 \le 1001001 \dots 001$ 
 
 And finally if $n$ and $15n$ have the same number of digits in base $16$ then $1000 \dots 0 \le n_2 \le 100010001 \dots 0001$ 
 
 Therefore the maximum possible value of $n$ would be when $n_2$ is in the form $100010001 \cdots 0001$ 
 Hence $2^{12} + 2^8 + 2^4 + 2^0 = 1000100010001_2 = \boxed{4369}$ is the maximum possible value of $n$ less than $10 000$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A4/B7
text: What is the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $20 \equiv n^{15} \pmod{29}$?
solution: By Fermat's Little Theorem $n^{28}\equiv1\pmod{29}$ so $n^{14}\equiv\pm n\pmod{29}$ So $n\equiv9 20\pmod{29}$ Check that \[\left(\frac{20}{29}\right)=\left(\frac{5}{29}\right)=\left(\frac{29}{5}\right)=\left(\frac{4}{5}\right)=1 \] so $20^{14}\equiv1\pmod{29}$ and hence $20^{15}\equiv20\pmod{29}$ Also $\left(\frac{9}{29}\right)=1$ so $9^{14}\equiv1\pmod{29}$ and hence $9^{15}\equiv9\pmod{29}$ so $n\equiv20\pmod{29}$ Thus $n=\boxed{20}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A5
text: Given that there are $24$ primes between $3$ and $100$, inclusive, what is the number of ordered pairs $(p, a)$ with $p$ prime, $3 \le p < 100$, and $1 \le a < p$ such that the sum \[a+a^2+a^3+\cdots+a^{(p-2)!} \]is not divisible by $p$?
solution:
Observe that $a=1$ is always a solution because $\left(p 2\right)!$ is not divisible by $p$ Otherwise assume $a\neq1$ so the sum is $a\cdot\frac{a^{\left(p 2\right)!} 1}{a 1}$ by geometric series We can multiply by $\frac{a 1}{a}$ without changing divisibility by $p$ so it suffices to find when $a^{\left(p 2\right)!} 1$ is not divisible by $p$ 
 
 If $p=3$ then we need $a 1$ to not be divisible by $p$ This works for $a=2$ for $1$ extra solution here If $p=5$ then we need $a^6 1$ to not be divisible by $p$ But $a^4 1$ is divisible by $p$ by Fermat's Little Theorem so we need $a^2 1$ to not be divisible by $p$ This works for $a=2 3$ for $2$ extra solutions here If $p>5$ then $p 1$ divides $\left(p 2\right)!$ so $a^{\left(p 2\right)!} 1$ is divisible by $p$ always Thus there are $24+1+2=\boxed{27}$ solutions that work

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A6
text: For a positive integer $n$, let $d(n)$ be the number of positive divisors of $n$. What is the smallest positive integer $n$ such that \[\sum_{t \mid n} d(t)^3\]is divisible by $35$?
solution:
If $n=\displaystyle\prod p^e$ then use multiplicative properties of $d$ and the sum of cubes formula to get that the sum is $\left(\displaystyle\prod\frac{\left(e+1\right)\left(e+2\right)}{2}\right)^2$ so we want $35$ to divide the product This can be achieved when one term is divisible by $35$ that is $\left(e+1\right)\left(e+2\right)\equiv0\pmod{35}$ You can CRT the solutions ( $3 4\pmod5$ and $5 6\pmod7$ ) to get that the solutions are $13 19 33 34\pmod{35}$ so $e=13$ works The smallest value of $n$ which uses this is $2^{13}$ 
 
 Another way this can be achieved is if two of the terms of the product are divisible by $5$ and $7$ $e=3$ gives divisible by $5$ and $e=5$ gives divisible by $7$ Then the smallest value of $n$ which uses this is $2^5\cdot3^3=\boxed{864}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A7/B8
text: Given a positive integer $k$, let $f(k)$ be the sum of the $k$-th powers of the primitive roots of $73$. For how many positive integers $k < 2015$ is $f(k)$ divisible by $73?$ Note: A primitive root of $r$ of a prime $p$ is an integer $1 \le r < p$ such that the smallest positive integer $k$ such that $r^k \equiv 1 \pmod{p}$ is $k = p-1$.
solution:
ok i really hate bill why is k<2015 even necessary 
 
 Solution So note that $73|f(k)$ iff 73 divides the sum of the elements of $\mathbb{F}_{73}$ with order $\frac{72}{\gcd(k 72)}$ This is because when you raise primitive to the $k$ t h power the set of outputs is the set of elements with order $\frac{72}{\gcd(k 72)}$ and the outputs evenly space themselves Furthermore there are $\varphi(d)$ numbers $k$ so that $g^k$ has order $d$ The sum of the numbers with order $d$ is the same as the sum of the $d$ th primitive roots of unity so it is $\mu(d)$ 
 
 So we want to sum $\varphi(d)$ over all divisors of $d$ with $\mu(d)=0$ since otherwise it is 1 or 1 which is not divisible by 73 This is all divisors of 72 except the squarefree ones which are 1 2 3 6 Thus there are $72 \varphi(1) \varphi(2) \varphi(3) \varphi(6)=66$ numbers Except the question asks for k<2015 so we have to do $66\cdot\frac{2016}{72} 1=1847$ since 2016 doesn't work but 2015 works So this was a cool problem except bill decided to make it k<2015 so </3

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory A8
text: Let $n = 2^{2015} - 1$. For any integer $1 \le x < n$, let \[f_n(x) = \sum\limits_p s_p(n-x) + s_p(x) - s_p(n),\]where $s_q(k)$ denotes the sum of the digits of $k$ when written in base $q$ and the summation is over all primes $p$. Let $N$ be the number of values of $x$ such that $4 | f_n(x)$. What is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $1000?$
solution:
Partial Solution Note that $s_p(n x)+s_p(x) s_p(n)\equiv n x+x n\equiv 0\pmod{p 1}$ For $p\equiv1\pmod{4}$ this is a multiple of $4$ and we can ignore it For $p\equiv 3\pmod{4}$ we at least know that it is even Now we break out the handy dandy Legendre's formula \[v_p(n!)=\dfrac{n s_p(n)}{p 1}\] This is well motivated because things cancel and the expression we're left with magically has binomials in it \[s_p(n x)+s_p(x) s_p(n)=(p 1)(v_p(n!) v_p((n x)!) v_p(x!))=(p 1)\cdot v_p(\binom{n}{x})\] Now let $\omega(x)$ denote $\sum_{p=4k+3}v_p(x)$ The question is now reduced to the following for how many $x$ is $\omega(\binom{n}{x})$ even? 
 This is all the progress I made on the test and some not legitimate math follows The answer should be "about" half of all values of $x$ (this turns out to be true but I don't know why) Not counting the trivial case $x=n$ there are $2^{2015} 2$ values of $x$ Note that by the symmetry of Pascal's triangle there are only $2^{2014} 1$ distinct values By our groundless assumption above $2^{2013}$ are odd and $2^{2013} 1$ are even or vice versa Doubling for symmetry the final answer is either $2^{2014}$ or $2^{2014} 2$ The answer is apparently the latter but of course I put the former on the test 
 I'm not sure if I actually have the right approach but it seems to work so nicely that there must be a way to finish from here

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory B1
text: What is the remainder when \[\sum_{k=0}^{100}10^k\]is divided by $9$?
solution:
Note that 
 \[\sum_{k=0}^{100} 10^k \equiv \sum_{k=0}^{100} 1^k \equiv 101 \equiv \boxed{2} \pmod{9} \]

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory B4
text: A circle with radius $1$ and center $(0, 1)$ lies on the coordinate plane. Ariel stands at the origin and rolls a ball of paint at an angle of $35$ degrees relative to the positive $x$-axis (counting degrees counterclockwise). The ball repeatedly bounces off the circle and leaves behind a trail of paint where it rolled. After the ball of paint returns to the origin, the paint has traced out a star with $n$ points on the circle. What is $n$?

title: 2015 PUMaC Number Theory B5
text: Given that there are $24$ primes between $3$ and $100$, inclusive, what is the number of ordered pairs $(p, a)$ with $p$ prime, $3 \le p < 100$, and $1 \le a < p$ such that $p \mid (a^{p-2} - a)$?
solution: $p\nmid a$ so $p\mid a^{p 3} 1$ But $p\mid a^{p 1} 1$ by Fermat's Little Theorem so $p\mid a^2 1$ The only solutions to this are $a\equiv\pm1\pmod p$ This always works so there are $2\cdot24=\boxed{48}$ solutions

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A1/B1
text: A word is an ordered, non-empty sequence of letters, such as $word$ or $wrod$. How many distinct $3$-letter words can be made from a subset of the letters $c, o, m, b, o$, where each letter in the list is used no more than the number of times it appears?
solution: There are $4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 = 24$ words with one $o$ and $\binom{3}{2} \cdot 3 = 9$ possible words with two $o$ s Therefore the total number of possible words is $24+9 = \boxed{33}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A2/B4
text: Andrew has $10$ balls in a bag, each a different color. He randomly picks a ball from the bag $4$ times, with replacement. The expected number of distinct colors among the balls he picks is $\tfrac{p}{q}$, where $\gcd(p, q) = 1$ and $p, q > 0$. What is $p + q$?
solution:
Bash Consider the probability of each number of distinct colors Then the expected number of distinct colors is is 
 $\frac{1}{10^4}\cdot\left(4\cdot\left(10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7\right)+3\cdot\left(10\cdot\binom{4}{2} \cdot9\cdot8\right)+2\cdot\left(\binom{10}{2} \cdot \binom{4}{2}+10\cdot9\cdot4\right)+1 \cdot 10\right) = \boxed{\frac{3439}{1000}}$ 
 
 Slick Consider an individual color The expected contribution that individual color will make to the total number of individual colors is $1 \left( \frac{9}{10} \right)^4 = \frac{3439}{10000}$ because that is probability that individual color is chosen at least once Therefore since there are $10$ colors by the linearity of expectation the expected number of distinct colors is $\boxed{\frac{3439}{1000}}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A3/B5
text: Consider a random permutation of the set $\{1, 2,..., 2015\}$. In other words, for each $1 \le i \le 2015$, $i$ is sent to the element $a_i$ where $a_i \in \{1, 2,..., 2015\}$ and if $i \neq j$, then $a_i \neq a_j$. What is the expected number of ordered pairs $(a_i, a_j )$ with $i - j > 155$ and $a_i - a_j > 266$?
solution: Consider a random pair $(a_i a_j)$ The probability that $a_i a_j >266$ is $\frac{1}{2014\cdot2015}\cdot\left(1+2+3+ \cdots + \left(2015 265\right)\right) = \frac{759}{2015}$ Since there are a total of $1+2+3+ \cdots + (2015 154) = 1728870$ pairs $(i j)$ that satisfy $i j >155$ by the linearity of expectation the expected number of pairs that satisfy both is $1728870 \cdot \frac{759}{2015} = \boxed{651222}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A4/B6
text: A number is interesting if it is a $6$-digit integer that contains no zeros, its first $3$ digits are strictly increasing, and its last $3$ digits are non-increasing. What is the average of all interesting numbers?
solution:
Let the $6$ digit number be $\overline{abcdef}$ We find the expected value of each digit By symmetry $\mathbb{E}(b) = \mathbb{E}(e) =5$ and $\mathbb{E}(a)+\mathbb{E}(c)=\mathbb{E}(d)+\mathbb{E}(f)=10$ so it suffices to find $\mathbb{E}(a)$ and $\mathbb{E}(f)$ If $a = n$ then there are $\binom{9 n}{2}$ ways to choose $b$ and $c$ Therefore $\mathbb{E}(a) = \frac{1}{\binom{9}{3}} \cdot \left(\binom{8}{2} + 2 \cdot \binom{7}{2} + 3 \cdot \binom{6}{2} + \cdots + 7 \cdot \binom{2}{2} \right) = \frac{\binom{10}{4}}{\binom{9}{2}} = \frac{5}{2}$ by hockey stick Similarly if $d=n$ then there are $\binom{11 n}{2}$ ways to choose $e$ and $f$ Therefore $\mathbb{E}(d) = \frac{1}{\binom{11}{3}} \cdot \left(\binom{10}{2} + 2 \cdot \binom{9}{2} + 3 \cdot \binom{8}{2} + \cdots + 9 \cdot \binom{2}{2} \right) = \frac{\binom{12}{4}}{\binom{11}{2}} = 3$ 
 Therefore $\mathbb{E}(\overline{abcdef}) = 250000 + 50000 + 7500 + 700 + 50 + 3 = \boxed{308253}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A5/B7
text: Alice has an orange $\text{3-by-3-by-3}$ cube, which is comprised of $27$ distinguishable, $\text{1-by-1-by-1}$ cubes. Each small cube was initially orange, but Alice painted $10$ of the small cubes completely black. In how many ways could she have chosen $10$ of these smaller cubes to paint black such that every one of the $27$ $\text{3-by-1-by-1}$ sub-blocks of the $\text{3-by-3-by-3}$ cube contains at least one small black cube?
solution: Split the $3 \times 3 \times 3$ cube into three $3 \times 3 \times 1$ blocks Clearly each block must contain at least $3$ black cubes Therefore $2$ of the blocks contain $3$ black cubes and $1$ contains $4$ black cubes WLOG the bottom block contains $4$ black cubes Now focus on the bottom block We must have at least one black block in each row and column Ignoring that condition there are $\binom{9}{4}=126$ ways to color the bottom block Ignoring overcounts the number of colorings that have one row/column empty is $6 \cdot \binom{6}{4}$ because there are $6$ rows/columns and $\binom{6}{4}$ ways to color the other $6$ blocks Finally we subtract the number of colorings that leave $2$ rows/columns empty Clearly we must have one row and one column empty so there are $3^2=9$ ways here Therefore the number of ways to color the bottom block is $126 90+9 = 45$ Since each vertical $1 \times 1 \times 3$ block must also contain at least $1$ black block we must have one of the $3 \times 3 \times 1$ block contain $3$ of the black blocks that are directly above $3$ orange blocks in the bottom block It's easy to see that there is only one way to do this Since there are $2$ blocks left there are $2$ ways to color the rest of the cube Therefore the total number of colorings is $3 \cdot 45 \cdot 2 = \boxed{270}$ because any of the three blocks can have the $4$ black cubes

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A6
text: Every day, Heesu talks to Sally with some probability $p$. One day, after not talking to Sally the previous day, Heesu resolves to ask Sally out on a date. From now on, each day, if Heesu has talked to Sally each of the past four days, then Heesu will ask Sally out on a date. Heesu’s friend remarked that at this rate, it would take Heesu an expected $2800$ days to finally ask Sally out. Suppose $p=\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $\gcd(m, n) = 1$ and $m, n > 0$. What is $m + n$?

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A7
text: The lattice points $(i, j)$ for integers $0 \le i, j \le 3$ are each being painted orange or black. Suppose a coloring is good if for every set of integers $x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2$ such that $0 \le x_1 < x_2 \le 3$ and $0 \le y_1 < y_2 \le 3$, the points $(x_1, y_1),(x_1, y_2),(x_2, y_1),(x_2, y_2)$ are not all the same color. How many good colorings are possible?

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics A8
text: In a tournament with $2015$ teams, each team plays every other team exactly once and no ties occur. Such a tournament is imbalanced if for every group of $6$ teams, there exists either a team that wins against the other $5$ or a team that loses to the other $5$. If the teams are indistinguishable, what is the number of distinct imbalanced tournaments that can occur?

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics B2
text: Jonathan has a magical coin machine which takes coins in amounts of $7, 8$, and $9$. If he puts in $7$ coins, he gets $3$ coins back; if he puts in $8$, he gets $11$ back; and if he puts in $9$, he gets $4$ back. The coin machine does not allow two entries of the same amount to happen consecutively. Starting with $15$ coins, what is the minimum number of entries he can make to end up with $4$ coins?
solution: The first move says that if he has at least $7$ coins then he looses $4$ coins The second move says that if he has at least $8$ coins then he gains $3$ The third moves says that if he has at least $9$ coins then he looses $5$ Now we work backwards from $4$ coins He could either gain $4$ or gain $5$ leaving him with $8$ or $9$ coins respectively Case 1 If he has $8$ coins then his only option is to gain $5$ leaving him with $13$ coins With $13$ coins it's easy to see that the fastest way to get to $15$ is to loose $3$ then gain $5$ This way takes $4$ moves Case 2 If he has $9$ coins then the must gain $4$ leaving him with $13$ coins Then he is left in the same position as in case $1$ so the minimum number of moves is clearly $\boxed{4}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics B3
text: Princeton’s Math Club recently bought a stock for $\$2$ and sold it for $\$9$ thirteen days later. Given that the stock either increases or decreases by $\$1$ every day and never reached $\$0$, in how many possible ways could the stock have changed during those thirteen days?
solution: Clearly for this to happen the stock must increase on $10$ days and decrease on $3$ days Ignoring the condition that the stock never reached $0$ there are $\binom{13}{3} = 286$ ways to distribute the $3$ days when the stock decreases Now we subtract the the cases where the stock reaches $0$ If the stock decreases on the first two days then there are $11$ cases here because there are $13 2=11$ ways to place the third decreasing day If the stock reaches $0$ for the first time then there are $2$ ways here $2 \to 3 \to 2 \to 1 \to 0$ and $2 \to 1 \to 2 \to 1 \to 0$ The rest of the days must be increasing Clearly the stock cannot reach $0$ after the third day so the answer is $286 11 2 = \boxed{273}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Combinatorics B8
text: In how many ways can $9$ cells of a $\text{6-by-6}$ grid be painted black such that no two black cells share a corner or an edge with each other?
solution:
Divide the $6 \times 6$ grid into nine $2 \times 2$ square grids Clearly we can have at most $1$ black square in each $2 \times 2$ square so each $2 \times 2$ square has exactly $1$ black square Now we can describe the position of the black square in the $2 \times 2$ square as being on the left or right side and on the up or down half We denote these as $L$ or $R$ and $U$ or $D$ respectively The condition tells us that two consecutive black squares in a row cannot be $RL$ and two consecutive black squares in a column cannot be $DU$ Then the only $4$ possibilities for a row (from left to right) are $LLL LLR LRR$ or $RRR$ Similarly the only $4$ possibilities for a column are $UUU UUD UDD$ or $DDD$ Since there are $3$ rows and $3$ columns the total number of configuration is $4^{3+3} = 4096$ 
 
 Unfortunately not all of these work Consider the corners of the middle $2 \times 2$ square We have to subtract the cases where one of these corners is shared by two black squares We proceed with PIE WLOG the top left corner is shared There are two ways this can happen 1 One black square in the top left $2 \times 2$ square shares the corner with a black square in the center $2 \times 2$ square Then the top row must be $RRR$ because the first one is on the right In the second row we have $LL \ \_$ Since the middle square is $L$ the first one must also be $L$ Then the third one can either be $L$ or $R$ In the third row we can have any of the $4$ possibilities so there are $2 \cdot 4 = 8$ ways to decide the left/right positions We also see that there are $8$ ways to decide the up and down positions so there are $8^2=64$ ways to color the gird 2 Once black square in the middle left $2 \times 2$ square shares the corner with a black square in the middle top $2 \times 2 $ square Doing the same thing as in case $1$ we see that there are also $8^2=64$ ways to color the grid in this case Since there are $4$ corners the total number of colorings that have a shared corner is $4 \cdot (64+64)=512$ Now we have to subtract the number of colorings where two of the corners are shared We can either have the top right and the bottom left corners shared or the top left and the bottom right corners shared WLOG the top left and the bottom right corners shared Then it's easy to see that there are $2$ ways to choose which squares have black square's corners shared and $2^2=4$ ways to color the rest of the grid Therefore there are $2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2^2=16$ overcounts Therefore the answer is $4096 512+16 = \boxed{3600}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Algebra A4/B6
text: Define the sequence $a_i$ as follows: $a_1 = 1, a_2 = 2015$, and $a_n = \frac{na_{n-1}^2}{a_{n-1}+na_{n-2}}$ for $n > 2$. What is the least $k$ such that $a_k < a_{k-1}$?
solution:
Solution $a_n = \frac{na_{n 1}^2}{a_{n 1}+na_{n 2}} \implies \frac{a_n}{a_{n 1}} = \frac{na_{n 1}}{a_{n 1}+na_{n 2}} \implies \frac{a_{n 1}}{a_n} = \frac{1}{n}+\frac{a_{n 2}}{a_{n 1}}$ 
 
 Plugging in $3$ for n gives $\frac{a_2}{a_3} = \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{2015}$ By a simple induction argument we can easily see that $\frac{a_{k 1}}{a_k} = \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{4}+ \dots + \frac{1}{k}+\frac{1}{2015}$ We want this to be greater than $1$ and the first time this is achieved is when $k=\boxed{7}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Algebra A5
text: Since counting the numbers from 1 to 100 wasn't enough to stymie Gauss, his teacher devised another clever problem that he was sure would stump Gauss. Defining $\zeta_{15} = e^{2\pi i/15}$ where $i = \sqrt{-1}$, the teacher wrote the 15 complex numbers $\zeta_{15}^k$ for integer $0 \le k < 15$ on the board. Then, he told Gauss: On every turn, erase two random numbers $a, b$, chosen uniformly randomly, from the board and then write the term $2ab - a - b + 1$ on the board instead. Repeat this until you have one number left. What is the expected value of the last number remaining on the board?
solution:
troll Note that $\frac{2a 1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{2b 1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}$ combine to give $\frac{(2a 1)(2b 1)}{2}+\frac{1}{2}$ Thus at the end the only number possible (!) is 
 \[\frac{\prod_{k=0}^{14}(2r^k 1)}{2}+\frac{1}{2}=\frac{2^{15}\prod_{k=0}^{14}(r^k \frac{1}{2})}{2}+\frac{1}{2}= 2^{14}\prod_{k=0}^{14}\left(\frac{1}{2} r^k\right)+\frac{1}{2}= 2^{14}\left(\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{15} 1\right)+\frac{1}{2}=2^{14}=\boxed{16384 }\]

title: 2015 PUMaC Algebra A6/B7
text: We define the function $f(x,y)=x^3+(y-4)x^2+(y^2-4y+4)x+(y^3-4y^2+4y)$. Then choose any distinct $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$ such that the following holds: $f(a,b)=f(b,c)=f(c,a)$. Over all such choices of $a, b, c$, what is the maximum value achieved by \[\min(a^4 - 4a^3 + 4a^2, b^4 - 4b^3 + 4b^2, c^4 - 4c^3 + 4c^2)?\]
solution:
My very excellent solution First of all $f(x y)$ is symmetric in $x$ and $y$ Now suppose that $f(a b)=f(a c)$ it is apparent that $b c|f(a b) f(a c)$ Dividing this factor out (since $a b c$ are distinct) we see that the remaining factor is 
 \[a^2+b^2+c^2+ab+bc+ca 4a 4b 4c+4=0\] which is symmetric in $a b c$ (!!) So this being true implies that $f(a b)=f(b c)=f(c a)$ Now seeing as the problem asks for $\max\min(a^2(a 2)^2 b^2(b 2)^2 c^2(c 2)^2)$ we make the substitution $a=p+1 b=q+1 c=r+1$ which gives 
 \[p^2+q^2+r^2+pq+qr+rp 2=0\implies (p+q)^2+(q+r)^2+(r+p)^2=4\] and we want to find 
 \[S=\max\min((p^2 1)^2 (q^2 1)^2 (r^2 1)^2) \] Our first try is $p=q=r$ which gives $p^2=q^2=r^2=1/3$ and $S=4/9$ This is the PUMaC which only accepts integers so $1$ must be possible somehow Eventually you see that $p=q=0$ $r=\sqrt{2}$ gives $S=1$ Now we suspect that $S=2$ is not possible (our construction gives $(p^2 1)^2=(q^2 1)^2=(r^2 1)^2=1$ ) Now suppose that $S=2$ is possible Then $(p^2 1)^2\geq2$ so $p^2\geq1+\sqrt{2}$ and similarly for $q^2 r^2$ Now two of $p$ and $q$ have the same sign WLOG they are $p$ and $q$ and WLOG they are positive (we can negate all of $p q r$ ) Then $p+q\geq\sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}}+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}}>2$ so $(p+q)^2>4$ which is bad Thus $S<2$ so $S=\boxed{1}$ 
 
 (After the test I realized that the above argument works with any $S>1$ all that happens is that $\sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}}$ gets replaced with $\sqrt{1+\sqrt{S}}$ and $2\sqrt{1+\sqrt{S}}$ is still bigger than $2$ )

title: 2015 PUMaC Algebra A7/B8
text: We define the ridiculous numbers recursively as follows: 1 is a ridiculous number. If $a$ is a ridiculous number, then $\sqrt{a}$ and $1+\sqrt{a}$ are also ridiculous numbers. A closed interval $I$ is ``boring'' if $I$ contains no ridiculous numbers, and There exists an interval $[b,c]$ containing $I$ for which $b$ and $c$ are both ridiculous numbers. The smallest non-negative $l$ such that there does not exist a boring interval with length $l$ can be represented in the form $\dfrac{a + b\sqrt{c}}{d}$ where $a, b, c, d$ are integers, $\gcd(a, b, d) = 1$, and no integer square greater than 1 divides $c$. What is $a + b + c + d$?
solution: Sol The least upper bound for the ridiculous numbers is $\frac{3+\sqrt{5}}{2} $ Therefore the least upper bound for a ridiculous number under 2 is $\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2} $ Therefore $l=\frac{3 \sqrt{5}}{2} $ which means that the answer is $3 1+5+2=\boxed{9} $

title: 2015 PUMaC Individual Finals A1/B1
text: Alice places down $n$ bishops on a $2015\times 2015$ chessboard such that no two bishops are attacking each other. (Bishops attack each other if they are on a diagonal.) Find, with proof, the maximum possible value of $n$. (A1 only) For this maximal $n$, find, with proof, the number of ways she could place her bishops on the chessboard.
solution: I'm not sure which thread is the official thread so I'll add my solution here as well We will show that the maximal number of non attacking bishops that can be placed on an $n \times n$ chessboard is $2n 2 $ Moreover there are precisely $2^n$ possible bishop placements From the top left square of the board label the $2n 1$ diagonals (with orientation $\nearrow$ as opposed to $\searrow$ ) $d_1 d_2 \cdots d_{2n 1} $ Clearly each diagonal can contain only one bishop for if two bishops belonged to the same diagonal these two would attack one another Moreover $d_1$ and $d_{2n 1}$ cannot both contain bishops because $d_1$ consists of only the top left square of the board and $d_{2n 1}$ consists only of the bottom right square of the board If a bishop belonged to each of these two squares then these two bishops would attack one another Hence at most $2n 2$ diagonals can contain bishops establishing the desired bound Now we will show that this bound is attainable We claim that any bishop on the chessboard attacks at least $n 1$ squares Indeed consider any bishop $B$ and let $d$ be a diagonal passing through $B $ Let $B$ vary on $d$ and as $B$ varies let $d'$ be the second diagonal passing through $B $ If $|d| |d'|$ denote the number of squares on $d d'$ then the total number of squares attacked by $B$ is $(|d| 1) + (|d'| 1) $ However $|d'| 1$ is minimized when $d'$ is as short as possible This clearly occurs when $B$ belongs the the side of the board Moreover it is easy to see that any bishop belonging to the side of the board attacks precisely $n 1$ squares Thus any bishop attacks at least $n 1$ squares as desired Now consider a non corner square $s$ of the chessboard that does not contain a bishop Since two diagonals pass through $s$ at most two bishops can attack $s$ (for otherwise two bishops would belong to the same diagonal and hence attack one another) Then if $2n 2$ non attacking bishops are placed on the chessboard $n^2 (2n 2)$ square do not contain bishops Therefore the total number of times a bishop attacks a square is bounded above by $2(n^2 2n + 2) $ However notice that each of the four corner squares can only be attacked by one bishop not two Since at least two corner squares are not occupied by a bishop we may strengthen the above bound as $2(n^2 2n + 2) 2 $ But since each bishop attacks at least $n 1$ squares the total number of times a bishop attacks a square is bounded below by $(n 1)(2n 2) = 2(n^2 2n + 2) 2 $ Therefore equality must occur in which case all $2n 2$ bishops belong to the side of the board It remains to count how many ways this can happen For $k = 2 3 \cdots n 1$ it is easy to see that there are exactly two ways in which the bishops belonging to $d_k$ and $d_{2n k}$ can be placed so that these two bishops belong to the side of the board Moreover there are two ways in which the bishop in $d_n$ can be placed Finally there are two choices for whether $d_1$ or $d_{2n 1}$ contains a bishop Thus we have a total of $2^{n 2} \cdot 2 \cdot 2 = 2^n$ possible bishop placements $\square$

title: 2015 PUMaC Individual Finals A2/B3
text: For an odd prime number $p$, let $S$ denote the following sum taken modulo $p$: \[ S \equiv \frac{1}{1 \cdot 2} + \frac{1}{3\cdot 4} + \ldots + \frac{1}{(p-2)\cdot(p-1)} \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{\frac{p-1}{2}} \frac{1}{(2i-1) \cdot 2i} \pmod p\]Prove that $p^2 | 2^p - 2$ if and only if $S \equiv 0 \pmod p$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text $$2^p 2=\sum_{i=1}^{p 1}\binom{p}{i}= \sum_{i=1}^{p 1}p\frac{( 1)^{i+1}}{i}=p\cdot\left(\left(\frac{1}{1} \frac{1}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{3} \frac{1}{4}\right) +\left(\frac{1}{p 2} \frac{1}{p 1}\right)\right)=p\left(\frac{1}{1\cdot 2}+\frac{1}{3\cdot 4}+ +\frac{1}{(p 2)(p 1)}\right)=pS\pmod{p^2}$$ so $p^2\mid 2^p 2\iff p\mid S$

title: 2015 PUMaC Individual Finals A3
text: Let $I$ be the incenter of a triangle $ABC$ with $AB = 20$, $BC = 15$, and $BI = 12$. Let $CI$ intersect the circumcircle $\omega_1$ of $ABC$ at $D \neq C $. Alice draws a line $l$ through $D$ that intersects $\omega_1$ on the minor arc $AC$ at $X$ and the circumcircle $\omega_2$ of $AIC$ at $Y$ outside $\omega_1$. She notices that she can construct a right triangle with side lengths $ID$, $DX$, and $XY$. Determine, with proof, the length of $IY$.
solution:
I'm not sure which thread is the official one so I'll add my solution here as well Let $I_a I_b$ be the excenters opposite $A B$ in $\triangle ABC$ and let $E$ be the midpoint of arc $\widehat{BCA}$ on $\omega_1 $ Let $\rho$ be the circumcircle of $\triangle AIB $ 
 
 It is well known that $D$ is the center of $\rho $ Then if $r \equiv DA = DB = DI$ is the radius of $\rho$ note that $XD^2 r^2 = XY^2 $ Therefore $X$ has equal power WRT $\rho$ and $Y $ Furthermore $\overline{DE}$ is a diameter of $\omega_1$ so $EX \perp DY $ Hence $EX$ is the radical axis of $\rho Y$ and it follows that \[EY^2 = ED^2 r^2 = ED^2 DA^2 = EA^2 \] where the last step follows from the Pythagorean Theorem in right triangle $\triangle ADE $ But it is well known that $A B I_a I_b$ lie on the circle of diameter $\overline{I_aI_b}$ centered at $E $ Therefore $EA = EI_b \implies Y \equiv I_b $ To finish note that $CI_b$ is the external bisector of $\angle BCA \implies \angle BCI_b = 90^{\circ} + \tfrac{C}{2} = \angle BIA $ Together with $\angle I_bBC = \angle ABI$ this is enough to imply that $\triangle I_bCB \sim \triangle AIB $ Therefore $\tfrac{BI_b}{BC} = \tfrac{BA}{BI}$ whence it follows that $BI_b = \tfrac{75}{3} $ Hence $II_b = BI_b BI = 13 $

solution: Click to reveal hidden text This problem is amazing Create a point $B'$ on the arc $CD$ which does not contain $A$ such that $B'D = CB$ and $B'C = BD$ Then by Ptolemy the condition rearranges to $AB' = CD$ Now considering a few configurations we can force the relation to come through

For the third term of the geometric sequence to be an integer we must have $a | b^2$ We do casework on $a$

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 4
text: Ryan is messing with Brice’s coin. He weights the coin such that it comes up on one side twice as frequently as the other, and he chooses whether to weight heads or tails more with equal probability. Brice flips his modified coin twice and it lands up heads both times. The probability that the coin lands up heads on the next flip can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{p}{q}$ for positive integers $p, q$ satisfying $\gcd(p, q) = 1$, what is $p + q$?
solution: The probability that he flipped two heads when the coin is weighted more toward heads is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{2}{3}=\frac{4}{18}$ while the probability that he flipped two heads when the coin is weighted more toward tails is $\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{3}=\frac{1}{18}$ So after these two flips there is a $\frac{4}{5}$ probability that the coin is weighted toward heads and $\frac{1}{5}$ probability that the coin is weighted toward tails Our answer is $\frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{1}{3}=\frac{3}{5}$ = $\boxed{8}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 5
text: Imagine a regular a $2015$-gon with edge length $2$. At each vertex, draw a unit circle centered at that vertex and color the circle’s circumference orange. Now, another unit circle $S$ is placed inside the polygon such that it is externally tangent to two adjacent circles centered at the vertices. This circle $S$ is allowed to roll freely in the interior of the polygon as long as it remains externally tangent to the vertex circles. As it rolls, $S$ turns the color of any point it touches into black. After it rolls completely around the interior of the polygon, the total length of the black lengths can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{p\pi}{q}$ for positive integers $p, q$ satisfying $\gcd(p, q) = 1$. What is $p + q$?
solution: Just draw what happens when $S$ travels from one circle to the next Essentially it's the part of the circumference of the orange circle that's at a $\frac{2013\pi}{2015} \frac{2\pi}{3}$ angle Multiply this number by $2015$ for the total length of the black lengths so the answer is $\frac{2009\pi}{3}$ = > $\boxed{2012}$

He then folds the ticket so that two opposite corners (vertices connected by a diagonal) coincide and makes a sharp crease (the ticket folds just as any regular piece of paper would). The area of the resulting shape can be expressed as $a + b \varphi$. What is $\tfrac{b}{a}$?
solution:
probably wrong Assume the small edge is $1$ then solve for the short edge of the isosceles triangle formed Let's call it $y$ Then the area is $\varphi \frac{y}2$ 
 By Pythagoras we have $y^2=1+(\varphi y)^2$ so $y=\frac32$ 
 Then the area is $ \frac34+\varphi$ and our answer is $ \frac43$ Also you never specified that $a$ and $b$ are rational so we can have $a=0$ etc

title: 2015 PUMac Team Problem 8
text: Let $\sigma_1: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ be a function that takes a natural number $n$, and returns the sum of the positive integer divisors of $n$. For example, $\sigma_1(6) = 1 + 2 + 3 + 6 = 12$. What is the largest number n such that $\sigma_1(n) = 1854$?
solution: Note that $1854=(1+2)(1+617)$ where $2$ and $617$ are primes So the answer is $\boxed{1234}$ Note that this is the only number that works because we need to express $1854$ as $(1+prime)(1+prime) $ and this is the only way that works

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 9
text: Triangle $ABC$ has $\overline{AB} = 5, \overline{BC} = 4, \overline{CA} = 6$. Points $D$ and $E$ are on sides $AB$ and $AC$, respectively, such that $\overline{AD} = \overline{AE} = \overline{BC}$. Let $CD$ and $BE$ intersect at $F$ and let $AF$ and $DE$ intersect at $G$. The length of $FG$ can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{a\sqrt{b}}{c}$ in simplified form. What is $a + b + c$?
solution: Use barycentric coordinates Set $A=\left(1 0 0\right) B=\left(0 1 0\right) C=\left(0 0 1\right)$ Then $D=\left(1 4 0\right) E=\left(2 0 4\right)$ so $F=\left(1 4 2\right)=\left(\frac{1}{7} \frac{4}{7} \frac{2}{7}\right)$ Calculate line $DE$ as $4x y 2x=0$ so $G=\left(1 2 1\right)=\left(\frac{1}{4} \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{4}\right)$ Then displacement vector from $F$ to $G$ is $\left(\frac{3}{28} \frac{1}{14} \frac{1}{28}\right)$ so the distance $FG$ is \[\sqrt{ 4^2\cdot \frac{1}{14}\cdot \frac{1}{28} 6^2\cdot \frac{1}{28}\cdot\frac{3}{28} 5^2\cdot\frac{3}{28}\cdot \frac{1}{14}}=\frac{\sqrt{226}}{28} \] Then $a+b+c=1+226+28=\boxed{255}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 10
text: Let $S$ be the set of integer triplets $(a, b, c)$ with $1 \le a \le b \le c$ that satisfy $a + b + c = 77$ and: \[\frac{1}{a} +\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}= \frac{1}{5}.\]What is the value of the sum $\sum_{a,b,c \in S} a\cdot b \cdot c$?
solution:
We rewrite the given conditions in the form $(a 5)(b 5)(c 5)=abc 5(ab+bc+ca)+25(a+b+c) 125=25 \cdot 72$ Set $x=a 5$ $y=b 5$ and $z=c 5$ We now proceed by casework on the possible integer triples $(x y z)$ We either have two of those numbers be divisible by $5$ in which case the last number has to be $2$ or $12$ in order that $x+y+z=62$ or a multiple of $25$ ( $25$ or $50$ ) divides one of those numbers If one of the numbers is $2$ then the other two are divisible by $5$ and sum to $60$ and product is $25 \cdot 36$ generating the triple $(2 30 30)$ 
 If one of the numbers is $12$ then the other two are divisible by $5$ and sum to $50$ and product is $25 \cdot 6$ generating no solutions If one of the numbers is $25$ then the other two sum to $37$ and product is $72$ generating no solutions If one of the numbers is $50$ then the other two sum to $12$ and the product is $36$ generating the triple $(6 6 50)$ 
 Thus the answer is $(7+5)(30+5)(30+5)+(6+5)(6+5)(50+5)=\boxed{15230}$

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 11
text: Given a rational number $r$ that, when expressed in base-$10$, is a repeating, non-terminating decimal, we define $f(r)$ to be the number of digits in the decimal representation of $r$ that are after the decimal point but before the repeating part of $r$. For example, $f(1.2\overline{7}) = 0$ and $f(0.35\overline{2}) = 2$. What is the smallest positive integer $n$ such that $\tfrac{1}{n}, \tfrac{2}{n}$, and $\tfrac{4}{n}$ are non-terminating decimals, where $f\left( \tfrac{1}{n} \right) = 3, f\left( \tfrac{2}{n} \right) = 3$, and $f\left( \tfrac{4}{n} \right) = 2$?.

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 12
text: Alice is stacking balls on the ground in three layers using two sizes of balls: small and large. All small balls are the same size, as are all large balls. For the first layer, she uses $6$ identical large balls $A, B, C, D, E$, and $F$ all touching the ground and so that $D, E, F$ touch each other, A touches $E$ and $F$, $B$ touches $D$ and $F$, and $C$ touches $D$ and $E$. For the second layer, she uses $3$ identical small balls, $G, H$, and $I$; $G$ touches $A, E$, and $F, H$ touches $B, D$, and $F$, and $I$ touches $C, D$, and $E$. Obviously, the small balls do not intersect the ground. Finally, for the top layer, she uses one large ball that touches $D, E, F, G, H$, and $I$. If the large balls have volume $2015$, the sum of the volumes of all the balls in the pyramid can be written in the form $a\sqrt{b}+c$ for integers $a, b, c$ where no integer square larger than $1$ divides $b$. What is $a + b + c$? (This diagram may not have the correct scaling, but just serves to clarify the layout of the problem.)

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 13
text: We define $\lfloor x \rfloor$ as the largest integer less than or equal to $x$. What is \[ \left\lfloor \frac{5^{2017015}}{5^{2015}+7} \right\rfloor \mod 1000?\]

title: 2015 PUMaC Team Problem 14
text: Marie is painting a $4 \times 4$ grid of identical square windows. Initially, they are all orange but she wants to paint $4$ of them black. How many ways can she do this up to rotation and reflection?
solution: Let us solve this with Burnside's Lemma For the identity there are $\binom{16}{4}=1820$ ways For $90^{\circ}$ and $270^{\circ}$ there are $4$ ways each For $180^{\circ}$ there are $\binom{8}{2}=28$ ways For vertical and horizontal reflections there are $\binom{8}{2}=28$ ways For diagonal reflections there are $2$ diagonals and we can do casework on the number of black squares on the diagonal If there are $4$ blacks on the diagonal there is $1$ way If there are $2$ blacks on the diagonal there are $\binom{4}{2} \cdot 6=36$ ways If there are none on the diagonal there are $\binom{6}{2}=15$ ways for a total of $1+36+15=52$ ways Then the answer is $\frac{1820+4+4+28+28+28+52+52}{8} = 252$

title: 2008 PUMaC Geometry A1/B2
text: What is the area of a circle with a circumference of $8$?
solution: From the formula for circumference $2\pi r = 8 \implies r = \frac{4}{\pi}$ Thus the area of the circle is $\pi r^2 = \boxed{\frac{16}{\pi}}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Geometry A2/B3
text: Consider a convex polygon $\mathcal{P}$ in space with perimeter $20$ and area $30$. What is the volume of the locus of points that are at most $1$ unit away from some point in the interior of $\mathcal{P}$?
solution:
Note that the locus of points that are at most $1$ unit away from some point in the interior of $\mathcal{P}$ is made up of a prism some half cylindrical chunks and some chunks of a sphere The prism has area $60 $ the cylindrical chunks have a total area of 
 \begin{align*}
20 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1^2 \cdot \pi &= 10\pi \cdot 1 \\
&= 10\pi \end{align*} and the spherical chunks add up to a full sphere of radius $1 $ so the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
60 + 10\pi + \frac{4}{3} \cdot 1^2 \cdot \pi
&= 60 + 10\pi + \frac{4\pi}{3} \cdot 1 \\
&= 60 + 10\pi + \frac{4\pi}{3} \\
&= \boxed{60+\frac{34\pi}{3}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2008 PUMaC Geometry A4/B7

solution: excellent! algebraic way so let $P=\sqrt{(x 5)^2+(y 5)^2}+\sqrt{(x+5)^2+(y+5)^2}$ now $P>=0$ so applying RMS>=AM we get $\sqrt{4(x^2+y^2)+200}<=P$ so we get $P<=10\sqrt{10}$ now applying AM>=GM we get $P>=2\sqrt{\sqrt{[(x 5)^2+(y 5)^2][(x+5)^2+(y+5)^2]}}$ now for minimum bound equality should follow so $\sqrt{(x 5)^2+(y 5)^2}=\sqrt{(x+5)^2+(y+5)^2}$ so from here we get $x= y$ so we get $x=10$ and $y=10$ so minimum bound of $P$ comes as $20\sqrt{2}$ now this implies $20\sqrt{2}<=P<=10\sqrt{10}$ now $P$ and $x^2+y^2=200$ has exactly $4$ intersection points and as $P$ strictly lies between them the possible integer values comes as $4*3=12$

title: 2008 PUMaC Algebra A1 / B3
text: Given the sequence $1, 2, 1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 1,...,$ find $n$ such that the sum of the first $n$ terms is $2008$ or $2009$.
solution:
Group the terms as follows $(1) (2 1) (2 2 1) $ We see that the sum of the first $\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$ terms is $n^2$ We know that $44^2=1936$ and $45^2=2025$ And in between the first $1936$ and the first $2025$ terms exclusive there are $2$ ' s just $2$ ' s(lol) So the solution for $n$ in the linear equation $1936+2n=2008$ * is the number of terms in the sequence after those terms that sum to $44^2$ We see that $n=36$ And by our statement in the second sentence we see that the sum of the first $\frac{44(45)}{2}$ terms is $44^2$ so the answer is $\frac{44(45)}{2}+36=\boxed{1026}$ 
 *It cannot equal $2009$ because the LHS is clearly $0\pmod 2$ and it follows that the RHS must be $0\pmod 2$ and $2009$ is $1\pmod 2$ while $2008$ is $0\pmod 2$ so we have to use $2008$

solution:
parmenides51 wrote Let $H_k =\Sigma_{i=1}^k \frac{1}{i}$ for all positive integers $k$ Find an closed form expression for $\Sigma_{i=1}^k H_k$ in terms of $n$ and $H_n$ 
 a little change in wordings of the problem! it should be $H_{i}$ in the last sigma notation now original wordings of the problem looks like this Let $H_k =\Sigma_{i=1}^k \frac{1}{i}$ for all positive integers $k$ Find an closed form expression for $\Sigma_{k=1}^n H_{k}$ in terms of $n$ and $H_n$ 
 nice partial fractions $\Sigma_{k=1}^n\Sigma_{i=1}^k \frac{1}{i}$ we get $\Sigma_{i=1}^n \frac{n+1 i}{i}$ we get a standard telescopic series and hence we get our required sum a s $(n+1)H_{n} n$

title: 2008 PUMaC Algebra A6
text: Let $x$ be the largest root of $x^4 - 2009x + 1$. Find the nearest integer to $\frac{1}{x^3-2009}$.
solution: Let $f(x)=x^4 2009x+1$ If $x$ is a root of $f$ then $x^4 2009x+1=0\implies x^4 2009x= 1\implies x(x^3 2009)= 1\implies \frac{1}{x^3 2009}= x$ So we want to find the nearest integer to $ x$ Now let's investigate the behavior of the function so we can bound the largest root If $x$ is some small positive integer like $1$ we have $f(1)= 2007$ In general if $x$ is some small positive integer we see that $x^4 2009x+1$ because for small positive $x$ $2009x>x^4$ And when will this stop? When $x$ is around somewhere between $12$ and $13$ If it get's any larger than that then $x^4 2009x+1$ will blow up to infinity as $x$ gets larger Hence the largest root of $f$ is between $12$ and $13$ Let's bound this further We know that $f(12)= 3371$ and $f(13)=2445$ We have reason to believe that $x$ is closer to $13$ because $2445$ is closer to $0$ than $ 3371$ to $0$ but we must prove our instinct We see that $f(12 5)$ is negative so $12 5<x<13\implies 13> x> 12 5$ so the closest integer is $\boxed{ 13}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Algebra A7
text: Suppose $x^9 = 1$ but $x^3 \ne 1$. Find a polynomial of minimal degree equal to $\frac{1}{1+x}$.
solution: nice! first of all factorize $x^{9} =1$ in this fashion $(x^3)^3 1=0$ so we get $(x^3 1)(x^{6}+1+x^3)=0$ since $x^3 1$ is not $0$ we get $x^{6}+x^3= 1$ we transform this as $\frac{ 1}{1+x}=\frac{x^{6}+x^3}{x+1}$ hence solving for this we get minimal degree polynomial as $(x^{5} x^{4}+x^{3})=0$

solution: $\log_3 9=2$ and $\log_4{2*2*2}=\log_4{8}=\log_4 4+\log_4 2=1+\frac{1}{2}=\frac{3}{2}$ $\frac{3}{2}\cdot 2\cdot 3=9$ so the answer is $\boxed{9}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Algebra B4
text: Find the product of the minimum and maximum values of $\frac{3x+1}{9x^2+6x+2}$.
solution: Let $g(x)=\frac{3x+1}{9x^2+6x+2}$ We see that the denominator is equal to $(3x+1)^2+1$ Since $3x+1$ is unbounded and its range is $\mathbb{R}$ we wish to maximize and minimize $f(n)=\frac{n}{n^2+1}$ We know that $f'(n)=\frac{ n^2 1}{(n^2+1)^2}$ Setting this equal to $0$ yields $n=1 1$ By the second derivative test we see that $f''(1)=\frac{ 1}{2}$ hence $f(1)$ is a maximum We also see that $f''( 1)=\frac{1}{2}$ hence $f( 1)$ is a minimum Hence the product of the minimum and maximum values is $f(1)f( 1)=\boxed{\frac{ 1}{4}}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics A1 / B2
text: How many $3$-digit numbers contain the digit $7$ exactly once?
solution: If the first digit is $7$ then there are $1\cdot 9\cdot 9$ choices for the number If the second digit is $7$ then there are $8\cdot 1\cdot 9$ choices for the number If the third digit is $7$ then there are $8\cdot 9 \cdot 1$ choices for the number Altogether there are $1\cdot 9\cdot 9+8\cdot 1\cdot 9+8\cdot 9\cdot 1=\boxed{225}$ total three digit numbers that contain the digit $7$ exactly once

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics A2 / B3

If this figure is continued symmetrically off to infinity, what is the ratio between the number of triangles and the number of squares?
solution:
(Assume that by "continued symmetrically off to infinity" the problem means that after the first few steps written we draw squares again on the 12 gon and repeat the process ) 
 
 At every "layer" the number of sides of the previous layer is the number of squares in the new one We need to draw edges between the squares in the newest layer making equilateral triangles between them The number of equilateral triangles formed by drawing these edges is equal to the number of squares in the layer so the ratio is $\boxed{1 1}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics A4 / B6
text: Find the sum of the values of $x$ for which $\binom{x}{0}-\binom{x}{1}+\binom{x}{2}-...+\binom{x}{2008}=0$
solution: By reverse engineering Newton's Little Formula we get that the LHS is a degree $2008$ polynomial $f$ such that $f(0)=1$ and for all $i\in \{1 2 3 4 5 2008\} f(i)=0$ By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra we have that the LHS can have at most $2008$ roots and we know of $2008$ roots hence they are the only roots Hence the sum of the roots is $1+2+ +2008=\frac{2008(2009)}{2}=\boxed{2017036}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics A10
text: In his youth, Professor John Horton Conway lived on a farm with $2009$ cows. Conway wishes to move the cows from the negative $x$ axis to the positive $x$ axis. The cows are initially lined up in order $1, 2,..., 2009$ on the negative $x$ axis. Conway can give two possible commands to the cows. One is the PUSH command, upon which the first cow from the negative $x$ axis moves to the lowest position on the positive $y$ axis. The other is the POP command, upon which the cow in the lowest position on the $y$ axis moves to the positive $x$ axis. For example, if Conway says PUSH POP $2009$ times, then the resulting permutation of cows is the same, $1, 2,..., 2009$. If Conway says PUSH $2009$ times followed by POP $2009$ times, the resulting permutation of cows is $2009,..., 2, 1$. How many output permutations are possible after Conway finishes moving all the cows from the negative $x$ axis to the positive $x$ axis?

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics B1
text: Sarah buys $3$ gumballs from a gumball machine that contains $10$ orange, $6$ green, and $9$ yellow gumballs. What is the probability that the first gumball is orange, the second is green or yellow, and the third is also orange?
solution: The probability that the first gumball is orange is $\frac{10}{25}=\frac{2}{5}$ Now there are $24$ total gumballs The probability that the second is green is $\frac{6}{24}$ and the probability that the second is yellow is $\frac{9}{24}$ Hence the probability that the second gumball is green or yellow is $\frac{15}{24}=\frac{5}{8}$ There are now $23$ total gumballs The probability that the third gumball is orange is $\frac{9}{23}$ because we already have an orange gumball Hence the desired probability is $\frac{2}{5}\times \frac{5}{8}\times \frac{9}{23}=\boxed{\frac{9}{92}}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Combinatorics B4
text: A $2008 \times 2009$ rectangle is divided into unit squares. In how many ways can you remove a pair of squares such that the remainder can be covered with $1 \times 2$ dominoes?
solution: We proceed with a checkerboard coloring We realize that each domino will be over exactly $1$ white and $1$ black square Thus we need to remove $1$ white and $1$ black square and we can do that $\bigg(\frac{2008*2009}{2}\bigg)^2=\boxed{4068434225296}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory A1 / B2
text: How many zeros are there at the end of $792!$ when written in base $10$?
solution:
We simply need to find how many factors of $5$ there are in $792!$ 
 $$\lfloor \frac{792}{5} \rfloor = 158$$ $$\lfloor \frac{158}{5} \rfloor = 31$$ $$\lfloor \frac{31}{5} \rfloor = 6$$ $$\lfloor \frac{6}{5} \rfloor = 1$$ Thus our answer is $158+31+6+1=\boxed{196}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory A2 / B3

solution: The answers are $\boxed{(2 1) (3 2)}$ by Inspection

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory A3 / B4
text: Find the largest integer $n$, where $2009^n$ divides $2008^{2009^{2010}} + 2010^{2009^{2008}}$.
solution: Contrived Binomial Theorem $$2008^{2009^{2010}} + 2010^{2009^{2008}}=(2009 1)^{2009^{2010}} + (2009+1)^{2009^{2008}}$$ Thus we look at the smallest term which is $\binom{2009^{2010}}{1}*2009+\binom{2009^{2008}}{1}*2009$ thus the largest factor would be $2009^{2009} $ Thus the answer is $\boxed{2009}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory A4 / B6
text: $f(n)$ is the sum of all integers less than $n$ and relatively prime to $n$. Find all integers $n$ such that there exist integers $k$ and $\ell$ such that $f(n^k) = n^{\ell}$.

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory A5
text: If $f(x) = x^{x^{x^x}}$, find the last two digits of $f(17) + f(18) + f(19) + f(20)$.
solution:
Cute Clearly $f(17) \equiv 1 \pmod{4} $ 
 
 If gc d $(a n) = 1$ then $a^b \equiv a^{b \pmod{\phi(n)}} \pmod {n} $ 
 
 So to evaluate $f(17) \pmod{25} $ we first need to find $17^{{17}^{17}} \pmod{20} $ 
 
 And to compute $17^{{17}^{17}} \pmod{20} $ we first need to compute $17^{17} \pmod {8} $ 
 
 $\implies 17^{17} \equiv 1^{17} \equiv 1 \pmod {8}$ 
 
 So $f(17) \equiv 17^{17} \equiv 2 \pmod{25} $ 
 
 Thus $\boxed{f(17) \equiv 77 \pmod{100}}$ 
 
 Now $f(18) \equiv 0 \pmod{4} $ 
 
 To evaluate $f(18) \pmod{25} $ we first need to compute $18^{{18}^{18}} \pmod{20} $ 
 
 $18^{{18}^{18}} \equiv 0 \pmod{4}$ and $18^{{18}^{18}} \equiv 1\pmod{5} $ 
 
 $\implies 18^{{18}^{18}} \equiv 16 \pmod{20}$ 
 
 $\implies f(18) \equiv 18^{16} \equiv 1\pmod{25}$ 
 
 $\boxed{f(18) \equiv 76 \pmod{100}}$ 
 
 Now $f(19) \equiv 3\pmod{4}$ and $f(19) \equiv 19^{ 1} \equiv 4\pmod{25} $ 
 
 $\boxed{f(19) \equiv 79\pmod{100}}$ 
 
 And $\boxed{f(20) \equiv 0\pmod{100}}$ 
 
 $\therefore f(17) + f(18) + f(19) + f(20) \equiv 77 + 76 + 79 + 0 \pmod{100} \equiv \boxed{32} \pmod{100}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory B1
text: What is the remainder, in base $10$, when $24_7 + 364_7 + 43_7 + 12_7 + 3_7 + 1_7$ is divided by $6$?
solution: We realize that when a base $7$ digit number is divided by $6$ the remainder is just the sum of the digits $$2+4+3+6+4+4+3+1+2+3+1=33$$ The remainder when $33$ is divided by $6$ is $\boxed{3}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory B5
text: How many integers $n$ are there such that $0 \le n \le 720$ and $n^2 \equiv 1$ (mod $720$)?
solution:
Note that $720=2^4\cdot 3^2\cdot 5=16\cdot 9\cdot 5$ Hence it suffices to find solutions to 
 \begin{align*}
x^2&\equiv 1\pmod{5}\implies x=\{1 4\}\\
x^2&\equiv 1\pmod{9}\implies x=\{1 8\}\\
x^2&\equiv 1\pmod{16}\implies x=\{1 7 9 15\} \\
\end{align*} By the Chinese Remainder Theorem we see that there must be $2\cdot 2\cdot4=\boxed{16}$ total solutions since $0 1 2 \ldots 717 718 719$ forms a complete residue cycle

title: 2008 PUMaC Number Theory B7

Call a polynomial $p$ partial credit if no polynomial of lesser degree is really close to it. What is the maximum possible degree of partial credit?

title: 2008 PUMaC Individual Finals A1
text: Find all positive real numbers $b$ for which there exists a positive real number $k$ such that $n-k \leq \left\lfloor bn \right\rfloor <n$ for all positive integers $n$.
solution:
No such $b$ exists Take $n=1$ to obtain $\left\lfloor b \right\rfloor<1$ and so $b<1$ 
 However if $b<1$ and $k$ is some positive real number we get $\left\lfloor bn \right\rfloor \leq bn<n k$ for large enough $n$

title: 2008 PUMaC Individual Finals A2 / B3
text: A hypergraph consists of a set of vertices $V$ and a set of subsets of those vertices, each of which is called an edge. (Intuitively, it's a graph in which each edge can contain multiple vertices). Suppose that in some hypergraph, no two edges have exactly one vertex in common. Prove that one can color this hypergraph's vertices such that every edge contains both colors of vertices.
solution:
At first we colour the vertices in an arbitrary way Assume we have a monochromatic edge $e$ afterwards wlog let it be blue Take any vertex and colour it red This decreases the amount of monochromatic edges by one It can be seen that no edge $f$ becomes red due to this operation as there are at least two vertices of 
 $f$ which are also vertices of $e$ and so at least one of the vertices is still blue after the operation By repeating this process we eventually get a colouring which has the requested properties

title: 2008 PUMaC Individual Finals B2

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B1
text: Calculate $$\sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 +... }}}+\frac{6}{1+ \frac{6}{1+...}}$$
solution:
Let $A=\sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 + }}}$ and Let $B=\frac{6}{1+ \frac{6}{1+ }}$ We want to find $A+B$ so we will find tha value each of the addends individually $A=\sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 + \sqrt{6 + }}}\implies A=\sqrt{6+A}\implies A^2=6+A$ $\implies A^2 A 6=0$ $\implies A=\frac{1\pm \sqrt{1+24}}{2}$ $\implies A=\frac{1\pm 5}{2}\implies A=3 2$ and because $A$ is clearly positive we have $A=3$ 
 
 $B=\frac{6}{1+ \frac{6}{1+ }}$ $\implies B=\frac{6}{1+B}$ $\implies B+B^2=6\implies B^2+B 6=0\implies $ $B=\frac{ 1\pm \sqrt{1+24}}{2}$ $\implies B=\frac{ 1\pm 5}{2}$ $\implies B=2 3$ and because $B$ is clearly positive we have $B=2$ 
 
 Hence the answer is $3+2=\boxed{5}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B2
solution: By converting all the logs into log base 2 we get $\log_2 3 * \log_3 4 * \log_4 5 * * \log_{62} 63 * \log_{63} 64=\log_2{3}*\frac{\log_2{4}}{\log_2{3}}*\frac{\log_2 5}{\log_2 4}* \frac{\log_2 6}{\log_2 5}* *\frac{\log_2 63}{\log_2 62}*\frac{\log_2 64}{\log_2 63}$ Everything besides the $\log_2 64$ "cancels" so all we are left with is $\log_2 64$ which is equal to $\boxed{6}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B3
text: What is the smallest positive integer value of $x$ for which $x \equiv 4$ (mod $9$) and $x \equiv 7$ (mod $8$)?
solution: By the Chinese Remainder Theorem we have that $x\le 8\cdot 9\implies x\le 72 $ We list out all the $4\pmod 9$ values less than $72$ $4 13 22 31 40 49 58 67$ and then we list all the $7\pmod 8$ value that are less than $72$ $7 15 23 31 39 47 55 63 71$ We see that $31$ is the smallest value that are in both of the sets so the answer is $\boxed{31}$

solution:
By Inspection the median is $44$ and the mean is $\frac{534}{13}$ 
 Thus the positive difference is $\frac{572 547}{13}=\boxed{\frac{25}{13}}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B5
text: Quadrilateral $ABCD$ has both an inscribed and a circumscribed circle and sidelengths $BC = 4, CD = 5, DA = 6$. Find the area of $ABCD$.
solution: Sol Let $AC \cup BD = E$ We have $AB + CD = BC + AD \Rightarrow AB = 5$ This implies $\triangle ABE \cong \triangle DCE$ since $\angle BAC = \angle BDC$ Thus $AC = BD = x$ By Ptolemy $4\cdot 6 + 5^2 = x^2 \Rightarrow x = 7$ Let $\angle ABC = \theta$ LoC now gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{1}{5} \Rightarrow \sin \theta = \frac{2\sqrt{6}}{5}$ So the desired area is $[ABC] + [ADC] = \frac{1}{2}\cdot 4 \cdot 5 \sin \theta + \frac{1}{2} \cdot 5 \cdot 6 \cdot \sin (180 \theta) = 25 \sin \theta = \boxed{10\sqrt{6}}$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B6
text: The seven dwarves are at work on day when they find a large pile of diamonds. They want to split the diamonds evenly among them, but find that they would need to take away one diamond to split into seven equal piles. They are still arguing about this when they get home, so Snow White sends them to bed without supper. In the middle of the night, Sneezy wakes up and decides that he should get the extra diamond. So he puts one diamond aside, splits the remaining ones in to seven equal piles, and takes his pile along with the extra diamond. Then, he runs off with the diamonds. His sneeze wakes up Grumpy, who, thinking along the same lines, removes one diamond, divides the remainder into seven equal piles, and runs off. Finally, Sleepy, for the first time in his life, wakes up before sunrise and performs the same operation. When the remaining four dwarves arise, they find that the remaining diamonds can be split into $5$ equal piles. Doc suggests that Snow White should get a share, so they have no problem splitting the remaining diamonds. Happy, Dopey, Bashful, Doc, and Snow White live happily ever after. What’s the smallest possible number of diamonds that the dwarves could have started out with?

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B7
text: The graphs of the following equations divide the $xy$ plane into some number of regions. $4 + (x + 2)y =x^2$ $(x + 2)^2 + y^2 =16$ Find the area of the second smallest region.
solution:
$$(x + 2)^2 + y^2 = x^2 + 4x + 4 + y^2 = 16$$ and we know that $$4 + (x + 2)y =x^2$$ $$(x + 2)^2 + y^2 = x^2 + 4x + 4 + y^2 = 4 + xy + 2y + 4x + 4 + y^2 = 16$$ If we organize $ xy + 2y + 4x + y^2 = 8$ and $(y+1)^2 + x( y+4 )= 9$ Which means 
 $$ x(y + 4) = (2 y)(y + 4) \rightarrow \text{(If $y \neq 4$)} x = 2 y$$ $$\text{Let's go back to the first equalities and wrote $2 y$ instead of x}$$ $$16 + y^2 8y + y^2 = 16 \rightarrow 2y^2 = 8y \text{ which gives us y = 0 x = 2 and y = 4 x = 2 } $$ $$ \text{If $y = 4$ $x = 2$}$$ $$\text{we have} (x y) \in \boxed{( 2 4)( 2 4)(2 0)} $$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B8
text: Suppose that the roots of the quadratic $x^2 + ax + b$ are $\alpha$ and $\beta$. Then $\alpha^3$ and $\beta^3$ are the roots of some quadratic $x^2 + cx + d$. Find $c$ in terms of $a$ and $b$.
solution:
From vieta we know that $ a = \alpha+\beta $ and $b = \alpha \times\beta$ 
 And again from vieta $ c = \alpha^3+\beta^3$ and $d = (\alpha \times \beta)^3$ 
 So $$ c = \alpha^3+\beta^3 = (\alpha+\beta)^3 3\alpha \times\beta(\alpha+\beta) = a^3+3ab$$ And $$d = (\alpha \times \beta)^3 = b^3$$ $$ c = 3ab a $$

title: 2008 PUMaC Team B9
