text: Given $k \ge 1,$ let $p_k$ denote the $k$-th smallest prime number. If $N$ is the number of ordered $4$-tuples $(a,b,c,d)$ of positive integers satisfying $abcd=\prod_{k=1}^{2023} p_k$ with $a<b$ and $c<d,$ find $N \pmod{1000}.$

title: 2022 PUMaC Number Theory A4 / B6
text: Find the number of ordered pairs $(x,y)$ of integers with $0 \le x < 2023$ and $0 \le y < 2023$ such that $y^3 \equiv x^2 \pmod{2023}.$

title: 2022 PUMaC Number Theory A5 / B7
text: A positive integer $\ell \ge 2$ is called sweet if there exists a positive integer $n \ge 10$ such that when the leftmost nonzero decimal digit of $n$ is deleted, the resulting number $m$ satisfies $n = m\ell.$ Let $S$ denote the set of all sweet numbers $\ell.$ If the sum $\sum_{\ell \in S} \tfrac{1}{\ell-1}$ can be written as $\tfrac{A}{B}$ for relatively prime positive integers $A,B,$ find $A+B.$

title: 2022 PUMaC Number Theory A6 / B8
text: Given a positive integer $\ell,$ define the sequence $\{a^{(\ell)}\}_{n=1}^{\infty}$ such that $a_n^{(\ell)}=\lfloor n + \sqrt[\ell]{n}+\tfrac{1}{2}\rfloor$ for all positive integers $n.$ Let $S$ denote the set of positive integers that appear in all three of the sequences $\{a_n^{(2)} \}_{n=1}^{\infty},$ $\{a_n^{(3)} \}_{n=1}^{\infty},$ and $\{a_n^{(4)} \}_{n=1}^{\infty}.$ Find the sum of the elements of $S$ that lie in the interval $[1,100].$

title: 2022 PUMaC Number Theory A7
text: For a positive integer $n,$ let $f(n)$ be the number of integers $m$ satisfying $0 \le m \le n - 1$ such that there exists an integer solution to the congruence $x^2 \equiv m \pmod{n}.$ It is given that as $k$ goes to $\infty,$ the value of $f(225^k)/225^k$ converges to some rational number $p/q,$ where $p,q$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $p + q.$

title: 2022 PUMaC Number Theory A8
text: For $n \ge 2,$ let $\omega(n)$ denote the number of distinct prime factors of $n.$ We set $\omega(1) = 0.$ Compute the absolute value of $$\sum_{n=1}^{160} (-1)^{\omega(n)} \left\lfloor \frac{160}{n} \right\rfloor.$$

title: 2022 PUMaC Individual Finals B1
text: Let $a, b, c, d$ be real numbers for which $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 = 1$. Show the following inequality: $$a^2 + b^2 - c^2 - d^2 \le \sqrt{2 + 4(ac + bd)}.$$

title: 2022 PUMaC Individual Finals B2
text: Given a triangle $\vartriangle ABC$,construct squares $BAQP$ and $ACRS$ outside the triangle $ABC$ (with vertices in that listed in counterclockwise order).Show that the line from $A$ perpendicular to $BC$ passes through the midpoint of the segment $QS$.
solution: We proceed with coordinate bashing Let $A$ be the origin and let $$B = ( w x) C=(w x) $$ for some $w x y > 0 $ Note that this implies that line $BC$ is parallel with the $x$ axis so the altitude from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$ coincides with the $y$ axis Then it is not difficult to see that $$Q = ( x w) S=(x y) $$ The midpoint of these two points is $$\left(0 \frac{w+y}{2}\right) $$ which obviously lies on the $y$ axis so we are done $\square$

title: 2022 PUMaC Individual Finals A1
text: Let $f: Z_{>0} \to Z_{>0}$ be a function which satisfies $k|f^k(x)-x$ for all $k, x \in Z_{>0}$ and $f(x)-x \le 2023$. If $f(1) = 2000$, what can $f$ be? Remark: Here, $f^k (x)$ denotes the $k$-fold application of $f$ to $x$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Individual Finals A2 / B3
text: Anna and Bob play the following game. In the beginning, Bob writes down the numbers $1, 2,..., 2022$ on a piece of paper, such that half of the numbers are on the left and half on the right. Furthermore, we assume that the $1011$ numbers on both sides are written in some order. After Bob does this, Anna has the opportunity to swap the positions of the two numbers lying on different sides of the paper if they have different parity. Anna wins if, after finitely many moves, all odd numbers end up on the left, in increasing order, and all even ones end up on the right, in increasing order. Can Bob write down a arrangement of numbers for which Anna cannot win? For example, Bob could write down numbers in the following way: $$4, 2, 5, 7, 9,..., 2021\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,,\, \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,,\, 3, 1, 6, 8, 10,..., 2022$$Then Anna could swap the numbers $1, 4$ and then swap $2, 3$ to win. However, if Anna swapped the pairs $3, 4$ and $1, 2$, the resulting numbers on the left and on the right would not be in increasing order, and hence Anna would not win.
solution: Bob can do this if $2022$ is replaced for $2n$ for any $n \geq 2$ Turn the numbers into a single permutation $a_1 \ldots a_{2022}$ of $[2n]$ by reading off the first number on the left then the first number on the right then the second number on the left and so on Thus $1 2$ on the left and $3 4$ on the right would become $1 3 2 4$ (here $n=2$ ) Then the swapping process corresponds to picking two opposite parity elements whose positions are also opposite parity and switching them so $1 3 2 4 \to 2 3 1 4$ is illegal but $1 3 2 4 \to 4 3 2 1$ is legal Then it is easy to verify that the number of same parity inversions—i e the number of pairs $i<j$ such that $a_i>a_j$ and $a_i \equiv a_j \pmod{2}$ — has invariant parity whenever we swap $a_i$ and $a_j$ the number of same parity inversions among $(i k)$ and $(k j)$ for $i<k<j$ changes by $\pm 1$ Since there are an even number of such $k$ the result follows The desired final state has $0$ same parity inversions On the other hand the starting state $3 2 1 4 5 6 7 8 \ldots$ has $1$ same parity inversion so starting with $3 1 5 7 9 \ldots$ on the left and $2 4 6 8 10 \ldots$ on the right will make Anna unable to win

title: 2022 PUMaC Individual Finals A3
text: Let $n$ be a positive integer. We call a $n$-tuple $(a_1,..., a_n)$ of positive integers nice if $\bullet$ $gcd (a_1,..., a_n) = 1$, and $\bullet$ $a_i|a_{i-1} + a_{i+1}$, for all $i = 1,..., n$ (we define $a_0 = a_n$ and $a_{n+1} = a1$ here). Find the maximal possible value of the sum $a_1 +...+ a_n$ if $(a_1,..., a_n)$ is a nice $n$-tuple.
solution:
Let $\{F_n\}$ denote the Fibonacci sequence with $F_0=F_1=1$ and $F_n=F_{n 1}+F_{n 2}$ for $n \geq 2$ The answer is then $F_{n+2} 2$ 
 
 Consider an $n$ tuple of positive integers and consider some maximal element $a_i$ such that $a_{i 1}$ isn't maxima Then we must have $a_i=a_{i 1}+a_{i+1}$ Now suppose we delete $a_i$ I claim the result is $(n 1)$ nice Indeed $a_{i+1} \equiv a_i \pmod{a_{i 1}}$ so $a_{i 1} \mid a_{i 2}+a_i \implies a_{i 1} \mid a_{i 2}+a_{i+1}$ Likewise $a_{i+1} \mid a_{i 1}+a_{i+2}$ Moreover by the Euclidean algorithm we have 
 $$1=\gcd(a_1 \ldots a_{i 1} a_{i 1}+a_{i+1} a_i \ldots a_n)=\gcd(a_1 \ldots a_{i 1} 0 a_{i+1} \ldots a_n)=\gcd(a_1 \ldots a_{i 1} a_{i+1} \ldots a_n) $$ so the claim is true unless no such $i$ exists In this case the $n$ tuple is clearly all $1$ ' s due to the gcd condition (every element is maximal) in which case the claim still holds so it's true in general I now claim that for $n \geq 2$ the maximal element of an $n$ tuple is at most $F_n$ and the second largest element is at most $F_{n 1}$ This follows by induction first off the only good $1$ tuple is $(1)$ so the only good $2$ tuples are $(1 2)$ and $(1 1)$ up to cyclic permutations thus the claim is true for $n=2$ Now if the claim is true for $n$ it immediately follows that the maximal element of a good $(n+1)$ tuple $T$ is at most $F_{n+1}$ since it's the sum of two elements of the $n$ tuple $T'$ obtained by deleting it Furthermore the second largest element of $T$ is still in $T'$ so it's at most $F_n$ 
 
 By successively deleting maximal elements and applying the above claim it follows that the maximum value of $a_1+\cdots+a_n$ is $F_1+\cdots+F_n$ By induction it is easy to show that this equals $F_{n+2} 2$ so we're done $\blacksquare$

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #1
text: Have $b, c \in R$ satisfy $b \in (0, 1)$ and $c > 0$, then let $A,B$ denote the points of intersection of the line $y = bx+c$ with $y = |x|$, and let $O$ denote the origin of $R^2$. Let $f(b, c)$ denote the area of triangle $\vartriangle OAB$. Let $k_0 = \frac{1}{2022}$, and for $n \ge 1$ let $k_n = k^2_{n-1}$. If the sum $\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}f(k_n, k_{n-1})$ can be written as $\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$, find the remainder when $p+q$ is divided by 1000.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #2
text: A triangle $\vartriangle A_0A_1A_2$ in the plane has sidelengths $A_0A_1 = 7$,$A_1A_2 = 8$,$A_2A_0 = 9$. For $i \ge 0$, given $\vartriangle A_iA_{i+1}A_{i+2}$, let $A_{i+3}$ be the midpoint of $A_iA_{i+1}$ and let Gi be the centroid of $\vartriangle A_iA_{i+1}A_{i+2}$. Let point $G$ be the limit of the sequence of points $\{G_i\}^{\infty}_{i=0}$. If the distance between $G$ and $G_0$ can be written as $\frac{a\sqrt{b}}{c}$, where $a, b, c$ are positive integers such that $a$ and $c$ are relatively prime and $b$ is not divisible by the square of any prime, find $a^2 + b^2 + c^2$.
solution:
Note that $A_3=\frac 12(A_0+A_1)$ $A_4=\frac 12(A_1+A_2)$ $A_5=\frac 14(A_0+A_1+2A_2)$ and $A_6=\frac 14(A_0+2A_1+A_2)$ Computing $A_4 A_5 A_5 A_6 A_6 A_4$ we see that $\triangle A_4A_5A_6$ is similar to $A_0A_1A_2$ From here it is clear that $G$ is simply the center of homothety of these triangles (the scaling factor to get from one triangle to the next is $ \frac 14$ ) 
 
 It's well known that the centroid $G_0$ of $\triangle A_0A_1A_2$ divides the median $A_0A_4$ in the ratio $1 2$ while the above discussion shows that $G$ divides this median in the ratio $1 4$ Thus \[
|G_0G|=\frac 13|A_0A_4| \frac 15|A_0A_4|=\frac 2{15}|A_0A_4|=\frac 2{15}\sqrt{\frac 12(7^2+9^2) \frac 14\cdot 8^2}=\frac{14}{15} \] Hence $a=14 b=1 c=15$ giving a final answer of $422$

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #3
text: Provided that $\{a_i\}^{28}_{i=1}$ are the $28$ distinct roots of $29x^{28} + 28x^{27} +... + 2x + 1 = 0$, then the absolute value of $\sum^{28}_{i=1}\frac{1}{(1-a_i)^2}$ can be written as $\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$. Find $p + q$.
solution:
Very Painful Let $\{a_i\}^{28}_{i=1}$ be the $28$ distinct roots of $f(x) = 29x^{28} + 28x^{27} + + 2x + 1 = 0$ 
 
 Then $f(x) = 29\left(\prod_{i = 1}^{28} (x a_i)\right)$ 
 
 $\implies \ln(f(x)) = \ln(29) + \sum_{i=1}^{28} \ln(x a_i)$ where $\ln (x) = \log_{e} (x)$ 
 
 On differentiating both sides wrt $x$ we get 
 
 $\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} = \sum_{i = 1}^{28} \frac{1}{x a_i}$ 
 
 Again on differentiating both sides wrt $x$ we get 
 
 $\frac{f(x) f''(x) (f'(x))^2}{(f(x))^2} = \sum_{i=1}^{28} \frac{ 1}{(x a_i)^2}$ 
 
 On plugging $x = 1$ in the above equation we get 
 
 $\sum_{i=1}^{28} \frac{1}{(1 a_i)^2} = \frac{(f'(1))^2 f(1) f''(1)}{(f(1))^2}$ 
 
 Now $f(1) = \sum_{r = 1}^{29} r = \frac{29 30}{2} = 435$ 
 
 and $f'(1) = \sum_{r=1}^{28} r(r + 1) = \frac{1}{3}\left(\sum_{r=1}^{28} r(r + 1)(r + 2) (r 1)r(r + 1)\right) = \frac{28 29 30}{3} = 28 29 10$ 
 
 also $f''(1) = \sum_{r = 1}^{27} r(r + 1)(r + 2) = \frac{1}{4}\left(\sum_{r=1}^{27} r(r + 1)(r + 2)(r + 3) (r 1)r(r + 1)(r + 2)\right) = \frac{27 28 29 30}{4} = 27 7 29 30$ 
 
 $\implies \sum_{i=1}^{28} \frac{1}{(1 a_i)^2} = \frac{14 19}{9} = \frac{266}{9}$ 
 
 $\therefore p + q = 266 + 9 = \boxed{\textcolor{red}{275}}$

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #4
text: Patty is standing on a line of planks playing a game. Define a block to be a sequence of adjacent planks, such that both ends are not adjacent to any planks. Every minute, a plank chosen uniformly at random from the block that Patty is standing on disappears, and if Patty is standing on the plank, the game is over. Otherwise, Patty moves to a plank chosen uniformly at random within the block she is in; note that she could end up at the same plank from which she started. If the line of planks begins with $n$ planks, then for sufficiently large n, the expected number of minutes Patty lasts until the game ends (where the first plank disappears a minute after the game starts) can be written as $P(1/n)f(n) + Q(1/n)$, where $P,Q$ are polynomials and $f(n) =\sum^n_{i=1}\frac{1}{i}$. Find $P(2023) + Q(2023)$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #5
text: You’re given the complex number $\omega = e^{2i\pi/13} + e^{10i\pi/13} + e^{16i\pi/13} + e^{24i\pi/13}$, and told it’s a root of a unique monic cubic $x^3 +ax^2 +bx+c$, where $a, b, c$ are integers. Determine the value of $a^2 + b^2 + c^2$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #6
text: A sequence of integers $x_1, x_2,...$ is double-dipped if $x_{n+2} = ax_{n+1} + bx_n$ for all $n \ge 1$ and some fixed integers $a, b$. Ri begins to form a sequence by randomly picking three integers from the set $\{1, 2,..., 12\}$, with replacement. It is known that if Ri adds a term by picking anotherelement at random from $\{1, 2,..., 12\}$, there is at least a $\frac13$ chance that his resulting four-term sequence forms the beginning of a double-dipped sequence. Given this, how many distinct three-term sequences could Ri have picked to begin with?

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #7
text: Pick $x, y, z$ to be real numbers satisfying $(-x+y+z)^2-\frac13 = 4(y-z)^2$, $(x-y+z)^2-\frac14 = 4(z-x)2$, and $(x+y-z)^2 -\frac15 = 4(x-y)^2$. If the value of $xy+yz +zx$ can be written as $\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$, find $p + q$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #8
text: Ryan Alweiss storms into the Fine Hall common room with a gigantic eraser and erases all integers $n$ in the interval $[2, 728]$ such that $3^t$ doesn’t divide $n!$, where $t = \left\lceil \frac{n-3}{2} \right\rceil$. Find the sum of the leftover integers in that interval modulo $1000$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #9
text: In the complex plane, let $z_1, z_2, z_3$ be the roots of the polynomial $p(x) = x^3- ax^2 + bx - ab$. Find the number of integers $n$ between $1$ and $500$ inclusive that are expressible as $z^4_1 +z^4_2 +z^4_3$ for some choice of positive integers $a, b$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #10
text: Let $\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in C$ be the roots of the polynomial $x^3 - 3x2 + 3x + 7$. For any complex number $z$, let $f(z)$ be defined as follows: $$f(z) = |z -\alpha | + |z - \beta|+ |z-\gamma | - 2 \underbrace{\max}_{w \in \{\alpha, \beta, \gamma}\} |z - w|.$$Let $A$ be the area of the region bounded by the locus of all $z \in C$ at which $f(z)$ attains its global minimum. Find $\lfloor A \rfloor$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #11
text: For the function $$ g(a) = \underbrace{\max}_{x\in R} \left\{ \cos x + \cos \left(x + \frac{\pi}{6} \right)+ \cos \left(x + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) + cos(x + a) \right\},$$let $b \in R$ be the input that maximizes $g$. If $\cos^2 b = \frac{m+\sqrt{n}+\sqrt{p}-\sqrt{q}}{24}$ for positive integers $m, n, p, q$, find $m + n + p + q$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #12
text: Observe the set $S =\{(x, y) \in Z^2: |x| \le 5$ and $-10 \le y\le 0\}$. Find the number of points $P$ in $S$ such that there exists a tangent line from $P$ to the parabola $y = x^2 + 1$ that can be written in the form $y = mx + b$, where $m$ and $b$ are integers.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #13
text: Of all functions $h: Z_{>0} \to Z_{\ge 0}$, choose one satisfying $h(ab) = ah(b) + bh(a)$ for all $a, b \in Z_{>0}$ and $h(p) = p$ for all prime numbers $p$. Find the sum of all positive integers $n\le 100$ such that $h(n) = 4n$.

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #14
text: Let $\vartriangle ABC$ be a triangle. Let $Q$ be a point in the interior of $\vartriangle ABC$, and let $X, Y,Z$ denote the feet of the altitudes from $Q$ to sides $BC$, $CA$, $AB$, respectively. Suppose that $BC = 15$, $\angle ABC = 60^o$, $BZ = 8$, $ZQ = 6$, and $\angle QCA = 30^o$. Let line $QX$ intersect the circumcircle of $\vartriangle XY Z$ at the point $W\ne X$. If the ratio $\frac{ WY}{WZ}$ can be expressed as $\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$, find $p + q$.
solution:
PUMAC thinks they are so special to make an April fools joke! 
 
 We have $\frac{WZ}{\sin \angle{ZXW}}=\frac{WY}{\sin \angle{WXY}}$ We can see $\angle{ZXW}=\angle{ZBQ} \angle{WXY}=\angle{QCY}$ 
 
 Thus the desired ratio is merely $\frac{\sin \angle{QCA}}{\sin \angle{ZBY}}=\frac{5}{6}\implies \boxed{11}$

title: 2022 PUMaC Team #15
text: Subsets $S$ of the first 3$5$ positive integers $\{1, 2, 3,..., 35\}$ are called contrived if $S$ has size $4$ and the sum of the squares of the elements of $S$ is divisible by $7$. Find the number of contrived sets.
solution:
First note that the quadratic residues modulo $7$ are $0 1 2 $ and $4 $ The residue classes that give these quadratic residues are $\{0\} $ $\{1 6\} $ $\{3 4\} $ and $\{2 5\} $ respectively so it follows that the number of positive integers in the set $\{1 2 \ldots 35\}$ whose square leaves a remainder of $0 1 2 $ or $4$ modulo $7$ are $5 10 10 $ and $10 $ respectively Now it is a matter of figuring out which combinations of $4$ numbers $a b c d$ in which $a b c d \in \{0 1 2 4\}$ satisfy $$a+b+c+d \equiv 0 \pmod{7} $$ Through careful casework we get $(a b c d) \in \{(0 0 0 0) (0 1 2 4) (1 2 2 2) (1 1 1 4) (2 4 4 4)\}$ (up to permutation) Therefore the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
\binom{5}{4} + 5 \cdot 10 \cdot 10 \cdot 10 + 10 \cdot \binom{10}{3} + \binom{10}{3} \cdot 10 + 10 \cdot \binom{10}{3} &= 5 + 5000 + 3 \cdot 10 \cdot 120 \\
&= 5005 + 3600 \\
&= \boxed{8605} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra B1
text: Let $x, y$ be distinct positive real numbers satisfying $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{x + y} -\sqrt{x - y}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x + y} +\sqrt{x - y}} =\frac{x}{\sqrt{y^3}}.$$If $\frac{x}{y} =\frac{a+\sqrt{b}}{c}$ for positive integers $a, b, c$ with $gcd (a, c) = 1$, find $a + b + c$.
solution:
we get $\frac{\sqrt{x+y}}{y}=\frac{x}{y\sqrt{y}}\implies \sqrt{a+1}=a$ where $a=\frac{x}{y}$ 
 
 which gives $a=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2} \implies a+b+c=\boxed{8}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra B2
text: Kris is asked to compute $\log_{10} (x^y)$, where $y$ is a positive integer and $x$ is a positive real number. However, they misread this as $(\log_{10} x)^y$, and compute this value. Despite the reading error, Kris still got the right answer. Given that $x > 10^{1.5}$, determine the largest possible value of $y$.
solution:
Let $x^y$ = $a$ $\log_{10} (x)$ = $\log (a)$ $\frac{1}{y}$ 
 Therefore by question $\log_{10} (a)$ = $(\log (a)$ $\frac{1}{y})^y$ 
 $(\log(a))^{1 y}$ = $\frac{1}{y^y}$ Then we have $(\log(x))^{1 y}$ = $\frac{1}{y}$ and 
 hence $\log_{10} (x)$ = $y^{1/(y 1)}$ which is greater than 1 5 according to the question $y^{1/(y 1)}$ $>$ $3/2$ $\log (3/2)$ $\approx$ $0 176$ 
 And $\log (5)$ $\approx$ $0 699$ 
 Hence by putting in LHS we get $0 174$ which is very close to $0 176$ but less Therefore $y_{max}$ should be just less than 5 that's 4 (as $y$ is integer)

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A1 / B3
text: Compute the sum of all real numbers x which satisfy the following equation $$\frac {8^x - 19 \cdot 4^x}{16 - 25 \cdot 2^x}= 2$$
solution:
set $a=2^{x}$ 
 
 we get the equation tranforms to $\frac{a^3 19a^2}{16 25a}=2$ 
 
 $a^3 19a^2+50a 32=0\implies (a 1)(a 2)(a 16)=0\implies a=1 2 16\implies x=0 1 4$ 
 
 sum of all such $x=\boxed{5}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A2 / B4
text: For a bijective function $g: R \to R$, we say that a function $f: R \to R$ is its superinverse if it satisfies the following identity $(f \circ g)(x) = g^{-1}(x)$, where $g^{-1}$ is the inverse of $g$. Given $g(x) = x^3 + 9x^2 + 27x + 81$ and $f$ is its superinverse, find $|f(-289)|$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A3 / B5
text: Let $f(x) = 1 + 2x + 3x^2 + 4x^3 + 5x^4$ and let $\zeta = e^{2\pi i/5} = \cos \frac{2\pi}{5} + i \sin \frac{2\pi}{5}$. Find the value of the following expression: $$f(\zeta)f(\zeta^2)f(\zeta^3)f(\zeta^4).$$
solution:
Let $g(x) = x(1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + x^4) $ then $f(x) = g'(x)$ 
 Therefore we have $g(x) = \frac{x^6 x}{x 1}$ and $g'(x) = \frac{5x^6 6x^5 + 1}{(x 1)^2}$ 
 Now we have $f(x) = 1 +2x + 3x^2 + 4x^3 + 5x^4 = \frac{5x^6 6x^5 + 1}{(x 1)^2} = g'(x)$ 
 $f(\zeta) = \frac{5\zeta^6 6\zeta^5 + 1}{(\zeta 1)^2} = \frac{1 6+5\zeta}{(1 \zeta)^{2}}=\frac{ 5+5\zeta}{(1 \zeta)^{2}}=\frac{ 5}{1 \zeta}$ 
 $f(\zeta^2)=\frac{ 5}{1 \zeta^{2}}$ and $f(\zeta^3)=\frac{ 5}{1 \zeta^{3}}$ and $f(\zeta^4)=\frac{ 5}{1 \zeta^{4}}$ 
 $T=f(\zeta)f(\zeta^2)f(\zeta^3)f(\zeta^4)=\frac{625}{(1 \zeta)(1 \zeta^{2})(1 \zeta^{3})(1 \zeta^{4})}$ 
 $ T = \frac{625}{5}$ because $\prod_{i=1}^5 (1 \zeta^i)=P(1)$ where $P(x)=1+x+x^2+x^3+x^4$ 
 $T=f(\zeta)f(\zeta^2)f(\zeta^3)f(\zeta^4)= 125$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A4 / B6
text: The roots of a monic cubic polynomial $p$ are positive real numbers forming a geometric sequence. Suppose that the sum of the roots is equal to $10$. Under these conditions, the largest possible value of $|p(-1)|$ can be written as $\frac{m}{n}$, where $m$, $n$ are relatively prime integers. Find $m + n$.
solution:
The condition that the roots form a geometric sequence is completely useless because "all numbers equal" is a geometric sequence Let $r_1$ $r_2$ and $r_3$ be the roots of $p$ so $r_1 + r_2 + r_3 = 10$ Then 
 \[
|p( 1)| = (1+r_1)(1+r_2)(1+r_3) \leq \left(\frac{3+r_1+r_2+r_3}3\right)^3 = \left(\frac{13}3\right)^3 = \frac{2197}{27} \] The requested answer is $2197 + 27 = \boxed{2224}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A5 / B7
text: Consider the sum $$S =\sum^{2021}_{j=1} \left|\sin \frac{2\pi j}{2021}\right|.$$The value of $S$ can be written as $\tan \left( \frac{c\pi}{d} \right)$ for some relatively prime positive integers $c, d$, satisfying $2c < d$. Find the value of $c + d$.
solution:
Ignore $j=2021$ since that term equals to $0$ 
 
 Due to absolute value we can rewrite $\frac{S}{2}=\sum_{j=1}^{1010}\sin \frac{2\pi j}{2021}$ 
 
 It is the imaginary part of $\sum_{j=1}^{1010} e^\frac{ i\cdot 2\pi j}{2021}$ 
 
 By geometric sequence we attain $\sum_{j=1}^{1010} e^\frac{ i\cdot 2\pi j}{2021}= \frac{e^{\frac{i \pi}{2021}}+e^{\frac{2i \pi}{2021}}}{e^{\frac{2i \pi}{2021}} 1}$ 
 
 By difference of squares it is equivalent to $ \frac{e^{\frac{i \pi}{2021}}}{e^{\frac{i \pi}{2021}} 1}$ 
 
 In order to find the imaginary part we can add one then subtract one in the numerator such that we only need to find the imaginary part of $\frac{1}{1 e^{\frac{i\pi}{2021}}}$ Let $\frac{\pi}{2021}=x$ the expression after expanding is equivalent to 
 
 $\frac{1 \cos x+i\sin x}{2 2\cos x}$ The imaginary part is $\frac{\sin x}{2 2\cos x}=\cot \frac{x}{2}$ 
 
 Thus the desired value is $\frac{\pi}{2} \frac{\pi}{4042}=\tan \frac{1010\pi}{2021}$ leads to $\boxed{3031}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A6 / B8
text: Let $f$ be a polynomial. We say that a complex number $p$ is a double attractor if there exists a polynomial $h(x)$ so that $f(x)-f(p) = h(x)(x-p)^2$ for all x \in R. Now, consider the polynomial $$f(x) = 12x^5 - 15x^4 - 40x^3 + 540x^2 - 2160x + 1,$$and suppose that it’s double attractors are $a_1, a_2,..., a_n$. If the sum $\sum^{n}_{i=1}|a_i|$ can be written as $\sqrt{a} +\sqrt{b}$, where $a, b$ are positive integers, find $a + b$.
solution:
This is pretty cool the double attractors are just the roots of $f'(x)$ The derivative if 
 \[ 60x^4 60x^3 120x^2 + 1080x 2160 = 60 (x 2)(x+3)(x^2 2x+6) \] Hence the possible attractors are $2 3 1 \pm \sqrt{5}i$ Hence the sum of the magnitudes is $\sqrt{25}+\sqrt{24}$ which comes out to $\boxed{49}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A7
text: Consider the following expression $$S = \log_2 \left( \sum^{2019}_{k=1}\sum^{2020}_{j=2}\log_{2^{1/k}} (j) \log_{j^2} \left(\sin \frac{\pi k}{2020}\right) \right).$$Find the smallest integer $n$ which is bigger than $S$ (i.e. find $\lceil S \rceil$).

title: 2021 PUMaC Algebra A8
text: Consider the sequence of Fibonacci numbers $F_0, F_1, F_2,... $, given by $F_0 = F_1= 1$ and $F_{n+1} =F_n + F_{n-1}$ for $n\ge 1$. Define the sequence $x_0, x_1, x_2,....$ by $x_0 = 1$ and $x_{k+1} = x^2_k + F^2_{2^k}$ for $k \ge 0$. Define the sequence $y_0, y_1, y_2,...$ by $y_0 = 1$ and $y_{k+1} = 2x_ky_k - y^2_k$ for $k \ge 0$. If $$\sum^{\infty}_{k=0} \frac{1}{y_k}= \frac{a -\sqrt{b}}{c}$$for positive integers a$, b, c$ with $gcd (a, c) = 1$, find $a + b + c$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics B1
text: A nonempty word is called pronounceable if it alternates in vowels (A, E, I, O, U) and consonants (all other letters) and it has at least one vowel. How many pronounceable words can be formed using the letters P, U, M, A, C at most once each? Words of length shorter than $5$ are allowed.
solution:
We proceed with casework on the number of letters in the word 1 Obviously the total for this case is just $\underline{2} $ 
 
 2 There are $2$ ways to choose which vowel is used $3$ ways to choose which consonant is used and then $2$ ways to permute the letters for a total of $$2 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 = \underline{12} $$ 
 3 If the word has two vowels then there are $3$ ways to pick which consonant is used and then $2$ ways to permute the vowels which yields $2 \cdot 3 = 6 $ On the other hand if there are two consonants then there are $3$ ways to pick the consonants that are used $2$ ways to choose which vowel is used and then $2$ ways to permute the consonants which yields $3\cdot2\cdot2=12 $ Therefore the total for this case is $$6+12=\underline{18} $$ 
 4 There are $2$ ways to choose which way the letters alternate $3$ ways to choose which consonants are used $2$ ways to permute the vowels and $2$ ways to permute the consonants so the total for this case is $$2 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 = \underline{24} $$ 
 5 The total for this case is just 
 \begin{align*}
3!\cdot2! &= 6 \cdot 2 \\
&= \underline{12} \end{align*} 
 Hence adding up the totals from these five cases yields $$2+12+18+24+12=\boxed{68} $$ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics B2
text: Neel and Roshan are going to the Newark Liberty International Airport to catch separate flights. Neel plans to arrive at some random time between 5:30 am and 6:30 am, while Roshan plans to arrive at some random time between 5:40 am and 6:40 am. The two want to meet, however briefly, before going through airport security. As such, they agree that each will wait for $n$ minutes once he arrives at the airport before going through security. What is the smallest $n$ they can select such that they meet with at least 50% probability? The answer will be of the form $a + b\sqrt{c}$ for integers $a$, $b$, and $c$, where $c$ has no perfect square factor other than $1$. Report $a + b + c.$
solution:
If we interpret this problem with geometric probability we easily see that if we let the total possible region of arrival times be a square with side length $60 $ then the region within that square where they meet has area $$\frac{(50 n)^2}{2}+\frac{(70 n)^2}{2} $$ Hence we get 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{(50 n)^2}{2}+\frac{(70 n)^2}{2} \ge \frac{60^2}{2} &\implies n^2 100n+2500+n^2 140n+4900 \ge 3600 \\
&\implies n^2 120n+900 \ge 0 \\
&\implies n \in \left( \infty 60 10\sqrt{17}\right] \cup \left[60+10\sqrt{17} \infty \right) \end{align*} Clearly we can't have $n \ge 60+10\sqrt{17} $ so it follows that $$n \le 60 10\sqrt{17} $$ Therefore the answer is $$60+( 10)+17=\boxed{67} $$ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A1/B3
text: Select two distinct diagonals at random from a regular octagon. What is the probability that the two diagonals intersect at a point strictly within the octagon? Express your answer as $a + b$, where the probability is $\tfrac{a}{b}$ and $a$ and $b$ are relatively prime positive integers.
solution:
Solved with kootrapali 
 
 The key is to realize there is only 1 way for them to intersect given any 4 vertices But then the answer is just $\frac{\binom 8 4}{\binom{20}{2}}=\boxed{\frac{7}{19}}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A2/B4
text: Eighteen people are standing in a (socially-distanced) line to enter a grocery store. Five people are wearing a black mask, $6$ are wearing a gray mask, and $7$ are wearing a white mask. Suppose that these $18$ people got on line in a random order. The expected number of pairs of adjacent people wearing different-colored masks can be given by $\tfrac{a}{b}$, where $\gcd(a, b) = 1$. Compute $a+b$.
solution:
Clearly the probability that an arbitrary pair of adjacent people are wearing different colored masks is just 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{5\cdot6+6\cdot7+7\cdot5}{\binom{18}{2}} &= \frac{30+42+35}{153} \\
&= \frac{107}{153} \end{align*} Therefore since there are $17$ pairs of adjacent people by Linearity of Expectation the desired expected value is 
 \begin{align*}
17 \cdot \frac{107}{153} \\
&= \frac{107}{9} \end{align*} Hence the answer is $$107+9=\boxed{116} $$ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A3/B5
text: Nelson is having his friend drop his unique bouncy ball from a $12$ foot building, and Nelson will only catch the ball at the peak of its trajectory between bounces. On any given bounce, there is an $80\%$ chance that the next peak occurs at $\frac13$ the height of the previous peak and a $20\%$ chance that the next peak occurs at $3$ times the height of the previous peak (where the first peak is at $12$ feet). If Nelson can only reach $4$ feet into the air and will catch the ball as soon as possible, the probability that Nelson catches the ball after exactly $13$ bounces is $2^a \times 3^b \times 5^c \times 7^d \times 11^e$ for integers $a, b, c, d$, and $e$. Find $|a| + |b| + |c| + |d| + |e|$.
solution:
Let a small bounce be one that brings the ball to a peak which is $\tfrac{1}{3}$ as high as the previous peak and let a big bounce be one that brings the ball to a peak that is $3$ times as high as the previous peak Since the ball reaches a peak of $4$ feet for the first time on the $13$ t h bounce it follows that the last bounce must have been a small one and the first $12$ bounces must have been $6$ small bounces and $6$ big bounces in some order in which at no point was there more small bounces that happened than large bounces Hence if we let $C_n$ denote the $n$ t h Catalan number then the desired probability is 
 \begin{align*}
C_6 \cdot \left(\frac{4}{5}\right)^7 \cdot \left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^6 &= 132 \cdot \frac{4^7}{5^13} \\
&= \frac{2^2 \cdot 3 \cdot 11 \cdot 2^{14}}{5^{13}} \\
&= \frac{2^{16} \cdot 3 \cdot 11}{5^{13}} \\
&= 2^{16} \cdot 3^1 \cdot 5^{ 13} \cdot 7^0 \cdot 11^1 \end{align*} It follows that the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
|16|+|1|+| 13|+|0|+|1| &= 16+1+13+1 \\
&= \boxed{31} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A4/B6
text: There are n lilypads in a row labeled $1, 2, \dots, n$ from left to right. Fareniss the Frog picks a lilypad at random to start on, and every second she jumps to an adjacent lilypad; if there are two such lilypads, she is twice as likely to jump to the right as to the left. After some finite number of seconds, there exists two lilypads $A$ and $B$ such that Fareniss is more than $1000$ times as likely to be on $A$ as she is to be on $B$. What is the minimal number of lilypads $n$ such that this situation must occur?

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A5/B7
text: A Princeton slot machine has $100$ pictures, each equally likely to occur. One is a picture of a tiger. Alice and Bob independently use the slot machine, and each repeatedly makes independent plays. Alice keeps playing until she sees a tiger, at which point she stops. Similarly, Bob keeps playing until he sees a tiger. Given that Bob plays twice as much as Alice, let the expected number of plays for Alice be $\tfrac{a}{b}$ with $a, b$ relatively prime positive integers. Find the remainder when $a + b$ is divided by $1000$.
solution:
We wish to find 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k\left(\tfrac{99}{100}\right)^{k 1}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)\left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{2k 1}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)}{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(\tfrac{99}{100}\right)^{k 1}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)\left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{2k 1}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)} &= \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k\left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{3k 2}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^2}{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{3k 2}\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^2} \\
&= \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k \left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{3k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^{3k}} \end{align*} Thus if we let $r=\left(\tfrac{99}{100}\right)^3 $ then we wish to find $$\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} kr^k}{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k} $$ Using the infinite arithmetico geometric and infinite geometric series formulas gives us 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} kr^k}{\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k} &= \frac{\frac{r}{(1 r)^2}}{\frac{r}{1 r}} \\
&= \frac{1}{1 r} \end{align*} Hence the expected number of plays for Alice is 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{1}{1 \left(\frac{99}{100}\right)^3} &= \frac{1}{1 \frac{99^3}{100^3}} \\
&= \frac{100^3}{100^3 99^3} \end{align*} so the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
a+b &= 100^3+100^3 99^3 \\
&\equiv 99^3 \\
&= 970299 \\
&\equiv 299 \\
&\equiv \boxed{701} \pmod{1000} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A6/B8
text: Alice, Bob, and Carol are playing a game. Each turn, one of them says one of the $3$ players' names, chosen from {Alice, Bob, Carol} uniformly at random. Alice goes first, Bob goes second, Carol goes third, and they repeat in that order. Let $E$ be the expected number of names that are have been said when, for the first time, all $3$ names have been said twice. If $E = \tfrac{m}{n}$ for relatively prime positive integers $m$ and $n$, find $m + n$. (Include the last name to be said twice in your count.)
solution:
Let $E_{X Y Z}$ be the expected number of more names that need to be said until each name was said at least twice for nonnegative integers $X Y Z $ not all three greater than $1 $ where the number of times that each name has been said is $X Y $ and $Z$ in some order We wish to find $E_{0 0 0} $ 
 
 Proceeding recursively starting at $E_{2 2 1}$ and going back we eventually get that $$E_{0 0 0}=\frac{347}{36} $$ which results in an answer of $347+36=\boxed{383} $ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A7
text: Cassidy has string of $n$ bits, where $n$ is a positive integer, which initially are all $0$s or $1$s. Every second, Cassidy may choose to do one of two things: 1. Change the first bit (so the first bit changes from a $0$ to a $1$, or vice versa) 2. Change the first bit after the first $1$. Let $M$ be the minimum number of such moves it takes to get from $1\dots 1$ to $0 \dots 0$ (both of length $12$), and $N$ the number of starting sequences with $12$ bits that Cassidy can turn into all $0$s. Find $M + N$.
solution:
We will construct a new binary string $T$ from the binary string described in the problem which we will call $S$ as follows the $i$ th bit of $T$ is 1 if and only if the suffix of $S$ consisting of the $i$ th to $n$ th bits (inclusive) contains an odd number of 1's The given operation on $S$ reduces to the following operation on $T$ either flip the first bit (as before) or flip a prefix of bits up to and including the leftmost bit that differs from the first bit This is equivalent to the following reading $T$ as a binary number where the leftmost bit is least significant either increment or decrement $T$ by 1 Now the problem is much easier $M$ will just be the starting value of the binary number formed by $T$ which will be $101010101010_2 = 2 + 8 + 32 + 128 + 512 + 2048 = 2730$ (note that when we actually write the binary number out by convention the rightmost bit is least significant) In addition all $2^{12} = 4096$ configurations of $T$ are reachable so all 4096 configurations of $S$ are reachable and $N = 4096$ 
 
 The requested sum is $2730 + 4096 = \boxed{6826}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Combinatorics A8
text: Physicists at Princeton are trying to analyze atom entanglement using the following experiment. Originally there is one atom in the space and it starts splitting according to the following procedure. If after $n$ minutes there are atoms $a_1, \dots, a_N$, in the following minute every atom $a_i$ splits into four new atoms, $a_i^{(1)},a_i^{(2)},a_i^{(3)},a_i^{(4)}$. Atoms $a_i^{(j)}$ and $a_k^{(j)}$ are entangled if and only the atoms $a_i$ and $a_k$ were entangled after $n$ minutes. Moreover, atoms $a_i^{(j)}$ and $a_k^{(j+1)}$ are entangled for all $1 \le i$, $k \le N$ and $j = 1$, $2$, $3$. Therefore, after one minute there is $4$ atoms, after two minutes there are $16$ atoms and so on. Physicists are now interested in the number of unordered quadruplets of atoms $\{b_1, b_2, b_3, b_4\}$ among which there is an odd number of entanglements. What is the number of such quadruplets after $3$ minutes? Remark. Note that atom entanglement is not transitive. In other words, if atoms $a_i$, $a_j$ are entangled and if $a_j$, $a_k$ are entangled, this does not necessarily mean that $a_i$ and $a_k$ are entangled.

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry B2
text: A right cylinder is given with a height of $20$ and a circular base of radius $5$. A vertical planar cut is made into this base of radius $5$. A vertical planar cut, perpendicular to the base, is made into this cylinder, splitting the cylinder into two pieces. Suppose the area the cut leaves behind on one of the pieces is $100\sqrt2$. Then the volume of the larger piece can be written as $a + b\pi$, where $a, b$ are positive integers. Find $a + b$.
solution:
Let the center of the base circle be $O$ and the points of intersection of the plane with the base circle be $A B $ 
 
 Since the area of the cut left behind on one of the pieces is $100\sqrt{2} $ it follows that $$AB = \frac{100\sqrt{2}}{20} = 5\sqrt{2} $$ Therefore since $AB=5\sqrt{2}$ and $OA=OB=5 $ we have $$\angle AOB = 90^\circ $$ Hence the area of the larger part of the base circle cut by $\overline{AB}$ is $$\frac{3}{4} \cdot 5^2 \cdot \pi + \frac{5^2}{2} = \frac{75\pi}{4} + \frac{25}{2} $$ Therefore the volume of the larger piece cut by the plane is $$20 \cdot \left(\frac{75\pi}{4}+\frac{25}{2}\right) = 375\pi+1250 $$ which means that the answer is $$375+1250=\boxed{1625} $$ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry B1
text: Parallelogram $ABCD$ is given such that $\angle ABC$ equals $30^o$. Let $X$ be the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ onto $BC$, and $Y$ the foot of the perpendicular from $C$ to $AB$. If $AX = 20$ and $CY = 22$, find the area of the parallelogram.
solution: nice problem! in $\triangle CYB$ we see that $\angle{CBY}=30^\circ$ and $\triangle{CYB}$ is right at $Y$ so we get $\angle{BCY}=60^\circ$ so we get $\frac{BC}{YC}=\cos60^\circ$ so we get $BC=44$ now this gives area of $\parallel$ gm $ABCD$ as $20*44=\boxed{880}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A1 / B3
text: A circle is inscribed in a regular octagon with area $2024$. A second regular octagon is inscribed in the circle, and its area can be expressed as $a + b\sqrt{c}$, where $a, b, c$ are integers and $c$ is square-free. Compute $a + b + c$.
solution: Let the radius be $r$ Then the apothem of the first octagon is $r$ The apothem of the smaller octagon is $r\cos(22 5^\circ) = \frac{\sqrt{2+\sqrt{2}}}{2}r$ Therefore the desired area is $2024\cdot \frac{2+\sqrt{2}}{4} = 1012 + 506\sqrt{2}$ giving $\boxed{1520}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A2 / B4
text: Triangle $\vartriangle ABC$ has $AB = 8$, $AC = 10$, and $AD =\sqrt{33}$, where $D$ is the midpoint of $BC$. Perpendiculars are drawn from $D$ to meet $AB$ and $AC$ at $E$ and $F$, respectively. The length of $EF$ can be expressed as $\frac{a\sqrt{b}}{c}$, where $a, c$ are relatively prime and $b$ is square-free. Compute $a + b + c$.
solution:
Firstly let $BD=CD=x $ Applying Stewart's Theorem then yields $x=7 $ Therefore $\triangle{ABC}$ has side lengths of $8 10 $ and $14 $ so we can apply Heron's Formula to get $$[ABC] = 16\sqrt{6} $$ Therefore each of $[ADC]$ and $[ADB]$ are $8\sqrt{6} $ so we get 
 \begin{align*}
DF &= \frac{2[ADC]}{AC} \\
&= \frac{2\cdot8\sqrt{6}}{10} \\
&= \frac{16\sqrt{6}}{10} \\
&= \frac{8\sqrt{6}}{5} \end{align*} and analogously we have 
 \begin{align*}
DE &= \frac{2[ADB]}{AB} \\
&= \frac{2\cdot8\sqrt{6}}{8} \\
&= \frac{16\sqrt{6}}{8} \\
&= 2\sqrt{6} \end{align*} Now applying the Pythagorean Theorem in $\triangle{ADF}$ and $\triangle{ADE}$ yields $$AF=\frac{21}{5} AE=3 $$ Finally since 
 \begin{align*}
\angle{AFD} + \angle{AED} &= 90^\circ+90^\circ \\
&= 180^\circ \end{align*} we know that $AEDF$ is a cyclic quadrilateral so we can apply Ptolemy's Theorem to get 
 \begin{align*}
EF &= \frac{AF \cdot DE + AE \cdot DF}{AD} \\
&= \frac{\frac{21}{5} \cdot 2\sqrt{6} + 3 \cdot \frac{8\sqrt{6}}{5}}{\sqrt{33}} \\
&= \frac{\frac{42\sqrt{6}}{5} + \frac{24\sqrt{6}}{5}}{\sqrt{33}} \\
&= \frac{\frac{66\sqrt{6}}{5}}{\sqrt{33}} \\
&= \frac{6\sqrt{22}}{5} \end{align*} Hence the answer is $$6+22+5=\boxed{33} $$ $\square$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A3 / B5
text: Consider a circle centered at $O$. Parallel chords $AB$ of length $8$ and $CD$ of length $10$ are of distance $2$ apart such that $AC < AD$. We can write $\tan \angle BOD =\frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b$ are positive integers such that gcd $(a, b) = 1$. Compute $a + b$.
solution:
Drop $OM\bot CD ON\bot AB$ note that $MO=x$ 
 Use Pythagorean theorem $16+(x+2)^2=25+x^2 x=\frac{5}{4}$ 
 
 $\tan \angle{MOD}=4 \tan \angle{BON}=\frac{16}{13}$ $\tan \angle{BOD}=\frac{4 \frac{16}{13}}{1+4\cdot \frac{16}{13}}=\frac{36}{77}$ leads to the answer $\boxed{113}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A4 / B6
text: Let $BCDE$ be a trapezoid with $BE\parallel CD$, $BE = 20$, $BC = 2\sqrt{34}$, $CD = 8$, $DE = 2\sqrt{10}$. Draw a line through $E$ parallel to $BD$ and a line through $B$ perpendicular to $BE$, and let $A$ be the intersection of these two lines. Let $M$ be the intersection of diagonals $BD$ and $CE$, and let $X$ be the intersection of $AM$ and $BE$. If $BX$ can be written as $\frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b$ are relatively prime positive integers, find $a + b$
solution:
Firstly we have to find the height of the trapezoid We drop $CN\bot BE DK\bot BE$ let $BN=x EK=12 x$ 
 
 $136 x^2=40 (12 x)^2 x=10 CN=6$ Since $CD||BE \frac{CD}{BE}=\frac{2}{5}$ Let $ML\bot BE ML=6\cdot \frac{5}{7}=\frac{30}{7}$ 
 
 We can see that $\tan \angle{DBE}=\frac{DK}{BK}=\frac{DK}{BE EK}=\frac{1}{3}$ Since $BM||AE \angle{BEA}=\angle{DBE} BA=\frac{20}{3}$ 
 
 Now we can get that $\frac{BM}{EA}=\frac{ML}{AB}=\frac{BX}{EX}=\frac{9}{14} BX=\frac{180}{23}$ leads to $\boxed{203}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A5 / B7
text: A pentagon has vertices labelled $A, B, C, D, E$ in that order counterclockwise, such that $AB$, $ED$ are parallel and $\angle EAB = \angle ABD = \angle ACD = \angle CDA$. Furthermore, suppose that$ AB = 8$, $AC = 12$, $AE = 10$. If the area of triangle $CDE$ can be expressed as $\frac{a \sqrt{b}}{c}$, where $a, b, c$ are integers so that $b$ is square free, and $a, c$ are relatively prime, find $a + b + c$.
solution:
Firstly we claim that five points lie on the same circle $AB||ED$ implies that $ABED$ is a trapezoid with $\angle{EAB}=\angle{ABD} AE=BD$ $A B D E$ lies on the same circle Then we can find that since $\angle{ACD}=\angle{DBA}$ $A B C D$ lie on the same circle as well We finish the claim Now we can calculate the value of $\cos \angle{DBA}$ denote this as $x$ we can have that $x=\frac{100+64 144}{2\cdot 10 \cdot 8}=\frac{1}{8}$ $DE=8 2\cdot \frac{1}{8}\cdot 10=\frac{11}{2}$ 
 
 Since $\angle{DCA}=\angle{DBA} CD=2\cdot \cos\angle{DCA}\cdot 12=3$ The only thing left is to find what is $\sin \angle{CDE}$ 
 
 We use the cyclic quadrilateral $CDEA$ let $\cos \angle{CDE}=k \cos \angle{EAC}= k$ Applying LOC $144+100 240k=9+\frac{121}{4}+33k k=\frac{3}{4}$ 
 
 So $\sin \angle{CDE}=\frac{\sqrt{7}}{4}$ the desired answer is $3\cdot \frac{11}{2}\cdot \frac{\sqrt{7}}{4}\cdot \frac{1}{2}=\frac{33\sqrt{7}}{16}$ leads to $\boxed{56}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Geometry A7

Let $P$ be the second intersection of the circumcircles of $ABC$ and $AEF$. Suppose that $AP$ can be written as $\frac{a \sqrt{b}}{c}$ where $a, c$ are relatively prime and $b$ is square-free.  Now we could apply Coord Bash denote the centers of $(ABC)$ and $(AEF)$ as $O$ and $O_1$ respectively the given condition implies $OO_1$ is perpendicular to $AP$ 
 
 We could find the coordinates of $O (10 \frac{29}{4\sqrt{30}}) O_1 (7 \frac{211}{4\sqrt{30}})$ by some simple computations Thus we could find the tangent value of the angle formed by $AH$ and $OO_1$ denoted as $\theta$ is $\frac{3}{\frac{182}{4\sqrt{30}}}=\frac{6\sqrt{30}}{91}$ The desired value is $AO_1\sin(\theta)=\frac{87}{\sqrt{9361}}$ the answer is $\boxed{87}$

title: 2021 PUMaC NT B1
text: Andrew has a four-digit number whose last digit is $2$. Given that this number is divisible by $9$, determine the number of possible values for this number that Andrew could have. Note that leading zeros are not allowed.
solution:
Let number be $ A_{1} A_{2} A_{3} 2 $ then $ A_{1}+ A_{2}+ A_{3}= 7 16 $ or 25 as max 3 digit sum can be 27 For 7 we can simply go with beggars and get as $ 8 \choose 2 $ = 28 
 For 16 $ 1 \le A_{1} \le 9 $ and $ 0 \le A_{2} A_{3} \le 9 $ 
 Therefore $ (9 T_{1}) + (9 T_{2})+ (9 T_{3})= 15 $ where $ 9 T_{1} = A_{1} 1 $ 
 $ T_{1} + T_{2} + T_{3} =12 $ and all terms less than equal to 9 except $ T_{1} $ which is less than 8 
 No of possible combinations with above conditions by counting = 25 
 Therefore Total combinations for 16 are $ 14 \choose 2 $ $ $ $25$ = 66 
 And for 25 just systematic count as its easy to do that and its comes as 6 Therefore total numbers Andrew can form are 28+66+6= 100

title: 2021 PUMaC NT B2
text: The smallest three positive proper divisors of an integer n are $d_1 < d_2 < d_3$ and they satisfy $d_1 + d_2 + d_3 = 57$. Find the sum of the possible values of $d_2$.
solution:
$d_1=1$ and $d_2$ must be a prime number If not there will be another divisor(s) between $d_1$ and $d_2$ which will contradict the fact $d_2$ is the second smallest divisor Since $2d_2<d_2+d_3=56$ $\implies$ $d_2<28$ So $d_2 \in \big\{2 3 5 7 11 13 17 19 23 \big\}$ 
 If $d_2=2$ then $d_3=54$ Since $3 \mid 54$ $54$ can not be the third smallest positive divisor of $n$ 
 If $d_2=3$ then $d_3=53$ And it is possible as $53$ is a prime number If $d_2=5$ then $d_3=51$ Since $3 \mid d_3=51$ and $d_2 >3$ it is impossible If $d_2=7$ then $d_3=49$ And it is possible as the only natural number that divides $49$ is $d_2=7$ 
 If $d_2=11$ then $d_3=45$ Since $3 \mid 45$ $45$ can not be the third smallest positive divisor of $n$ 
 If $d_2=13$ then $d_3=43$ And it is possible as $43$ is a prime number If $d_2=17$ then $d_3=39$ Since $3 \mid 39$ $39$ can not be the third smallest positive divisor of $n$ 
 If $d_2=19$ then $d_3=37$ And it is possible as $37$ is a prime number If $d_2=23$ then $d_3=33$ Since $3 \mid 33$ $33$ can not be the third smallest positive divisor of $n$ 
 From analyses made above the possible values $d_2$ can take are $3 7 13$ and $19$ So the answer is $3+7+13+19=42$

title: 2021 PUMaC NT A1 / B3
text: Compute the remainder when $2^{3^5}+ 3^{5^2}+ 5^{2^3}$ is divided by $30$.
solution:
$ \frac{2^{3^5}}{30} $ = $ \frac{2^{242}}{3 5} $ Now we find the remainder by 3 and 5 respectively $ 2^{242} \equiv 1(mod 3) $ and $ 2^{242} \equiv 1(mod 5) $ 
 By CRT $ 2^{242} \equiv 4(mod 15) $ 
 Similarly we do this with the other terms to get $ 3^{24} \equiv 1(mod 10) $ and $ 5^7 \equiv 5(mod 6) $ 
 Hence summing them all we get $ (4+1+5)= 10 $ as the remainder

title: 2021 PUMaC NT A2 / B4
text: A substring of a number $n$ is a number formed by removing some digits from the beginning and end of $n$ (possibly a different number of digits is removed from each side). Find the sum of all prime numbers $p$ that have the property that any substring of $p$ is also prime.
solution:
The number should obviously be formed with $2 3 5$ and $7$ 
 $ 23 37 73 53 $ are the only two digit primes formed by them The thing to notice is $2$ and $5$ can only be placed at the leftmost place Otherwise they will form a number that is either an even or div by $5$ 
 And two similar digits ( $33 77$ ) can’t be placed together or else they will form a no div by $11$ 
 Hence only three digit numbers possible are $237$ $373$ $737$ and $537$ are possible out of which only $373$ is prime Four digit numbers formed $5373$ $2373$ $3737$ $7373$ out of which none are prime And I we try to form any numbers with 5 or 6 digits we will always have either $3737$ or $7373$ in them which is div by 101 Hence the only such numbers are $2$ $3$ $5$ $7$ $23$ $37$ $53$ $73$ and $373$ 
 Sum is 576

text: Let $\vartriangle ABC$ be a triangle, and let $C_0, B_0$ be the feet of perpendiculars from $C$ and $B$ onto $AB$ and $AC$ respectively. Let $\Gamma$ be the circumcircle of $\vartriangle ABC$. title: 2021 PUMaC Individual  Finals A1
text: Prove that, for an arbitrary positive integer $n \in Z_{>0}$, the number $n^2- n + 1$ does not have any prime factors of the form $6k + 5$, for $k \in Z_{>0}$.
solution:
Let $p\ne 2 3$ be a prime factor of $n^2 n+1 $ Then we get 
 $$ \left(n \frac{1}{2}\right)^2 \equiv \frac{3}{4} \ \text{mod} \ p$$ and so $ 3$ is a square modulo $p$ which means that $\left( \frac{ 3}{p} \right)=1 $ On the other hand $$ \left( \frac{ 3}{p} \right) = \left( \frac{3}{p} \right) \cdot\left( \frac{ 1}{p} \right) = ( 1)^{\frac{p 1}{2}} \left( \frac{p}{3} \right) ( 1)^{\frac{p 1}{2}} = \left( \frac{p}{3} \right)$$ by the properties of the Legendre symbol This shows that $p\equiv 1$ mod $3$ and the problem follows

Remark: For a circle $C$ and points $X, Y \in C$, we say that $X$ and $Y$ are diametrically opposite if $XY$ is a diameter of $C$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Individual  Finals A3
text: Alice and Bob are playing a game, starting with a binary string$ b$ of length $2022$. In each step, the rightmost digit of the string is deleted. If the deleted digit was $1$, Alice gets to choose which digit she wants to append on the left. Otherwise, Bob gets to choose the digit to append on the left of the string. Alice would like to turn the string $b$ into the all-zero string $\underbrace{00... 0}_{2022}$, in the least number of steps possible, while Bob would like to maximize the number of steps necessary, or prevent Alice from doing this at all. a) Is there a string $b$ for which Bob can prevent Alice in her goal, if both players play optimally? b) If the answer to part a is yes, find all such strings $b$. If the answer is no, find the maximal game time and find the set of strings $b$ for which the game time is maximal.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #3
text: Let $f(N) = N \left( \frac{9}{10} \right)^N$, and let $\frac{m}{n}$ denote the maximum value of $f(N)$, as $N$ ranges over the positive integers. If $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers, find the remainder when $m + n$ is divided by $1000$.
solution: we notice that $\frac{f(N+1)}{f(N)}=\frac{N+1}{N}\cdot \frac{9}{10}$ for $N<10$ we have $\frac{f(N+1)}{f(N)}>1$ but for $N>10$ we have $\frac{f(N+1)}{f(N)}<1$ so $f$ increases till $N<10$ and achives it maximum at $N=9 10$ so $f(9)=f(10)=\max{\left(N\left(\frac{9}{10}\right)^{N} \right)}=\frac{9^{10}}{10^{9}}$ so $m+n=9^{10}+10^{9} \equiv 401 \pmod{1000}$ so our answer is $\boxed{401}$
