Compute the number of positive divisors of $N$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #5
text: Given a real number $t$ with $0 < t < 1$, define the real-valued function $f(t, \theta) = \sum^{\infty}_{n=-\infty} t^{|n|}\omega^n$, where $\omega = e^{i \theta} = \cos \theta + i\sin \theta$. For $\theta \in [0, 2\pi)$, the polar curve $r(\theta) = f(t, \theta)$ traces out an ellipse $E_t$ with a horizontal major axis whose left focus is at the origin. Let $A(t)$ be the area of the ellipse $E_t$. Let $A\left( \frac12 \right) = \frac{a\pi}{b}$, where $a, b$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $100a +b$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #6
text: Jack plays a game in which he first rolls a fair six-sided die and gets some number $n$, then, he flips a coin until he flips $n$ heads in a row and wins, or he flips $n$ tails in a row in which case he rerolls the die and tries again. What is the expected number of times Jack must flip the coin before he wins the game.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #7
text: The roots of the polynomial $f(x) = x^8 +x^7 -x^5 -x^4 -x^3 +x+ 1 $ are all roots of unity. We say that a real number $r \in [0, 1)$ is nice if $e^{2i \pi r} = \cos 2\pi r + i \sin 2\pi r$ is a root of the polynomial $f$ and if $e^{2i \pi r}$ has positive imaginary part. Let $S$ be the sum of the values of nice real numbers $r$. If $S =\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p, q$, find $p + q$.
solution:
It is magic to realize that $f(x)(x^2 x+1)=x^{10} x^5+1$ 
 
 Solve for the roots of $x^{10} x^5+1=0$ it is not hard to realize such possible $r$ are $\frac{1}{30} \frac{7}{30} \frac{11}{30} \frac{13}{30}\implies \frac{16}{15}\implies \boxed{31}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #8
text: The new PUMaC tournament hosts $2020$ students, numbered by the following set of labels $1, 2,..., 2020$. The students are initially divided up into $20$ groups of $101$, with each division into groups equally likely. In each of the groups, the contestant with the lowest label wins, and the winners advance to the second round. Out of these $20$ students, we chose the champion uniformly at random. If the expected value of champion’s number can be written as $\frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b$ are relatively prime integers, determine $a + b$.
solution:
Note that the given procedure of randomly choosing 20 groups of 101 and then randomly choosing one of the groups whose lowest numbered contestant will win is equivalent to just choosing one group of 101 and letting its lowest numbered contestant win The problem now becomes Find the expected value of the smallest number chosen when 101 distinct numbers are randomly chosen from $\{1 2 \dots 2020\}$ 
 
 Let this minimum be $x$ Then the desired expected value is simply $$\sum_{x=1}^{1920} x \frac{\binom{2020 x}{100}}{\binom{2020}{101}} = \frac{1}{\binom{2020}{101}} \sum_{x=1}^{1920} x \binom{2020 x}{100} $$ since once the minimum number is fixed we have to choose 100 numbers higher than that minimum (out of $2020 x$ available choices) This can be rewritten as $$\frac{1}{\binom{2020}{101}} \sum_{x=1}^{1920} \binom{x}{1} \binom{2020 x}{100} $$ which simplifies as $$\frac{1}{\binom{2020}{101}} \binom{2021}{102} $$ since any way of choosing 102 elements from 2021 by considering the second chosen element as a divider corresponds to a way to choose one element from the first $x$ and 100 elements from the last $2020 x$ for some $x$ giving a bijection Expanding the binomial coefficients as factorials gives $$\frac{101!1919!}{2020!}\cdot\frac{2021!}{102!1919!} = \frac{2021!101!}{2020!102!} = \frac{2021}{102} $$ The requested sum is $2021 + 102 = \boxed{2123}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #9
text: Let $AX$ be a diameter of a circle $\Omega$ with radius $10$, and suppose that $C$ lies on $\Omega$ so that $AC = 16$. Let $D$ be the other point on $\Omega$ so $CX = CD$. From here, define $D'$ to be the reflection of $D$ across the midpoint of $AC$, and $X'$ to be the reflection of $X$ across the midpoint of $CD$. If the area of triangle $CD'X'$ can be written as $\frac{p}{q}$, where $p, q$ are relatively prime, find $p + q$.
solution:
Since homothey $\triangle{CD'X'}\cong \triangle{ADX}$ 
 
 Assume $AD=x$ since $A D C X$ are concyclic $\cos \angle{CDA}= \cos \angle{CXA}= \frac{3}{5}$ 
 
 Use loc $x^2+144+\frac{72x}{5}=16^2 x=\frac{28}{5}$ so $DX=\sqrt{20^2 (\frac{28}{5})^2}=\frac{96}{5}$ the desired answer is $\frac{1344}{25}$ leads to $\boxed{1369}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #10
text: Determine the number of pairs $(a, b)$, where $1 \le a \le b \le 100$ are positive integers, so that $\frac{a^3+b^3}{a^2+b^2}$ is an integer.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #11
text: $ABC$ is a triangle where $AB = 10$, $BC = 14$, and $AC = 16$. Let $DEF$ be the triangle with smallest area so that $DE$ is parallel to $AB$, $EF$ is parallel to $BC$, $DF$ is parallel to $AC$, and the circumcircle of $ABC$ is $DEF$’s inscribed circle. Line $DA$ meets the circumcircle of $ABC$ again at a point $X$. Find $AX^2$.
solution:
It is supposed to be $BE$ meets $(ABC)$ at $X$ and asking for $BX^2$ ( it is the wording in their solution packet) 
 
 It is well known that $\angle{BAC}=60^{\circ}$ Denote the center of the circumcircle of $\triangle{ABC}$ be $O$ It is easy to compute the radius of circle $O$ is $\frac{14}{\sqrt{3}}$ It is also easy to compute the in radius of the i circle of $\triangle{ABC}$ is $2\sqrt{3}$ Thus $DEF ABC$ are similar with a ratio of $\frac{7}{3}$ Let the tangency point of $(ABC)$ at $EF$ as $N$ and drop $BM$ to $EF$ Since $\angle{BAC}=60 \angle{NOC}=60$ Let $ON$ meets $BC$ at $K OK=\frac{7}{\sqrt{3}}=BM$ We can see $10=4+6 16=6+10 14=4+10$ So $EN=\frac{7}{3}\cdot 4=\frac{28}{3}$ Since $MN=BK=7 EM=\frac{7}{3}$ We can then see $\angle{BEF}=\angle{XBC}=60^{\circ} \angle{XOC}=120^{\circ}$ Furthermore we have $XC=\sqrt{3}R=14=BC$ we have $BXC$ is an equilateral triangle yielding $BX=14 BX^2=\boxed{196}$

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #12
text: Given an integer $a_0$, we define a sequence of real numbers $a_0, a_1,...$ using the relation $$a^2_i = 1 + ia^2_{i-1},$$for $i \ge 1$. An index $j$ is called good if $a_j$ can be an integer for some $a_0$. Determine the sum of the indices $j$ which lie in the interval $[0, 99]$ and which are not good.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #13
text: Given a positive integer $n$ with prime factorization $p_1^{e_1}p_2^{e_2}... p_k^{e_k}$, we define $f(n)$ to be $\sum^k_{i=1}p_ie_i$. In other words, $f(n)$ is the sum of the prime divisors of $n$, counted with multiplicities. Let $M$ be the largest odd integer such that $f(M) = 2023$, and $m$ the smallest odd integer so that $f(m) = 2023$. Suppose that $\frac{M}{m}$ equals $p_1^{e_1}p_2^{e_2}... p_l^{e_l}$, where the $e_i$ are all nonzero integers and the $p_i$ are primes. Find $\left| \sum^l_{i=1} (p_i + e_i) \right|$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #14
text: Heron is going to watch a show with $n$ episodes which are released one each day. Heron wants to watch the first and last episodes on the days they first air, and he doesn’t want to have two days in a row that he watches no episodes. He can watch as many episodes as he wants in a day. Denote by $f(n)$ the number of ways Heron can choose how many episodes he watches each day satisfying these constraints. Let $N$ be the $2021$st smallest value of $n$ where $f(n) \equiv 2$ mod $3$. Find $N$.

title: 2021 PUMaC Team #15
text: Let $\vartriangle ABC$ be an acute triangle with angles $\angle BAC = 70^o$, $\angle ABC = 60^o$, let $D, E$ be the feet of perpendiculars from $B, C$ to $AC$, $AB$, respectively, and let $H$ be the orthocenter of $ABC$. Let $F$ be a point on the shorter arc $AB$ of circumcircle of $ABC$ satisfying $\angle F AB = 10^o$ and let $G$ be the foot of perpendicular from $H$ to $AF$. If $I = BF \cap EG$ and $J = CF \cap DG$, compute the angle $\angle GIJ$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra B1
text: The function $f(x) = x^2 + (2a + 3)x + (a^2 + 1)$ only has real zeroes. Suppose the smallest possible value of $a$ can be written in the form $p/q$, where $p, q$ are relatively prime integers. Find $|p| + |q|$.
solution:
We know that the discriminant must be greater than $0$ if it has real zeros Thus by looking at the discriminant we get 
 $$(2a+3)^2 (4)(1)(a^2+1) \geq 0$$ $$12a+5 \geq 0$$ $$a \geq \frac{5}{12}$$ $$|p|+|q|=\boxed{17}$$

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra B2
text: Princeton has an endowment of $5$ million dollars and wants to invest it into improving campus life. The university has three options: it can either invest in improving the dorms, campus parties or dining hall food quality. If they invest $a$ million dollars in the dorms, the students will spend an additional $5a$ hours per week studying. If the university invests $b$ million dollars in better food, the students will spend an additional $3b$ hours per week studying. Finally, if the $c$ million dollars are invested in parties, students will be more relaxed and spend $11c - c^2$ more hours per week studying. The university wants to invest its $5$ million dollars so that the students get as many additional hours of studying as possible. What is the maximal amount that students get to study?
solution: Obviously it is not sensible to invest in food Hence we just have to maximize $11c c^2 +5(5 c)=25+6c c^2$ which attains the maximal value $\boxed{34}$ at $c=3$ so this is the answer

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A1 / B3
text: Let $f(x) =\frac{x+a}{x+b}$ satisfy $f(f(f(x))) = x$ for real numbers $a, b$. If the maximum value of a is $p/q$, where $p, q$ are relatively prime integers, what is $|p| + |q|$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A2 / B4
text: Let $C$ denote the curve $y^2 =\frac{x(x+1)(2x+1)}{6}$. The points $(1/2, a)$,$(b, c)$, and $(24, d)$ lie on $C$ and are collinear, and $ad < 0$. Given that $b, c$ are rational numbers, find $100b^2 + c^2$.
solution: $a^{2} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \cdot 2}{6} = \frac{1}{4} a = \pm \frac{1}{2}$ $d^{2}=\frac{24 \cdot 25 \cdot 49}{6}= 4900 d = \pm 70$ Since $ad<0$ either one of $a$ or $d$ is negative so WLOG assume it is $a$ so the line that contains these 3 points is $y=3x 2$ $(3x 2)^{2} = \frac{x(x+1)(2x+1)}{6}$ solving this cubic or just seeing that $x = 1$ works gives the solution $(1 1)$ So the requested answer is $100+1 = \fbox{101}$

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A3 / B5
text: Let $\{x\} = x- \lfloor x \rfloor$. Consider a function f from the set $\{1, 2,..., 2020\}$ to the half-open interval $[0, 1)$. Suppose that for all $x, y,$ there exists a $z$ so that $\{f(x) + f(y)\} = f(z)$. We say that a pair of integers $m, n$ is valid if $1 \le m, n \le 2020$ and there exists a function $f$ satisfying the above so $f(1) = \frac{m}{n}$. Determine the sum over all valid pairs $m, n$ of ${m}{n}$.
solution:
Claim All $f(1) = \frac{m}{n}$ work Proof Let $f(1) =\frac{a}{b}$ with $b>a$ and let $f(2) =\frac{b a}{a}$ this means that $\{f(1)+f(2)\} = 0$ and let this value be $f(3)$ see that the rest of $f(4) f(5) \ldots f(2020)$ can replaced by one of $\frac{a}{b} \frac{b a}{a} 0$ and they will all fit the condition given So now we want the sum of $\frac{m}{n}$ over all $1 \leq m < n \leq 2020$ which is equivalent to 
 \[ \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{2020} \frac{(n 1)n}{2n} = \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{2020} \frac{n 1}{2} = \frac{1+2+\ldots+2020}{2} = \boxed{1019595} \]

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A4 / B6
text: Let $P$ be a $10$-degree monic polynomial with roots $r_1, r_2,..., r_{10} \ne $ and let $Q$ be a $45$-degree monic polynomial with roots $\frac{1}{r_i}+\frac{1}{r_j}-\frac{1}{r_ir_j}$ where $i < j$ and $i, j \in \{1,..., 10\}$. If $P(0) = Q(1) = 2$, then $\log_2 (|P(1)|)$ can be written as $a/b$ for relatively prime integers $a, b$. Find $a + b$.
solution:
$P(0)=\prod_{i=1}^{10}r_i=2 Q(1)=\prod_{i<j}\frac{r_{i}r_{j} r_{i} r_{j}+1}{r_{i}r_{j}}=\frac{(r_i 1)(r_j 1)}{r_ir_j}$ 
 
 It is easy to find in $Q$ each $r_i$ appears nine times thus $Q(1)$ can be rewritten as $\frac{( P(1))^9}{2^9}=2\implies P(1)=2^{ \frac{10}{9}}$ yields the answer $19$

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A5 / B7
text: Suppose we have a sequence $a_1, a2_,...$ of positive real numbers so that for each positive integer $n$, we have that $\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_ka_{\lfloor \sqrt{k} \rfloor} = n^2$. Determine the first value of $k$ so $a_k > 100$.
solution:
Note that $a_1=1 a_2=3 a_3=5 a_4=\frac{7}{3} a_5=3$ and that $a_n = \frac{2n 1}{a_{\lfloor \sqrt{n} \rfloor}}$ 
 As a result the maximum value of $a_i$ for $r^2 \leq i < (r+1)^2$ is achieved with $i = (r+1)^2 1$ so $\max(a_i) = \frac{2(r+1)^2 3}{a_r} $ 
 Suppose $q^2 \leq r < (q+1)^2$ so $a_r= \frac{2r 1}{a_q}$ and now we can do casework on $q$ 
 Clearly $q \geq 3$ so we consider these values only If $q=3$ then $a_r = \frac{2r 1}{5}$ and $\max(a_i) = \frac{10(r+1)^2 15}{2r 1}$ so we need $10(r+1)^2 200r+85 > 0 \rightarrow 2r^2 39r+16 >0 \rightarrow r>\frac{1}{2}(18+\sqrt{286})$ but $r < 16 < 17 5 \approx \frac{1}{2}(18+\sqrt{286})$ so no solutions here If $q=4$ then $a_r = \frac{2r 1}{\frac{7}{3}}$ and $\max(a_i) = \frac{14(r+1)^2 21}{6r 3}$ so we need $14r^2 572r+293>0 \rightarrow r > \frac{1}{28}(572+\sqrt{572^2 4\cdot14\cdot293})$ so we will try to approximate this $\frac{1}{28}(572+\sqrt{572^2 4\cdot14\cdot293}) \approx \frac{1}{28}(572+\sqrt{572^2 30 \cdot 572}) < \frac{1}{28}(572+23^2)$ but $r<25<\frac{1}{28}(572+23^2)$ so no solutions here If $q=5$ then $a_r = \frac{2r 1}{3}$ and $\max(a_i) = \frac{6(r+1)^2 9}{2r 1}$ so we need $6r^2 188r+97 > 0 \rightarrow r > \frac{1}{12}(188+\sqrt{188^2 4\cdot6\cdot97})$ we will again try to approximate this so $\frac{1}{12}(188+\sqrt{188^2 4\cdot6\cdot97}) \approx \frac{1}{12}(188+\sqrt{188^2 12 \cdot 188}) = \frac{1}{12}(188+\sqrt{188}\cdot\sqrt{176}) \approx \frac{1}{12}(188+13\cdot14) = 30 8\overline{3}$ 
 And this fits the needed bound Since $\frac{6\cdot31^2 9}{2\cdot30 1}<100$ and $\frac{6\cdot32^2 9}{2\cdot31 1}>100 r=31$ is the desired value So $a_r = \frac{61}{3}$ and $31^2 \leq i < 32^2$ so we now need to find the least $i$ such that $a_i = \frac{3}{61}(2i 1) > 100$ so $i>\frac{6103}{6} = 1017 1\overline{6}$ and the desired answer is thus $\boxed{1018} $ 
 
 Remark This solutions is not that visually pleasing but it actually isn't too bad (and I think is much more approachable than the official solutions) Also for possible approximation issues for $q=3 4$ the approximation needed for $q=3$ was very close to the actual value as $17^2 = 289 $ so there is no worry for that And for $q=4$ the approximations were not as close (but not nearly far off) but since $\frac{1}{28}(572+23^2)$ is (relatively) a lot bigger than 25 there is also no worry for this solution

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A6 / B8
text: Given integer $n$, let $W_n$ be the set of complex numbers of the form $re^{2qi\pi}$, where $q$ is a rational number so that $q_n \in Z$ and $r$ is a real number. Suppose that p is a polynomial of degree $ \ge 2$ such that there exists a non-constant function $f: W_n \to C$ so that $p(f(x))p(f(y)) = f(xy)$ for all $x, y \in W_n$. If $p$ is the unique monic polynomial of lowest degree for which such an $f$ exists for $n = 65$, find $p(10)$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A7
text: Suppose that $p$ is the unique monic polynomial of minimal degree such that its coefficients are rational numbers and one of its roots is $\sin \frac{2\pi}{7} + \cos \frac{4\pi}{7}$. If $p(1) = \frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b$ are relatively prime integers, find $|a + b|$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Algebra A8
text: Let $a_n$ be the number of unordered sets of three distinct bijections $f, g, h: \{1, 2,..., n\} \to \{1, 2,..., n\}$ such that the composition of any two of the bijections equals the third. What is the largest value in the sequence $a_1, a_2,...$ which is less than $2021$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics B1
text: Runey is speaking his made-up language, Runese, that consists only of the “letters” zap, zep, zip, zop, and zup. Words in Runese consist of anywhere between $1$ and $5$ letters, inclusive. As well, Runey can choose to add emphasis on any letter(s) that he chooses in a given word, hence making it a totally distinct word! What is the maximum number of possible words in Runese?
solution:
Since each of the five possible letters can have emphasis we essentially have ten possible letters Therefore the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
10^1+10^2+10^3+10^4+10^5 &= 10+100+1000+10000+100000 \\
&= \boxed{111110} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A1 / B2
text: Joey is playing with a $2$-by-$2$-by-$2$ Rubik’s cube made up of $ 8$ $1$-by-$1$-by-$1$ cubes (with two of these smaller cubes along each of the sides of the bigger cubes). Each face of the Rubik’s cube is distinct color. However, one day, Joey accidentally breaks the cube! He decides to put the cube back together into its solved state, placing each of the pieces one by one. However, due to the nature of the cube, he is only able to put in a cube if it is adjacent to a cube he already placed. If different orderings of the ways he chooses the cubes are considered distinct, determine the number of ways he can reassemble the cube.
solution:
First note that there are $8 \cdot 6 \cdot 4 = 96$ ways to place the first three cubes The result after the first three cubes will always be an L shape of unit cubes so we have two choices either the next cube placed shares a face with the "corner" cube in the L shape or it doesn't In the former case there are 
 \begin{align*}
4! 3! &= 24 6 \\
&= 18
\end{align*} ways to place the remaining cubes because we cannot place the cube that is diagonal to the corner of the original L shape before the other three remaining cubes In the latter case there are $3$ ways to choose which cube is chosen fourth and then any of the remaining placements is valid so we get 
 \begin{align*}
3 \cdot 4! &= 3 \cdot 24 \\
&= 72 \end{align*} Hence the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
96 \cdot (18+72) &= 96 \cdot 90 \\
&= \boxed{8640} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A2 / B3
text: Cary has six distinct coins in a jar. Occasionally, he takes out three of the coins and adds a dot to each of them. Determine the number of orders in which Cary can choose the coins so that, eventually, for each number $i \in \{0, 1,..., 5\}$, some coin has exactly $i$ dots on it.
solution:
First note that there are $6!=720$ ways to choose which coin is which Then we can rephrase the problem as finding the number of ways to choose an ordered set of five triples $(x_1 y_1 z_1) \ldots (x_5 y_5 z_5)$ where $x_i y_i z_i \in \{A B C D E\}$ for $i=1 2 \ldots 5$ and where exactly one of the $15$ variables is $A $ exactly two are $B $ and so on such that the order of $x_i y_i $ and $z_i$ within each triple doesn't matter Note that $E$ must be in all triples and $D$ must be in all but one of the triples so it follows that there are $$1\cdot5=5$$ ways to place the $D$ ' s and the $E$ ' s Then we split into two cases The A is in the triple that doesn't have a D Then there are $$\binom{5}{2}=\underline{10}$$ ways to permute the three $C$ ' s and the two $B$ ' s The A is not in the triple that doesn't have a D Then the two other elements in the triple without the $D$ must be $B$ and $C $ There are $4$ ways to choose which of the remaining triples has the $A$ in it and then $3$ ways to permute the two remaining $C$ ' s and the remaining $B$ into the last three sets for a total of $$4 \cdot 3 = \underline{12} $$ 
 Hence the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
720 \cdot 5 \cdot (10+12) &= 3600 \cdot 22 \\
&= \boxed{79200} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A3 / B4
text: Katie has a chocolate bar that is a $5$-by-$5$ grid of square pieces, but she only wants to eat the center piece. To get to it, she performs the following operations: i. Take a gridline on the chocolate bar, and split the bar along the line. ii. Remove the piece that doesn’t contain the center. iii. With the remaining bar, repeat steps $1$ and $2$. Determine the number of ways that Katie can perform this sequence of operations so that eventually she ends up with just the center piece.
solution:
Let an outer grid line be one that runs from one side of the square to the opposite side of the square and splits it into a $1 \times 5$ rectangle and a $4 \times 5$ rectangle Let an inner grid line be one that runs from one side of the square to the opposite side of the square and splits it into a $2 \times 5$ rectangle and a $3 \times 5$ rectangle Note that Katie must cut along all of the inner grid lines but she can cut along any subset of the outer grid lines (which may be empty) The one condition is that she obviously needs to cut along an outer grid line before cutting along its corresponding inner grid line (it's corresponding inner grid line is the inner grid line parallel with it and closest to it) Therefore the number of ways to cut out the middle $1 \times 1$ square while cutting along exactly $k$ outer grid lines (where $0 \le k \le 4$ ) is 
 \begin{align*}
\frac{\binom{4}{k} \cdot (4+k)!}{2^k} \end{align*} It follows that the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^4 \frac{\binom{4}{k} \cdot (4+k)!}{2^k} &= \frac{\binom{4}{0} \cdot (4+0)!}{2^0}+\frac{\binom{4}{1} \cdot (4+1)!}{2^1}+\frac{\binom{4}{2} \cdot (4+2)!}{2^2}+\frac{\binom{4}{3} \cdot (4+3)!}{2^3}+\frac{\binom{4}{4} \cdot (4+4)!}{2^4} \\
&= \frac{1 \cdot 4!}{1} + \frac{4 \cdot 5!}{2} + \frac{6 \cdot 6!}{4} + \frac{4 \cdot 7!}{8} + \frac{1 \cdot 8!}{16} \\
&= 24 + 240 + 1080 + 2520 + 2520 \\
&= \boxed{6384} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A4 / B5
text: Let $P$ be the power set of $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ (meaning the elements of P are the subsets of $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$). How many subsets $S$ of $P$ are there such that no two distinct integers $a, b \in \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ appear together in exactly one element of $S$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics B6
text: Billy the baker makes a bunch of loaves of bread every day, and sells them in bundles of size $1, 2$, or $3$. On one particular day, there are $375$ orders, $125$ for each bundle type. As such, Billy goes ahead and makes just enough loaves of bread to meet all the orders. Whenever Billy makes loaves, some get burned, and are not sellable. For nonnegative i less than or equal to the total number of loaves, the probability that exactly i loaves are sellable to customers is inversely proportional to $2^i$ (otherwise, it’s $0$). Once he makes the loaves, he distributes out all of the sellable loaves of bread to some subset of these customers (each of whom will only accept their desired bundle of bread), without worrying about the order in which he gives them out. If the expected number of ways Billy can distribute the bread is of the form $\frac{a^b}{2^c-1}$, find $a + b + c$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A5 / B7
text: Jacob has a piece of bread shaped like a figure $8$, marked into sections and all initially connected as one piece of bread. The central part of the “$8$” is a single section, and each of the two loops of “$8$” is divided into an additional $1010$ pieces. For each section, there is a $50$ percent chance that Jacob will decide to cut it out and give it to a friend, and this is done independently for each section. The remaining sections of bread form some number of connected pieces. If $E$ is the expected number of these pieces, and $k$ is the smallest positive integer so that $2^k(E - \lfloor E \rfloor ) \ge 1$, find $\lfloor E \rfloor +k$. (Here, we say that if Jacob donates all pieces, there are $0$ pieces left).

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A6 / B8
text: In the country of Princetonia, there are an infinite number of cities, connected by roads. For every two distinct cities, there is a unique sequence of roads that leads from one city to the other. Moreover, there are exactly three roads from every city. On a sunny morning in early July, n tourists have arrived at the capital of Princetonia. They repeat the following process every day: in every city that contains three or more tourists, three tourists are picked and one moves to each of the three cities connected to the original one by roads. If there are $2$ or fewer tourists in the city, they do nothing. After some time, all tourists will settle and there will be no more changing cities. For how many values of n from $1$ to $2020$ will the tourists end in a configuration in which no two of them are in the same city?

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A7
text: Let $f$ be defined as below for integers $n \ge 0$ and $a_0, a_1,...$ such that $\sum_{i\ge 0}a_i$ is finite: $$f(n; a_0, a_1,...) = \begin{cases} a_{2020}, & \text{ $n = 0$} \\ \sum_{i\ge 0} a_i f(n-1;a_0,...,a_{i-1},a_i-1,a_{i+1}+1,a_{i+2},...)/ \sum_{i\ge 0}a_i & \text{$n > 0$} \end{cases}$$. Find the nearest integer to $f(2020^2; 2020, 0, 0,...)$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Combinatorics A8
text: Let $f(k)$ denote the number of triples $(a, b, c)$ of positive integers satisfying $a + b + c = 2020$ with $(k - 1)$ not dividing $a, k$ not dividing $b$, and $(k + 1)$ not dividing $c$. Find the product of all integers $k$ in the range 3 \le k \le 20 such that $(k + 1)$ divides $f(k)$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry B1
text: You are walking along a road of constant width with sidewalks on each side. You can only walk on the sidewalks or cross the road perpendicular to the sidewalk. Coming up on a turn, you realize that you are on the “outside” of the turn; i.e., you are taking the longer way around the turn. The turn is a circular arc. Assuming that your destination is on the same side of the road as you are currently, let $\theta$ be the smallest turn angle, in radians, that would justify crossing the road and then crossing back after the turn to take the shorter total path to your destination. What is $\lfloor 100 \cdot \theta \rfloor$?
solution:
Let $r_1$ denote the radius of the inner circular arc and let $r_2$ denote the radius of the outer circular arc Then it follows that the length of the path along the outer circular arc is $\theta r_2$ and the length you would walk if you cross the road to the inner circular arc instead would be $2(r_2 r_1)+\theta r_1 $ Thus we have 
 \begin{align*}
2(r_2 r_1)+\theta r_1 \le \theta r_2 &\implies 2(r_2 r_1) \le \theta (r_2 r_1) \\
&\implies \theta \ge 2 \end{align*} Hence the answer is 
 \begin{align*}
\lfloor 100 \cdot 2 \rfloor &= \lfloor 200 \rfloor \\
&= \boxed{200} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry B2
text: Seven students in Princeton Juggling Club are searching for a room to meet in. However, they must stay at least $6$ feet apart from each other, and due to midterms, the only open rooms they can find are circular. In feet, what is the smallest diameter of any circle which can contain seven points, all of which are at least $6$ feet apart from each other?

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A1 / B3
text: Let $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$ be circles centered at $O$ and $ P$ respectively, and externally tangent to each other at point $Q$. Draw point $D$ on $\gamma_1$ and point $E$ on $\gamma_2$ such that line $DE$ is tangent to both circles. If the length $OQ = 1$ and the area of the quadrilateral $ODEP$ is $520$, then what is the value of length $PQ$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A2 / B4
text: Hexagon $ABCDEF$ has an inscribed circle $\Omega$ that is tangent to each of its sides. If $AB = 12$, $\angle FAB = 120^o$, and $\angle ABC = 150^o$, and if the radius of $\Omega$ can be written as $m +\sqrt{n}$ for positive integers $m, n$, find $m + n$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A3 / B5
text: Let $ABCD$ be a cyclic quadrilateral with circumcenter $O$ and radius $10$. Let sides $AB$, $BC$, $CD$, and $DA$ have midpoints $M, N, P$, and $Q$, respectively. If $MP = NQ$ and $OM + OP = 16$, then what is the area of triangle $\vartriangle OAB$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A4 / B6
text: Let $C$ be a circle centered at point $O$, and let $P$ be a point in the interior of $C$. Let $Q$ be a point on the circumference of $C$ such that $PQ \perp OP$, and let $D$ be the circle with diameter $PQ$. Consider a circle tangent to $C$ whose circumference passes through point $P$. Let the curve $\Gamma$ be the locus of the centers of all such circles. If the area enclosed by $\Gamma$ is $1/100$ the area of $C$, then what is the ratio of the area of $C$ to the area of $D$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A5 / B7
text: Triangle $ABC$ is so that $AB = 15$, $BC = 22$, and $AC = 20$. Let $D, E, F$ lie on $BC$, $AC$, and $AB$, respectively, so $AD$, $BE$, $CF$ all contain a point $K$. Let $L$ be the second intersection of the circumcircles of $BFK$ and $CEK$. Suppose that $\frac{AK}{KD} = \frac{11}{7}$, and $BD = 6$. If $KL^2 =\frac{a}{b}$, where $a, b$ are relatively prime integers, find $a + b$.
solution:
Using Menelaus theorem we have $\frac{CB}{BD}\cdot \frac{DK}{KA}\cdot \frac{AE}{EC}= 1$ we can get that $\frac{AE}{EC}=\frac{3}{7} AE=6$ 
 
 Similarly we can get that $\frac{BC}{CD}\cdot \frac{DK}{KA}\cdot \frac{AF}{FB}= 1$ we can get that $\frac{AF}{FB}=\frac{8}{7} AF=8$ 
 
 We can find $AF\cdot AB=AE\cdot AC=120$ which means $A$ lies on the radical axis of the two circles so it implies $AK\cdot AL=120$ as well Applying Stewart's theorem $AB^2\cdot CD+AC^2\cdot BD=(BD+CD)(AD^2+BD\cdot CD)$ plug numbers in and we can get $AD=\frac{18\sqrt{66}}{11}$ so $AK=\sqrt{66}$ Now we set $KL=x \sqrt{66}\cdot (\sqrt{66}+x)=120 x=\frac{54}{\sqrt{66}} x^2=\frac{486}{11}$ leads to answer $\boxed{497}$

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A6 / B8
text: Triangle $ABC$ has side lengths $13$, $14$, and $15$. Let $E$ be the ellipse that encloses the smallest area which passes through $A, B$, and $C$. The area of $E$ is of the form $\frac{a \sqrt{b}\pi}{c}$, where $a$ and $c$ are coprime and $b$ has no square factors. Find $a + b + c$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A7
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with sides $AB = 34$, $BC = 15$, $AC = 35$ and let $\Gamma$ be the circle of smallest possible radius passing through $A$ tangent to $BC$. Let the second intersections of $\Gamma$ and sides $AB$, $AC$ be the points $X, Y$. Let the ray $XY$ intersect the circumcircle of the triangle $ABC$ at $Z$. If $AZ =\frac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime integers $p$ and $q$, find $p + q$.
solution:
Let the tangency point of $\Gamma$ and $BC$ be $D$ 
 
 Then note that $AD^2=AX\cdot AB=AY\cdot AC$ By Inversion it inverts the circumcircle of $\triangle{ABC}$ to line $XY$ Since $Z$ lies on $(ABC)$ and line $XY$ we have $AZ^2=AD^2 AZ=AD$ 
 
 By computation the area of the triangle is $252$ by Heron's formula Then $AD=\frac{252\cdot 2}{15}=\frac{168}{5}\implies \boxed{173}$

title: 2020 PUMaC Geometry A8
text: $A_1A_2A_3A_4$ is a cyclic quadrilateral inscribed in circle $\Omega$, with side lengths $A_1A_2 = 28$, $A_2A_3 =12\sqrt3$, $A_3A_4 = 28\sqrt3$, and $A_4A_1 = 8$. Let $X$ be the intersection of $A_1A_3, A_2A_4$. Now, for $i = 1, 2, 3, 4$, let $\omega_i$ be the circle tangent to segments$ A_iX$, $A_{i+1}X$, and $\Omega$, where we take indices cyclically (mod $4$). Furthermore, for each $i$, say $\omega_i$ is tangent to $A_1A_3$ at $X_i $, $A_2A_4$ at $Y_i$, and $\Omega$ at $T_i$. Let $P_1$ be the intersection of $T_1X_1$ and $T_2X_2$, and $P_3$ the intersection of $T_3X_3$ and $T_4X_4$. Let $P_2$ be the intersection of $T_2Y_2$ and $T_3Y_3$, and $P_4$ the intersection of $T_1Y_1$ and $T_4Y_4$. Find the area of quadrilateral $P_1P_2P_3P_4$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT B1
text: The number $2021$ leaves a remainder of $11$ when divided by a positive integer. Find the smallest such integer.
solution: The number must be greater than $11$ to give a remainder of $11 $ Then we just need to find the smallest factor of $2021 11=2010$ which is greater than $11 $ By Inspection our answer is $\boxed{15}$

title: 2020 PUMaC NT B2
text: Last year, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a bill which would make Washington, D.C. into the $51$st state. Naturally, the mathematicians are upset that Congress won’t prioritize mathematical interest of flag design in choosing how many U.S. states there should be. Suppose the U.S. flag must contain, as it does now, stars arranged in rows alternating between $n$ and $n - 1$ stars, starting and ending with rows of n stars, where $n \ge 2$ is some integer and the flag has more than one row. What is the minimum number of states that the U.S. would need to contain so that there are at least three different ways, excluding rotations, to arrange the stars on the flag?

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A1 / B3
solution: Finding powers of $9$ mod $100$ gives $9^{1} = 09 9^{2}=81 9^{3} = 29 9^{4} = 61 9^{5} = 49 9^{6} = 41 9^{7} = 69 9^{8} = 21 9^{9} = 89 9^{10} = 01 9^{11}=09$ so the pattern is cyclic mod $10$ since $2020$ and any power of it is divisible by $10$ the last two digits of each of the terms is $01$ so the sum is $20\fbox{20}$

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A2 / B4
text: How many ordered triples of nonzero integers $(a, b, c)$ satisfy $2abc = a + b + c + 4$?
solution: We have $c=\frac{a+b+4}{2ab 1}$ Notice that $2ab 1$ is going to be much larger than $a+b+4$ eventually If $|a| |b|>2$ the denominator is going to be larger than the numerator which definitely won't work since $c$ is going to be a decimal So we must have at least one of $a$ or $b$ to $ 1$ or $1$ Also note that when $|a|=|b|=2$ there are no cases Case 1 $a=1$ This gives us $(1 1 6)$ and the other two permutations We have $3$ so far Case 2 $a= 1$ This gives us $( 1 1 2)$ and the other two permutations We have $\boxed{6}$ in total

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A3 / B5
text: Find the sum (in base $10$) of the three greatest numbers less than $1000_{10}$ that are palindromes in both base $10$ and base $5$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A4 / B6
text: Given two positive integers $a \ne b$, let $f(a, b)$ be the smallest integer that divides exactly one of $a, b$, but not both. Determine the number of pairs of positive integers $(x, y)$, where $x \ne y$, $1\le x, y, \le 100$ and $\gcd(f(x, y), \gcd(x, y)) = 2$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A5 / B7
text: We say that a positive integer $n$ is divable if there exist positive integers $1 < a < b < n$ such that, if the base-$a$ representation of $n$ is $\sum_{i=0}^{k_1} a_ia^i$, and the base-$b$ representation of $n$ is $\sum_{i=0}^{k_2} b_ib^i$, then for all positive integers $c > b$, we have that $\sum_{i=0}^{k_2} b_ic^i$ divides $\sum_{i=0}^{k_1} a_ic^i$. Find the number of non-divable $n$ such that $1 \le n \le 100$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A6 / B8
text: Find the number of ordered pairs of integers $(x, y)$ such that $2167$ divides $3x^2 + 27y^2 + 2021$ with $0 \le x, y \le 2166$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A7
text: Let $\phi (x, u)$ be the smallest positive integer $n$ so that $2^u$ divides $x^n + 95$ if it exists, or $0$ if no such positive integer exists. Determine$ \sum_{i=0}^{255} \phi(i, 8)$.

title: 2020 PUMaC NT A8
text: What is the smallest integer $a_0$ such that, for every positive integer $n$, there exists a sequence of positive integers $a_0, a_1,..., a_{n-1}, a_n$ such that the first $n-1$ are all distinct, $a_0 = a_n$, and for $0 \le i \le n -1$, $a_i^{a_{i+1}}$ ends in the digits $\overline{0a_i}$ when expressed without leading zeros in base $10$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals A1
text: Let $a_1,..., a_{2020}$ be a sequence of real numbers such that $a_1 = 2^{-2019}$, and $a^2_{n-1}a_n = a_n-a_{n-1}$. Prove that $a_{2020} <\frac{1}{2^{2019} -1}$

title: segment construction by straightedge + pencil 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals A2
text: Helen has a wooden rectangle of unknown dimensions, a straightedge, and a pencil (no compass). Is it possible for her to construct a line segment on the rectangle connecting the midpoints of two opposite sides, where she cannot draw any lines or points outside the rectangle? Note: Helen is allowed to draw lines between two points she has already marked, and mark the intersection of any two lines she has already drawn, if the intersection lies on the rectangle. Further, Helen is allowed to mark arbitrary points either on the rectangle or on a segment she has previously drawn. Assume that only the four vertices of the rectangle have been marked prior to the beginning of this process.

title: 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals A3
text: Let $n$ be a positive integer, and let $F$ be a family of subsets of $\{1, 2,..., 2^n\}$ such that for any non-empty $ A\in F$ there exists $B \in F$ so that $|A| = |B| + 1$ and $B \subset A$. Suppose that F contains all $(2^n - 1)$-element subsets of $\{1, 2,..., 2^n\}$ Determine the minimal possible value of $|F|$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals B1
text: Find all pairs of natural numbers $(n, k)$ with the following property: Given a $k\times k$ array of cells, such that every cell contains one integer, there always exists a path from the left to the right edges such that the sum of the numbers on the path is a multiple of $n$. Note: A path from the left to the right edge is a sequence of cells of the array $a_1, a_2,..., a_m$ so that $a_1$ is a cell of the leftmost column, $a_m$ is the cell of the rightmost column, and $a_{i}$, $a_{i+1}$ share an edge for all $i = 1, 2,..., m -1$.
solution: The answer is that $(n k)$ is a solution iff $n\leq k $ Putting a $1$ in every cell in the leftmost column shows that there are no other solutions To see that the above solutions actually work note first that there is a path covering a $m\times k$ rectangle for $1\leq m \leq k $ Consider thus the paths through the uppermost $r\times k$ rectangles for $r=1 2 \ldots k$ and consider the sum on these paths modulo $n $ If we obtain the residue $0$ we are finished Otherwise there exist two rectangles of size $a\times k$ and $b\times k$ with the same sum modulo $n$ by the Pigeonhole principle using that $n\leq k $ But then the path covering the respective $(b a) \times k$ rectangle has sum divisible by $n $

title: 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals B2
text: Prove that there is a positive integer $M$ for which the following statement holds: For all prime numbers $p$, there is an integer $n$ for which $\sqrt{p} \le n \le M\sqrt{p}$ and $p \mod n \le \frac{n}{2020}$. Note: Here, $p \mod n$ denotes the unique integer $r \in {0, 1,..., n - 1}$ for which $n|p -r$. In other words, $p \mod n$ is the residue of $p$ upon division by $n$.

title: tangent circles of BDX, CEX iff ABxAD<=4R^2 2020 PUMaC Individual Finals B3
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle and let the points $D, E$ be on the rays $AB$, $AC$ such that $BCED$ is cyclic. Prove that the following two statements are equivalent: $\bullet$ There is a point $X$ on the circumcircle of $ABC$ such that $BDX$, $CEX$ are tangent to each other. $\bullet$ $AB \cdot AD \le 4R^2$, where $R$ is the radius of the circumcircle of $ABC$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 1
text: Consider a $2021$-by-$2021$ board of unit squares. For some integer $k$, we say the board is tiled by $k$-by-$k$ squares if it is completely covered by (possibly overlapping) $k$-by-$k$ squares with their corners on the corners of the unit squares. What is the largest integer k such that the minimum number of $k$-by-$k$ squares needed to tile the $2021$-by-$2021$ board is exactly equal to $100$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 2
text: Gary is baking cakes, one at a time. However, Gary’s not been having much success, and each failed cake will cause him to slowly lose his patience, until eventually he gives up. Initially, a failed cake has a probability of $0$ of making him give up. Each cake has a $1/2$ of turning out well, with each cake independent of every other cake. If two consecutive cakes turn out well, the probability resets to $0$ immediately after the second cake. On the other hand, if the cake fails, assuming that he doesn’t give up at this cake, his probability of breaking on the next failed cake goes from p to $p + 0.5$. If the expected number of successful cakes Gary will bake until he gives up is$ p/q$, for relatively prime $p, q$, find $p + q$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 3
text: Alice and Bob are playing a guessing game. Bob is thinking of a number n of the form $2^a3^b$, where a and b are positive integers between $ 1$ and $2020$, inclusive. Each turn, Alice guess a number m, and Bob will tell her either $\gcd (m, n)$ or $lcm (m, n)$ (letting her know that he is saying that $gcd$ or $lcm$), as well as whether any of the respective powers match up in their prime factorization. In particular, if $m = n$, Bob will let Alice know this, and the game is over. Determine the smallest number $k$ so that Alice is always able to find $n$ within $k$ guesses, regardless of Bob’s number or choice of revealing either the $lcm$, or the $gcd$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 4
text: Find the number of points $P \in Z^2$ that satisfy the following two conditions: 1) If $Q$ is a point on the circle of radius $\sqrt{2020}$ centered at the origin such that the line $PQ$ is tangent to the circle at $Q$, then $PQ$ has integral length. 2) The x-coordinate of $P$ is $38$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 5
text: Suppose two polygons may be glued together at an edge if and only if corresponding edges of the same length are made to coincide. A $3\times 4$ rectangle is cut into $n$ pieces by making straight line cuts. What is the minimum value of $n$ so that it’s possible to cut the pieces in such a way that they may be glued together two at a time into a polygon with perimeter at least $2021$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 6
text: We say that a string of digits from $0$ to $9$ is valid if the following conditions hold: First, for $2 \le k \le 4$, no consecutive run of $k$ digits sums to a multiple of $10$. Second, between any two $0$s, there are at least $3$ other digits. Find the last four digits of the number of valid strings of length $2020$.

title: max area of triangle with vertices on concentric circles 2020 PUMaC Team 7
text: Let $X, Y$, and $Z$ be concentric circles with radii $1$, $13$, and $22$, respectively. Draw points $A, B$, and $C$ on $X$, $Y$, and $Z$, respectively, such that the area of triangle $ABC$ is as large as possible. If the area of the triangle is $\Delta$, find $\Delta^2$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 8
text: Let there be a tiger, William, at the origin. William leaps $ 1$ unit in a random direction, then leaps $2$ units in a random direction, and so forth until he leaps $15$ units in a random direction to celebrate PUMaC’s 15th year. There exists a circle centered at the origin such that the probability that William is contained in the circle (assume William is a point) is exactly $1/2$ after the $15$ leaps. The area of that circle can be written as $A\pi$. What is $A$?

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 9
text: Consider a regular $2020$-gon circumscribed into a circle of radius $ 1$. Given three vertices of this polygon such that they form an isosceles triangle, let $X$ be the expected area of the isosceles triangle they create. $X$ can be written as $\frac{1}{m \tan((2\pi)/n)}$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers. Compute $m + n$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 10
text: Let $N$ be the number of sequences of positive integers greater than $ 1$ where the product of all of the terms of the sequence is $12^{64}$. If $N$ can be expressed as $a(2^b)$ ), where $a$ is an odd positive integer, determine $b$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 11
text: Three (not necessarily distinct) points in the plane which have integer coordinates between $ 1$ and $2020$, inclusive, are chosen uniformly at random. The probability that the area of the triangle with these three vertices is an integer is $a/b$ in lowest terms. If the three points are collinear, the area of the degenerate triangle is $0$. Find $a + b$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 12
text: Given a sequence $a_0, a_1, a_2,..., a_n$, let its arithmetic approximant be the arithmetic sequence $b_0, b_1,..., b_n$ that minimizes the quantity $\sum_{i=0}^{n}(b_i -a_i)^2$, and denote this quantity the sequence’s anti-arithmeticity. Denote the number of integer sequences whose arithmetic approximant is the sequence $4$, $8$, $12$, $16$ and whose anti-arithmeticity is at most $20$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 13
text: Will and Lucas are playing a game. Will claims that he has a polynomial $f$ with integer coefficients in mind, but Lucas doesn’t believe him. To see if Will is lying, Lucas asks him on minute $i$ for the value of $f(i)$, starting from minute $ 1$. If Will is telling the truth, he will report $f(i)$. Otherwise, he will randomly and uniformly pick a positive integer from the range $[1,(i+1)!]$. Now, Lucas is able to tell whether or not the values that Will has given are possible immediately, and will call out Will if this occurs. If Will is lying, say the probability that Will makes it to round $20$ is $a/b$. If the prime factorization of $b$ is $p_1^{e_1}... p_k^{e_k}$, determine the sum $\sum_{i=1}^{k} e_i$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 14
text: Let $N$ be the number of convex $27$-gons up to rotation there are such that each side has length $ 1$ and each angle is a multiple of $2\pi/81$. Find the remainder when $N$ is divided by $23$.

title: 2020 PUMaC Team 15
text: Suppose that f is a function $f: R_{\ge 0} \to R$ so that for all $x, y \in R_{\ge 0}$ (nonnegative reals) we have that $$f(x)+f(y) = f(x+y+xy)+f(x)f(y).$$Given that $f\left(\frac{3}{5} \right) = \frac12$ and$ f(1) = 3$, determine $$\lfloor \log_2 (-f(10^{2021} - 1)) \rfloor.$$

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals A1
text: Given the graph $G$ and cycle $C$ in it, we can perform the following operation: add another vertex $v$ to the graph, connect it to all vertices in $C$ and erase all the edges from $C$. Prove that we cannot perform the operation indefinitely on a given graph.
solution: Suppose otherwise and suppose we start with $E$ edges Clearly the operation preserves the connectedness of the graph and doesn't change the number of edges so as we increase the number of vertices by one in each step of the operation we eventually end up with $E$ edges and $E+2$ vertices so it's disconnected—contradiction

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals A2
text: Prove that for every positive integer $m$, every prime $p$ and every positive integer $j \le p^{m-1}$, $p^m$ divides $${p^m \choose p^j }- {p^{m-1} \choose j}$$

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals A3
text: Let $ABCDEF$ be a convex hexagon with area $S$ such that $AB \parallel DE$, $BC \parallel EF$, $CD \parallel FA$ holds, and whose all angles are obtuse and opposite sides are not the same length. Prove that the following inequality holds: $$A_{ABC} + A_{BCD} + A_{CDE} + A_{DEF} + A_{EFA} + A_{FAB} < S$$, where $A_{XYZ}$ is the area of triangle $XYZ$

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals B1 2^n = 7^m + 9
text: Find all pairs of nonnegative integers $(n, m)$ such that $2^n = 7^m + 9$.
solution:
Considering the equation modulo $3$ shows that $m$ is even write $n=2k $ Then we can rearrange to get 
 $$7^m =2^{2k} 9 =(2^k 3)(2^k+3) $$ Hence $2^k 3 2^k +3$ must both be powers of $7$ but as their difference is $6$ they cannot simultaneously be divisible by $7 $ Thus $2^k 3=1$ and so $n =4 $ This lead to the only solution $(n m)=(4 1) $

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals B2
text: Let $G = (V, E)$ be a simple connected graph. Show that there exists a subset of edges $F \subseteq E$ such that every vertex in $H = (V, F)$ has odd degree if and only if $|V |$ is even. Note: A connected graph is a graph such that any two vertices have a sequence of edges connecting one to the other. Note: A simple graph has no loops (edges of the form $(v, v)$) or duplicate edges.

title: 2019 PUMaC Individual Finals B3
text: Let $MN$ be a chord of the circle $\Gamma$ and let $S$ be the midpoint of $MN$. Let $A, B, C, D$ be points on $\Gamma$ such that $AC$ and $BD$ intersect at $S$ and $A$ and $B$ are on the same side of $MN$. Let $d_A, d_B, d_C, d_D$ be the distances from $MN$ to $A, B, C,$ and $D,$ respectively. Prove that $\frac{1}{d_A}+\frac{1}{d_D}=\frac{1}{d_B}+\frac{1}{d_C}$.
solution:
Similar to the official solution we want to show $\frac{1}{d_A} \frac{1}{d_C}$ is constant This is the same as $\frac{d_C d_A}{d_A\cdot d_C}=\frac{CS\sin\theta AS\sin\theta}{AS\sin\theta\cdot CS\sin\theta}$ where $\theta$ is the angle between $MN$ and $AC$ $AS\cdot CS=MS\cdot NS$ so it suffices to show $\frac{CS AS}{\sin\theta}$ is constant (You can figure out that $CS AS$ has to be $2OS\sin\theta$ from this considering the case where $AC\perp MN$ ) Use Law of Cosines on triangles $OSA$ and $OSC$ (WLOG assume $CS\ge AS$ and $\theta\le 90^\circ$ ) Then 
 $$OS^2+CS^2 2OS\cdot CS\cos(90^\circ \theta)=OC^2=OA^2=OS^2+AS^2 2OS\cdot AS\cos(90^\circ+\theta) $$ Use $\cos(90^\circ \theta)=\sin\theta$ and $\cos(90^\circ+\theta)= \sin\theta$ and then a difference of squares to get $CS AS=2\sin\theta$

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics B1
text: How many ways can you arrange $3$ Alice’s, $1$ Bob, $3$ Chad’s, and $1$ David in a line if the Alice’s are all indistinguishable, the Chad’s are all indistinguishable, and Bob and David want to be adjacent to each other? (In other words, how many ways can you arrange $3$ A’s, $1$ B, $3$ C’s, and $1$ D in a row where the B and D are adjacent?)
solution: Consider $B$ and $D$ being one group Then there are $\frac{7!}{3!3!1!}=140$ ways to arrange them However we must account for the two ways $B$ and $D$ can arrange themselves within the group Thus there are $2\cdot140=\boxed{280}$ ways

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics B2
text: Suppose Alan, Michael, Kevin, Igor, and Big Rahul are in a running race. It is given that exactly one pair of people tie (for example, two people both get second place), so that no other pair of people end in the same position. Each competitor has equal skill; this means that each outcome of the race, given that exactly two people tie, is equally likely. The probability that Big Rahul gets first place (either by himself or he ties for first) can be expressed in the form $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Compute $m+n$.
solution: Click to reveal hidden text 60/240 or 5

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A1/B3
text: Prinstan Trollner and Dukejukem are competing at the game show WASS. Both players spin a wheel which chooses an integer from $1$ to $50$ uniformly at random, and this number becomes their score. Dukejukem then flips a weighted coin that lands heads with probability $\tfrac{3}{5}$. If he flips heads, he adds $1$ to his score. A player wins the game if their score is higher than the other player's score. A player wins the game if their score is higher than the other player's score. The probability Dukejukem defeats the Trollner to win WASS equals $\tfrac{m}{n}$ where $m$ and $n$ are coprime positive integers. Computer $m+n$.
solution:
Let $T$ and $D$ be the numbers that the Trollner and Dukejukem get from the wheel Envision a $50\times 50$ grids where rows correspond to values of $T$ and columns correspond to values of $D$ (a $4\times 4$ of similar nature is shown below the colors will be explained shortly) Each element of this grid corresponds to a pair $(T D)$ 
 $$\begin{matrix}
\color{red}{(1 1)}&\color{blue}{(2 1)}&(3 1)&(4 1)\\
(1 2)&\color{red}{(2 2)}&\color{blue}{(3 2)}&(4 2)\\
(1 3)&(2 3)&\color{red}{(3 3)}&\color{blue}{(4 3)}\\
(1 4)&(2 4)&(3 4)&\color{red}{(4 4)}
\end{matrix}$$ Consider the "main diagonal" of this grid (colored in red) where $T=D$ Each grid slot below this main diagonal represents a situation in which Dukejukem wins if the coin lands tails In this case he would have a 
 $$\frac{1+2+3+\dots+49}{50^2}=\frac{49}{100}$$ probability of winning If instead the coin were to land heads the set of ties shifts upwards to the points where $T=D+1$ (colored in blue) Using similar reasoning to before the probability Dukejukem wins is 
 $$\frac{1+2+3+\dots+50}{50^2}=\frac{51}{100} $$ These situations occur with probability $\tfrac{2}{5}$ and $\tfrac{3}{5}$ respectively so our final probability is 
 $$\frac{2}{5}\cdot\frac{49}{100}+\frac{3}{5}\cdot{51}{100}=\frac{251}{500} $$ yielding a final answer of $251+500=\boxed{751}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A2 / B4
text: Keith has $10$ coins labeled $1$ through $10$, where the $i$th coin has weight $2^i$. The coins are all fair, so the probability of flipping heads on any of the coins is $\tfrac{1}{2}$. After flipping all of the coins, Keith takes all of the coins which land heads and measures their total weight, $W$. If the probability that $137\le W\le 1061$ is $\tfrac{m}{n}$ for coprime positive integers $m,n$, determine $m+n$.
solution: I realized you could do casework on the highest value of the coin heads up If the highest you flip is $1024$ then the sum of the rest is $37$ If we do $64$ as the next highest that will be too much and if we do $16$ that will be too little so every combination below that is valid There are $3$ coins below $16$ so there are $2^4$ combinations including the $16$ The last possibility is getting a $32$ Then the only two ways to get below $1061$ is a $2$ or a $4$ Thus there are $2$ possibilities for this subcase Below $1024$ we can check that $512$ and everything below it is valid meaning $2^8$ ways and $256$ and everything below it is valid meaning $2^7$ ways Lastly we have $128$ since $64$ can't sufficiently reach $137$ For the $128$ case we need to get above $9$ more So we use complementary counting There are $4$ ways we can't reach $9$ (2 4 8 2 & 4) and everything else works so there are $2^6 4$ combinations for this case Adding up the cases we get $2^4+2+2^8+2^7+2^6 4=16+2+256+128+64 4=462$ ways There are $2^{10}$ total possibilities so the probability is $\frac{462}{1024}=\frac{231}{512}\Rightarrow \boxed{743}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A3 / B5
text: Marko lives on the origin of the Cartesian plane. Every second, Marko moves $1$ unit up with probability $\tfrac{2}{9}$, $1$ unit right with probability $\tfrac{2}{9}$, $1$ unit up and $1$ unit right with probability $\tfrac{4}{9}$, and he doesn’t move with probability $\tfrac{1}{9}$. After $2019$ seconds, Marko ends up on the point $(A, B)$. What is the expected value of $A\cdot B$?
solution:
Let Marko's position at time $n$ seconds be $(A B)$ At $n+1$ seconds the expected value of the product $A\cdot B$ would be $$\frac{2}{9} A(B+1)+\frac{2}{9} (A+1)B +\frac{4}{9} (A+1)(B+1) +\frac{1}{9} AB$$ $$=\frac{2}{9}AB+\frac{2}{9}AB+\frac{4}{9}AB+\frac{1}{9}AB+\frac{2}{9}A+\frac{4}{9}A+\frac{2}{9}B+\frac{4}{9}B+\frac{4}{9}$$ $$=AB+\frac{2}{3} A+\frac{2}{3} B+\frac{4}{9}$$ $$=\left (A+\frac{2}{3}\right)\left(B+\frac{2}{3}\right) $$ Since Marko started at $(0 0)$ his coordinates in the expected situation for the product would be $\left(2019\cdot \frac{2}{3} 2019\cdot\frac{2}{3}\right)$ so the product would be $1346^2=\boxed{1811716} $ 
 
 I'm not entirely certain my reasoning was correct (the "expected situation for the product" part) but it got me the right answer so I think it's right

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A4/B6
text: Kelvin and Quinn are collecting trading cards; there are $6$ distinct cards that could appear in a pack. Each pack contains exactly one card, and each card is equally likely. Kelvin buys packs until he has at least one copy of every card, and then he stops buying packs. If Quinn is missing exactly one card, the probability that Kelvin has at least two copies of the card Quinn is missing is expressible as $\tfrac{m}{n}$ for coprime positive integers $m$ and $n$. Determine $m+n$.
