title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A5/B7
text: A candy store has $100$ pieces of candy to give away. When you get to the store, there are five people in front of you, numbered from $1$ to $5$. The $i$th person in line considers the set of positive integers congruent to $i$ modulo $5$ which are at most the number of pieces of candy remaining. If this set is empty, then they take no candy. Otherwise they pick an element of this set and take that many pieces of candy. For example, the first person in line will pick an integer from the set $\{1,6,\dots,96\}$ and take that many pieces of candy. How many ways can the first five people take their share of candy so that after they are done there are at least $35$ pieces of candy remaining?
solution: Note that the $i$ t h person takes a number of pieces of candy of the form $i+5a_i$ where $a_i$ is a valid non negative integer We then get that the total number of taken pieces of candy is $$\sum_{i=1}^5 (i+5a_i) = 15 + 5(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_5) $$ We wish to satisfy $$100 (15 + 5(a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_5)) \geq 35 \implies a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_5 \leq 10 $$ By Stars and Bars and Hockey Stick the answer is $$\binom{4}{4}+\binom{5}{4}+\binom{6}{4}+\cdots+\binom{14}{4} = \binom{15}{5} = \boxed{3003} $$ as desired

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A6/B8
text: The Nationwide Basketball Society (NBS) has $8001$ teams, numbered $2000$ through $10000$. For each $n$, team $n$ has $n+1$ players, and in a sheer coincidence, this year each player attempted $n$ shots and on team $n$, exactly one player made $0$ shots, one player made $1$ shot,..., one player made $n$ shots. A player's field goal percentage is defined as the percentage of shots the player made, rounded to the nearest tenth of a percent (For instance, $32.45\%$ rounds to $32.5\%$). A player in the NBS is randomly selected among those whose field goal percentage is $66.6\%$. If this player plays for team $k$, the probability that $k\geq 6000$ can be expressed as $\tfrac{p}{q}$ for relatively prime positive integers $p$ and $q$. Find $p+q$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra B1
text: Let $a,b$ be positive integers such that $a+b=10$. Let $\tfrac{p}{q}$ be the difference between the maximum and minimum possible values of $\tfrac{1}{a}+\tfrac{1}{b}$, where $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime positive integers. Compute $p+q$.
solution:
Simplifying $\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}$ we get 
 $$\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = \frac{a + b}{ab} = \frac{10}{ab}$$ 
 To find the minimum value we set $a = 1$ and $b = 9$ order not of particular importance Doing so we get 
 $$min = \frac{10}{1 \times 9} = \frac{10}{9}$$ 
 The maximum value will be achieved if we set $a = b = 5$ In this case we get 
 $$max = \frac{10}{5 \times 5} = \frac{10}{25} = \frac{2}{5}$$ 
 Subtracting we get 
 $$\frac{10}{9} \frac{2}{5} = \frac{50}{45} \frac{18}{45} = \frac{32}{45}$$ 
 Summing we get $32 + 45 = \boxed{77}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra B2
text: If $x$ is a real number so $3^x=27x$, compute $\log_3 \left(\tfrac{3^{3^x}}{x^{3^3}}\right)$.
solution:
We simplify the expression 
 $$\log_3 \bigg(\frac{3^{3^x}}{x^{27}}\bigg) = \log_3 (3^{3^x}) \log_3(x^{27})$$ We can bring out the exponents as a logarithm rule and get 
 $$ = 3^x(1) 27\log_3(x)$$ We can replace the $3^x$ with $27x$ 
 
 We now use the relation given and say 
 $$3^{x 3} = x$$ $$x 3 = \log_3(x)$$ 
 Substituting this we get 
 $$27x 27(x 3) = \boxed{81}$$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A1/B3
text: Let $x$ and $y$ be positive real numbers that satisfy $(\log x)^2+(\log y)^2=\log(x^2)+\log(y^2)$. Compute the maximum possible value of $(\log(xy))^2$.
solution:
The questions asks for the maximum value of 
 $$(\log(xy))^2 = (\log(x) + \log(y))^2$$ 
 This becomes 
 $$(\log(x))^2 + 2\log(x)\log(y) + (\log(y))^2$$ 
 We know that 
 $$(\log(x))^2 + (\log(y))^2 = 2\log(x) + 2\log(y)$$ 
 We can substitute this and get 
 $$2\log(x) + 2\log(y) + 2\log(x)\log(y)$$ Thus we want the maximum value of this expression By intuitive guessing ( /) we get $x = 100$ and $y = 100$ as working pair Thus substituting we get 
 $$2(2) + 2(2) + 2(2)(2) = 4 + 4 + 8 = \boxed{16}$$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A2/B4
text: Let $f(x)=x^2+4x+2$. Let $r$ be the difference between the largest and smallest real solutions of the equation $f(f(f(f(x))))=0$. Then $r=a^{\frac{p}{q}}$ for some positive integers $a$, $p$, $q$ so $a$ is square-free and $p,q$ are relatively prime positive integers. Compute $a+p+q$.
solution:
For brevity let 
 $$f^n(x)=\underbrace{f(f(\dots(x)\dots))}_{n\ f\text{'s}}$$ Note that $f(x)=(x+2)^2 2$ which has solutions $ 2\pm\sqrt{2}$ 
 
 Setting $(x+2)^2 2= 2\pm\sqrt{2}$ gives us $(x+2)^2=\sqrt{2}$ which implies that $ 2\pm\sqrt[4]{2}$ are the roots of $f^2(x)$ 
 
 Doing this again gives $(x+2)^2=\sqrt[4]{2}$ which implies that $ 2\pm\sqrt[8]{2}$ are the roots of $f^3(x)$ 
 
 Finally doing this one more time gives that $ 2\pm\sqrt[16]{2}$ are the roots of $f^4(x)$ The difference between which is $2\sqrt[16]{2}=2^{\frac{17}{16}}$ which gives a final answer of $2+17+16=\boxed{35}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A3/B5
text: Let $Q$ be a quadratic polynomial. If the sum of the roots of $Q^{100}(x)$ (where $Q^i(x)$ is defined by $Q^1(x)=Q(x)$, $Q^i(x)=Q(Q^{i-1}(x))$ for integers $i\geq 2$) is $8$ and the sum of the roots of $Q$ is $S$, compute $|\log_2(S)|$.
solution: Let $Q(x) = x^2 + ax$ We have that the sum of the roots of $Q^{1}(x)$ is $ a$ Similarly $Q^{2}(x) = (x^2+ax)^2+a(x^2+ax)$ whose roots sum to $ 2a$ By the same reasoning $Q^{3}(x)$ is $ 4x$ It is easy to show using induction that $Q^4{n}(x)$ has roots that sum to $ 2^{n 1}a$ Therefore the sum of the roots of $Q^{100}(x)$ is $ 2^{99}a$ $ 2^{99}a = 8 \implies a = \frac{ 8}{2^{99}} = 2^{ 96}$ The sum of the roots of $Q$ are $\log _ 2(2^{ 96}) = \boxed{96}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A4/B6
text: Let $\mathbb N_0$ be the set of non-negative integers. There is a triple $(f,a,b)$, where $f$ is a function from $\mathbb N_0$ to $\mathbb N_0$ and $a,b\in\mathbb N_0$ that satisfies the following conditions: $f(1)=2$ $f(a)+f(b)\leq 2\sqrt{f(a)}$ For all $n>0$, we have $f(n)=f(n-1)f(b)+2n-f(b)$ Find the sum of all possible values of $f(b+100)$.
solution: Note that from condition 2 we must have $f(a)\leq 2\sqrt{f(a)}\implies f(a)\leq 4$ If you run through the possible values of $f(a)$ we easily see that $f(b)=0 1$ For the first case we have that $f(n)=2n$ which gives $b=0\implies f(b+100)=200$ In the second case we have $f(n)=f(n 1)+2n 1$ Since $f(1)=2$ we see that $f(n)$ is the sum of the first $n$ odd numbers with an extra $1$ tacked on the sum of the first $n$ odd numbers is well known to be $n^2$ so $f(n)=n^2+1$ which is easily verified Again this gives $b=0\implies f(b+100)=10001$ so our answer is $\boxed{10201}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A5/B7
text: Let $\omega=e^{\frac{2\pi i}{2017}}$ and $\zeta = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{2019}}$. Let $S=\{(a,b)\in\mathbb{Z}\,|\,0\leq a \leq 2016, 0 \leq b \leq 2018, (a,b)\neq (0,0)\}$. Compute $$\prod_{(a,b)\in S}(\omega^a-\zeta^b).$$
solution: Let's fix $a$ and ignore $a=0$ for now we have the product $$\prod_{a=1}^{2016} (\omega^a \zeta^0)(\omega^a \zeta^1)\cdots (\omega^a \zeta^{2018})$$ Observe that the 2019th roots of unity are the roots of the polynomial $x^{2019} 1$ so our product simplifies to $$\prod_{a=1}^{2016}(\omega^{2019a} 1)$$ Note that $\gcd(2017 2019)=1$ this means that the se t $(0 2019 4038 \cdots 2019\cdot 2016) \pmod {2017}$ is equivalent to the complete residue class $\mod 2017$ Because roots of unity cycle we can then simplify our product even further $$\prod_{a=1}^{2016} (\omega^a 1)=\prod_{a=1}^{2016} (1 \omega^a) $$ Now observe that the 2017th roots of unity other than one are roots of the polynomial $\frac{x^{2017} 1}{x 1}=x^{2016}+x^{2015}+\cdots +x+1$ If we let this equal $f(x)$ the product is essentially equivalent to $f(1)=2017$ Now we address the case when $a=0 b>0$ which is exactly the same as what we just did We have $$\prod_{b=1}^{2018} (1 \zeta^b)$$ Taking the polynomial $x^{2018}+x^{2017}+\cdots +x+1$ we see that this product is equivalent to $2019$ so our answer is $2017\cdot 2019=\boxed{4072323}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A6/B8
text: A weak binary representation of a nonnegative integer $n$ is a representation $n=a_0+2\cdot a_1+2^2\cdot a_2+\dots$ such that $a_i\in\{0,1,2,3,4,5\}$. Determine the number of such representations for $513$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A7
text: A doubly-indexed sequence $a_{m,n}$, for $m$ and $n$ nonnegative integers, is defined as follows: $a_{m,0}=0$ for all $m>0$ and $a_{0,0}=1$. $a_{m,1}=0$ for all $m>1$, $a_{1,1}=1$, and $a_{0,1}=0$. $a_{0,n}=a_{0,n-1}+a_{0,n-2}$ for all $n\geq 2$. $a_{m,n}=a_{m,n-1}+a_{m,n-2}+a_{m-1,n-1}-a_{m-1,n-2}$ for all $m>0$, $n\geq 2$. Then there exists a unique value of $x$ so $\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{m,n}x^m}{3^{n-m}}=1$. Find $\lfloor 1000x^2 \rfloor$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Algebra A8
text: For real numbers $a$ and $b$, define the sequence $\{x_{a,b}(n)\}$ as follows: $x_{a,b}(1)=a$, $x_{a,b}(2)=b$, and for $n>1$, $x_{a,b}(n+1)=(x_{a+b}(n-1))^2+(x_{a,b}(n))^2$. For real numbers $c$ and $d$, define the sequence $\{y_{c,d}(n)\}$ as follows: $y_{c,d}(1)=c$, $y_{c,d}(2)=d$, and for $n>1$, $y_{c,d}(n+1)=(y_{c,d}(n-1)+y_{c,d}(n))^2$. Call $(a,b,c)$ a good triple if there exists $d$ such that for all $n$ sufficiently large, $y_{c,d}(n)=(x_{a,b}(n))^2$. For some $(a,b)$ there are exactly three values of $c$ that make $(a,b,c)$ a good triple. Among these pairs $(a,b)$, compute the maximum value of $\lfloor 100(a+b)\rfloor$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry B1
text: Suppose we have a convex quadrilateral $ABCD$ such that $\angle B = 100^\circ$ and the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$ has a center at $D$. Find the measure, in degrees, of $\angle D$. Note: The circumcircle of a $\triangle ABC$ is the unique circle containing $A$, $B$, and $C$.
solution:
Let us say $\angle D = 2x$ and construct another point on the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$ outside $\triangle ABC$ labeled $D' $ 
 $\angle AD'C=x$ and since $ABC'D$ is cyclic we know that opposite angles sum to $180^{\circ} $ Thus $\angle D' = 180 100=80$ and $\angle D=\boxed{160^{\circ}}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A1/B2
text: A right cone in $xyz$-space has its apex at $(0,0,0)$, and the endpoints of a diameter on its base are $(12,13,-9)$ and $(12,-5,15)$. The volume of the cone can be expressed as $a\pi$. What is $a$?
solution: We see that the midpoint of the base of the cone is $(12 4 3)$ which means that the height is $12^2+3^2+4^2=c^2$ which means that $c=13$ or that the height is $13$ We can also see that the diameter of the base is $\sqrt{24^2+18^2}=30$ Thus the radius of the base is $15$ The area of the cone is $\frac{15*15*13*\pi}{3}=975\pi$ thus $a=975$

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A2/B3
text: Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with circumcenter $O$ and orthocenter $H$. Let $D$ be a point on the circumcircle of $ABC$ such that $AD \perp BC$. Suppose that $AB = 6, DB = 2$, and the ratio $\tfrac{\text{area}(\triangle ABC)}{\text{area}(\triangle HBC)}=5.$ Then, if $OA$ is the length of the circumradius, then $OA^2$ can be written in the form $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Compute $m + n$.
solution:
Note that $D$ is the reflection of $H$ over $\overline{BC}$ and set $F = \overline{AH} \cap \overline{BC}$ Area ratios give $AH = 4x HF = DF = x$ for some $x$ By the Pythagorean theorem $BF = \sqrt{4 x^2}$ Also $BF^2 + AF^2 = AB^2 = 36 \implies 24x^2 = 32 \implies x = \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{3}$ Moreover $BF = \frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3}$ By Power of a Point $$BF \cdot CF = AF \cdot DF$$ hence $CF = \frac{5\sqrt{6}}{3}$ and $BC = \frac{7\sqrt{6}}{3}$ Now we compute the circumradius $R$ in two different ways On the one hand it is well known that $AH = 2R \cos A$ so $\cos A = \frac{8\sqrt{3}}{6R}$ On the other hand by the extended Law of Sines we have $\sin A = \frac{BC}{2R} = \frac{7\sqrt{6}}{6R}$ 
 
 By the Pythagorean Identity we have $1 = \sin^2A + \cos^2A = \frac{(8\sqrt{3})^2 + (7\sqrt{6})^2}{36R^2}$ so we may solve for $R^2 = \frac{27}{2}$ yielding an answer of $\boxed{29}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A3/B4
text: Suppose we choose two numbers $x,y\in[0,1]$ uniformly at random. If the probability that the circle with center $(x,y)$ and radius $|x-y|$ lies entirely within the unit square $[0,1]\times [0,1]$ is written as $\tfrac{p}{q}$ with $p$ and $q$ relatively prime nonnegative integers, then what is $p^2+q^2$?
solution:
If we proceed with geometric probability then we wish to compute the region of overlap between the regions described by the following four equations (within the square $x y \in [0 1]$ ) 
 $$\begin{cases}
x |x y| &\ge 0 \\
x + |x y| &\le 1 \\
y |x y| &\ge 0 \\
y + |x y| &\le 1
\end{cases} $$ It is not difficult to find that the region of overlap is a quadrilateral with vertices described by the coordinates $(0 0) (\tfrac{1}{3} \tfrac{2}{3}) (1 1) $ and $(\tfrac{2}{3} \tfrac{1}{3}) $ Using the Shoelace Formula we get that the area of this region is $\tfrac{1}{3} $ so the answer is $$1^2+3^2=\boxed{10} $$ $\square$

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A4/B5
text: Let $BC=6$, $BX=3$, $CX=5$, and let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$. Let $\overline{AX}\perp\overline{BC}$ and $AF=\sqrt{247}$. If $AC$ is of the form $\sqrt{b}$ and $AB$ is of the form $\sqrt{c}$ where $b$ and $c$ are nonnegative integers, find $2c+3b$.
solution: Let $BC\cap AX=D$ Then finding $BD$ is straightforward using either $\cos\angle XBC=\frac{5}{9}\Rightarrow BD=\frac{5}{3}$ by LoC or $[BXC]=2\sqrt{14}\Rightarrow DX=\tfrac{2\sqrt{14}}{3}\Rightarrow BD=\tfrac{5}{3}$ with Heron's Thus $DF=\tfrac{4}{3}$ and $c=AB^2=AD^2+BD^2=247 \frac{16}{9}+\frac{25}{9}=248$ and $b=AC^2=AD^2+DC^2=247 \frac{16}{9}+\frac{169}{9}=264$ so $2c+3b=2\cdot 248+3\cdot 264=\boxed{1288}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A5/B6
text: Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with center $A$, radius $1$ and diameter $BX$. Let $\Omega$ be a circle with center $C$, radius $1$ and diameter $DY $, where $X$ and $Y$ are on the same side of $AC$. $\Gamma$ meets $\Omega$ at two points, one of which is $Z$. The lines tangent to $\Gamma$ and $\Omega$ that pass through $Z$ cut out a sector of the plane containing no part of either circle and with angle $60^\circ$. If $\angle XY C = \angle CAB$ and $\angle XCD = 90^\circ$, then the length of $XY$ can be written in the form $\tfrac{\sqrt a+\sqrt b}{c}$ for integers $a, b, c$ where $\gcd(a, b, c) = 1$. Find $a + b + c$.
solution:
The tangent line condition is sort of weird but if you draw in the radii to $Z$ you'll find that it's equivalent to $\angle AZC=120^\circ$ Then you can find that $AC=\sqrt3$ We also know that $\angle XYC=\angle CAB=180^\circ \angle XAC$ so $ACYX$ is cyclic Moreover since $\angle XCD=90^\circ$ we also have $\angle XCY=\angle XAY=90^\circ$ Since $AX=CY=1$ we have $AY=CX=\sqrt{a^2 1}$ where $XY=a$ Then using Ptolemy's on $ACYX$ we have 
 $$1+\sqrt3 a=a^2 1 $$ and solving for the positive solution for $a$ is $\tfrac{\sqrt3+\sqrt{11}}{2}$ so the answer is $\boxed{16} $

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A6/B7
text: Let two ants stand on the perimeter of a regular $2019$-gon of unit side length. One of them stands on a vertex and the other one is on the midpoint of the opposite side. They start walking along the perimeter at the same speed counterclockwise. The locus of their midpoints traces out a figure $P$ in the plane with $N$ corners. Let the area enclosed by the convex hull of $P$ be $\tfrac{A}{B}\tfrac{\sin^m\left(\tfrac{\pi}{4038}\right)}{\tan\left(\tfrac{\pi}{2019}\right)}$, where $A$ and $B$ are coprime positive integers, and $m$ is the smallest possible positive integer such that this formula holds. Find $A+B+m+N$. Note: The convex hull of a figure $P$ is the convex polygon of smallest area which contains $P$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry A7/B8
text: Let $ABCD$ be a trapezoid such that $AB||CD$ and let $P=AC\cap BD,AB=21,CD=7,AD=13,[ABCD]=168.$ Let the line parallel to $AB$ through $P$ intersect the circumcircle of $BCP$ in $X.$ Circumcircles of $BCP$ and $APD$ intersect at $P,Y.$ Let $XY\cap BC=Z.$ If $\angle ADC$ is obtuse, then $BZ=\frac{a}{b},$ where $a,b$ are coprime positive integers. Compute $a+b.$
solution: First extend $PX$ to meet $(APD)$ at $E$ and let $F=YE\cap AD $ It's well known that there exists a spiral similarity $\phi$ at $Y$ sending $\triangle EDA$ to $\triangle XBC $ so in particular we get that $\phi(F)=Z$ and thus $\tfrac{YF}{YE}=\tfrac{YZ}{YX}\implies FZ||AB $ which combined with the fact that $\phi(AFD)=CZB\implies \tfrac{AF}{FD}=\tfrac{CZ}{ZB}$ gives us $BZ=CZ $ Now we actually start computing stuff which is thankfully not hard we observe that the height of the trapezoid is $\tfrac{2[ABCD]}{AB+CD}=\tfrac{168}{14}=12 $ so the Pythagorean Theorem then gives us $BC=15\implies BZ=\tfrac{15}{2}\implies\boxed{17} $ $\blacksquare$

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A7
text: In the country of PUMACsboro, there are $n$ distinct cities labelled $1$ through $n$. There is a rail line going from city $i$ to city $j$ if and only if $i<j$; you can only take this rail line from city $i$ to city $j$. What is the smallest possible value of $n$ such that if each rail line's track is painted orange or black, you can always take the train between $2019$ cities on tracks that are all the same color? (This means there are some cities $c_1,c_2,\dots,c_{2019}$ such that there is a rail line going from city $c_i$ to $c_{i+1}$ for all $1\leq i\leq 2018$ and their rail lines' tracks are either all orange or all black.)

title: 2019 PUMaC Combinatorics A8
text: Let $S_n$ be the set of points $(x/2,y/2)\in\mathbb{R}^2$ such that $x$ and $y$ are odd integers and $|x|\leq y\leq 2n$. Let $T_n$ be the number of graphs $G$ with vertex set in $S_n$ satisfying the following conditions: G has no cycles. If two points share an edge, then the distance between them is $1$. For any path $P = (a,\dots,b)$ in $G$, the smallest $y$-coordinate among the points in $P$ is either that of $a$ or that of $b$. However, multiple points may share this $y$-coordinate. Find the $100$th-smallest positive integer $n$ such that the units digit of $T_{3n}$ is $4$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Geometry G8
text: Let $\gamma$ and $\Gamma$ be two circles such that $\gamma$ is internally tangent to $\Gamma$ at a point $X$. Let $P$ be a point on the common tangent of $\gamma$ and $\Gamma$ and $Y$ be the point on $\gamma$ other than $X$ such that $PY$ is tangent to $\gamma$ at $Y$. Let $PY$ intersect $\Gamma$ at $A$ and $B$, such that $A$ is in between $P$ and $B$ and let the tangents to $\Gamma$ at $A$ and $B$ intersect at $C$. $CX$ intersects $\Gamma$ again at $Z$ and $ZY$ intersects $\Gamma$ again at $Q$. If $AQ = 6, AB = 10$ and $\tfrac{AX}{XB} = \tfrac{1}{4}$. The length of $QZ = \tfrac{p}{q}\sqrt{r}$ where $p$ and $q$ are coprime positive integers, and $r$ is square free positive integer. Find $p + q + r$.
solution:
It is well known that $\overline{XC}$ is the symmedian in $\triangle XAB$ so $XAZB$ is harmonic Moreover by the Archimedes Lemma $XY$ is the bisector of $\angle AXB$ As the bisectors of opposite angles intersect on the diagonal in a harmonic quadrilateral (easy to prove with the angle bisector theorem) we have that $ZY$ must be an angle bisector so $Q$ is the midpoint of arc $\widehat{AXB}$ of $\Gamma$ 
 
 By the angle bisector theorem $\frac{AX}{XB} = \frac{AY}{YB} = \frac{1}{4}$ so $AY = 2 BY = 8$ Since $AQ = BQ = 6$ if $M$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AB}$ by the Pythagorean theorem we get $QM = \sqrt{11}$ Note that $MY = 3$ so $QY = \sqrt{11 + 3^2} = 2\sqrt{5}$ 
 
 Then by Power of a Point $YZ = \frac{AY \cdot BY}{QY} = \frac{8\sqrt{5}}{5}$ so $QZ = QY + YZ = \frac{18\sqrt{5}}{5}$ so the answer is $18 + 5 + 5 = \boxed{28}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 1
text: Two unit squares are stacked on top of one another to form a $1 \times 2$ rectangle. Each of the seven edges is colored either red or blue. How many ways are there to color the edges in this way such that there is exactly one path along all-blue edges from the bottom-left corner to the top-right corner?

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 2 Rock–Paper–Scissors
text: In a standard game of Rock–Paper–Scissors, two players repeatedly choose between rock, paper, and scissors, until they choose different options. Rock beats scissors, scissors beats paper, and paper beats rock. Nathan knows that on each turn, Richard randomly chooses paper with probability $33\%$, scissors with probability $44\%$, and rock with probability $23\%$. If Nathan plays optimally against Richard, the probability that Nathan wins is expressible as $a/b$ where $a$ and $b$ are coprime positive integers. Find $a + b$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 3
text: Julia is placing identical $1$-by-$1$ tiles on the $2$-by-$2$ grid pictured, one piece at a time, so that every piece she places after the first is adjacent to, but not on top of, some piece she’s already placed. Determine the number of ways that Julia can complete the grid.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 4
text: What is the sum of the leading (first) digits of the integers from $ 1$ to $2019$ when the integers are written in base $3$? Give your answer in base $10$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 5
text: Let $f(x) = x^3 + 3x^2 + 1$. There is a unique line of the form $y = mx + b$ such that $m > 0$ and this line intersects $f(x)$ at three points, $A, B, C$ such that $AB = BC = 2$. Find $\lfloor 100m \rfloor$.
solution:
$f(x+a) f(x)=3ax^2+3a^2x+a^3+6ax+3a^2$ 
 $f(x) f(x a)=3ax^2 3a^2x+a^3+6ax 3a^2$ 
 
 we want $3a^2x+3a^2=0$ but $a\ne 0$ so $x= 1$ 
 
 $f(x+a) f(x)$ simplifies into $a^3 3a$ at $x= 1$ 
 
 the slope will be $\frac{a^3 3a}{a}=a^2 3$ 
 
 we also know that $a^2+(a^3 3a)^2=4$ so $a^6 6a^4+10a^2 4=0$ so $(a^2 2)(a^4 4a^2+2)=0$ so $(a^2 2)^2=2$ so $a^2=2+\sqrt2$ so our answer is $\lfloor 100(\sqrt2 1)\rfloor=\boxed{41}$

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 6
text: Pavel and Sara roll two, fair six-sided dice (with faces labeled from $ 1$ to $6$) but do not look at the result. A third-party observer whispers the product of the face-up numbers to Pavel and the sum of the face-up numbers to Sara. Pavel and Sara are perfectly rational and truth-telling, and they both know this. Pavel says, “With the information I have, I am unable to deduce the sum of the two numbers rolled.” Sara responds, “Interesting! With the information I have, I am unable to deduce the product of the two numbers rolled.” Pavel responds, “Wow! I still cannot deduce the sum. But I’m sure you know the product by now!” What is the product?

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 7
text: For all sets $A$ of complex numbers, let $P(A)$ be the product of the elements of $A$. Let $S_z = \{1, 2, 9, 99, 999, \frac{1}{z},\frac{1}{z^2}\}$, let $T_z$ be the set of nonempty subsets of $S_z$ (including $S_z$), and let $f(z) = 1 + \sum_{s\in T_z} P(s)$. Suppose $f(z) = 6125000$ for some complex number $z$. Compute the product of all possible values of $z$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 8
text: The curves $y = x + 5$ and $y = x^2 - 3x$ intersect at points $A$ and $B$. $C$ is a point on the lower curve between $A$ and $B$. The maximum possible area of the quadrilateral $ABCO$ can be written as $A/B$ for coprime $A, B$. Find $A + B$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 10
text: Define the unit $N$-hypercube to be the set of points $[0, 1]^N \subset R^N$. For example, the unit $0$-hypercube is a point, and the unit $3$-hypercube is the unit cube. Define a $k$-face of the unit $N$-hypercube to be a copy of the $k$-hypercube in the exterior of the $N$-hypercube. More formally, a $k$-face of the unit $N$-hypercube is a set of the form $$\prod_{i=1}^{N} S_i$$where $S_i$ is either $\{0\}$, $\{1\}$, or $[0, 1]$ for each $1 \le i \le N$, and there are exactly $k$ indices $i$ such that $S_i = [0, 1]$. The expected value of the dimension of a random face of the unit $ 8$-hypercube (where the dimension of a face can be any value between $0$ and $N$) can be written in the form $p/q$ where $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $p + q$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 11
text: The game Prongle is played with a special deck of cards: on each card is a nonempty set of distinct colors. No two cards in the deck contain the exact same set of colors. In this game, a “Prongle” is a set of at least $2$ cards such that each color is on an even number of cards in the set. Let k be the maximum possible number of prongles in a set of $2019$ cards. Find $\lfloor \log 2 (k) \rfloor$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 12
text: In quadrilateral $ABCD$, angles $A, B, C, D$ form an increasing arithmetic sequence. Also, $\angle ACB = 90^o$. If $CD = 14$ and the length of the altitude from $C$ to $AB$ is $9$, compute the area of $ABCD$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 13
text: Let $e_1, e_2,... e_{2019}$ be independently chosen from the set $\{0, 1,..., 20\}$ uniformly at random. Let $\omega = e^{\frac{2\pi}{i} 2019}$. Determine the expected value of $$|e_1\omega + e_2\omega^2 +... + e_{2019}\omega^{2019}|.$$

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 14
text: Consider a grid of black and white squares with $3$ rows and $n$ columns. If there is a non-empty sequence of white squares $s_1$, $...$, $s_m$ such that $s_1$ is in the top row and $s_m$ is in the bottom row and consecutive squares in the sequence share an edge, then we say that the grid percolates. Let $T_n$ be the number of grids which do not percolate. There exists constants a, b such that $\frac{T_n}{ab^n}$ approaches $ 1$ as $n$ approaches $\infty$. Then $b$ is expressible as $(x+ \sqrt{y})/z$ for squarefree $y$ and coprime $x, z$. Find $x + y + z$.

title: 2019 PUMaC Team Round 15
text: Determine the number of functions $f: Z^+ \to Z^+$ so that for all positive integers $x$ we have $f(f(x)) = f(x + 1)$, and $\max (f(2),..., f(14)) \le f(1) - 2 = 12$.

title: 2019 A/NT1: A Geometric Progression
text: Let $a_1$, $a_2$, $\ldots$, $a_n$ be a geometric progression with $a_1 = \sqrt{2}$ and $a_2 = \sqrt[3]{3}$. What is \[\displaystyle{\frac{a_1+a_{2013}}{a_7+a_{2019}}}?\]
solution:
Let the value of the common ratio of the sequence be $r$ The given quantity is then equal to 
 $$\frac{a_1+a_{2013}}{r^6(a_1+a_{2013})}=\frac{1}{r^6} $$ We can then compute $r$ as the ratio of the second term to the first term so 
 $$\frac{1}{r^6}=\frac{(\sqrt{2})^6}{(\sqrt[3]{3})^6}=\boxed{\frac{8}{9}} $$

title: 2019 A/NT2: Fraction is Not an Integer
text: For all positive integers $n$, let $f(n)$ return the smallest positive integer $k$ for which $\tfrac{n}{k}$ is not an integer. For example, $f(6) = 4$ because $1$, $2$, and $3$ all divide $6$ but $4$ does not. Determine the largest possible value of $f(n)$ as $n$ ranges over the set $\{1,2,\ldots, 3000\}$.
solution: Calculate $12 \# = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 = 2310 $ Note that for prime factorized $n = \prod_{j = 1}^k p_j^{e_j}$ we have $f(n) = \min\left(p_1^{e_1 + 1} p_2^{e_2 + 1} \cdots p_k^{e_k + 1} q\right) $ where $q$ is the smallest prime that does not divide $n $ The upper bound on $f(n)$ is thus $q $ so we want all the $p_j^{e_j + 1} \geq q $ Also $q \leq 11$ because $13 \# > 3000 $ We have established $q = 11$ as an upper bound the number $n = 2^3 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 = 2520$ shows that $f(2520) = \boxed{11}$ is the maximum

title: 2019 A/NT3: The Annual Polynomial Problem
text: Let $P(x)$ be a quadratic polynomial with real coefficients such that $P(3) = 7$ and \[P(x) = P(0) + P(1)x + P(2)x^2\]for all real $x$. What is $P(-1)$?
solution:
Let $P(x)=ax^2+bx+c$ Then $P(0)=c P(1)=b P(2)=a$ gives the three equations $c=c a+b+c=b 4a+2b+c=a$ The second equation gives $a= c$ Substituting into the third equation gives $b=c$ 
 
 Thus $P(x)= cx^2+cx+c$ Since $P(3)=7$ $P(3)= 9c+3c+c= 5c=7$ so $c= \frac{7}{5}$ Thus $P( 1)= c=\boxed{\frac{7}{5}}$

title: 2019 A/NT4: Greatest Common Divisor is Three
text: Determine the sum of all positive integers $n$ between $1$ and $100$ inclusive such that \[\gcd(n,2^n - 1) = 3.\]
solution:
Careful From the given we see that $3|n $ Also since $2^n \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ we get that $2|n $ so $6|n $ However we must make sure that $\left(n 2^n 1\right)$ can never be greater than 3 If $2^n 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$ then $4|n $ So if $4 5|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum There is only one such $n = 60 $ 
 If $2^n 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$ then $6|n $ So if $6 7|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum The values of such $n$ are $n = 42 84 $ 
 If $2^n 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{9}$ then $6|n $ So if $6 9|n$ then discount $n$ from the sum The values of such $n$ are $n = 18 36 54 72 90 $ 
 
 Summing from all $n \in [1 100]$ we get $$\sum n = \sum_{k= 1}^{16}6k (60 + 42 + 84 + 18 + 36 + 54 + 72 + 90) = \boxed{360} $$

title: 2019 A/NT5: Two Less than a Square
text: Let $x_n$ be the smallest positive integer such that $7^n$ divides $x_n^2-2$. Find $x_1+x_2+x_3$.
solution: Mod Bash We solve the three equations $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{7 49 343} $ The first two can easily be guessed to give $x_1 = 3 x_2 = 10 $ However note that $x \equiv 3 4 \pmod{7} $ so write them as $x = 7a + 3 7b + 4 $ Substitute each of these into $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{49}$ to get $a \equiv 1 \pmod{7} b \equiv 5 \pmod{7} $ Now write $a = 7c + 1 b = 7d + 5$ to get $x = 49c + 10 49d + 39 $ Substitute $x = 49c + 10$ into $x^2 \equiv 2 \pmod{343}$ to get $c \equiv 2 \pmod{7} \iff c = 7e + 2 \iff x = 343e + 108 $ Now check $x = 39 88$ to see that none of them are congruent to $2 \pmod{343}$ so $x_3 = 108 $ Sum to get $\boxed{121} $

title: 2019 A/NT6: The Obligatory Vieta Problem
text: Let $a, b$ and $c$ be the distinct solutions to the equation $x^3-2x^2+3x-4=0$. Find the value of $$\frac{1}{a(b^2+c^2-a^2)}+\frac{1}{b(c^2+a^2-b^2)}+\frac{1}{c(a^2+b^2-c^2)}.$$
solution:
vieta's We rewrite the sum as $$\sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(P_2 2a^2)}$$ where we define $P_2 = a^2 + b^2 + c^2$ By a computation involving symmetric sums of the roots we can easily see that $P_2 = 2$ so the sum factors as $$ \frac{1}{2} \sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(1+a^2)}$$ One can now perform partial fractions on this summand (by breaking it into fractions with denominators $a a + i a i$ and compute the resulting cyclic sums easily using the given information and the sum inside should evaluate to $\frac{3}{4} \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{4}$ giving a final answer of $\boxed{\frac{1}{8}}$ 
 remark In competition I made a mistake and ended up with the sum $$ \frac{1}{2} \sum_{cyc} \frac{1}{a(1 a^2)}$$ without realizing this was actually wrong It turns out the answer is invariant of this issue most likely due to the fact that the complex phase factors must eventually cancel if all the symmetric sums are real (or something like that) This computation was a little easier to do (because I didn't have to carry the $i$ s around) but even though I haven't done this explicit computation since I don't think it would be much worse

title: 2019 A/NT7: Sum of Phis and Squares of Floors
text: For all positive integers $n$, let \[f(n) = \sum_{k=1}^n\varphi(k)\left\lfloor\frac nk\right\rfloor^2.\]Compute $f(2019) - f(2018)$. Here $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ which are relatively prime to $n$.
solution: Misplaced IMO Rewrite $f(2019) f(2018)$ as $$\sum_{k = 1}^{2018}\varphi(k)\left(\left\lfloor\dfrac{2019}{k}\right\rfloor ^2 \left\lfloor \dfrac{2018}{k} \right\rfloor ^2 \right) + \varphi(2019) $$ Note that the difference of floor functions is nonzero if and only if $k|2019 k < 2019$ and $k$ does not divide 2018 Since $(2019 2018) = 1$ the condition simplifies down to $k|2019 k < 2019 $ To see this write $2018 = qk + r$ using Euclidean division and note that $\left\lfloor \frac{2019}{k} \right \rfloor = \left\lfloor q + \frac{r + 1}{k} \right\rfloor > \left\lfloor \frac{2018}{k} \right\rfloor = q \iff r + 1 = k $ This gives us three such values of $k 1 3 673 $ Thus $f(2019) f(2018) = \varphi(1)\left(2019^2 2018^2\right) + \varphi(3)\left(673^2 672^2\right) + \varphi(673)\left(3^2 2^2\right) + \varphi(2019) = \boxed{11431} $

title: 2019 A/NT8: Transformation of Roots of Unity
text: It is given that the roots of the polynomial $P(z) = z^{2019} - 1$ can be written in the form $z_k = x_k + iy_k$ for $1\leq k\leq 2019$. Let $Q$ denote the monic polynomial with roots equal to $2x_k + iy_k$ for $1\leq k\leq 2019$. Compute $Q(-2)$.
solution:
Let the roots be $e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}} $ Notice that 
 $$Re(e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}})=\frac{e^{\frac{2ki\pi}{2019}}+e^{\frac{ 2ki\pi}{2019}}}{2} $$ 
 Now manipulating some exponents and factoring we see that the value we seek si 
 
 $$\prod_{k=1}^{2018} (\frac{ 4z_k 3z_k^2 1}{2z_k})=( 1)\prod_{k=1}^{2018} (\frac{(3z_k+1)(z_k+1)}{2z_k}) $$ 
 where $z_k$ is a 2019th root of unity Now evaluating each term separate and seeing that the answer is $$\frac{( 1)(T( 1/3))(T( 1))}{2^{2019}}$$ 
 where $T(z) = z^{2019} 1 $ 
 
 the answer is $\frac{ 1 3^{2019}}{2^{2018}} $

title: 2019 A/NT9: 29 Divides a GCD
text: Let $a_0=29$, $b_0=1$ and $$a_{n+1} = a_n+a_{n-1}\cdot b_n^{2019}, \qquad b_{n+1}=b_nb_{n-1}$$for $n\geq 1$. Determine the smallest positive integer $k$ for which $29$ divides $\gcd(a_k, b_k-1)$ whenever $a_1,b_1$ are positive integers and $29$ does not divide $b_1$.
solution:
I guess there is some typo here there is no way to determine the recurrence according to given information 
 Anybody having any nice solutions?

title: 2019 A/NT10: All Coefficients Divisible by n
text: Let $\varphi(n)$ denotes the number of positive integers less than or equal to $n$ which are relatively prime to $n$. Determine the number of positive integers $2\leq n\leq 50$ such that all coefficients of the polynomial \[ \left(x^{\varphi(n)} - 1\right) - \prod_{\substack{1\leq k\leq n\\\gcd(k,n) = 1}}(x-k) \]are divisible by $n$.
solution:
We can actually classify all $n$ with the requested property An integer $n$ satisfies the property if and only if it is prime 4 or twice a Fermat prime (Hence answer 19 ) It's obvious that primes work to see that $n = 2p$ works if $p$ is a Fermat prime note that 
 \[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k n) = 1}}(x k) \equiv (x 1)^{p 1} \equiv x^{p 1} 1 \pmod{2}\] since $p 1$ is a power of 2 and also 
 \[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k n) = 1}}(x k) \equiv \prod_{1 \le k \le p 1} (x k) \equiv x^{p 1} 1 \pmod{p}\] as expected The case $n = 4$ can be checked directly Now we show these $n$ are all Suppose $n$ satisfies the condition Lemma (Necessary condition modulo $p$ ) Let $p$ be a prime divisor of $n$ Then $\varphi(n)$ equals $p 1$ times a power of $p$ 
 
 Proof Suppose $p$ prime divides $n$ Then modulo $p$ 
 \[\prod_{\substack{1\le k\le n\\\gcd(k n) = 1}}(x k) \equiv \prod_{1 \le k \le p 1} (x k)^{\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p 1}} \equiv (x^{p 1} 1)^{\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p 1}}\] which is supposed to equal $x^{\varphi(n)} 1$ This only happens when $\tfrac{\varphi(n)}{p 1}$ is a power of $p$ which concludes the proof Claim (Elimination of non prime powers) If $n$ is not a prime power then $n$ is twice a Fermat prime Proof Suppose $p > q$ are two distinct primes dividing $n$ Then $(p 1)(q 1) \mid \varphi(n)$ so $q 1$ is a power of $p$ and $p 1$ is a power of $q$ But $q 1 < p$ so $q 1 = 1$ and $q = 2$ Thus $p = 2^s + 1$ for some $s$ 
 
 This also demonstrates that 2 and $2^s + 1$ are the only prime factors of $n$ so let $n = 2^e (2^s + 1)^f$ Then $\varphi(n) = 2^{e+s 1} (2^s + 1)^{f 1}$ This is supposed to be a power of 2 so $f = 1$ It is also supposed to be $2^s$ times a power of $2^s + 1$ so $e+s 1 = s$ whence $e = 1$ Hence $n = 2(2^s + 1)$ as expected Now only prime power $n$ remain to be dealt with Write $n = p^e$ say with $e \ge 2$ (since we know $e = 1$ works) Then we require 
 \[x^{p^{e 1}(p 1)} 1 \equiv \prod_{\substack{1 \le k \le p^e\\p \nmid k}} (x k) \pmod{n}\] or upon setting $x \mapsto x 1$ 
 \[(x 1)^{p^{e 1}(p 1)} 1 \equiv \prod_{\substack{1 \le k \le p^e\\p \nmid k 1}} (x k) \pmod{n} \] It is clear that $x^2$ does not divide the LHS above However if $e \neq 2$ then the RHS contains the three distinct factors $x$ $x p$ $x p^{e 1}$ which collectively contain a factor of $x^2$ (as $x$ divides $(x p)(x p^{e 1})$ ) 
 
 Thus $e = 2$ Likewise if $p \neq 2$ the RHS contains the three distinct factors $x$ $x p$ $x 2p$ which multiply to a product divisible by $x^2$ contradiction Thus $(p e) = (2 2)$ so $n = 2^2 = 4$ as expected

title: 2019 C/CS1: Multiple of Four
text: Patrick tosses four four-sided dice, each numbered $1$ through $4$. What's the probability their product is a multiple of four?
solution:
Using complementary counting the chance that the cube does not have a 4 is $1 \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^4=\left(\frac{175}{256}\right) $ 
 
 Then we have cases for the four die of they are 1 to 3 $2 2 2 2 1$ way 
 $2 2 2 (1 3) 4 \times 2=8$ ways 
 $2 2 (1 3) (1 3) 6 \times 4 = 24$ ways 
 
 adding them up there is $\frac{1+8+24+175}{256}=\frac{208}{256}=\boxed{\frac{13}{16}} $

title: 2019 C/CS2: Coloring the Vertices of a Cube
text: How many ways are there to color the vertices of a cube red, blue, or green such that no edge connects two vertices of the same color? Rotations and reflections are considered distinct colorings.
solution:
We don't need colors yet so WLOG we can first name one vertex A The vertices around it must be BBB or BBC (since CCB and CCC are both the same we use WLOG) Case 1 BBB By doing a mini bash you find that there are $10$ ways to color it Case 2 BBC By doing a mini bash you find that there are $9$ ways to color it Adding up we have $10+9=19$ 
 
 But wait! We haven't specified the colors for $A$ $B$ and $C$ 
 
 We have $3!=6$ ways to specify the colors of $A$ $B$ and $C$ Thus the total number of colorings is $19 \times 6 = \boxed{114}$

title: 2019 C/CS3: Two Numbers Multiply to a Third
text: How many ordered triples $(a,b,c)$ of integers with $1\le a\le b\le c\le 60$ satisfy $a\cdot b=c$?
solution:
By speculating we observe that $a \le 7$ because if $a\ge 8 $ then $b \ge 8$ too so $c \ge 64$ 
 
 We count the number of cases for $a=1 2 7$ 
 
 $a=1 60$ ways $a=2 29$ ways $a=3 18$ ways $a=4 12$ ways $a=5 8$ ways $a=6 5$ ways $a=7 2$ ways Adding up we get $60+29+18+12+8+5+2=\boxed{134}$

title: 2019 C/CS4: A Search Algorithm
text: Define a search algorithm called $\texttt{powSearch}$. Throughout, assume $A$ is a 1-indexed sorted array of distinct integers. To search for an integer $b$ in this array, we search the indices $2^0,2^1,\ldots$ until we either reach the end of the array or $A[2^k] > b$. If at any point we get $A[2^k] = b$ we stop and return $2^k$. Once we have $A[2^k] > b > A[2^{k-1}]$, we throw away the first $2^{k-1}$ elements of $A$, and recursively search in the same fashion. For example, for an integer which is at position $3$ we will search the locations $1, 2, 4, 3$. Define $g(x)$ to be a function which returns how many (not necessarily distinct) indices we look at when calling $\texttt{powSearch}$ with an integer $b$ at position $x$ in $A$. For example, $g(3) = 4$. If $A$ has length $64$, find \[g(1) + g(2) + \ldots + g(64).\]
solution:
If we have $2^k$ numbers then doubling the number of numbers would just be adding $k$ to all numbers and then subtracting $k 2$ from the last number for a duplicate Let $f(2^k)$ be the sum of the $g$ s from $1$ to $2^k$ Then we have $f(2^{k+1})=2f(2^k)+(k+2) \times 2^k (k+1)$ 
 
 By calculating the first few numbers we have $f(4)=10$ Thus $f(8)=33$ $f(16)=102$ $f(32)=295$ and $f(64) = \boxed{808}$

title: 2019 C/CS5: Not Tic-Tac-Toe
text: In the game of Ric-Rac-Roe, two players take turns coloring squares of a $3 \times 3$ grid in their color; a player wins if they complete a row or column of their color on their turn. If Alice and Bob play this game, picking an uncolored square uniformly at random on their turn, what is the probability that they tie?

title: 2019 C/CS6: Lightbulbs in a Circle
text: There are $100$ lightbulbs $B_1,\ldots, B_{100}$ spaced evenly around a circle in this order. Additionally, there are $100$ switches $S_1,\ldots, S_{100}$ such that for all $1\leq i\leq 100$, switch $S_i$ toggles the states of lights $B_{i-1}$ and $B_{i+1}$ (where here $B_{101} = B_1$). Suppose David chooses whether to flick each switch with probability $\tfrac12$. What is the expected number of lightbulbs which are on at the end of this process given that not all lightbulbs are off?

title: 2019 C/CS7: Languages Do Not Intersect
text: Consider the set $L$ of binary strings of length less than or equal to $9$, and for a string $w$ define $w^{+}$ to be the set $\{w,w^2,w^3,\ldots\}$ where $w^k$ represents $w$ concatenated to itself $k$ times. title: 2019 C/CS8: Algorithm on a Graph
text: Consider the following graph algorithm (where $V$ is the set of vertices and $E$ the set of edges in $G$). $\textbf{procedure }\textsc{s}(G)$ $\qquad \textbf{if } |V| = 0\textbf{ then return true}$ $\qquad \textbf{for }(u,v)\textbf{ in }E\textbf{ do}$ $\qquad\qquad H\gets G-u-v$ $\qquad\qquad\textbf{if } \textsc{s}(H)\textbf{ then return true}$ $\qquad\textbf{return false}$ Here $G - u - v$ means the subgraph of $G$ which does not contain vertices $u,v$ and all edges using them. How many graphs $G$ with vertex set $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ and exactly $6$ edges satisfy $s(G)$ being true?

title: 2019 C/CS10: Rooted Trees Equivalent Under Cycling
text: Define a rooted tree to be a tree $T$ with a singular node designated as the root of $T$. (Note that every node in the tree can have an arbitrary number of children.) Each vertex adjacent to the root node of $T$ is itself the root of some tree called a maximal subtree of $T$. Say two rooted trees $T_1$ and $T_2$ are similar if there exists some way to cycle the maximal subtrees of $T_1$ to get $T_2$. For example, the first pair of trees below are similar but the second pair are not. How many rooted trees with $2019$ nodes are there up to similarity?

title: 2019 G1: Intersection of Two Congruent Triangles
text: The figure below depicts two congruent triangles with angle measures $40^\circ$, $50^\circ$, and $90^\circ$. What is the measure of the obtuse angle $\alpha$ formed by the hypotenuses of these two triangles?
solution:
Consider the quadrilateral formed by the union of the two triangles Since three of the angles are clearly $90^{\circ}$ $50^{\circ}$ and $50^{\circ}$ the final angle is simply 
 $$360^{\circ} (50^{\circ}+50^{\circ}+90^{\circ})=\boxed{170^{\circ}} $$

title: 2019 G2: Minimum Distance Between Circumcenters
text: Suppose $X, Y, Z$ are collinear points in that order such that $XY = 1$ and $YZ = 3$. Let $W$ be a point such that $YW = 5$, and define $O_1$ and $O_2$ as the circumcenters of triangles $\triangle WXY$ and $\triangle WYZ$, respectively. What is the minimum possible length of segment $\overline{O_1O_2}$?
solution: $\overline{WY}$ lies on the radical axis of the circumcircles Furthermore $H$ is the midpoint of $\overline{WY} $ Angle chase to find $\angle{X} = \angle{YO_1H} \angle{Z} = \angle{YO_2H}$ so $\triangle{YO_1O_2} \sim \triangle{WXZ} $ Thus $\frac{O_1O_2}{HY} = \frac{XZ}{h_W} \iff O_1O_2 = \frac{4 \cdot \frac{5}{2}}{h_W} = \frac{10}{h_W} $ Since $WY = 5 $ the maximum value of $h_W$ is $5 $ when $\overline{WY} \perp \overline{XZ} $ any other configuration gives less Thus $O_1O_2 \geq \boxed{2} $

title: 2019 G3: Isosceles Right Triangle in an Equilateral Triangle
text: Let $ABC$ be an equilateral triangle with side length $2$, and let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$. Points $X$ and $Y$ are placed on $AB$ and $AC$ respectively such that $\triangle XMY$ is an isosceles right triangle with a right angle at $M$. What is the length of $\overline{XY}$?
solution: The problem is symmetric so $\angle{BMX} = \angle{CMY} = 45 \iff \angle{BXM} = \angle{CYM} = 75 $ Using Law of Sines on $\triangle{BXM}$ we see that $\frac{XM}{\sin 60} = \frac{1}{\sin 75} \iff XY = XM \sqrt{2} = \frac{ \sqrt{2} \sin 60}{\sin 75} = \boxed{3 \sqrt{3}} $

title: 2019 G4: Cube in a Right Tetrahedron
text: Suppose $\mathcal{T}=A_0A_1A_2A_3$ is a tetrahedron with $\angle A_1A_0A_3 = \angle A_2A_0A_1 = \angle A_3A_0A_2 = 90^\circ$, $A_0A_1=5, A_0A_2=12$ and $A_0A_3=9$. A cube $A_0B_0C_0D_0E_0F_0G_0H_0$ with side length $s$ is inscribed inside $\mathcal{T}$ with $B_0\in \overline{A_0A_1}, D_0 \in \overline{A_0A_2}, E_0 \in \overline{A_0A_3}$, and $G_0\in \triangle A_1A_2A_3$; what is $s$?
solution: Using 3D coordinates let $A_0=(0 0 0)$ $A_1=(5 0 0)$ $A_2=(0 12 0)$ and $A_3=(0 0 9)$ The point $G_0$ has coordinates $(s s s)$ such that it is on the plane defined by $A_0$ $A_1$ $A_2$ One equation for this plane is $1=\frac{1}{5}x+\frac{1}{12}y+\frac{1}{9}z$ and setting $x=y=z=s$ we get $1=\frac{71}{180}s$ so $s=\boxed{\frac{180}{71}}$

title: 2019 G5: MATH MASH
text: Let $MATH$ be a trapezoid with $MA=AT=TH=5$ and $MH=11$. Point $S$ is the orthocenter of $\triangle ATH$. Compute the area of quadrilateral $MASH$.
solution: Let $P$ be the foot from $A$ to $\overline{MH} $ and $P'$ (not drawn) the foot from $T$ to $\overline{MH} $ Since $MATH$ is symmetrical we have $MP = HP'$ and $MP + PP' + HP' = MP + HP' + 5 = MH = 11 \iff MP + HP' = 6 \iff MP = 3 $ so $AP = 4 $ Furthermore let $\overline{SR} \overline{AQ}$ be the $T $ and $A $ altitudes of $\triangle{HAT} $ respectively We clearly see that $\triangle{SQT} \sim \triangle{ART} \iff SQ = \frac{AR \cdot QT}{RT} $ However by Pythagorean Theorem we have $AH = \sqrt{4^2 + 8^2} = 4\sqrt{5} $ so $AR = 2\sqrt{5}$ and $TR = \sqrt{5} $ by common sense $QT = 3$ and $QH = 4$ so $SQ = 6$ and $SH = 10 $ Thus $[MASH] = [PAM] + [PASH] = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 3 \cdot 4 + \frac{1}{2} (4 + 10) \cdot 8 = 6 + 56 = \boxed{62} $

title: 2019 G6: Parallel to Side of Triangle Through Arc Midpoint
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=209$, $AC=243$, and $\angle BAC = 60^\circ$, and denote by $N$ the midpoint of the major arc $\widehat{BAC}$ of circle $\odot(ABC)$. Suppose the parallel to $AB$ through $N$ intersects $\overline{BC}$ at a point $X$. Compute the ratio $\tfrac{BX}{XC}$.
solution:
Trig Let $\angle{ABN} = a$ and note that $N \in \overarc{AC} $ Since $N$ is the midpoint of $\overarc{BAC}$ we have $BN = CN $ but since $\angle{BNC} = \angle{BAC} = 60$ we see that $\triangle{BCN}$ is equilateral Since $\overline{AB} \parallel \overline{XN}$ we have $\angle{BNX} = a$ as well Use Law of Sines on $\triangle{BXN}$ and $\triangle{CXN}$ to get $$\dfrac{BX}{\sin{a}} = \dfrac{NX}{\sin{60}} \dfrac{CX}{\sin{60 a}} = \dfrac{NX}{\sin{60}} $$ Combine the two to get $$\dfrac{BX}{CX} = \dfrac{\sin{a}}{\sin{60 a}} = \dfrac{\sin a}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos a \frac{1}{2} \sin a} = \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{3} \cot a 1} $$ Now $\angle{ABN}$ and $\angle{ACN}$ subtend the same arc so they are equal thus $\angle{B} = a + 60 \angle{C} = 60 a $ Use the Law of Sines on $\triangle{ABC}$ and get $$\dfrac{209}{\sin (60 a)} = \dfrac{243}{\sin (a + 60)} $$ Now solve for $\cot a $ 
 \begin{align*}
209\left(\frac{1}{2} \sin a + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos a\right) &= 243 \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos a \frac{1}{2} \sin a\right) \\
209 \sin a + 209 \sqrt{3} \cos a &= 243 \sqrt{3} \cos a 243 \sin a \\
34 \sqrt{3} \cos a &= 452 \sin a \\
\cot a &= \dfrac{226}{17 \sqrt{3}}
\end{align*} Substitute back in and solve getting $$\dfrac{BX}{CX} = \dfrac{2}{\frac{226}{17} 1} = \boxed{\dfrac{34}{209}} $$

A line $\ell$ tangent to $\omega$ intersects $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ at $X$ and $Y$ respectively. Suppose $XY=5$. Compute the positive difference between the lengths of $\overline{AX}$ and $\overline{AY}$.
solution:
Let the tangency points to AB and BC be P and Q Let XP=x We then have XA=7 x and YQ=5 x and YA=x+2 from tangents at stuff Now use LoC on ABC to find cosBAC and use that to bash for x with LoC on AXY 
 answer should be sqrt329/7

title: 2019 G8: Three Reflections
text: Consider the following three lines in the Cartesian plane: $$\begin{cases} \ell_1: & 2x - y = 7\\ \ell_2: & 5x + y = 42\\ \ell_3: & x + y = 14 \end{cases}$$and let $f_i(P)$ correspond to the reflection of the point $P$ across $\ell_i$. Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are points on the $x$ and $y$ axes, respectively, such that $f_1(f_2(f_3(X)))= Y$. Let $t$ be the length of segment $XY$; what is the sum of all possible values of $t^2$?
solution: First note that all three lines pass through $(7 7)$ Let $\theta_{1}$ $\theta_{2}$ $\theta_{3}$ be the angle that the three lines form with the ray with endpoint $(7 7)$ in the positive $x$ direction It's not hard to see that $\theta_{1} = \arctan{2}$ $\theta_{2}=\arctan{ 5}$ and $\theta_{3}=\arctan{ 1}$ Note that if a point $P$ makes an angle $\theta$ with the ray defined above then $f_{3}(P)$ will be the same distance from $(7 7)$ as $P$ and will form an angle of $2\theta_{3} \theta$ with the ray Repeating this process we get that $f_1(f_2(f_3(P)))$ will form an angle of $2\theta_{1} (2\theta_{2} (2\theta_{3} \theta))$ with the ray which is equivalent to reflecting $P$ across a line passing through $(7 7)$ forming an angle of $\theta_{1} \theta_{2}+\theta_{3}$ with the ray This line has slope $\tan(\theta_{1} \theta_{2}+\theta_{3})$ which can be computed to be $ 8$ Thus we want to find points on the $x$ axis such that when reflected over $y= 8x+63$ From here it can be seen that there is only one such point namely $X=(16 0)$ which maps to $Y=(0 2)$ $XY^2=2^2+16^2=\boxed{260}$

title: 2019 G9: Locus of Circumcenters of Right Triangles
text: Let $ABCD$ be a square of side length $1$, and let $P_1, P_2$ and $P_3$ be points on the perimeter such that $\angle P_1P_2P_3 = 90^\circ$ and $P_1, P_2, P_3$ lie on different sides of the square. As these points vary, the locus of the circumcenter of $\triangle P_1P_2P_3$ is a region $\mathcal{R}$; what is the area of $\mathcal{R}$?
solution:
Consider the figure formed by the eight parabolas with a focus at one of the vertices of the square and a directrix at each of the two sides opposite to its focus I claim that this figure is indeed the desired locus Firstly assume that $P_1$ and $P_3$ lie on adjacent vertices since otherwise the locus will simply be one of the midlines of the square which is clearly contained within the claimed locus Then WLOG assume that $P_1 \in AB$ $P_2 \in BC$ and $P_3 \in AD$ For any $P_1P_3$ to be the hypotenuse of a right triangle there must exist a $P_2 \in BC$ such that $\angle P_1P_2P_3=90^\circ$ or equivalently the circle $\omega$ with diameter $P_1P_3$ must intersect side $BC$ Note that $A \in \omega$ so $\omega$ intersects $BC$ iff $d(M BC) \le AM$ where $M$ is the midpoint of $P_1P_3$ since $\overline{AM}$ is a radius of $\omega$ Also $M$ must lie in the upper right quadrant of the square since otherwise $\omega$ will intersect $BC$ outside of the segment so the desired locus for this particular configuration is the region of points in the upper right quadrant of the square lying to the left of the parabola with focus $A$ and directrix $BC$ Applying the same argument for the other possibilities yields the desired locus Now we compute the area Scale the square so that its center lies at the origin and $A=(1 1)$ Then the intersection of the parabolas in the upper right quadrant is the intersection of $y=\tfrac{1}{4}(x 1)^2$ and $y=x$ or $(3 2\sqrt{2} 3 2\sqrt{2})$ Then the area of the locus is 
 \[ 4 \cdot (3 2\sqrt{2})^2+8\int_{3 2\sqrt{2}}^1 \tfrac{1}{4}(x 1)^2 dx=\tfrac{1}{3}(92 64\sqrt{2})\] so after scaling back to a unit square we arrive at the answer $\boxed{\tfrac{1}{3}(23 16\sqrt{2})}$

title: 2019 G10: Erecting Right Triangles Outside of Another Triangle
text: Suppose $ABC$ is a triangle, and define $B_1$ and $C_1$ such that $\triangle AB_1C$ and $\triangle AC_1B$ are isosceles right triangles on the exterior of $\triangle ABC$ with right angles at $B_1$ and $C_1$, respectively. Let $M$ be the midpoint of $\overline{B_1C_1}$; if $B_1C_1 = 12$, $BM = 7$ and $CM = 11$, what is the area of $\triangle ABC$?
solution:
Let $X$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$ and let $A_1$ be the point such that $\triangle BA_1C$ is right isosceles with right angle at $A_1$ pointing towards $\triangle ABC$ We prove two claims the first of which is well known Lemma Quadrilateral $AB_1A_1C_1$ is a parallelogram Proof Let $U$ and $V$ be the midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ (not in diagram) Since $\triangle B_1AC \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle C_1BA$ by mean geometry the midpoint triangle $\triangle MUV$ is similar to both and directly similar to $\triangle A_1BC$ Thus $M$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AA_1}$ too done Lemma (Main claim) The triangle $XB_1C_1$ is right isosceles with right angle at $X$ 
 Proof Let $Y$ be the reflection of $C$ over $B_1$ define $Z$ similarly Note $\triangle A_1BC \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle CAY$ so the midpoint triangle $\triangle MXB_1 \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle A_1BC$ Likewise $\triangle MC_1X \stackrel{+}{\sim} \triangle A_1BC$ so $\triangle XB_1C_1$ is right isosceles at $X$ as desired With these two claims the remainder of the solution is easy Since $B_1C_1 = 12$ $MX = 6$ Now 
 \[BC^2 = 2\big(MB^2 + MC^2\big) 4MX^2 = 2(7^2 + 11^2) 12^2 = 196\] and so $BC = 14$ By Heron's formula the area of $\triangle MBC$ equals $\sqrt{16 \cdot 9 \cdot 5 \cdot 2} = 12\sqrt{10}$ Finally since $M$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AA_1}$ 
 \[[ABC] = 2[MBC] [A_1BC] = 2 \cdot 12\sqrt{10} \big(\tfrac{14}{2}\big)^2 = 24\sqrt{10} 49 \]

What is the smallest number of tiles David must remove and/or replace so that he can rearrange them to read $\textsc{Carnegie Mellon University}$?
solution: By Inspecting we can see that $\textsc{Central Michigan University}$ is missing an $\textsc{e e l o}$ thus our answer is $\boxed{4}$

title: 2019 T2: Ordered Pairs Satisfying GCD Property
text: Determine the number of ordered pairs of positive integers $(m,n)$ with $1\leq m\leq 100$ and $1\leq n\leq 100$ such that \[ \gcd(m+1,n+1) = 10\gcd(m,n). \]
solution: sol In the set $S=\{9 19 29 39 49 59 69 79 89 99\}$ the only pairs that are not relatively prime are $(9 39)$ $(9 69)$ $(9 99)$ $(39 69)$ $(39 99)$ $(69 99)$ It can be checked that none of these pairs satisfy the condition On the other hand note that if $a b$ are relatively prime elements of $S$ and $\gcd(a+1 b+1)=10$ then the condition will be satisfied Furthermore the $5$ pairs $(9 39)$ $(9 69)$ $(9 99)$ $(39 69)$ satisfy the property that $\gcd(a+1 b+1)=10$ Finally note that $\gcd(a b)=10$ if $a b$ are multiples of $10$ and $\gcd(a/10 b/10)=1$ In the end all this implies that the answer is $$2\left(\sum_{k=2}^{10} \varphi(k) 5\right)=\boxed{52}$$ where $\varphi(k)$ is the Euler totient function

title: 2019 T3: Equidistant Points on a Parabola
text: Points $A(0,0)$ and $B(1,1)$ are located on the parabola $y=x^2$. A third point $C$ is positioned on this parabola between $A$ and $B$ such that $AC=CB=r$. What is $r^2$?
solution: Let $C=(x x^2)$ so that $x^2+x^4=(1 x)^2+(1 x^2)^2 $ Solving for $x $ we see that $x=\frac{\sqrt{5} 1}{2}$ so the answer is $x^2(1+x^2)=\boxed{1}$

title: 2019 T4: Expected Area of Triangle
text: Let $\triangle A_1B_1C_1$ be an equilateral triangle of area $60$. Chloe constructs a new triangle $\triangle A_2B_2C_2$ as follows. First, she flips a coin. If it comes up heads, she constructs point $A_2$ such that $B_1$ is the midpoint of $\overline{A_2C_1}$. If it comes up tails, she instead constructs $A_2$ such that $C_1$ is the midpoint of $\overline{A_2B_1}$. She performs analogous operations on $B_2$ and $C_2$. What is the expected value of the area of $\triangle A_2B_2C_2$?
solution: Obviously we are scaling here so WLOG $B_1C_1=1$ to make computation easier Note that all possible second points form the vertices of an equiangular hexagon with sides $1 2 1 2 1 2 $ But we know that there are $2^3=8$ possible triangles so we see that the expected value is $\frac{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot 6 + \frac{7\sqrt{3}}{4} \cdot 2}{8}=\frac{13\sqrt{3}}{16} $ so the answer is $\frac{60}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}} \cdot \frac{13\sqrt{3}}{16}=\boxed{195}$

title: 2019 T6: Minimum Value of Sum of Sines
text: Across all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, find the maximum value of the expression $$\sin x + \sin 3x + \sin 5x.$$
solution:
bashy in test sol Let $\sin{x} = y$ Then $$\sin{x}+\sin{3x}+\sin{5x} = y+3y 4y^3+\sin(2x + 3x)=4y 4y^3+\sin{2x}\cos{3x}+\sin{3x}\cos{2x}$$ $$=4y 4y^3+(2\sin{x}\cos{x})(4\cos^3{x} 3\cos{x})+(3\sin{x} 4\sin^3{x})(1 2\sin^2{x})$$ $$=4y 4y^3+(2y\sqrt{1 y^2})(4\sqrt{(1 y^2)^3} 3\sqrt{1 y^2})+(3y 4y^3)(1 2y^2)$$ $$=4y 4y^3+8y(1 y^2)^2 6y(1 y^2)+3y 6y^3 4y^3+8y^5$$ $$=8y^5 14y^3+7y+(8y)(y^4 2y^2+1) 6y+6y^3$$ $$=16y^5 24y^3+9y = y(16y^4 24y^2+9)=y(4y^2 3)^2$$ We want to maximize this function so we take the derivative (with product rule) and set it to $0$ $$16y^2(4y^2 3)+(4y^2 3)^2=(4y^2 3)(20y^2 3)=0\Rightarrow y^2=\frac{3}{4} \frac{3}{20}$$ Plugging these values in we get $y(4y^2 3)^2=0 \sqrt{\frac{3}{20}}(\frac{12}{5})^2$ Clearly $0$ isn't correct so the answer is $\sqrt{\frac{3}{20}}(\frac{12}{5})^2=\frac{\sqrt{15}}{10}(\frac{144}{25})=\boxed{\frac{72\sqrt{15}}{125}}$

title: 2019 T7: Random Walk with Three People
text: Suppose you start at $0$, a friend starts at $6$, and another friend starts at $8$ on the number line. Every second, the leftmost person moves left with probability $\tfrac14$, the middle person with probability $\tfrac13$, and the rightmost person with probability $\tfrac12$. If a person does not move left, they move right, and if two people are on the same spot, they are randomly assigned which one of the positions they are. Determine the expected time until you all meet in one point.

How many brgorable numbers are less than 2019?

title: 2019 T10: Areas of Triangles Formed by Excircle Tangency Points
text: Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with side lengths $a$, $b$, and $c$. Circle $\omega_A$ is the $A$-excircle of $\triangle ABC$, defined as the circle tangent to $BC$ and to the extensions of $AB$ and $AC$ past $B$ and $C$ respectively. Let $\mathcal{T}_A$ denote the triangle whose vertices are these three tangency points; denote $\mathcal{T}_B$ and $\mathcal{T}_C$ similarly. Suppose the areas of $\mathcal{T}_A$, $\mathcal{T}_B$, and $\mathcal{T}_C$ are $4$, $5$, and $6$ respectively. Find the ratio $a:b:c$.
solution:
Let the $A$ excircle be tangent to $AB BC CA$ at $X Y Z $ Then 
 \[[\mathcal{T}_A]=[XYZ]=[XYI_A]+[YZI_A] [XZI_A]=\frac{r_A^2}{2}\left(\sin B+\sin C \sin A\right)=\frac{r_A^2}{2R}(s a)=\frac{K^2}{2R(s a)} \] Now $[\mathcal{T}_A] [\mathcal{T}_B] [\mathcal{T}_C]=4 5 6$ gives $(s a)=\tfrac{x}{4} (s b)=\tfrac{x}{5} (s c)=\tfrac{x}{6} $ from which it is not hard to extract the answer $22 25 27 $

title: 2019 T11: Subset of Natural Numbers Satisfying Inclusion Property
text: Let $S$ be a subset of the natural numbers such that $0\in S$, and for all $n\in\mathbb N$, if $n$ is in $S$, then both $2n+1$ and $3n+2$ are in $S$. What is the smallest number of elements $S$ can have in the range $\{0,1,\ldots, 2019\}$?
solution:
Quote Let $S$ be a subset of the natural numbers such that $0\in S$ disgusting 
 
 The main observation is that if $f(n)=2n+1$ and $g(n)=3n+2 $ $f(g(n))=g(f(n)) $ Thus all that matters is how many times we apply each of $f$ and $g $ Now let $h(a b)=g^b(f^a(0)) $ We claim that $h$ is injective assume $h(a_1 b_1)=h(a_2 b_2) $ Note that the base $3$ representation of $h(a b)$ ends with exactly $2$ $3$ s as $f^a(0)$ cannot end with a $2 $ Thus $b_1=b_2$ whence $a_1=a_2$ follows Now we count by casework on $a $ 
 
 \[0\to 2\to 8\to 26\to 80\to 242\to 728\] \[1\to 4\to 14\to 44\to 134\to 404\to 1214\] \[3\to 11\to 35\to 107\to 323\to 971\] \[7\to 23\to 71\to 215\to 647\to 1943\] \[15\to 47\to 143\to 431\to 1295\] \[31\to 95\to 287\to 863\] \[63\to 191\to 575\to 1727\] \[127\to 383\to 1151\] \[255\to 767\] \[511\to 1535\] \[1023\] so the answer is $47$ or smth

title: 2019 T13: A Peculiar Laser
text: Points $A$, $B$, and $C$ lie in the plane such that $AB=13$, $BC=14$, and $CA=15$. A peculiar laser is fired from $A$ perpendicular to $\overline{BC}$. After bouncing off $BC$, it travels in a direction perpendicular to $CA$. When it hits $CA$, it travels in a direction perpendicular to $AB$, and after hitting $AB$ its new direction is perpendicular to $BC$ again. If this process is continued indefinitely, the laser path will eventually approach some finite polygonal shape $T_\infty$. What is the ratio of the perimeter of $T_\infty$ to the perimeter of $\triangle ABC$?
solution:
The limit case will be $\triangle XYZ$ with $X\in\overline{BC} Y\in\overline{CA} Z\in\overline{AB}$ with $XY\perp AC YZ\perp BA ZX\perp CB $ Angle chasing shows $\triangle YZX\sim \triangle ABC $ We now coordinate bash Let $B=( 5 0) C=(9 0) A=(0 12) X=(a 0) $ We quickly compute $Y=\left(a \frac{60a+300}{25}\right) Z=\left(\frac{9a+144}{25} \frac{ 12a+108}{25}\right) $ so since $YZ$ has slope $\tfrac{ 5}{12} $ 
 \[\frac{72a+192}{16a 144}=\frac{9a+24}{2a 18}=\frac{ 5}{12}\implies a=\frac{ 99}{59} \] Then $BX=\tfrac{196}{59}\implies XZ=\tfrac{2352}{295} $ from which we extract the answer $\tfrac{168}{295} $

title: 2019 T14: Integer Overflow
text: Consider the following function. $\textbf{procedure }\textsc{M}(x)$ $\qquad\textbf{if }0\leq x\leq 1$ $\qquad\qquad\textbf{return }x$ $\qquad\textbf{return }\textsc{M}(x^2\bmod 2^{32})$ Let $f:\mathbb N\to\mathbb N$ be defined such that $f(x) = 0$ if $\textsc{M}(x)$ does not terminate, and otherwise $f(x)$ equals the number of calls made to $\textsc{M}$ during the running of $\textsc{M}(x)$, not including the initial call. For example, $f(1) = 0$ and $f(2^{31}) = 1$. Compute the number of ones in the binary expansion of \[ f(0) + f(1) + f(2) + \cdots + f(2^{32} - 1). \]

title: 2019 T15: Prime-Covering Polynomials
text: Call a polynomial $P$ prime-covering if for every prime $p$, there exists an integer $n$ for which $p$ divides $P(n)$. Determine the number of ordered triples of integers $(a,b,c)$, with $1\leq a < b < c \leq 25$, for which $P(x)=(x^2-a)(x^2-b)(x^2-c)$ is prime-covering.
solution:
If one of $a b c$ are squares the corresponding factor splits into linear factors at which point it is clear that $P$ is prime covering There are $\tbinom{25}{3} \tbinom{20}{3}$ such cases now assume there are no squares Note that every number $\leq 25$ has at most two distinct prime divisors Thus we write $a=p^uq^v $ Then we want to characterize the primes $r$ in which $p^uq^v$ is a QR Since we dispensed of the square case there are only two more cases Case 1 $u\equiv 1\mod 2 v\equiv 0\mod 2 $ 
 Then this is equivalent to $p$ being a QR Call this $a$ type 1 Case 2 $u\equiv 1\mod 2 v\equiv 1\mod 2 $ 
 In this case both $p$ and $q$ are either QRs or NQRs Call this $a$ type 2 Now consider the case that one of $a b c$ is type 1 WLOG it is $a$ with relevant prime factor $p $ Then to account for the $p$ NQR case we need one of $b c$ to be type 2 with prime $p$ and some other prime $q $ Then to account for the $q$ QR case we need the other one of $b c$ to be type $1$ with relevant prime factor $q$ (it can't be type $2$ with some third prime because that creates counterexamples with Dirichlet) With similar case analysis the only case where all of $a b c$ are type $2$ is when the relevant primes of $a b c$ are $\{p q\} \{q r\} \{r p\} $ 
 
 We now compute the answer for each case We first separate the remaining numbers by type \[1 2 3 5 7 8 11 12 13 17 18 19 20 23\] \[2 6 10 14 15 21 22 24\] For the first case we do casework on the two primes $p=2$ yields three cases for the type $1 $ $p=3 5$ yields two cases for the type $1 $ $(p q)=(2 3)$ yields two cases for the type $2 $ and everything else has one case Adding everything gives $30$ cases For the second case the primes must be $(2 3 5)$ or $(2 3 7) $ This adds another $4$ cases We conclude that there are $\tbinom{25}{3} \tbinom{20}{3}+34=1194$ prime covering polynomials EDIT Thanks @below I forgot a lot of cases where primes have multiplicity $\geq 2 $ Note that the characterization above matches dj's characterization in post #3

title: 2018 A1: Misha Plays Catan
text: Misha has accepted a job in the mines and will produce one ore each day. At the market, he is able to buy or sell one ore for $3, buy or sell bundles of three wheat for $12 each, or $\textit{sell}$ one wheat for one ore. His ultimate goal is to build a city, which requires three ore and two wheat. How many dollars must Misha begin with in order to build a city after three days of working?
solution: Sol Clearly after the three days Misha will have $3$ ore that he did not have to pay for Notice that with only $\boxed{9}$ dollars it is possible to sell one ore for $3$ dollars bringing his total to $12$ dollars $2$ ore then buy three wheat and then sell one bringing him to exactly one city We notice that this is the only way to be more efficient and checking that this strategy does not yield the desired result for $1 8$ dollars we get $9$ as out answer But why do this when you could go for the longest road????

title: 2018 A2: Sum of a Number and its Reciprocal
text: Suppose $x>1$ is a real number such that $x+\tfrac 1x = \sqrt{22}$. What is $x^2-\tfrac1{x^2}$?
solution: Notice that $\left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)^2 = \left(x \frac{1}{x}\right)^2 + 4 $ so $x \frac{1}{x} = \sqrt{18} $ So we can multiply the two equations to get $\left(x + \frac{1}{x}\right)\left(x \frac{1}{x}\right) = x^2 \frac{1}{x^2} = \sqrt{18}\sqrt{22} = \boxed{6\sqrt{11}} $

title: 2018 A3: Product of Real Solutions
text: Let $P(x)=x^2+4x+1$. What is the product of all real solutions to the equation $P(P(x))=0$?
solution:
The quadratic formula gives that the roots of $P$ are $ 2 \pm \sqrt{3}$ Next we know that if $y$ is a root then $P(y) = 2 + \sqrt{3}$ or $P(y) = 2 \sqrt{3}$ 
 
 Case 1 $P(y)= 2 + \sqrt{3}$ 
 
 Then $y^2 + 4y + 3 \sqrt{3} = 0$ A quick discriminant check yields that the roots are real in this case so we get that the product of the roots is $3 \sqrt{3}$ 
 
 Case 2 $P(y) = 2 \sqrt{3}$ 
 
 Then $y^2 + 4y + 3 + \sqrt{3} = 0$ The discriminant is negative so there are no real roots The answer is $3 \sqrt{3}$

title: 2018 A4: Little Ducklings
text: 2018 little ducklings numbered 1 through 2018 are standing in a line, with each holding a slip of paper with a nonnegative number on it; it is given that ducklings 1 and 2018 have the number zero. At some point, ducklings 2 through 2017 change their number to equal the average of the numbers of the ducklings to their left and right. Suppose the new numbers on the ducklings sum to 1000. What is the maximum possible sum of the original numbers on all 2018 slips?

title: 2018 C1: Bananas
text: Ninety-eight apples who always lie and one banana who always tells the truth are randomly arranged along a line. The first fruit says "One of the first forty fruit is the banana!'' The last fruit responds "No, one of the $\emph{last}$ forty fruit is the banana!'' The fruit in the middle yells "I'm the banana!'' In how many positions could the banana be?
solution: Banana can be in the very first position the very last position and anywhere in the middle 19 positions thus our answer is $\boxed{21}$

title: 2018 C2: Arrangements of Cubes
text: Compute the number of ways to rearrange nine white cubes and eighteen black cubes into a $3\times 3\times 3$ cube such that each $1\times1\times3$ row or column contains exactly one white cube. Note that rotations are considered $\textit{distinct}$.
solution: Obviously each layer of the cube must contain $3$ white cubes For the first layer we can arrange the blocks however we want so that no two are in the same row or column it is easy to see there are then $6$ ways to arrange the blocks in the $1$ s t layer Any white cube in the second layer will then determine the rest of the cube so there are $\frac{6}{3} = 2$ ways to place the rest of the white cubes giving $\boxed{12}$ total ways to rearrange the cubes

title: 2018 C3: Teleportation in a Grid
text: Michelle is at the bottom-left corner of a $6\times 6$ lattice grid, at $(0,0)$. The grid also contains a pair of one-time-use teleportation devices at $(2,2)$ and $(3,3)$; the first time Michelle moves to one of these points she is instantly teleported to the other point and the devices disappear. If she can only move up or to the right in unit increments, in how many ways can she reach the point $(5,5)$?
solution: Without the teleportation devices there are ${10\choose5}=252$ ways for Michelle to go from $(0 0)$ to $(5 5)$ Since there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{6\choose3}=120$ ways for Michelle to go through $(2 2)$ and the same number of ways for her to go through $(3 3)$ and there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{2\choose1}\cdot{4\choose2}=72$ ways for her to go through both points there are $252 120 120+72=84$ ways for her to go through neither point With her teleporting from $(2 2)$ to $(3 3)$ there are ${4\choose2}\cdot{4\choose2}=36$ possible paths and with her teleporting the other way there are $\left({6\choose3} {4\choose2}\cdot{2\choose1}\right)\cdot{6\choose3}=160$ possible paths Therefore there are a total of $84+36+160=280$ possible paths for her

title: 2018 C4: Waiting for Busses
text: At CMU, the A and the B buses arrive once every 20 and 18 minutes, respectively. Kevin prefers the A bus but does not want to wait for too long. He commits to the following waiting scheme: he will take the first A bus that arrives, but after waiting for five minutes he will take the next bus that comes, no matter what it is. Determine the probability that he ends up on an A bus.
solution: We proceed using geometric probability with the number of minutes until the first A bus arrives on the $x$ axis and that for the B bus on the $y$ axis Since the A bus will arrive at a time randomly and uniformly selected from 0 to 20 minutes and the B bus from 0 to 18 minutes our sample space is $0\leq x\leq20$ and $0\leq y\leq18$ with area $360$ Kevin will end up on an A bus if $x\leq5$ or $x\leq y$ Thus the desired area is $5\cdot18+\frac{13^2}{2}=\frac{349}{2}$ and so the probability he ends up on an A bus is $\frac{\frac{349}{2}}{360}=\frac{349}{720}$

title: 2018 CS1: Perfect Code?
text: Consider the following two vertex-weighted graphs, and denote them as having vertex sets $V=\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_6\}$ and $W=\{w_1,w_2,\ldots,w_6\}$, respectively (numbered in the same direction and way). The weights in the second graph are such that for all $1\le i\le 6$, the weight of $w_i$ is the sum of the weights of the neighbors of $v_i$. Determine the sum of the weights of the original graph.
solution: 10 seconds Realize that both $w_2+w_6$ and $w_5+w_3$ give the desired sum as they are adjacent to all 6 vertices with no overlap Therefore the answer is $\boxed{32}$

title: 2018 CS2: FiboNOTci
text: Consider the natural implementation of computing Fibonacci numbers: \begin{tabular}{l} 1: \textbf{FUNCTION} $\text{FIB}(n)$: \\ 2:$\qquad$ \textbf{IF} $n = 0$ \textbf{OR} $n = 1$ \textbf{RETURN} 1 \\ 3:$\qquad$ \textbf{RETURN} $\text{FIB}(n-1) + \text{FIB}(n-2)$ \end{tabular} When $\text{FIB}(10)$ is evaluated, how many recursive calls to $\text{FIB}$ occur?
solution: Recursion for recursion We set up a recursion for c(n) the number of recursive calls inside FIB(n) c(0) and c(1) are both 0 From here note that c(n)=c(n 1)+c(n 2)+2 Evaluating to 10 gives $\boxed{176}$

You do not have access to the $a_i$, but you do have an oracle which, when given two indexes $1\leq i < j\leq 5$, will tell you whether $a_i < a_j$ or $a_i > a_j$. What is the minimum number of calls to the oracle needed in order to identify an ordered triple of integers $(r,s,t)$ such that $a_r,a_s,a_t$ is one such sequence?

solution: Sometimes it really is that obvious Summing down the 4th row gives 196 and you can easily check there is no smaller solution

title: 2018 G1: Difference of Angles
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. Point $P$ lies in the interior of $\triangle ABC$ such that $\angle ABP = 20^\circ$ and $\angle ACP = 15^\circ$. Compute $\angle BPC - \angle BAC$.
solution: Since $ABPC$ is a quadrilateral the reflex angle of $\angle{BPC}=360^{\circ} 15^{\circ} 20^{\circ} \angle{BAC}$ so $\angle{BPC}=15^{\circ}+20^{\circ}+\angle{BAC}$ so the answer is $35$

title: 2018 G2: Locus of Angle Bisector Foot
text: Let $ABCD$ be a square of side length $1$, and let $P$ be a variable point on $\overline{CD}$. Denote by $Q$ the intersection point of the angle bisector of $\angle APB$ with $\overline{AB}$. The set of possible locations for $Q$ as $P$ varies along $\overline{CD}$ is a line segment; what is the length of this segment?
solution: The extreme cases for where $Q$ lies are when $P$ is at $C$ or $D$ When $P$ is at $C$ we can use angle bisector theorem to deduce that $Q$ is $\sqrt{2} 1$ from $B$ By symmetry when $P$ is at $D$ $Q$ is $\sqrt{2} 1$ from $A$ Since $Q$ has to be at least $\sqrt{2} 1$ distance from $A$ and $B$ the answer is $1 2(\sqrt{2} 1)=3 2\sqrt{2}$

title: 2018 G3: Extended Law of Sines
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with side lengths $5$, $4\sqrt 2$, and $7$. What is the area of the triangle with side lengths $\sin A$, $\sin B$, and $\sin C$?
solution: You can use Law of Cosines to get the angle opposite of side $5$ is $45^{\circ}$ so the ratio of the new to original triangles areas is $(\sin{45^{\circ}})^2$ divides by $5^2$ is $\frac{1}{50}$ The original triangle has area $\frac{1}{2} \cdot 4\sqrt{2} \cdot 7 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=14$ The new area is $\frac{14}{50}=\frac{7}{25}$

title: 2018 G4: Composition of Rotations
text: Suppose $\overline{AB}$ is a segment of unit length in the plane. Let $f(X)$ and $g(X)$ be functions of the plane such that $f$ corresponds to rotation about $A$ $60^\circ$ counterclockwise and $g$ corresponds to rotation about $B$ $90^\circ$ clockwise. Let $P$ be a point with $g(f(P))=P$; what is the sum of all possible distances from $P$ to line $AB$?
solution: We proceed using complex numbers Let $A$ be $0$ and $B$ be $1$ Let $P=p$ be desired point When we rotate $60^{\circ}$ across $A$ we have a new point $q$ where $q=pe^{\frac{\pi \cdot i}{3}}$ When we rotate $q$ $ 90^{\circ}$ across $B$ we are back to $p$ so $p 1=e^{ \frac{\pi \cdot i}{2}}(q 1)$ Substituting in $q$ in terms of $p$ we want to find the absolute value of the imaginary coordinate of $p$ because that's the distance from the $x$ axis so the answer is $\frac{1+\sqrt{3}}{2}$

title: 2018 NT1: System of Equations
text: Suppose $a$, $b$, and $c$ are relatively prime integers such that \[\frac{a}{b+c} = 2\qquad\text{and}\qquad \frac{b}{a+c} = 3.\]What is $|c|$?
solution: Use your fraction manipulation skills to get $\frac{b}{a+b+c}=\frac{3}{4}$ and $\frac{a}{a+b+c}=\frac{2}{3}$ Therefore $\frac{c}{a+b+c}=1 \frac{3}{4} \frac{2}{3}=\frac{ 5}{12}$ Since $a$ $b$ $c$ are relatively prime integers we multiply by $a+b+c=12$ to the three equations to get $b=9$ $a=8$ and $c= 5$ So answer is $5$

Determine the smallest possible value of $a$ such that the numbers $a_1$, $a_2$,$\ldots$, $a_7$ are all distinct.

title: 2018 Team 1-1/1-2: Circles
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with $BC=30$, $AC=50$, and $AB=60$. Circle $\omega_B$ is the circle passing through $A$ and $B$ tangent to $BC$ at $B$; $\omega_C$ is defined similarly. Suppose the tangent to $\odot(ABC)$ at $A$ intersects $\omega_B$ and $\omega_C$ for the second time at $X$ and $Y$ respectively. Compute $XY$. Let $T = TNYWR$. For some positive integer $k$, a circle is drawn tangent to the coordinate axes such that the lines $x + y = k^2, x + y = (k+1)^2, \dots, x+y = (k+T)^2$ all pass through it. What is the minimum possible value of $k$?
solution:
1 The tangencies imply $XAB \sim BCA $ and $YAC \sim CBA$ Then $XY=XA+AY=36+25=\boxed{61} $ 
 
 2 Let the center of the circle be $(a a) $ Then looking at the farthest lines and using distance from point to line we get $(k+61)^2 \le (2+\sqrt{2})a $ and $(2 \sqrt{2})a \le k^2$ Combining we get $(2 \sqrt{2})(k+61)^2 \le (2+\sqrt{2})k^2$ This simplifies to $\frac{61}{k} \le \sqrt{2} $ Then the minimum $k $ is $\boxed{44} $

title: 2018 Team 2-1/2-2: Integer Equations
text: Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are non-negative integers satisfying $a + b + ab + a^b = 42$. Find the sum of all possible values of $a + b$. Let $T = TNYWR$. Suppose that a sequence $\{a_n\}$ is defined via $a_1 = 11, a_2 = T$, and $a_n = a_{n-1} + 2a_{n-2}$ for $n \ge 3$. Find $a_{19} + a_{20}$.
solution:
Firstly trying the cases when $a$ or $b$ is $0$ or when $a$ or $b$ is $1 $ we get the solutions $(1 20) (0 42) $ and $(0 41) $ Otherwise $a^b$ must be $4 8 9 16 25 27 32 $ or $36 $ Testing each of them yields the solutions $(3 3)$ and $(5 2) $ 
 
 Therefore the sum of all possible values of $a+b$ is 
 \begin{align*}
(1+20)+(0+42)+(0+41)+(3+3)+(5+2) &= 21+42+41+6+7 \\
&= \boxed{117} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2018 Team 3-1/3-2: Semicircle and Marbles

Points $X$ and $Y$ are located on the boundary of $\Omega$ such that the distance from $X$ to $AB$ is $\frac{5}{4}$ and the distance from $Y$ to $AB$ is $\frac{1}{4}$. Compute \[(AX+BX)^2 - (AY+BY)^2.\] Let $T = TNYWR$. $T$ people each put a distinct marble into a bag; its contents are mixed randomly and one marble is distributed back to each person. Given that at least one person got their own marble back, what is the probability that everyone else also received their own marble?
