title: 2016 G7: Collinear Points on Incircle
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with incenter $I$ and incircle $\omega$. It is given that there exist points $X$ and $Y$ on the circumference of $\omega$ such that $\angle BXC=\angle BYC=90^\circ$. Suppose further that $X$, $I$, and $Y$ are collinear. If $AB=80$ and $AC=97$, compute the length of $BC$.
solution: solution Let $M$ be the midpoint of $BC$ Since $BXC$ and $BYC$ are both right triangles with hypotenuse $BC$ $BM=XM=YM=CM$ Also since $XIY$ is a straight line $XY$ is a diameter of $\omega$ Since every chord of a circle is perpendicularly bisected by a radius of that circle $XY$ is perpendicular to $IM$ and $XI^2+IM^2=XM^2=BM^2=CM^2$ Let $\omega$ meet $BC$ at $h_I$ and let the radius of $\omega$ be $r$ Therefore $XI^2+IM^2=r^2+Ih_I^2+h_IM^2=2r^2+h_IM^2=BM^2$ rearranging gives $2r^2=BM^2 h_IM^2=(BM h_IM)(BM+h_IM)=(BM h_IM)(CM+h_IM)=(Bh_I)(Ch_I)$ It is well known that $r=\sqrt{\frac{(s AB)(s BC)(s AC)}{s}}$ $Bh_I=s AC$ and $Ch_I=s AB$ Plugging these in and cancelling we get $2(s BC)=s$ or $s=2BC$ Plugging in the semi perimeter formula we get $BC+80+97=4BC$ or $BC=\boxed{59}$

title: 2016 G8: Weird Quadrilateral
text: Suppose $ABCD$ is a convex quadrilateral satisfying $AB=BC$, $AC=BD$, $\angle ABD = 80^\circ$, and $\angle CBD = 20^\circ$. What is $\angle BCD$ in degrees?
solution: Solution First consider the projection $D'$ of $D$ such that $ABDD'$ is a parallelogram Now let the foot of the perpendicular from $B$ to $AC$ be $E$ the intersection of $AC$ and $BD$ be $F$ and the intersection of $BD$ and $D'C$ be $G$ Then $\angle BFE = 90^{\circ} 30^{\circ} = 60^{\circ}$ It is easy to find that $\angle FCB = 40^{\circ}$ Also $\angle{CAD'} = \angle{D'AB} \angle{EAB} = 100^{\circ} 40^{\circ} = 60^{\circ} $ Now realize that $ \Delta AD'C$ is isosceles So it is actually an equilateral triangle Consequently $\angle GCF = 60^{\circ}$ and $\angle DGC = 120^{\circ}$ Now realize that $\Delta D'DC \cong \Delta BCD$ So $\Delta GCD$ is isosceles so $\angle GCD = 30^{\circ}$ So $\angle BCD = 40^{\circ}+60^{\circ}+30^{\circ} = \boxed{130^{\circ}}$

title: 2016 G9: Almost-Inscribed Circle
text: Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with $AB=65$, $BC=70$, and $CA=75$. A semicircle $\Gamma$ with diameter $\overline{BC}$ is constructed outside the triangle. Suppose there exists a circle $\omega$ tangent to $AB$ and $AC$ and furthermore internally tangent to $\Gamma$ at a point $X$. The length $AX$ can be written in the form $m\sqrt{n}$ where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers with $n$ not divisible by the square of any prime. Find $m+n$.
solution:
Nice 13/14/15 Let the center of $\Gamma$ be $O $ To be tangent to $AB$ and $AC $ it is evident that $O$ lies on the angle bisector of $\angle A $ so $A \ O \ X$ are collinear Then it follows that $X$ is the midpoint of $\overarc{BC}$ of $\Gamma $ 
 
 Using Cartesian coordinates letting the midpoint of $BC=M(0 0)$ yields $X=(0 35) \ A=(10 60) \implies AX=\sqrt{5^2(2^2+19^2)}=5\sqrt{365} \ m+n=\boxed{370} $

title: 2016 G10: Inversely Similar Triangle
text: Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle with circumcircle $\Omega$ and let $N$ be the midpoint of the major arc $\widehat{BC}$. The incircle $\omega$ of $\triangle ABC$ is tangent to $AC$ and $AB$ at points $E$ and $F$ respectively. Suppose point $X$ is placed on the same side of $EF$ as $A$ such that $\triangle XEF\sim\triangle ABC$. Let $NX$ intersect $BC$ at a point $P$. Given that $AB=15$, $BC=16$, and $CA=17$, compute $\tfrac{PX}{XN}$.
solution:
nice synthetic Let $A'$ be the point on $(ABC)$ with $AA'||BC$ 
 
 Since $XFE \sim A'BC$ and $A N$ are the respective midpoints of arcs we have that $AFEX NBCA'$ are directly similar figures Also notice $\angle A'AC = \angle A'BC = \angle XFE = \angle XAC$ which implies $A A' X$ are collinear and that $AX || BC$ Now let $D$ be the intersection of $AN BC$ Since $AX||DP$ we know $\frac{PX}{XN} = \frac{DA}{AN}$ It suffices to find this ratio and erase basically everything except $A B C N D$ 
 
 There's probably an easy way to compute now but instead I will find the answer in a very synthetic manner Let $f(Q)$ be the length of the height from $Q$ to $BC$ and let $I_B I_C$ be the excenters Note $N$ is the midpoint of $I_BI_C$ We compute $\frac{DA}{AN} = \frac{f(A)}{f(N) f(A)} = \frac{ f(A)}{0 5 (f(I_B) + f(I_C)) f(A)} = \frac{2f(A)}{f(I_B) + f(I_C) 2f(A)}$ 
 
 But of course if $K$ is area then $f(A) = \frac{2K}{a} f(I_B) = \frac{2K}{a+c b} f(I_C) = \frac{2K}{a+b c}$ 
 
 Thus $f(A) f(I_B) f(I_C) = \frac{1}{16} \frac{1}{14} \frac{1}{18}$ Then the answer is $63$ by computation I probably made a silly so feel free to do my calculations for me

title: 2016 NT1: Typos are Bad Part 2
text: David, when submitting a problem for CMIMC, wrote his answer as $100\tfrac xy$, where $x$ and $y$ are two positive integers with $x<y$. Andrew interpreted the expression as a product of two rational numbers, while Patrick interpreted the answer as a mixed fraction. In this case, Patrick's number was exactly double Andrew's! What is the smallest possible value of $x+y$?
solution: Solution Patrick's number is $100 + \frac{x}{y}$ and Andrew's number is $\frac{100x}{y}$ so we have the equation \[100 + \frac{x}{y} = \frac{200x}{y} \] Multiplying through by $y$ and rearranging gives $100y = 199x$ As $\gcd(100 199) = 1$ we conclude that $y$ must be a multiple of $199$ and $x$ a multiple of $100$ so the smallest possible value of $x+y$ is $100 + 199 = \boxed{299}$

title: 2016 NT2: Sequence of Integers
text: Let $a_1$, $a_2$, $\ldots$ be an infinite sequence of (positive) integers such that $k$ divides $\gcd(a_{k-1},a_k)$ for all $k\geq 2$. Compute the smallest possible value of $a_1+a_2+\cdots+a_{10}$.
solution: Solution Substituting $k = 2$ into the condition gives $2| \gcd(a_1 a_2)$ and substituting $k = 3$ gives $3 | \gcd(a_2 a_3)$ From here we conclude that $6|a_2$ As only $k = 2$ and $k = 3$ impose conditions on $a_2$ the minimum possible value of $a_2$ is $6$ Similarly $k = 4$ gives $4 | \gcd(a_3 a_4)$ so $12|a_3$ In general substituting $k = i$ and $k = i+1$ will yield $i(i+1) | a_i$ so the minimum possible value of $a_i$ is $i(i+1)$ for $i \ge 2$ Only $k = 2$ restricts $a_1$ so we only require $2|a_1$ so the minimum possible value for $a_1$ is $2$ Therefore the minimum possible value of $a_1 + a_2 + \cdots + a_{10}$ is $1(2) + 2(3) + \cdots + 10(11) = \sum_{i=1}^{10}i(i+1) = \sum_{i=1}^{10}i^2 + \sum_{i=1}^{10}i = 385 + 55 = \boxed{440}$

title: 2016 NT3: Difference of Powers of Two Divisible by 2016
text: How many pairs of integers $(a,b)$ are there such that $0\leq a < b \leq 100$ and such that $\tfrac{2^b-2^a}{2016}$ is an integer?
solution:
Solution As $2016 = 2^5 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 7$ we can rewrite $2016 | (2^b 2^a)$ as the set of congruences \begin{align*} 2^a &\equiv 2^b \pmod{32} \\ 2^a &\equiv 2^b \pmod{9} \\ 2^a &\equiv 2^b \pmod{7}\end{align*} As $b > a$ the first congruence is automatically satisfied if $a \ge 5$ and it is easy to see that it cannot be satisfied otherwise As the order of $2$ modulo $9$ is $6$ we require $a \equiv b \pmod{6}$ for the second congruence and as the order of $2$ modulo $7$ is $3$ we require $a \equiv b \pmod{3}$ for the third congruence Putting these conditions together we have $a \ge 5$ and $a \equiv b \pmod{6}$ 
 
 Now we simply count For each residue modulo $6$ there happens to be $16$ integers between $5$ and $100$ inclusive with that residue so for a given residue there are $\binom{16}{2} = 120$ ways to choose $2$ distinct numbers Then we must assign the smaller number to $a$ and the larger to $b$ With $6$ possible residues the answer is therefore $6 \cdot 120 = \boxed{720}$

title: 2016 NT4: Functions Defined on Prime Factorizations
text: For some positive integer $n$, consider the usual prime factorization \[n = \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_{i}^{e_{i}}=p_1^{e_1}p_2^{e_2}\ldots p_k^{e_k},\]where $k$ is the number of primes factors of $n$ and $p_{i}$ are the prime factors of $n$. Define $Q(n), R(n)$ by \[ Q(n) = \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_{i}^{p_{i}} \text{ and } R(n) = \prod_{i=1}^{k} e_{i}^{e_{i}}. \]For how many $1 \leq n \leq 70$ does $R(n)$ divide $Q(n)$?
solution: Sketch It will be easier to count those that don't satisfy the condition rather than those that do Nevertheless you essentially have to enumerate through all $70$ numbers though many can be thrown out easily in your head For example for all squarefree numbers $R(n) = 1$ so they work Numbers such as $2^2 \cdot 3$ and $2^2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5$ also work since $R(n) = 2^2$ Most powers of $2$ don't work such as $n = 2^3$ since $R(n) = 3^3$ Odd perfect squares also don't work as $R(n)$ will be even while $Q(n)$ odd In the end we find that the following numbers don't work 8 9 16 25 32 36 40 45 48 49 56 63 and 64 This gives us $13$ numbers that don't work so $70 13 = \boxed{57}$ do Then comes the debate of what the prime factorization of $1$ is The answer $\boxed{56}$ also ended up being accepted

title: 2016 NT5: Diophantine on Primes
text: Determine the sum of the positive integers $n$ such that there exist primes $p,q,r$ satisfying $p^{n} + q^{2} = r^{2}$.
solution:
Solution Start by rewriting the equation as $p^n = (r q)(r+q)$ We will consider two cases $p$ is even and $p$ is odd Case 1 $p$ is even Then we have $r q = 2^a$ and $r+q = 2^{n a}$ for some nonnegative integer $a \le \frac{n}{2}$ Solving gives $r = \frac{1}{2}(2^a + 2^{n a})$ Clearly $q$ and $r$ must be odd so $2^a + 2^{n a}$ cannot be divisible by $4$ This requires $a = 1$ or $r q = 2$ and $r+q = 2^{n 1}$ Solving gives $r = 2^{n 2} + 1$ and $q = 2^{n 2} 1$ As any power of $2$ will be $\pm 1$ modulo $3$ we see that either $r$ or $q$ will be divisible by $3$ Therefore either $q$ or $r$ must be $3$ and we find only one solution $n = 4$ which satisfies $2^4 + 3^2 = 5^2$ 
 
 Case 2 $p$ is odd As $r q$ and $r+q$ have the same parity they must both be odd Then either $r$ or $q$ must be even If $r = 2$ then there are clearly no solutions Thus $q = 2$ and we have $p^n = (r 2)(r+2)$ so $r 2 = p^a$ and $r+2 = p^{n a}$ for some $a \le \frac{n}{2}$ Subtracting second equation from the first gives $p^{n a} p^a = 4$ This means we are looking for two powers of a prime that differ by $4$ Clearly $p$ and $n$ must be small (we can rigorously bound it but who cares) so a direct search gives the unique solution $5^1 5^0 = 4$ so $n = 1$ works Therefore the answer is $1 + 4 = \boxed{5}$

title: 2016 NT6: Tasty Residues
text: Define a $\textit{tasty residue}$ of $n$ to be an integer $1<a<n$ such that there exists an integer $m>1$ satisfying \[a^m\equiv a\pmod n.\]Find the number of tasty residues of $2016$.
solution:
Solution We are looking for integers $1 < a < 2016$ satisfying $a^m \equiv a \pmod{2016}$ for some $m > 1$ As $2016 = 2^5 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 7$ we can split this into three congruences \begin{align*} a^{m_1} &\equiv a \pmod{32} \\ a^{m_2} &\equiv a \pmod{9} \\ a^{m_3} &\equiv a \pmod{7}\end{align*} If some $m_1 m_2 m_3$ satisfy these three congruences then the overall condition is satisfied with $m = \text{lcm}(m_1 m_2 m_3)$ The third congruence is immediately satisfied with $m_3 = 6$ 
 
 Let us now consider possible values of $a$ modulo $9$ such that there exists an $m_2$ satisfying the second condition If $a \equiv 0 \pmod{9}$ then we may simply take $m_2 = 2$ If $a \equiv 3 6 \pmod{9}$ then the congruence will never be satisfied as $a^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{9}$ For all other $a$ relatively prime to $9$ we have $a^6 \equiv 1 \pmod{9}$ by Euler's Totient Theorem so $m_2 = 7$ will work Therefore the possible residues modulo $9$ for $a$ are $0 1 2 4 5 7 8$ for $7$ possibilities We can do something similar for possible values of $a$ modulo $32$ Note that $a \equiv 0 \pmod{32}$ works with $m = 2$ and any other even $a$ will never work However all odd $a$ will work since by Euler's Theorem $a^{16} \equiv 1 \pmod{32}$ so we may take $m_1 = 17$ Thus the possible residues modulo $32$ for $a$ are $0 1 3 5 7 \ldots 31$ for $17$ possibilities Combining our results together with $7$ possibilities modulo $7$ $7$ possibilities modulo $9$ and $17$ possibilities modulo $32$ by the Chinese Remainder Theorem we get a total of $7 \cdot 7 \cdot 17 = 833$ possibilities modulo $2016$ However we must subtract off $0$ and $1$ as we require $a > 1$ leaving us with $833 2 = \boxed{831}$

title: 2016 NT7: Sum of Prime and its Inverse
text: Determine the smallest positive prime $p$ which satisfies the congruence \[p+p^{-1}\equiv 25\pmod{143}.\]Here, $p^{-1}$ as usual denotes multiplicative inverse.
solution: Solution As $143 = 11 \cdot 13$ we may rewrite the congruence as a set of congruences with modulo a prime \begin{align*} p + p^{ 1} \equiv 3 &\pmod{11} \\ p + p^{ 1} \equiv 12 &\pmod{13}\end{align*} With smaller numbers we may simply test all possible residues for each congruence and see if it works For example for mod $11$ we would start with $p=1$ and $p^{ 1} = 3 1 = 2$ and see whether $pp^{ 1} = 1$ If so they form a valid pair otherwise they do not We find that the solutions are $p \equiv 5 9 \pmod{11}$ for the first congruence and $p \equiv 3 9 \pmod{13}$ for the second By the Chinese Remainder Theorem there will be $4$ values satisfying $p + p^{ 1} \equiv 25 \pmod{143}$ which we can calculate to be $p \equiv 9 16 42 126 \pmod{143}$ At this point we have to start listing out possible $p$ and check whether it's prime We find that $9 16 42 126 152 159$ and $185$ are all not prime but $\boxed{269}$ is which is our desired answer

title: 2016 NT8: Sum of Fractions
text: Given that \[ \sum_{x=1}^{70} \sum_{y=1}^{70} \frac{x^{y}}{y} = \frac{m}{67!} \]for some positive integer $m$, find $m \pmod{71}$.
solution:
simple If the series evaluates as $ 6m$ mod $71$ then we want $m$ 
 
 Note $\sum_{x=1}^{70} \frac{x^y}{y} $ equals $0$ for $1\le y \le 69$ by primitive roots/well known results and it equals $1$ mod $71$ if $y=70$ So we just want the inverse of $ 6$ which happens to be $ 12 = 59$

title: 2016 NT9: Integers Satisfying a Property
text: Compute the number of positive integers $n \leq 50$ such that there exist distinct positive integers $a,b$ satisfying \[ \frac{a}{b} +\frac{b}{a} = n \left(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b}\right). \]
solution:
Solution The equation becomes $a^2+b^2=n(a+b)$ so $a+b\mid a^2+b^2$ equivalently $a+b\mid2ab$ We will find all pairs of positive integers $(a b)$ satisfying $a+b\mid2ab$ Let $\frac{2ab}{a+b}=c$ then $4ab 2ac 2bc=0$ so $(2a c)(2b c)=c^2$ Let $2a c=kp^2$ and $2b c=kq^2$ Then $c=kpq$ so $a=\frac{kp^2+kpq}{2}=kp\cdot\frac{p+q}{2}$ and $b=kq\cdot\frac{p+q}{2}$ 
 
 From above we have $a=kp\cdot\frac{p+q}{2}$ and $b=kq\cdot\frac{p+q}{2}$ Since $a\neq b$ we have $p\neq q$ Now \[n=\frac{a^2+b^2}{a+b}=\frac{k^2\left(\frac{p+q}{2}\right)^2(p^2+q^2)}{k\frac{(p+q)^2}{2}}=\frac{k(p^2+q^2)}{2} \] We need $k(p^2+q^2)$ to be even for $n$ to be an integer However note that since $a+b$ is an integer $k(p+q)^2$ is even which implies that $k(p^2+q^2)$ is too Thus it is enough for $2a=kp(p+q)$ and $2b=kq(p+q)$ to be even The only other restriction we have is that $p\neq q$ To satisfy $kp(p+q)$ and $kq(p+q)$ being even we take $k$ to be an even integer $2l$ This makes $a$ and $b$ both integers and makes $n=l(p^2+q^2)$ If $n$ has a prime divisor congruent to $1\pmod{4}$ then we can set $p^2+q^2$ to this divisor and we are good Conversely if $n$ ' s only prime divisors are congruent to $2$ or $3\pmod{4}$ we show that $n$ cannot be $\frac{k(p^2+q^2)}{2}$ If $k$ is even then letting $k=2l$ we have $n=l(p^2+q^2)$ which we have problems with since $p\neq q$ implies that $p^2+q^2$ has a prime divisor congruent to $1\pmod{4}$ If $k$ is odd then $p^2+q^2$ is even so $p\equiv q\pmod{2}$ Then $n=k\left(\left(\frac{p+q}{2}\right)^2+\left(\frac{p q}{2}\right)^2\right)$ so we run into the same problem as when $k$ is even So we see that $n$ satisfies the condition if and only if $n$ has a prime divisor congruent to $1\pmod{4}$ Now we simply bash 5 5 10 50 [10] 
 13 13 26 39 [13] 
 17 17 34 [15] 
 29 29 [16] 
 37 37 [17] 
 41 41 [18] 
 
 The answer is thus $\boxed{18}$ 
 
 Not sure of this solution can someone check?

title: 2016 NT10: Sum of Reciprocals of LCMs
text: Let $f:\mathbb{N}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$ be the function \[f(n)=\sum_{k=1}^\infty\dfrac{1}{\operatorname{lcm}(k,n)^2}.\]It is well-known that $f(1)=\tfrac{\pi^2}6$. What is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $m\cdot f(10)$ is the square of a rational multiple of $\pi$?

title: 2016T1: Construction Mayhem
text: Construction Mayhem University has been on a mission to expand and improve its campus! The university has recently adopted a new construction schedule where a new project begins every two days. Each project will take exactly one more day than the previous one to complete (so the first project takes 3, the second takes 4, and so on.) Suppose the new schedule starts on Day 1. On which day will there first be at least $10$ projects in place at the same time?
solution: The difference between when $1$ project starts and the 10th project after that is $18$ days Thus we need to find when the project takes $19$ days so that it is still going when the 10th project starts Thus we see that the project that starts will start on day $33$ then we add $18$ since that's when the 10th project will start Thus our answer is $33+18=\boxed{51}$

title: 2016T2: Projections onto the Axes
text: Right isosceles triangle $T$ is placed in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane. Suppose that the projection of $T$ onto the $x$-axis has length $6$, while the projection of $T$ onto the $y$-axis has length $8$. What is the sum of all possible areas of the triangle $T$?
solution:
Here's my solution using complex numbers Sadly I wasn't able to attend the competition due to its distance from where I live ( 
 
 Solution 
 Let the leftmost vertex of $T$ be $O$ Place $T$ on the complex plane and translate it so that $O$ lies on the origin Note that translation does not affect the lengths of the projections of $T$ onto the axes Since $T$ is an isosceles right triangle we know that $\angle AOB=45^{\circ}$ Furthermore $OB = \sqrt{2}\cdot OA$ Let $a b$ be the complex numbers that represent the points $A B$ respectively Then we deduce that \[ b = \sqrt{2}e^{\frac{\pi i}{4}}a \] Now let $a=6+yi$ and $b=x+8i$ Then \begin{align*} \sqrt2\cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{2}i}{2}\right)\cdot(6+yi) &= (1+i)(6+yi) \\ &= (6 y)+(y+6)i \\ &= x+8i \end{align*} Equating real and imaginary parts we find that $x+6=8$ meaning that $y=2$ and $x=4$ We finish by computing the area of $\triangle AOB$ which is \[ \frac{|a|^2}{2} = \frac{6^2+2^2}{2}=\boxed{20} \]

title: 2016 T3: Buckets
text: We have 7 buckets labelled 0-6. Initially bucket 0 is empty, while bucket $n$ (for each $1 \leq n \leq 6$) contains the list $[1,2, \ldots, n]$. Consider the following program: choose a subset $S$ of $[1,2,\ldots,6]$ uniformly at random, and replace the contents of bucket $|S|$ with $S$. Let $\tfrac{p}{q}$ be the probability that bucket 5 still contains $[1,2, \ldots, 5]$ after two executions of this program, where $p,q$ are positive coprime integers. Find $p$.

title: 2016 T4: Paper Folding
text: For some integer $n > 0$, a square paper of side length $2^{n}$ is repeatedly folded in half, right-to-left then bottom-to-top, until a square of side length 1 is formed. A hole is then drilled into the square at a point $\tfrac{3}{16}$ from the top and left edges, and then the paper is completely unfolded. The holes in the unfolded paper form a rectangular array of unevenly spaced points; when connected with horizontal and vertical line segments, these points form a grid of squares and rectangles. Let $P$ be a point chosen randomly from \textit{inside} this grid. Suppose the largest $L$ such that, for all $n$, the probability that the four segments $P$ is bounded by form a square is at least $L$ can be written in the form $\tfrac mn$ where $m$ and $n$ are positive relatively prime integers. Find $m+n$.

title: 2016 T5: Pascal Squared
text: Recall that in any row of Pascal's Triangle, the first and last elements of the row are $1$ and each other element in the row is the sum of the two elements above it from the previous row. With this in mind, define the $\textit{Pascal Squared Triangle}$ as follows: In the $n^{\text{th}}$ row, where $n\geq 1$, the first and last elements of the row equal $n^2$; Each other element is the sum of the two elements directly above it. The first few rows of the Pascal Squared Triangle are shown below. \[\begin{array}{c@{\hspace{7em}} c@{\hspace{2pt}}c@{\hspace{2pt}}c@{\hspace{4pt}}c@{\hspace{2pt}} c@{\hspace{2pt}}c@{\hspace{2pt}}c@{\hspace{2pt}}c@{\hspace{3pt}}c@{\hspace{2pt}} c@{\hspace{2pt}}c} \vspace{4pt} \text{Row 1: } & & & & & & 1 & & & & & \\\vspace{4pt} \text{Row 2: } & & & & & 4 & & 4 & & & & \\\vspace{4pt} \text{Row 3: } & & & & 9 & & 8 & & 9 & & & \\\vspace{4pt} \text{Row 4: } & & &16& &17& &17& & 16& & \\\vspace{4pt} \text{Row 5: } & &25 & &33& &34 & &33 & &25 & \end{array}\]Let $S_n$ denote the sum of the entries in the $n^{\text{th}}$ row. For how many integers $1\leq n\leq 10^6$ is $S_n$ divisible by $13$?
solution:
We have $S_1=1$ and $S_{n}=2\cdot S_{n 1}+2\cdot(2n 1)$ for $n\ge2$ 
 By a simple induction we prove $$S_n=11\cdot 2^{n 1} 4n 6$$ 
 Motivation Using multiple times $\uparrow$ we conjecture 
 
 $S_n=4\cdot S_{n 2}+4\cdot(2n 3)+2\cdot(2n 1)=\ldots=2^{n 1}S_1+\sum_{i=2}^{n}2^{n+1 i}\cdot(2i 1)$ 
 $\quad\ \ =\sum_{i=1}^{n}2^{n+1 i}\cdot(2i 1) 2^{n 1}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}2^{n+2 i}i \sum_{i=1}^{n}2^{n+1 i} 2^{n 1}$ 
 $\quad\ \ =4\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=i}^{n}2^{n j} 5\cdot 2^{n 1}+2$ 
 $\quad\ \ =4\sum_{i=1}^{n}(2^{n+1 i} 1) 5\cdot 2^{n 1}+2$ 
 $\quad\ \ =8\cdot(2^{n+1} 1) 4n 5\cdot 2^{n 1}+2$ 
 $\quad\ \ =11\cdot 2^{n 1} 4n 6$ 
 
 Looking $\pmod{13}$ 
 $$S_n\equiv 0\iff 11\cdot 2^{n 1}\equiv 4n+6\iff 2^n+4n+6\equiv 0$$ 
 
 Since $o_{13}(2)=12$ and $\text{GCD}(4 13)=1$ we have $12$ solutions $\mod{156=12 13}$ 
 We have $10^6=6410\cdot 156+40$ so there is $6410\cdot 12+\#\text{solutions with n in {1 40} }$ solutions The first solution are $n=3 \ 22 \ 32 \ 33 \ 37 \ 40$ 
 
 Finaly there are 
 $$\mathcal{N}=6410\cdot 12+6=76926$$ $n$ with $1\le n\le 10^6$ and $13\mid S_n$

title: 2016 T8: Integer Roots
text: Let $N$ be the number of triples of positive integers $(a,b,c)$ with $a\leq b\leq c\leq 100$ such that the polynomial \[P(x)=x^2+(a^2+4b^2+c^2+1)x+(4ab+4bc-2ca)\]has integer roots in $x$. Find the last three digits of $N$.

title: 2016 T9: System of Congruences Has Solution
text: For how many permutations $\pi$ of $\{1,2,\ldots,9\}$ does there exist an integer $N$ such that \[N\equiv \pi(i)\pmod{i}\text{ for all integers }1\leq i\leq 9?\]
solution:
This problem is mine and in fact it is the one I referred to in this blog post In the interest of the Contest Collections page I'll post the official solution Solution Before trudging onward it helps to deduce a few properties of any system of congruences which is valid First remark that the values of $\pi(1)$ $\pi(5)$ and $\pi(7)$ are independent of values of other congruences In other words when building a valid permutation it suffices to compute the other six values and then randomly assign these three at the end Now remark that $\pi(km)\equiv\pi(k)\pmod k$ for all $k$ and $m$ for which the previous congruence is valid This is because the modulus of $N$ modulo $km$ determines the modulus of $N$ mod $k$ and so the results must be consistent The following consequences are direct colloraries of this fact All even indexes i e all $\pi(2k)$ for $k\in\mathbb{N}\setminus\{0\}$ must have the same parity For example $\pi(2)\equiv\pi(8)\pmod 2$ (The same is not necessarily true of the odds however in particular when $\pi(2)$ is odd one of $\pi(1)$ $\pi(3)$ $\ldots$ $\pi(9)$ must also be odd This is a result of the fact that $9$ is itself odd ) 
 As an extension $\pi(8) \pi(4)$ must be an integral multiple of $4$ Since $9 1=8$ we need either $|\pi(8) \pi(4)|=4$ or $|\pi(8) \pi(4)|=8 $ 
 Note that $\pi(3)\equiv\pi(6)\equiv\pi(9)\pmod 3$ This in particular means that \[\{\pi(3) \pi(6) \pi(9)\}\in\{\{1 4 7\} \{2 5 8\} \{3 6 9\}\} \] Subject to all these conditions a solution exists by the Chinese Remainder Theorem on the moduli $5$ $7$ $8$ and $9$ 
 
 We now have enough information to start counting We split the calculation into two cases $\textbf{CASE 1 }\pi(2k)\equiv 0\pmod 2$ $\forall k$ In this case remark that $\{\pi(4) \pi(8)\}$ can only be one of $\{2 6\}$ or $\{4 8\}$ Noting the third bullet point above we see that in the former case we must have $\pi(6)=4$ in the latter case we must have $\pi(6)=6$ (why?) From these $\pi(2)$ is uniquely determined and there are two ways to choose the ordered pair $(\pi(3) \pi(9))$ Thus in total there are $2\times 2\times 2=8$ possibilities in this case $\textbf{CASE 2 }\pi(2k)\equiv 1\pmod 2$ $\forall k$ In this case there are more choices for the set $\{\pi(4) \pi(8)\}$ In fact there are four $\{1 5\}$ $\{3 7\}$ $\{5 9\}$ and $\{1 9\}$ Because of this we need to be more careful about how we enumerate the possible permutations which work We again split into two cases $\textbf{SUBCASE 1 }\{\pi(4) \pi(8)\} = \{1 5\}$ or $\{5 9\}$ Note that in these cases there are two possible values of $\pi(6)$ in the first one $\pi(6)\in\{3 9\}$ while in the second $\pi(6)\in\{1 7\}$ Regardless of which member of which set is chosen the other element in the set must also appear as some other element in $\{\pi(3) \pi(9)\}$ For example if $\pi(6)=1$ then either $\pi(3)=7$ or $\pi(9)=7$ Combining this with the fact that all $\pi(2k)$ have the same parity we see that $\pi(2)$ is actually fixed in these situations Thus for each of the four possibilities for $(\pi(4) \pi(8))$ there are two possible values of $\pi(6)$ and two possibilities for $(\pi(3) \pi(9))$ for $16$ different permutations which work $\textbf{SUBCASE 2 }\{\pi(4) \pi(8)\} = \{3 7\}$ or $\{1 9\}$ In contrast with the above note that in these two cases $\pi(6)$ is fixed which means there the value of $\pi(2)$ can vary More specifically for each of the four possibilities for $(\pi(4) \pi(8))$ there are two possible values for $\pi(2)$ and two possibilities for $(\pi(3) \pi(9))$ for $16$ different permutations which work Thus in this total case $32$ systems are possible Finally there are three numbers left and they can be assigned to $\pi(1)$ $\pi(5)$ and $\pi(7)$ in $3!=6$ ways Thus the total number of consistent systems is $6(8+32)=\boxed{240}$

title: 2016 T10: P-Friendly Lines
text: Let $\mathcal{P}$ be the unique parabola in the $xy$-plane which is tangent to the $x$-axis at $(5,0)$ and to the $y$-axis at $(0,12)$. We say a line $\ell$ is $\mathcal{P}$-friendly if the $x$-axis, $y$-axis, and $\mathcal{P}$ divide $\ell$ into three segments, each of which has equal length. If the sum of the slopes of all $\mathcal{P}$-friendly lines can be written in the form $-\tfrac mn$ for $m$ and $n$ positive relatively prime integers, find $m+n$.
solution:
In the interest of the Contests Page I'll post the official solution to this problem This problem was proposed by me but the solution below was discovered by AoPS user codyj 
 
 Solution We first make use of a lemma LEMMA Let $F(v)$ be a linear transformation in $\mathbb{R}^2$ and define \[F(\mathcal{P})=\{F(v)\ |\ v\in\mathcal{P}\} \] Then $F(\mathcal{P})$ is also a parabola Proof Omitted Use the fact that a conic of the form \[ax^2+bxy+cy^2+dx+ey+f=0\] is a parabola if and only if $b^2 4ac=0$ 
 
 With this in mind scale the $y$ axis by $\tfrac5{12}$ This scaling preserves the trisection property of lines and furthermore preserves the tangency of $\mathcal{P}$ to the $x$ and $y$ axes and so the answer to the original question will be $\tfrac{12}5$ the answer to this new problem Furthermore rotate the entire diagram $45^\circ$ counterclockwise about the origin By the arctangent formula a line with slope $m$ in this frame has a slope of $\tfrac{1 m}{1+m}$ in the original frame so it's not hard to transform back and forth Let $\mathcal{P}'$ be the parabola which results from these transformations then $\mathcal{P'}$ is tangent to the lines $y=x$ and $y= x$ and the directrix of $\mathcal{P'}$ is a line parallel to the line $y=0$ This in turn means that $y=cx^2+d$ for some constants $c$ and $d$ To deal with the fact that $\mathcal{P'}$ is tangent to the lines $y=\pm x$ note that this means the equations $y=cx^2 x+d$ and $y=cx^2+x+d$ each have exactly one root This means their discriminants are zero so $1^2 4cd = 0\implies d=\tfrac{1}{4c}$ In fact we can make $c$ arbitrary due to scaling so take $c=1$ This gives $d=\tfrac14$ so the equation of $\mathcal{P}'$ is now $y=x^2+\tfrac14$ 
 
 Consider any $\mathcal{P}'$ friendly segment with endpoints $( 3a 3a)$ and $(3b 3b)$ We want $( a+2b a+2b)$ and $( 2a+b 2a+b)$ to both be points on $\mathcal{P}'$ This gives the system of equations \[\begin{cases}a+2b&=( a+2b)^2+\frac14 \\2a+b&=( 2a+b)^2+\frac14 \end{cases}\] Subtracting the first equation from the second yields \[a b=( 2a+b)^2 ( a+2b)^2=(2a b)^2 (a 2b)^2=3(a+b)(a b) \] Hence either $a=b$ or $a+b=\tfrac13$ In the former case this segment is horizontal It's clear by the Intermediate Value Theorem (or an analogous argument) that there are precisely two such $\mathcal{P}'$ friendly segments contributing $2\cdot\tfrac{0 1}{0+1}= 2$ to the sum of the slopes of the lines On the other hand if $a+b=\tfrac13$ then let $m=\tfrac{b a}{b+a}=3(b a)=6b 1$ be the slope of the line in question We wish to find the sum of the values of \[\dfrac{m 1}{m+1}=\dfrac{6b 2}{6b}=1 \frac1{3b} \] i e the slopes of all lines after they have been rotated $45$ degrees Note that by plugging $a+b=\tfrac13$ into the first equation of the system we get the quadratic \[\frac13+b=\left( \frac13+3b\right)^2+\frac14 \] Expanding and simplifying yields that this quadratic is equivalent to \[9b^2 3b+\frac1{36}=0 \] so by Vieta's formulas if $b_1$ and $b_2$ are the two roots of the above quadratic then \[\left(1 \frac1{3b_1}\right)+\left(1 \frac1{3b_2}\right) = 2 \frac13\left(\dfrac{b_1+b_2}{b_1b_2}\right)=2 \frac13\left(\frac{3}{1/36}\right) = 2 \frac1{36} \] Therefore the sum of all the slopes of the lines for the original parabola $\mathcal{P}$ is \[\dfrac{12}5\left[ 2+\left(2 \frac1{36}\right)\right]= \frac{432}5\] and the requested answer is $432+5=\boxed{437}$

title: 2016 TB A1: Function Composition
text: Let \[f(x)=\dfrac{1}{1-\dfrac{1}{1-x}}\,.\]Compute $f^{2016}(2016)$, where $f$ is composed upon itself $2016$ times.
solution:
Click to reveal hidden text We have $f(x)=\dfrac{1}{\frac{ x}{1 x}}=\dfrac{x 1}{x} $ 
 
 But $f^2(x)=\dfrac{\frac{x 1}{x} 1}{\frac{x 1}{x}}=\dfrac{\frac{ 1}{x}}{\frac{x 1}{x}}=\dfrac{ 1}{x 1} \ f^3(x)=\dfrac{ 1}{x 1}=\dfrac{ 1}{\frac{x 1}{x} 1}=x$ 
 
 So $f$ is periodic with order $3 $ Hence since $3\ |\ 2016 $ it follows that $f^{2016}(2016)=2016 $

title: 2016 TB A3: System of Equations
text: Suppose $x$ and $y$ are real numbers which satisfy the system of equations \[x^2-3y^2=\frac{17}x\qquad\text{and}\qquad 3x^2-y^2=\frac{23}y.\]Then $x^2+y^2$ can be written in the form $\sqrt[m]{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers and $m$ is as small as possible. Find $m+n$.
solution:
Solution Clearing denominators we get 
 $$x^3 3xy^2=17$$ and 
 $$3x^2y y^3=23 $$ 
 Now the key is to notice that this looks like the expansion of a cubic except not quite In fact we may note that if we expand $(x+iy)^3$ by equating the real and imaginary parts we may reduce the system of equations to a statement that $(x+iy)^3=17+23i$ 
 
 Then $(x^2+y^2)^\frac{3}{2}=(17^2+23^2)^\frac{1}{2}$ so $x^2+y^2=(818)^\frac{1}{3}$ and we get $n=818$ $m=3$ for $m+n=821$

title: 2016 TB C3: Sets of Integers
text: Let $S$ be the set containing all positive integers whose decimal representations contain only 3’s and 7’s, have at most 1998 digits, and have at least one digit appear exactly 999 times. If $N$ denotes the number of elements in $S$, find the remainder when $N$ is divided by 1000.
solution:
Click to reveal hidden text WLOG let $3$ have $999$ usages within the integer The number of integers for which this is true not counting $1998$ digit integers is trivially $\binom{999}{0}+\binom{1000}{1}+\cdots+\binom{1997}{998} $ 
 Doubling this count to account for $7$ having $999$ usages our count so far becomes $2\left(\binom{999}{0}+\binom{1000}{1}+\cdots+\binom{1997}{998}\right) $ 
 
 There are exactly $\binom{1998}{999}$ integers with both $3 \ 7$ used $999$ times Hence $N=2\left(\binom{999}{0}+\binom{1000}{1}+\cdots+\binom{1997}{998}\right)+\binom{1998}{999}=2\binom{1998}{998}+\binom{1998}{999}=\binom{1998}{998}+\binom{1999}{999} $ where the identities $\sum_{i=0}^k\binom{n+i}{i}=\binom{n+k+1}{k}$ and Pascal's identity have been used After boring computations I got an answer of $\boxed{120} $ feel free to check

title: 2016 TB CS1: Planar Graphs
text: A $\emph{planar}$ graph is a connected graph that can be drawn on a sphere without edge crossings. Such a drawing will divide the sphere into a number of faces. Let $G$ be a planar graph with $11$ vertices of degree $2$, $5$ vertices of degree $3$, and $1$ vertex of degree $7$. Find the number of faces into which $G$ divides the sphere.
solution: Use the formula $V E+F=2$ There are $11+5+1=17$ vertices $\tfrac{2*11+3*5+7*1}{2}=22$ edges and thus $2 17+22=\boxed{7}$ faces

title: 2016 TB CS2: Stooge Sort
text: The $\emph{Stooge sort}$ is a particularly inefficient recursive sorting algorithm defined as follows: given an array $A$ of size $n$, we swap the first and last elements if they are out of order; we then (if $n\ge3$) Stooge sort the first $\lceil\tfrac{2n}3\rceil$ elements, then the last $\lceil\tfrac{2n}3\rceil$, then the first $\lceil\tfrac{2n}3\rceil$ elements again. Given that this runs in $O(n^\alpha)$, where $\alpha$ is minimal, find the value of $(243/32)^\alpha$.
solution: Solution Let $f(n)$ be the running time of Stooge sort Then $f(n) = 3f(2n/3)$ If $f(n) = O(n^a)$ then $n^a = 3(2n/3)^a$ so $1/3 = (2/3)^a$ Thus $(243/32)^a = (2/3)^{ 5a} = (1/3)^{ 5} = 243$

title: 2016 TB CS3: Operations on Strings
text: Let $\varepsilon$ denote the empty string. Given a pair of strings $(A,B)\in\{0,1,2\}^*\times\{0,1\}^*$, we are allowed the following operations: \[\begin{cases} (A,1)\to(A0,\varepsilon)\\ (A,10)\to(A00,\varepsilon)\\ (A,0B)\to(A0,B)\\ (A,11B)\to(A01,B)\\ (A,100B)\to(A0012,1B)\\ (A,101B)\to(A00122,10B) \end{cases}\] We perform these operations on $(A,B)$ until we can no longer perform any of them. We then iteratively delete any instance of $20$ in $A$ and replace any instance of $21$ with $1$ until there are no such substrings remaining. Among all binary strings $X$ of size $9$, how many different possible outcomes are there for this process performed on $(\varepsilon,X)$?

title: 2016 TB G1: Points on a Circle
text: Point $A$ lies on the circumference of a circle $\Omega$ with radius $78$. Point $B$ is placed such that $AB$ is tangent to the circle and $AB=65$, while point $C$ is located on $\Omega$ such that $BC=25$. Compute the length of $\overline{AC}$.
solution: nice problem First we extend $BC$ to hit the circle $\Omega$ at another point $P$ By PoP we have $AB^2=BC\times BP$ This means $BP=\frac{65^2}{25}=169$ But since $156^2+65^2=169^2$ as well we know that $P$ is the antipode of point $A$ with respect to circle $\Omega$ From this we can now conclude that $\angle ACP=90^{\circ}$ as it is inscribed in a semicircle Since $BP=169$ we know $CP=169 25=144$ By Pythagorean Theorem we have that $AC^2+CP^2=AP^2$ or $AC^2=3600$ This implies that $AC=60$

solution: Simple Invert about $A$ with radius $\sqrt{AB\cdot AC}$ composed with a reflection about the $A$ angle bisector and a dilation at $A$ with ratio $\frac{1}{2}$ Note that $G$ the centroid of $\triangle ABC$ maps to $\odot(ABN)\cap \odot (ACM)$ which is precisely $P$ by the spiral similarity lemma We can calculate $AG=\frac{56}{3}$ so that $$2AP\times AG=AB\times AC\Longrightarrow AP=\boxed{27} $$

title: 2016 TB N1: Sum of Functions
text: For all integers $n\geq 2$, let $f(n)$ denote the largest positive integer $m$ such that $\sqrt[m]{n}$ is an integer. Evaluate \[f(2)+f(3)+\cdots+f(100).\]
solution:
straightforward So first we add $99$ since everything can be itself raised to $1$ Now we count all powers of $2$ less than $100$ and greater than $2$ $2^2 2^3 2^4 2^5 2^6$ so we add $5$ Now we count all powers of $3$ less than $100$ and greater than $3$ $3^2 3^3 3^4$ so we add $3$ Now we add all powers of $4$ less than $100$ and greater than $4$ $4^2 4^3$ so we add $2$ From here on out we will only have the squares of the integers from $5 10$ appear so we just need to add $1$ for each of these $6$ numbers This means that our final answer is $99+5+3+2+1\times 6=115$

title: 2016 TB N2: Unions of Infinite Sets
text: For each integer $n\geq 1$, let $S_n$ be the set of integers $k > n$ such that $k$ divides $30n-1$. How many elements of the set \[\mathcal{S} = \bigcup_{i\geq 1}S_i = S_1\cup S_2\cup S_3\cup\ldots\]are less than $2016$?
solution:
Is this correct? 
 
 Solution Notice that $1<a\in S$ if and only if there exists some $n<a$ such that $a\mid 30n 1$ or $30n = 1\pmod a$ 
 
 However this is equivalent to $a$ being relatively prime to $30$ since then we just want $n<a$ $n = 30^{ 1}\pmod a$ and there clearly exists a positive integer $0 < n < a$ such that $30^{ 1} = n\pmod a$ since $30^{ 1}\neq 0\pmod a$ 
 
 Therefore we just want to count the number of integers less than $2016$ that are both not 1 and are relatively prime to 30 This is just $67\phi 30 1 + 1\text{ (for 2011)} = 67\phi 30 = 67\cdot 8 = \boxed{536}$

title: 2016 TB N3: Fractional Part Summation
text: Let $\{x\}$ denote the fractional part of $x$. For example, $\{5.5\}=0.5$. Find the smallest prime $p$ such that the inequality \[\sum_{n=1}^{p^2}\left\{\dfrac{n^p}{p^2}\right\}>2016\]holds.
solution:
On a phone so bad formatting 
 
 Solution Obviously p>2 so p is odd The terms where n is a multiple of p are just 0 so we can ignore them Let g be a primitive root modulo p^2 Now our sum is frac(g^(pn)/p^2) from n=0 to p^2 p 1 The expression frac(g^(pn)/p^2) does not change when n is increased by p 1 so the sum just becomes p times sum frac(g^(pn)/p^2) from n=0 to p 2 Note that frac(g^(p(n+(p 1)/2)))=1 frac(g^(pn)) so our p 1 terms split into (p 1)/2 pairs summing to 1 Thus the whole sum is equal to p(p 1)/2>2016 so p>64 Thus the smallest prime p satisfying the inequality is 67

title: 2020 Geometry 2
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. Points $D$ and $E$ are placed on $\overline{AC}$ in the order $A$, $D$, $E$, and $C$, and point $F$ lies on $\overline{AB}$ with $EF\parallel BC$. Line segments $\overline{BD}$ and $\overline{EF}$ meet at $X$. If $AD = 1$, $DE = 3$, $EC = 5$, and $EF = 4$, compute $FX$.
solution:
Let the line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meet $AB$ at $G$ Then 
 $$\frac{XF}{DG} = \frac{BF}{BG} = \frac{CE}{CD} = \frac{5}{8} \quad \text{and} \quad DG = \frac{AD}{AE} \cdot EF = 1 \quad \text{so} \quad XF = \boxed{\frac{5}{8}}$$

title: 2020 Geometry 3
text: Point $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ form a rectangle in that order. Point $X$ lies on $CD$, and segments $\overline{BX}$ and $\overline{AC}$ intersect at $P$. If the area of triangle $BCP$ is 3 and the area of triangle $PXC$ is 2, what is the area of the entire rectangle?
solution: From the area condition we get that $\frac{CP}{PA}=\frac{CX}{BA}=\frac{2}{3}\implies \frac{CX}{XD}=\frac{2}{1}\implies[PDX]=1$ So $[DPA]=\frac{9}{2}$ and similarly $[APB]=\frac{9}{2}$ So $[ABCD]=3+2+1+\frac{9}{2}+\frac{9}{2}=15$

title: 2020 Geometry 5
text: For every positive integer $k$, let $\mathbf{T}_k = (k(k+1), 0)$, and define $\mathcal{H}_k$ as the homothety centered at $\mathbf{T}_k$ with ratio $\tfrac{1}{2}$ if $k$ is odd and $\tfrac{2}{3}$ is $k$ is even. Suppose $P = (x,y)$ is a point such that $$(\mathcal{H}_{4} \circ \mathcal{H}_{3} \circ \mathcal{H}_2 \circ \mathcal{H}_1)(P) = (20, 20).$$What is $x+y$? (A homothety $\mathcal{H}$ with nonzero ratio $r$ centered at a point $P$ maps each point $X$ to the point $Y$ on ray $\overrightarrow{PX}$ such that $PY = rPX$.)
solution:
Work step by step from $P=(x y)$ 
 
 $\mathcal{H}_{1}$ is a $\tfrac{1}{2}$ ratio homothety at $(2 0)$ Thus $\mathcal{H}_{1}(P)=\left(\frac{x+2}{2} \frac{y}{2}\right)$ 
 
 $\mathcal{H}_{2}$ is a $\tfrac{2}{3}$ ratio homothety at $(6 0)$ Thus $\left(\mathcal{H}_{2}\circ\mathcal{H}_{1}\right)(P)=\mathcal{H}_{2}(\left(\frac{x+2}{2} \frac{y}{2}\right))=\left(\frac{x+8}{3} \frac{y}{3}\right)$ 
 
 Applying a $\tfrac{1}{2}$ ratio homothety at $(12 0)$ it becomes $\left(\frac{x+44}{6} \frac{y}{6}\right)$ 
 
 Applying to this new point a $\tfrac{2}{3}$ homothety at $(20 0)$ it maps to $\left(\frac{x+104}{9} \frac{y}{9}\right)$ 
 
 Since this point is $(20 20)$ we have $x+104=y=180$ so $x=76$ and $y=180$ giving $x+y=\boxed{256}$

title: 2020 Geometry 6
text: Two circles $\omega_A$ and $\omega_B$ have centers at points $A$ and $B$ respectively and intersect at points $P$ and $Q$ in such a way that $A$, $B$, $P$, and $Q$ all lie on a common circle $\omega$. The tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ intersects $\omega_A$ and $\omega_B$ again at points $X$ and $Y$ respectively. Suppose $AB = 17$ and $XY = 20$. Compute the sum of the radii of $\omega_A$ and $\omega_B$.
solution: By the conditions we have that triangles $APQ$ and $BPQ$ are isosceles which means that $A$ and $B$ are the midpoints of arc $PQ$ Since $A\ne B$ we must have $AB$ be the diameter of $\omega$ Let $\angle PBA=\theta$ Since $AB=17$ $PA=17\sin{\theta}$ and $PB=17\cos{\theta}$ Furthermore since $XY$ is tangent at $P$ we have $\angle XPA=\theta$ and $\angle BPY=90^{\circ} \theta$ Using trig once more gives $$XP+PY=2AP\cos{\theta}+2BP\sin{\theta}=10$$ $$\implies 17(\sin{\theta}\cos{\theta}+\cos{\theta}\sin{\theta})=17\sin{2\theta}=10$$ $$\implies \sin{2\theta}=\frac{10}{17}$$ We want $$17(\sin{\theta}+\cos{\theta})=17\sqrt{1+\sin{2\theta}}=3\sqrt{51}$$ which is our answer

title: 2020 Geometry 8
text: Let $\mathcal E$ be an ellipse with foci $F_1$ and $F_2$. Parabola $\mathcal P$, having vertex $F_1$ and focus $F_2$, intersects $\mathcal E$ at two points $X$ and $Y$. Suppose the tangents to $\mathcal E$ at $X$ and $Y$ intersect on the directrix of $\mathcal P$. Compute the eccentricity of $\mathcal E$. (A parabola $\mathcal P$ is the set of points which are equidistant from a point, called the focus of $\mathcal P$, and a line, called the directrix of $\mathcal P$. An ellipse $\mathcal E$ is the set of points $P$ such that the sum $PF_1 + PF_2$ is some constant $d$, where $F_1$ and $F_2$ are the foci of $\mathcal E$. The eccentricity of $\mathcal E$ is defined to be the ratio $F_1F_2/d$.)
solution:
Let $P$ be the intersection of the tangents to $\mathcal E$ at $X$ and $Y$ Then by definition $XP$ is an external bisector of $\angle F_1XF_2$ so by the external bisector theorem $\tfrac{XF_1}{XF_2} = \tfrac{F_1P}{F_2P} = \tfrac{1}{2}$ since $F_1$ is the midpoint of $PF_2$ Thus $XF_1 = \tfrac{d}{3}$ and $XF_2 = \tfrac{2d}{3}$ where $d$ is the same as in the definition of $\mathcal E$ Now let $D$ be the projection of $X$ onto line $F_1F_2$ let $\ell$ be the directrix of $\mathcal P$ and let $x$ be the length of $F_1F_2$ Then $DP = d(X \ell) = XF_2 = \tfrac{2d}{3}$ so $F_1D = \tfrac{2d}{3} x$ and $DF_2 = 2x \tfrac{2d}{3}$ By the Pythagorean Theorem $XF_2^2 DF_2^2=XF_1^2 F_1D^2$ so 
 \[\left(\frac{d}{3}\right)^{2} \left(\frac{2d}{3} x\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{2d}{3}\right)^{2} \left(2x \frac{2d}{3}\right)^{2} \] which rearranges as $9x^2=d^2+4dx$ Finally if $r = \tfrac{x}{d}$ is the eccentricity of $\mathcal E$ then $9r = \tfrac{1}{r} + 4$ so $r = \boxed{\tfrac{1}{9}(2+\sqrt {13})}$

title: 2020 Geometry 9
text: In triangle $ABC$, points $M$ and $N$ are on segments $AB$ and $AC$ respectively such that $AM = MC$ and $AN = NB$. Let $P$ be the point such that $PB$ and $PC$ are tangent to the circumcircle of $ABC$. Given that the perimeters of $PMN$ and $BCNM$ are $21$ and $29$ respectively, and that $PB = 5$, compute the length of $BC$.
solution: I'm a TRIG GOD YUH Let $BC=a$ Note that $\angle{PBC}=\angle{PCB}=A$ so $BP=5=\frac{a}{2\cos(A)}$ Since $\angle{AMC}=\angle{CMA}=A$ $AM=\frac{b}{2\cos(A)}$ and similarly $AN=\frac{c}{2\cos(A)}$ So $\triangle{ANM}$ is similar to $\triangle{ABC}$ and $MN=\frac{a}{2\cos(A)}=5$ Since $\angle{BMC}=2A=180^{\circ} \angle{BPC}$ $BMCP$ is cyclic so $\angle{BMP}=\angle{BCP}=A$ Then $\angle{PMN}=B$ and similarly $\angle{PNM}=C$ Let $p$ denote perimeter $p(\triangle{PMN})=\frac{p(\triangle{ABC})}{2\cos(A)}$ and $p(BCNM)=p(ABC) p(AMN)+2MN=p(ABC) 21+2 \cdot 5=29$ so $p(ABC)=40$ Then $21=\frac{40}{2\cos(A)}$ which gives $2\cos(A)=\frac{40}{21}$ So $a=\frac{200}{21}$

title: 2020 Geometry 10
text: Four copies of an acute scalene triangle $\mathcal T$, one of whose sides has length $3$, are joined to form a tetrahedron with volume $4$ and surface area $24$. Compute the largest possible value for the circumradius of $\mathcal T$.
solution:
Suppose the tetrahedron is inscribed in a rectangular prism with sides $a b c$ so that $\mathcal T$ has sides $\sqrt{a^2+b^2}$ $\sqrt{a^2+c^2}$ $\sqrt{b^2+c^2}$ 
 
 If ones of the sides has length $3$ then $a^2+b^2=9$ If the volume of the tetrahedron is $4$ then $abc = 3 \cdot 4 = 12$ If the surface area is $24$ then each acute triangle has area $6$ so $\tfrac{1}{2} \sqrt{a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2} = 6$ so $a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2 = 144$ This rearranges to $\tfrac{144}{c^2}+9c^2=144$ and we find $c^2=8+4\sqrt 3$ 
 
 Then the circumradius of $\mathcal T$ is $\tfrac{3}{16} \sqrt{(a^2+b^2)(a^2+c^2)(b^2+c^2)} = \tfrac{3}{16}\sqrt{144+c^4} =\boxed{\sqrt{ 4+\sqrt 3}}$

title: 2020 Geometry: Estimation
text: Gunmay picks $6$ points uniformly at random in the unit square. If $p$ is the probability that their convex hull is a hexagon, estimate $p$ in the form $0.abcdef$ where $a,b,c,d,e,f$ are decimal digits. (A convex combination of points $x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n$ is a point of the form $\alpha_1x_1 + \alpha_2x_2 + \dots + \alpha_nx_n$ with $0 \leq \alpha_i \leq 1$ for all $i$ and $\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 + \dots + \alpha_n = 1$. The convex hull of a set of points $X$ is the set of all possible convex combinations of all subsets of $X$.)

title: 2020 C/CS 1
text: The intramural squash league has 5 players, namely Albert, Bassim, Clara, Daniel, and Eugene. Albert has played one game, Bassim has played two games, Clara has played 3 games, and Daniel has played 4 games. Assuming no two players in the league play each other more than one time, how many games has Eugene played?
solution:
Let the people be called A B C D E 
 D has played 4 games $\implies$ D has played A B C E 
 A has played 1 game $\implies$ A has only played D 
 C played 3 games and he cannot play with A so C played with B D E Since B played 2 games B played with only B and D Therefore E played with D and C a total of 2 games

title: 2020 C/CS 2
text: David is taking a true/false exam with $9$ questions. Unfortunately, he doesn’t know the answer to any of the questions, but he does know that exactly $5$ of the answers are True. In accordance with this, David guesses the answers to all $9$ questions, making sure that exactly $5$ of his answers are True. What is the probability he answers at least $5$ questions correctly?
solution:
Let $\mathcal T$ denote the set of questions whose answers are true and $\mathcal F$ denote the set of questions whose answers are false If David makes $x$ questions correct in $\mathcal T$ set then he writes $5 x$ False in set $\mathcal T$ which means he writes $4 (5 x)$ False in set $\mathcal F$ This means he makes $x 1$ correct choises in set $\mathcal F$ 
 
 Together he makes $x+(x 1)=2x 1$ coreect choices We want $2x 1\ge 5\iff x\ge 3$ 
 Now the number of of making $x$ correct choice from $\mathcal T$ and $x 1$ correct choice from $\mathcal F$ is ${5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}$ 
 Therefore The required probability is $$\frac{{\sum}_{x\ge 3} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}{{\sum}_{x\ge 1} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}=\frac{81}{126}=\frac{9}{14}$$

title: 2020 C/CS 3
text: Consider a $1$-indexed array that initially contains the integers $1$ to $10$ in increasing order. The following action is performed repeatedly (any number of times): def action(): Choose an integer n between 1 and 10 inclusive Reverse the array between indices 1 and n inclusive Reverse the array between indices n+1 and 10 inclusive (If n = 10, we do nothing) How many possible orders can the array have after we are done with this process?
solution: Put all the numbers on a circle All this does is reverse the array and cycle it Since there are $2$ directions and $10$ possible cycles there are $20$ possible orders

title: 2020 C/CS 4
text: The continent of Trianglandia is an equilateral triangle of side length $9$, divided into $81$ triangular countries of side length $1$. Each country has the resources to choose at most $1$ of its $3$ sides and build a “wall” covering that entire side. However, since all the countries are at war, no two countries are willing to have their walls touch, even at a corner. What is the maximum number of walls that can be built in Trianglandia?

title: 2020 C/CS 5
text: Seven cards numbered $1$ through $7$ lay stacked in a pile in ascending order from top to bottom ($1$ on top, $7$ on bottom). A shuffle involves picking a random card of the six not currently on top, and putting it on top. The relative order of all the other cards remains unchanged. Find the probability that, after $10$ shuffles, $6$ is higher in the pile than $3$.
solution:
We write the shuffling as a sequence of numbers each representing the next card we move to the top This means that the first number is not $1$ and no two consecutive numbers are the same Then the $6$ is only higher than the $3$ if when we write the sequence the last $6$ comes after the last $3$ 
 
 If neither a $3$ or a $6$ appears in the sequence which happens with probability $\left( \dfrac{2}{3}\right)^{10}$ probability then we are destined to fail If either a $3$ or a $6$ appears we may biject sequences with last $3$ after last $6$ and last $6$ above last $3$ by replacing all $3$ s with $6$ s and all $6$ s with $3$ s 
 
 Thus the answer is $\dfrac{1 (\frac{2}{3})^{10}}{2}=\boxed{\dfrac{3^{10} 2^{10}}{2 \cdot 3^{10}}}$

title: 2020 C/CS 6
text: The nation of CMIMCland consists of 8 islands, none of which are connected. Each citizen wants to visit the other islands, so the government will build bridges between the islands. However, each island has a volcano that could erupt at any time, destroying that island and any bridges connected to it. The government wants to guarantee that after any eruption, a citizen from any of the remaining $7$ islands can go on a tour, visiting each of the remaining islands exactly once and returning to their home island (only at the end of the tour). What is the minimum number of bridges needed?
solution: At least two bridges are connected to each island so minimum 8 bridges Minimum is achieved when island number i is connected to i+1 and i 1 counting mod8

title: 2020 C/CS 8
text: Catherine has a plate containing $300$ circular crumbling mooncakes, arranged as follows: (This continues for $100$ total columns). She wants to pick some of the mooncakes to eat, however whenever she takes a mooncake all adjacent mooncakes will be destroyed and cannot be eaten. Let $M$ be the maximal number of mooncakes she can eat, and let $n$ be the number of ways she can pick $M$ mooncakes to eat (Note: the order in which she picks mooncakes does not matter). title: 2020 C/CS 9
text: Let $\Gamma = \{\varepsilon,0,00,\ldots\}$ be the set of all finite strings consisting of only zeroes. We consider $\textit{six-state unary DFAs}$ $D = (F,q_0,\delta)$ where $F$ is a subset of $Q = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$, not necessarily strict and possibly empty; $q_0\in Q$ is some $\textit{start state}$; and $\delta: Q\rightarrow Q$ is the $\textit{transition function}$. For each such DFA $D$, we associate a set $F_D\subseteq\Gamma$ as the set of all strings $w\in\Gamma$ such that \[\underbrace{\delta(\cdots(\delta(q_0))\cdots)}_{|w|\text{ applications}}\in F,\] We say a set $\mathcal D$ of DFAs is $\textit{diverse}$ if for all $D_1,D_2\in\mathcal D$ we have $F_{D_1}\neq F_{D_2}$. What is the maximum size of a diverse set?

title: 2020 A/NT 2
text: Find the unique real number $c$ such that the polynomial $x^3+cx+c$ has exactly two real roots.
solution: Note that it is impossible to have just 2 non distinct real roots (complex roots come in pairs so only 1 complex is impossible) Thus we must have three non distinct real roots implying that two of the real roots are equal The identical real roots must be roots of the derivative function $f'(x) = 3x^2 + c$ The product of the roots in this equation are $\frac{c}{3}$ while the product of the roots of $f(x)$ is $ c$ hence $ 3$ is the other root of $f(x)$ Plugging in $x= 3$ gives $ 27 2c = 0 \Rightarrow c = \boxed{\frac{27}{2}}$

title: 2020 A/NT 3
text: Call a number ``Sam-azing" if it is equal to the sum of its digits times the product of its digits. The only two three-digit Sam-azing numbers are $n$ and $n + 9$. Find $n$.
solution:
Let $n = \overline{abc} = 100a + 10b + c$ Obviously none of the digits are 0 so $n$ and $n + 9$ are in the form of $\overline{abc} \overline{a(b + 1)(c 1)}$ ( $(b + 1)$ doesn't have a carry because it would make $b + 1$ zero) Then we have $(a + b + c)(abc) = 100a + 10b + c$ (1) 
 $(a + (b + 1) + (c 1))(a(b + 1)(c 1) = 100a + 10b + 10 + c 1 = (100a + 10b + c) + 9$ (2) 
 
 Plugging 1 into 2 we have $(a + b + c)(ac ab a) = 9$ Then $(a + b + c) | 9 \implies a + b + c = 1 3 9$ 
 
 Case 1 $a + b + c = 1$ Not possible 
 
 Case 2 $a + b + c = 3$ 
 $a = b = c = 1$ but $111$ doesn't satisfy the conditions above Case 3 $a + b + c = 9$ 
 $a(c b a) = 1 \implies a = 1 b = 3 c = 5 \implies n = \boxed{135}$

title: 2020 A/NT 4
text: For all real numbers $x$, let $P(x)=16x^3 - 21x$. What is the sum of all possible values of $\tan^2\theta$, given that $\theta$ is an angle satisfying \[P(\sin\theta) = P(\cos\theta)?\]
solution:
\begin{align*}
P(\sin \theta) = P(\cos \theta) &\implies 16\sin^3 \theta 21\sin \theta = 16\cos^3\theta 21\cos \theta \\
&\implies 16(\sin \theta \cos \theta)(1+\sin \theta \cos \theta) = 21(\sin \theta \cos \theta) \\
&\implies \tan \theta=1 \text{ OR } \sin \theta \cos \theta = 5/16 \end{align*} In the latter case \[ \sin 2\theta = 5/8 \implies \tan 2\theta = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \implies \frac{2\tan \theta}{1 \tan^2\theta} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \] Then 
 \[ \tan^2 \theta + \frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5} \tan \theta 1=0 \] The sum of the squares of the possible values of $\tan \theta$ is then 
 \[ \left(\frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5}\right)^2 2( 1) = \frac{206}{25} \] Adding back the 1 then answer is $\boxed{\frac{231}{25}}$

title: 2020 C/CS 1
text: The intramural squash league has 5 players, namely Albert, Bassim, Clara, Daniel, and Eugene. Albert has played one game, Bassim has played two games, Clara has played 3 games, and Daniel has played 4 games. Assuming no two players in the league play each other more than one time, how many games has Eugene played?
solution:
Let the people be called A B C D E 
 D has played 4 games $\implies$ D has played A B C E 
 A has played 1 game $\implies$ A has only played D 
 C played 3 games and he cannot play with A so C played with B D E Since B played 2 games B played with only B and D Therefore E played with D and C a total of 2 games

title: 2020 C/CS 2
text: David is taking a true/false exam with $9$ questions. Unfortunately, he doesn’t know the answer to any of the questions, but he does know that exactly $5$ of the answers are True. In accordance with this, David guesses the answers to all $9$ questions, making sure that exactly $5$ of his answers are True. What is the probability he answers at least $5$ questions correctly?
solution:
Let $\mathcal T$ denote the set of questions whose answers are true and $\mathcal F$ denote the set of questions whose answers are false If David makes $x$ questions correct in $\mathcal T$ set then he writes $5 x$ False in set $\mathcal T$ which means he writes $4 (5 x)$ False in set $\mathcal F$ This means he makes $x 1$ correct choises in set $\mathcal F$ 
 
 Together he makes $x+(x 1)=2x 1$ coreect choices We want $2x 1\ge 5\iff x\ge 3$ 
 Now the number of of making $x$ correct choice from $\mathcal T$ and $x 1$ correct choice from $\mathcal F$ is ${5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}$ 
 Therefore The required probability is $$\frac{{\sum}_{x\ge 3} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}{{\sum}_{x\ge 1} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}=\frac{81}{126}=\frac{9}{14}$$

title: 2020 Geometry 2
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. Points $D$ and $E$ are placed on $\overline{AC}$ in the order $A$, $D$, $E$, and $C$, and point $F$ lies on $\overline{AB}$ with $EF\parallel BC$. Line segments $\overline{BD}$ and $\overline{EF}$ meet at $X$. If $AD = 1$, $DE = 3$, $EC = 5$, and $EF = 4$, compute $FX$.
solution:
Let the line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meet $AB$ at $G$ Then 
 $$\frac{XF}{DG} = \frac{BF}{BG} = \frac{CE}{CD} = \frac{5}{8} \quad \text{and} \quad DG = \frac{AD}{AE} \cdot EF = 1 \quad \text{so} \quad XF = \boxed{\frac{5}{8}}$$

title: 2020 Geometry 3
text: Point $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ form a rectangle in that order. Point $X$ lies on $CD$, and segments $\overline{BX}$ and $\overline{AC}$ intersect at $P$. If the area of triangle $BCP$ is 3 and the area of triangle $PXC$ is 2, what is the area of the entire rectangle?
solution: From the area condition we get that $\frac{CP}{PA}=\frac{CX}{BA}=\frac{2}{3}\implies \frac{CX}{XD}=\frac{2}{1}\implies[PDX]=1$ So $[DPA]=\frac{9}{2}$ and similarly $[APB]=\frac{9}{2}$ So $[ABCD]=3+2+1+\frac{9}{2}+\frac{9}{2}=15$

title: 2020 Team 2
text: Find all sets of five positive integers whose mode, mean, median, and range are all equal to $5$.
solution: We realize that the sum of the 5 positive integers must be $25 $ We also can let the middle term be $5 $ Now we can do casework on the range and we see that is the range goes from $[2 7]$ or $[3 8]$ then there are sets that satisfy the restrictions while all others do not Thus our answer is $\boxed{\{2 5 5 6 7\} \{3 4 5 5 8\}}$

title: 2020 Team 3
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle with centroid $G$ and $BC = 3$. If $ABC$ is similar to $GAB$, compute the area of $ABC$.
solution: Let the midpoint of $BC$ be $M$ By definition $A G M$ are collinear with $AG=1$ $GM=\frac{1}{2}$ Since $\angle{GAB}=\angle{ABC}$ $\triangle{ABM}$ is isosceles Next by the given similarity $\frac{AG}{AB}=\frac{AB}{BC} \implies AB=\sqrt{3}$ The area of $\triangle{ABM}$ is $\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}$ so the altitude from $A$ to $BC$ is $\sqrt{2}$ The area is thus $\boxed{\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2}}$

title: 2020 Team 7
text: Points $P$ and $Q$ lie on a circle $\omega$. The tangents to $\omega$ at $P$ and $Q$ intersect at point $T$, and point $R$ is chosen on $\omega$ so that $T$ and $R$ lie on opposite sides of $PQ$ and $\angle PQR = \angle PTQ$. Let $RT$ meet $\omega$ for the second time at point $S$. Given that $PQ = 12$ and $TR = 28$, determine $PS$.
solution:
Firstly I claim that $RS=2PS$ 
 Proof Note that $\angle{PQT}=\angle{PRQ}$ so $\triangle{PQT} \sim \triangle{PRQ}$ Note that $\angle{RTQ}=90^{\circ} \frac{\angle{PTQ}}{2} \angle{TRQ}=\angle{PRQ} \angle{TRQ}=\angle{PRT}=\angle{PTS}$ Let $PS$ intersect $QT$ at $M$ 
 By PoP $MS \cdot MP=MQ^2$ and since $\triangle{MTS} \sim \triangle{MPT}$ we have $MS \cdot MP=MT^2$ so $MT=MQ$ 
 Since $\angle{PTQ}=\angle{PQR}=\angle{PSR}$ $\triangle{SRP} \sim \triangle{TPM}$ $\frac{RS}{PS}=\frac{PT}{TM}=2$ 
 
 So we just need to calculate $RS$ By Law of Cosines on $\triangle{RQT}$ since $PQ=RQ=12$ $RT=28$ $QT=\frac{6}{\sin{90^{\circ} \frac{\angle{PQT}}{2}}}$ and $\angle{RQT}=90^{\circ}+\frac{\angle{PQT}}{2}$ we have $\sin^2{\frac{\theta}{2}}=\frac{9}{124}$ Then $QT^2=\frac{6^2}{\sin^2{\frac{\theta}{2}}}=496$ By PoP $QT^2=RT \cdot ST$ so $ST=\frac{496}{28}=\frac{124}{7}$ and $RS=28 \frac{124}{7}=\frac{72}{7}$ so $PS=\boxed{\frac{36}{7}}$

title: 2020 Team 10
text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle. The incircle $\omega$ of $\triangle ABC$, which has radius $3$, is tangent to $\overline{BC}$ at $D$. Suppose the length of the altitude from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$ is $15$ and $BD^2 + CD^2 = 33$. What is $BC$?
solution:
Call $M$ midpoint of arc $BC$ and $I_A$ center of $A$ excircle By area we have $\frac{a+b+c}{2} \cdot 3=\frac{15a}{2}$ so $4a=b+c$ 
 We can calculate exradius $r=\frac{Area}{s a}=5$ using the formula $\frac{1}{r}+\frac{a}{Area}=\frac{semiperimeter}{Area}$ 
 Then by Pythagoras’ Theorem $BI^2+CI^2=33+2 \cdot 3^2=51$ and $BI_A^2+CI_A^2=33+2 \cdot 5^2=83$ so $II_A^2=\frac{51+83}{2}=67$ 
 By Fact 5 this means that $IM=\frac{\sqrt{67}}{2}$ and $M$ is center of circle passing through $B C I I_A$ 
 By Ptolemy on $ABMC$ we have $(AB+AC)(IM)=BC(MA)$ 
 Since $AB+AC=4BC$ we have $MA=2\sqrt{67}$ and $IA=\frac{3\sqrt{67}}{2}$ 
 By Pythagorean’s Theorem on $\triangle{AIF}$ where $\omega$ hits $AC$ at $F$ we have $AF=\sqrt{MA^2 r^2}=\frac{3\sqrt{63}}{2}$ 
 By tangencies of $\omega$ we get $BC=\frac{2AF}{3}=\sqrt{63}=\boxed{3\sqrt{7}}$

title: 2020 Team 15
text: Let $ABC$ be an acute triangle with $AB = 3$ and $AC = 4$. Suppose $M$ is the midpoint of segment $\overline{BC}$, $N$ is the midpoint of $\overline{AM}$, and $E$ and $F$ are the feet of the altitudes of $M$ onto $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$, respectively. Further suppose $BC$ intersects $NE$ at $S$ and $NF$ at $T$, and let $X$ and $Y$ be the circumcenters of $\triangle MES$ and $\triangle MFT$, respectively. If $XY$ is tangent to the circumcircle of $\triangle ABC$, what is the area of $\triangle ABC$?
solution: Dilate $XY$ with a scale factor of $2$ at $M$ to $X'Y'$ Some angle chase gives that $\angle X'MA = 180 B$ so $X'BM$ is similar to $X'MA$ Thus $X'M^2 = X'A \cdot X'B$ and similarly $Y'M^2 = Y'A \cdot Y'B$ Thus $X'Y'$ is the radical axis of $(ABC)$ and $M$ Note that $XY$ is perpendicular to $OM$ so if it is tangent to the circumcircle it must be tangent at the midpoint of arc $BC$ Now this should be (hopefully) straight computation

solution: Note that it is impossible to have just 2 non distinct real roots (complex roots come in pairs so only 1 complex is impossible) Thus we must have three non distinct real roots implying that two of the real roots are equal The identical real roots must be roots of the derivative function $f'(x) = 3x^2 + c$ The product of the roots in this equation are $\frac{c}{3}$ while the product of the roots of $f(x)$ is $ c$ hence $ 3$ is the other root of $f(x)$ Plugging in $x= 3$ gives $ 27 2c = 0 \Rightarrow c = \boxed{\frac{27}{2}}$

title: 2020 A/NT 3
text: Call a number ``Sam-azing" if it is equal to the sum of its digits times the product of its digits. The only two three-digit Sam-azing numbers are $n$ and $n + 9$. Find $n$.
solution:
Let $n = \overline{abc} = 100a + 10b + c$ Obviously none of the digits are 0 so $n$ and $n + 9$ are in the form of $\overline{abc} \overline{a(b + 1)(c 1)}$ ( $(b + 1)$ doesn't have a carry because it would make $b + 1$ zero) Then we have $(a + b + c)(abc) = 100a + 10b + c$ (1) 
 $(a + (b + 1) + (c 1))(a(b + 1)(c 1) = 100a + 10b + 10 + c 1 = (100a + 10b + c) + 9$ (2) 
 
 Plugging 1 into 2 we have $(a + b + c)(ac ab a) = 9$ Then $(a + b + c) | 9 \implies a + b + c = 1 3 9$ 
 
 Case 1 $a + b + c = 1$ Not possible 
 
 Case 2 $a + b + c = 3$ 
 $a = b = c = 1$ but $111$ doesn't satisfy the conditions above Case 3 $a + b + c = 9$ 
 $a(c b a) = 1 \implies a = 1 b = 3 c = 5 \implies n = \boxed{135}$

title: 2020 A/NT 4
text: For all real numbers $x$, let $P(x)=16x^3 - 21x$. What is the sum of all possible values of $\tan^2\theta$, given that $\theta$ is an angle satisfying \[P(\sin\theta) = P(\cos\theta)?\]
solution:
\begin{align*}
P(\sin \theta) = P(\cos \theta) &\implies 16\sin^3 \theta 21\sin \theta = 16\cos^3\theta 21\cos \theta \\
&\implies 16(\sin \theta \cos \theta)(1+\sin \theta \cos \theta) = 21(\sin \theta \cos \theta) \\
&\implies \tan \theta=1 \text{ OR } \sin \theta \cos \theta = 5/16 \end{align*} In the latter case \[ \sin 2\theta = 5/8 \implies \tan 2\theta = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \implies \frac{2\tan \theta}{1 \tan^2\theta} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \] Then 
 \[ \tan^2 \theta + \frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5} \tan \theta 1=0 \] The sum of the squares of the possible values of $\tan \theta$ is then 
 \[ \left(\frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5}\right)^2 2( 1) = \frac{206}{25} \] Adding back the 1 then answer is $\boxed{\frac{231}{25}}$

title: 2020 A/NT 5
text: Let $f(x) = 2^x + 3^x$. For how many integers $1 \leq n \leq 2020$ is $f(n)$ relatively prime to all of $f(0), f(1), \dots, f(n-1)$?
solution:
The answer is $\boxed{11}$ with $n = 2^k$ working for $0 \le k \le \lfloor{\log_2(2020)}\rfloor = 11$ 
 
 Necessity is obvious as if $n = 2^e \cdot k$ for odd $k$ then $2^k + 3^k \mid f(n)$ 
 
 For sufficiency suppose that $2^{2^a} + 3^{2^a}$ and $2^{2^b} + 3^{2^b}$ share a common prime factor $p$ Then $$2^{2^a} \equiv 3^{2^a} \pmod{p} \hspace{2mm} \implies 2^{2^{a+1}} \equiv 3^{2^{a+1}} \pmod{p}$$ implying that $\text{ord}_p\left(\frac{3}{2}\right) = 2^{a+1}$ But if $p \mid f(2^b)$ then $\text{ord}_p\left(\frac{3}{2}\right) = 2^{b+1} \neq 2^{a+1}$ giving a contradiction

title: 2020 A/NT 6
text: Find all pairs of integers $(x,y)$ such that $x \geq 0$ and \[ (6^x-y)^2 = 6^{x+1}-y. \]
solution:
The solutions are $(1 0) (1 11) (4 1215) $ and $(4 1376)$ We can look at the problem as a quadratic in $y$ let $6^x=k$ for now $$(k y)^2=6k y\implies y^2 2ky+k^2=6k y$$ $$\iff y^2 (2k 1)y+k^2 6k=0$$ The only way to have an integer solution for $y$ is to have the discriminant be an integer or $$\sqrt{(2k 1)^2 4(k^2 6k)}=\sqrt{20k+1}=\sqrt{20\cdot 6^x+1}$$ is an integer Set this equal to $m$ Moving the $1$ and factoring gives $$(m 1)(m+1)=20\cdot 6^x$$ Note that the two terms on the LHS must both be even and thus one of them must be $2\pmod 4$ Furthermore the GCD between the two terms must be $2$ We now break into cases Case 1 $\nu_2(m 1)=1$ 
 We can have $m 1=2 2*5 2*3^x $ or $2*5*3^x$ Checking the former two gives that $m=11$ is a viable solution The latter two can be manually checked using bounds Case 2 $\nu_(m+1)=1$ 
 This is exactly the same as Case 1 just replace $m 1$ with $m+1$ In this case manually checking gives us the solution $m=161$ 
 Plugging these in gives our solution set

title: 2020 A/NT 7
text: Compute the positive difference between the two real solutions to the equation $$(x-1)(x-4)(x-2)(x-8)(x-5)(x-7)+48\sqrt 3 = 0.$$
solution: We can pair off the terms so that they are in the form $x^2 9x+c$ $$(x 1)(x 4)(x 2)(x 8)(x 5)(x 7)=(x 1)(x 8)(x 2)(x 7)(x 4)(x 5)=(x^2 9x+8)(x^2 9x+14)(x^2 9x+20)$$ Let $t=x^2 9x$ Using the quadratic formula shows that we want to find $\sqrt{81+4t}$ We need to find the real root of $$(t+8)(t+14)(t+20)= 48\sqrt{3}$$ Noting the symmetry in the constant terms and seeing the irrational part on the RHS we are motivated to let $t=a\sqrt{3} 14$ for some real $a$ Plugging this in gives $$( 6+a\sqrt{3})(a\sqrt{3})(6+a\sqrt{3})= 48\sqrt{3} \implies a(3a^2 36)= 48 \implies a(a^2 12)= 16$$ Solving this gives the solution $a=2$ so $t= 14+2\sqrt{3}$ which means our answer is $\sqrt{81+4( 14+2\sqrt{3})}=\sqrt{25+8\sqrt{3}}$

title: 2020 A/NT 8
text: Let $f:\mathbb N\to (0,\infty)$ satisfy $\prod_{d\mid n} f(d) = 1$ for every $n$ which is not prime. Determine the maximum possible number of $n$ with $1\le n \le 100$ and $f(n)\ne 1$.
solution: 97 because it must be a prime because if n not a prime with f(n)=1 then one of its divisors nust be different from 1

title: 2020 A/NT 9
text: Let $p = 10009$ be a prime number. Determine the number of ordered pairs of integers $(x,y)$ such that $1\le x,y \le p$ and $x^3-3xy+y^3+1$ is divisible by $p$.
solution: First observe that the expression factors (over the integers ) as $(x + y + 1)(x^2 + y^2 + 1 x y xy)$ There are easily $p$ pairs $(x y)$ such that $x + y + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$ as for each fixed $x$ there is exactly one solution for $y$ in the given interval Write the second expression as a quadratic in $x$ so it becomes $$x^2 (1 + y)x + y^2 y + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{p} \iff 4x^2 4(1 + y)x + 4(y^2 y + 1) = (2x (1 + y))^2 + 3y^2 6y + 3 \equiv 0 \pmod{p} $$ This has solutions iff $ 3(y 1)^2$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ or $0$ but this is always true since $p \equiv 1 \pmod{12}$ and thus $ 3$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ Each of the $\tfrac{1}{2}\cdot(p 1)$ quadratic residues give two distinct choices for $y$ and each $y$ (these are all different) gives two distinct values of $x$ (i e each $y$ gives two different values of $x$ but across all $y$ these $x$ s may be equal) If $ 3(y 1)^2 \equiv 0 \implies y = 1$ then we get $x = 1$ for a total of $4\cdot\tfrac{1}{2}\cdot (p 1) + 1 = 2p 1$ solutions here Finally we subtract out the overlap If $x \equiv (y + 1) \pmod{p}$ then $$x^2 (1 + y)x + y^2 y + 1 \equiv 3(y^2 + y + 1) \pmod{p} $$ which has exactly $2$ roots in the interval since there are $\varphi(3) = 2$ elements of order $3$ This gives a final answer of $p + 2p 1 2 = 3p 3 = \boxed{30024}$

title: 2020 A/NT 10
text: We call a polynomial $P$ square-friendly if it is monic, has integer coefficients, and there is a polynomial $Q$ for which $P(n^2)=P(n)Q(n)$ for all integers $n$. We say $P$ is minimally square-friendly if it is square-friendly and cannot be written as the product of nonconstant, square-friendly polynomials. Determine the number of nonconstant, minimally square-friendly polynomials of degree at most $12$.

title: 2020 A/NT 11: Estimation
text: Vijay picks two random distinct primes $1\le p, q\le 10^4$. Let $r$ be the probability that $3^{2205403200}\equiv 1\bmod pq$. Estimate $r$ in the form $0.abcdef$, where $a, b, c, d, e, f$ are decimal digits.
solution: Answer Answer is $\boxed{0 023294}$
